text: Greg Anderson Narrator Amy Sullivan Interviewer May 18, 2017 Duluth, Minnesota Greg Anderson-GA Amy Sullivan-AS GA:  My name is Greg Anderson.  I am the Social Service Supervisor for St. Louis County Public Health Human Services in the area of Chemical Dependency Services. 8 I have been employed with St. Louis County for twenty-four plus years. 14 I have a bachelor's degree in sociology from Minnesota State Mankato.  I have a master's degree in social work from the University of Minnesota Duluth. 19 I was born in extreme southeastern Minnesota. 14 I grew up on a farm outside of Mable, Minnesota, which is forty miles south of Winona. 8, 20 Went to high school, graduated from there. 7 I already described my college life. 7, 10, 14 I was born in June of 1956. 14 AS: Do you give me permission to record this interview?  AS: I just have to say that.  GA: Cover the bases.  In case my attorney calls sometime. 16, 17 AS: So you grew up on a farm outside of Mable, Minnesota and then went to Mankato. 8, 20 GA: Two years in Winona first, then transferred to Mankato State. 5, 14, 17 AS: Oh, okay.  So does your family have a history of college education? 7, 12, 14, 15 GA: Neither my mother or father does. 16 My sister had degrees in both sociology and nursing. 20 AS: Did your parents encourage you to go to college? 7, 20 GA: Absolutely.  Growing up in the sixties, early seventies in a small, rural town basically there wasn't a lot of industry. 19 The primary business or industry was farming. 8, 19 I was not in a position to really take on the doo-doo. 18 Allergies and other things.  I wasn't in a position to carry on with the family farm, so it was real clear. 8, 12 My sister was eight years older than I. 14, 20 She had gone and went to nursing school at Mankato State University. 7 Needed to move on, and I was more of a person-oriented person. 15 If I could have handled calculus I would have been a meteorologist.  Then I went to look at mass communication journalism, news broadcasting. 15, 16 Spent some time there.  Realized I couldn't handle the egos that were present in that area of work, so I slipped into sociology. 5, 8, 10 Got my BA degree and spent three summers as the summer rec program director for the Mable and Canton communities. 7, 18, 19 Had this strong love—my first love outside of family is baseball. 12, 14 I spend a lot of time following that when I'm not working. 10 That's kind of that.  That got me to the Twin Cities.  From 1978 to 1987 when I got married and moved up here I worked in nursing homes. 7, 15 I was a short-time activity assistant, activity director, and then spent probably eight years as a social service director. 14, 18, 19 Basically coordinated admissions, discharged planning, addressing psychosocial needs of nursing home residents while in the nursing home. 5, 9, 19 Did that, then met my wife and moved up here. 7, 15, 20 Realized I didn't have a lot of job opportunities with just a sociology degree, so I was one of the first graduating class members of—the advanced generalist program—MSW program—at the University of Minnesota Duluth. 7, 11, 14, 19 UMD had basically discontinued their MSW program, and this was the start up of a new program going more into advanced generalist or generalist practice of doing standard basic social work with advanced education. 14, 15, 16, 19 It was a really enlightening experience for me, and it was really unique because in school for the two years in our class of about twenty something individuals I was basically the only one that had worked in gerontology. 7, 8, 13, 14, 18, 19 Everybody else was Children/Family Services. 5 There were two or three individuals that were dealing with chemical dependency, substance use disorder type things. 6, 13 My interest at the time continued to be geriatric, elderly, assisting and supporting individuals going through the aging process. 13, 17 Being able to assist and support them and the families. 17 The aging process is an evolving process of grieving because as we age we transition. 17 When we transition we lose certain skills and/or certain access or stages of life, and we have to be able to deal with that and then go into the next phase of life. 9, 10, 17 As one gets older, as I currently am, even having more realization and understanding what I witnessed and experienced in the early years. 14, 17, 18, 20 Got through school at UMD. 7 Had done an internship here at Children and Family Service, which at that time was St. Louis County Social Services. 5 I was able to do an internship at the county nursing home. 19 Finished that.  Was later hired as a child protection worker. 5, 14, 19 Commuted for over a year and a half to Hibbing, Minnesota. 14 So it was a hundred and forty-four mile trip each day to work. 16 After about eighteen months of doing that our first child was born and I had the opportunity to work for the state of Minnesota at the Minnesota Veteran's Home in Silver Bay that had just opened. 11, 14, 16, 19 I spent a year there working on admission coordination. 14 It wasn't a lot in relationship to discharge [unclear]. 19 Basically it was kind of a last phase of life for veterans and veterans' spouses, and in the meantime the program was also looking at adding an Alzheimer's or dementia unit to the program. 6, 10, 12, 13, 19 I was there for a year. 14 We were starting to train staff as we looked at opening the additional forty beds in the unit for an Alzheimer's group, but then I was able to return to Duluth and get a job at Chris Jenson County Nursing Home as a discharge planner as Chris Jensen was adding a new role in a rehab unit. 10, 11, 16, 19 With my internship and experience I had established nice relationships in the nursing home, and so they were very happy to bring me on board. 18, 19 I spent two and a half years at the nursing home. 14 Came to the realization—I loved the work—but Duluth and St. Louis County Social Services was going to be my employer probably for the rest of my professional career. 14, 15, 19 I needed to come down to the government service center and get myself established here. 12, 14, 19 I came down in 1995.  Spent four plus years as a contract manager. 14, 19 Basically working on purchase of service contracts for various units and divisions anywhere from children family service group homes, home care agencies, board and lodge programs, assisted living programs, chemical dependency treatment programs, mental health centers. 5, 6, 8, 12, 13, 14, 19, 20 I had a very wide variety of experiences within those service areas. 8, 18, 19, 20 I did that until April of 2000.  In April of 2000 I decided I needed a change. 14 I needed to have more experience, so I became an adult foster care licenser. 13, 18, 19 I was an adult foster care licenser for over two and a half years, and then based on some encouragement I had received from one or two supervisors within the department we were going through a succession plan, we had an iconic adult service supervisor who had been managing both mental health and chemical dependency services for fifteen to twenty years—she was very iconic within the human services community here in Duluth and St. Louis County. 9, 12, 13, 14, 16, 19 She was looking at retirement. 12 I filled a position that had been vacant for two years, so I took on chemical dependency adult protection common entry point, and represented pay services, and my responsibilities have kind of evolved and switched, and so since January of 2003 I have been supervising chemical dependency services. 5, 10, 13, 14, 16, 19 For the first twelve years I was just supervising services in south St. Louis County, and we ended up doing some restructuring at that time. 14, 16, 19 I took on supervision for all of St. Louis County—both north and south. 16 Got Rule 25 assessors in three different offices.  We also have a special project, which has been generated through the county board's commitment to support and try to find resolutions to the opioid epidemic. 5, 9, 12, 13, 14, 19 I have been directing and overseeing substance abuse prevention, intervention initiatives since probably April of 2014. 6, 10, 13, 18, 19 AS: How have you observed the opioid crisis? 13, 14 You've been dealing with substance abuse professionally since when did you say? 6, 13 AS: You have a decade plus experience seeing what's happening in your community. 6, 14, 15, 18, 19 What have you witnessed?  Coming in in 2003 the primary substance of choice was alcohol. 6, 19 Alcohol is still seen as number one. 6 There have been a few cycles and trends that have changed. 13 We get into the later 2000s, maybe starting 2006, 2007 we had an incredible upswing in methamphetamine. 5, 6, 8 We were basically dealing with that on two different fronts. 19 Not only the effect it was having on the individuals and family through the use, but also the public health crisis we were dealing with through the manufacturing. 6, 12, 13, 19 A lot of money, a lot of resources were put into that. 8, 10 We actually worked through a collaboration through Children and Family Services unit and through our Financial Assistance unit we were working on setting up a shared family program where basically mothers and/or parents dealing with substance use would be placed into an adult foster home, or actually it would end up being a dually licensed foster home where a parent and child could be placed together to assist and support during the initial phases of the recovery process. 5, 6, 7, 8, 12, 13, 14, 17, 19, 20 A lot of barriers in place from a state perspective in regards to funding.  Funding for adults, for residential services through what is called the Group State Residential Housing Program has significant effects on the Minnesota Family Investment Program, MFIP. 6, 9, 11, 12, 13, 19 So using 1) has impacts on others, and I can't get into great detail right now because my memory's kind of faded. 6, 12, 20 We operated it for about two to three years, but there were continuing barriers in regards to getting the appropriate level of funding and getting families to accept what was needing to be done from a financial assistance standpoint. 12, 13, 14, 17 AS: So you were trying to put parents in recovery with their children in order so that their children didn't have to be away from them, but they were being supervised by some other caregiver or adult. 5, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20 Monitoring, mentoring, those types of— AS: And you weren't able to coordinate the different funding streams in order to make it work the way you imagined it? 12, 18 GA: It got to be very frustrating.  We had actually before I had come into this position there had been ongoing discussions in the past regarding trying to do this for parents dealing with mental illness. 7, 12, 20 This was a continuation.  There were some barriers in regards to the funding streams.  The state has worked very hard in trying to get things in place in relationship to the efforts to reduce homelessness and provide permanent support of housing services. 5, 6, 9, 14, 19 I'm not sure if some of those things may have now changed. 12, 13 We haven't really taken a look at that. 18 In recent times we've been looking at other projects in relationship to harm reduction for chronic inebriates who face long-term homelessness. 5, 6, 14, 17, 19 We have a program called the San Marco, which was basically a project that has been modeled in several other communities not only within the state of Minnesota, but also throughout the country. 5, 19 Center for Alcohol and Drug Treatment and Center City Housing were key players in that. 6, 12, 15 St. Louis County Public Health and Human Services provided a supportive role in the development. 10, 12, 19 We worked with assistance in utilizing a group residential housing financial assistance benefit to provide funding for those individuals meeting those characteristics. 6, 9, 13, 15, 18 As a matter of fact we're having a ten-year anniversary of it's opening on June 22nd. 10, 14 Alcohol consumption is not a— AS: Do they call those a wet house? 6, 13 That might be extreme.  GA: That's a common term. 17 We've kind of shifted from a wet house to a supportive housing for chronic inebriates. 6, 8, 13, 19 That's just another example of what the collaboration and commitment of a community can do to address it. 5, 12, 19 I wish I still had a DVD—a DVD was made I think two years after the opening—and it's called "There Are No Losers," and it's a very telling story. 10, 14, 15 They bring tears to some.  I'll have to see if I can find it in my office. 6 Law enforcement was real, I don't want to say cynical, but they had some real concerns about putting this together, and basically the end of the DVD is a very moving statement by our then police chief in regards to the program and what it has done not only for the individuals residing there, but for the positive impact on the city and community. 8, 12, 13, 19 AS: That is a harm reduction model. 5, 14 When you walk out of our office, our building, if you look one block over and up San Marco is there. 16, 19 It is 230 West 3rd Street.  It actually has seventy units. 7, 19 Thirty is the board and watch component for the inebriates, and we have forty single room SRO units for individuals. 8, 13, 14, 17, 19 Basically the SRO is geared—we have our Human Development Center which is a community mental health center—they provide supportive services for individuals in the SRO in the Center for Alcohol and Drug Treatment provides the services for the individuals in the board watch. 5, 12, 13, 17, 19 AS: To get back to meth—you saw that was a crisis, you tried to do a housing situation, then— GA: 6 There were a lot of resources being allocated for this.  There were enhanced services for Children or Family Services to provide support, direction, and intervention for those families afflicted with the issue. 5, 13, 17, 18, 19 Things kind of, well at least from our standpoint, things fell to the wayside for a period of time, and I think the biggest thing was from a law enforcement standpoint being able to focus and reduce, and not ever totally eliminate, but greatly reduce the labs in the community. 5, 8, 9, 12, 13, 14, 18, 19, 20 AS: Were they in houses in Duluth? 6, 9, 13 They were in Duluth, rural Duluth— AS: I've heard of them in rural areas, but you actually had them here in the city? 7, 8, 9, 20 I can think of at least three or four instances of those being in homes in Duluth.  Basically it wasn't necessarily in lower income areas that this was occurring. 8, 10, 20 It had no boundaries in relationship to income. 19 AS: Yeah, that myth is being busted right now. 12 GA: It's really coming back. 18 Meth is also very, very prevalent. 10 But, things really slowed down probably, and I'm guessing, 2010, 2011. 10, 18 We're just kind of going along. 17 We were dealing with issues, but things were really coming to light, things were really becoming noticeable in 2011, 2012. 12, 13, 18 In late 2012 the then commissioner of the Department of Human Services came up to Duluth with community leaders, I believe our police chief was a part of this panel and presentation, but I want to say it was Lucinda Jesson who was the Department of Human Services Commissioner at that time. 5, 8, 9, 10, 12, 19 Long story short she came in and she was discussing the state's direction to put together and implement a substance use state plan to address substance use. 5, 6, 8, 12, 13, 15, 18 AS: She came up from St. Paul?  GA: She came up from St. Paul.  I believe there may have been—I think the Minnesota Department of Health and I think another state department was there along with our Chief of Police at the time Gordon Ramsey. 9, 12, 17, 19 We were excited that this was taking place. 11 I attended the session along with our adult service division director Mark Nelson. 6, 18, 19 At the time our north St. Louis County MCD supervisor Mike [unclear], and we also had in attendance a professor from the University of Duluth's school of pharmacy Mark Sneiderhan, and the CEO of the Center for Alcohol and Drug Treatment Gary Olson, Dr. Faris Keeling, and Dr. Beth Bilden from Essentia—at that point it was St. Mary's Duluth clinic. 5, 7, 12, 16 We had some other treatment providers there, but this group started talking after the session, and that discussion led to a series of meetings, which basically was the first step for the development of our Opioid Abuse Response Strategies work group. 6, 12, 13, 14, 18, 19 That's an overview.  AS: You had seen the impact in St. Louis County in 2012 was still there, right? 6, 12 At that point in time the primary concern was focused on prescription opioids. 6, 10, 13, 15, 16, 19 As conversations came about reviews, discussions, as time went on basically there came to be greater monitoring and control of prescription medications. 10, 14, 18, 19, 20 When those were no longer easily accessed, the entrepreneurship of others reflecting back on supply and demand basically said they can't have prescription medications, but we have something that will fit their need and we will be able to provide it at a price that will be good for us and affordable for them. 9, 10, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19 That started to swing or shift into heroin. 8, 16 The second page of this references an appearance of two OARS [Opioid Abuse Response Strategies] members, which was basically myself and our first Substance Abuse Prevention Intervention Initiative team member [Marsha Gertel]. 6, 13, 14, 19 We were interviewed on Almanac North.  Almanac North is a spin-off of Almanac on Channel 2 in the Twin Cities.  Basically those questions were posed to us and we kind of went through them.  There had been a major heroin bust I think the day before—the date we were on Almanac North was Good Friday of 2014. 13, 16 There was a major heroin bust either Wednesday or Thursday of that week, and based on that Channel 8 had called Dana Kazel, the communication manager, and was wanting to get some response from St. Louis County in relationship to this. 13, 15, 16, 19 Through that our department was contacted. 9, 12, 19 Our Adult Service Division director was unable to attend, so basically it went to myself and [Marsha Gertel] and we did the interview with two hosts of the program. 18, 19 The OARS group basically ended up having discussions and leading up to a proposal put together through our then—I think it was late 2000s—our Public Health department and Social Service department merged into Public Health and Human Services. 8, 9, 12, 19 Our Public Health and Human Services department proposed to the county commissioner's developing our Substance Use Prevention Intervention Initiative. 8, 9, 12, 14, 19 Through a unanimous vote in January 2014 they basically approved the allocation of four FTE's to provide prevention/intervention services throughout St. 10, 19 Louis County to address issues relating to substance abuse. 5, 6, 12, 13 That's our latest draft of our pamphlet or brochure. 5 As you can tell—yeah.  [shows the pamphlet] 17 So, that basically gives you the description of what we do in relationship to assisting and supporting individuals, families, and communities throughout St. Louis County. 13, 17, 19 We will do things from public education, trainings, we'll do consultations within a department and family members or others that are calling and concerned and wanting direction or ideas. 9, 12, 14, 15, 16, 18, 19 AS: So people can reach OARS? 9 GA: We're basically an extension of OARS. 19 It was through OARS that this program was founded.  OARS came first. 14 AS: That's interesting because what I take from that is that opioid crisis led to thinking about substance abuse prevention and intervention more broadly. 6, 10, 13, 14, 17, 19 Is that true? 5 GA: I think that's very fair. 9 That's basically what we are looking at. 19 AS: You didn't necessarily have coordinated services here, but you decided to expand this to include all substance use rather than just opioids. 6, 13, 14, 19 We are doing a lot of our focus on the opioid piece. 13 We do what is called expedited Rule 25 assessments for Children and Family Services. 5, 12, 13 We have an incredibly high rate of out of home placement. 5, 7, 12, 18 Kids in foster care or other licensed facilities and programs related to parental substance use. 6, 13, 19, 20 We have a parent or parents that come in who are at risk of losing their children. 5, 14, 20 They are in borderline crisis or in crisis.  If they are willing and wanting we'll do the assessment, oftentimes right then if one of our workers is available, either [Matt Johnson] or [Marsha Gertel]. 12, 13, 19 We also have a social worker in north St. Louis County. 19 He's based in Hibbing, but we'll be able to go and if not exactly that day then the next day. 13, 16 It happens very quickly. 15 Let me see if I can find [rustling through papers]. 6 Minnesota Department of Health has put together some annual—I can probably forward you through the Minnesota Department of Health—it's basically data, statistics on overdoses in Minnesota. 8, 9, 12, 13, 19 It does a county breakdown. 19 I have basically broken things down for St. Louis County through 2015. 8, 19 The 2016 statistics should be coming out at any point, but we are up to through 2015 right now. 12 You can take a look at the overdoses related to opioids. 6, 13 This is based on admissions to licensed chemical dependency treatment programs. 12, 13, 14 It's not necessarily dealing with individuals, but admissions. 13 AS: Because some people might go in three times in a year. 9, 14 GA: Yeah, as you well know from personal experience. 12, 18 AS: Can you talk to me about the climate of collaboration and cooperation that you think Duluth has, and is doing a good job? 10, 11 Why do you think that is?  What are the factors? 17 GA: I don't know if it is something in the drinking water. 5, 11, 12, 16 I mean it's something that I witnessed when I first came to the community in 1987, and there is just something here that is just part of the culture and the value of being able to work together and support each other even though we may not agree on other various items or values in life. 8, 9, 10, 14, 19 When we have a common purpose or see a problem that needs to be solved we can push our differences aside to work jointly and in a collaborative fashion. 6, 9, 12 We submitted a grant proposal to the Department of Human Services for approximately 1.3 million dollars for the state targeted response to the opioid crisis. 9, 12, 13, 14 The state of Minnesota received 5.3 million dollars for 2017 and 2018 through legislation that was pushed and supported very hard by Senator [Amy] Klobuchar to address the opioid crisis for rural communities. 5, 9, 13, 14, 19 AS: Did you say the state got five million?  AS: That was for rural?  I'll see if I can send you a PowerPoint and some handouts that will give you even more information. 6 AS: So you just turned that in?  GA: We submitted that on April 28th [2017].  St. Louis County Public Health Human Service submitted a proposal as the lead partner in a consortium with Duluth Police Department, Lake Superior Drug and Violent Crime Task Force, Rural AIDS Action Network, Center for Alcohol and Drug Treatment, University of Minnesota Duluth School of Pharmacy, six judicial district drug courts, and Carleton County Public Health and Human Service. 5, 6, 9, 12, 14 AS: So it's for St. Louis and Carleton County?  GA: Carleton County will receive no financial benefit from the application, but the things that we're doing will allow Carleton County residents access to particular things in relationship to drug court and probably the star component in this proposal is the development of a medically monitored opioid withdrawal program through Duluth Detox. 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 19 Basically it's a six-bed expansion of the Duluth Detox program, which is managed by the Center for Alcohol and Drug Treatment, who collaborated and helped facilitate the San Marco program. 12 Basically this will be for individuals to go through medical withdrawal with nurses and doctors monitoring. 5, 7, 12, 13, 14, 18 There will be medication that they need. 14 The Center for Alcohol and Drug Treatment also has the Clear Path program, which is a medication assisted treatment program, which utilizes both methadone and Suboxone. 6, 8, 12, 13, 14 We went through a significant borderline crisis situation back in I want to say 2013. 9, 11 We had a methadone program, and I don't want to get sued for what I'm about to say, but we had a methadone program called Lake Superior Treatment Center. 12 Basically they were going through significant concerns and issues in relationship to meeting licensing. 11, 12, 13, 18, 19 State Rule 31 licensing requirements. 12 I want to say it was either in 2012 or 2013 their license was revoked, which put the state of Minnesota in a crisis situation because they were one of five or six programs under the same company based out of state. 13, 14 In the state of Minnesota when a license is revoked it is revoked for all programs under the parent company. 13, 14, 20 If they would have closed Lake Superior Treatment Center they would have ended up closing I think three or four programs in the Twin Cities, one in St. Cloud, and one in Rochester. 5, 9, 10, 12, 14 [section omitted]  AS: But the other place was a licensing issue about the way they were monitoring the methadone? 6, 8, 13, 18 GA: Yeah, there was a long list, but things are set up where if a provider appeals the revocation they can maintain operation through the appeal process. 17 The appeal process went through about a two plus year time period. 14, 17, 18 During the initial onset of this we were meeting with the Department of Human Services state contingency plans if something ended up playing out and the program was closed. 5, 9, 10, 12, 18 As a result through collaboration with the OARS group St. Louis County put out an ROP for a community based treatment program. 6, 12, 13, 19 We received a number of proposals.  We ended up doing personal or presentations by three finals in the area and we basically ended up reviewing and choosing the Center for Alcohol and Drug Treatment. 5, 8, 10, 12, 14, 19 Gary Olson, the CEO, had been talking about putting something together four or five years prior to this piece, so this raised the level of need. 8, 14 Gary and the Center are just so reflective of the collaboration and the efforts to do things.  It's a non-profit. 15 He's the chief executive officer that's been working and dealing with this stuff for thirty plus years. 8, 14 AS: You picked someone that also reflects the community itself. 19 GA: Yes.  Focusing on community needs. 6, 19 Gary is very adamant about this being a public health issue because it has such an impact on individuals' families in the overall community. 13, 17, 19 It's very reflective of what we are trying to do as the OARS group.  AS: Is he on OARS?  AS: You keep all the people who've got their hands in this issue around the table? 9, 13, 17 We meet every two months. 11, 16, 18 Our next meeting is June 15th. 18 If your calendar allows you can certainly—I can send you an appointment. 8, 10, 12, 17 We meet on the second floor. 14, 18 It's a really exciting time. 18 Based on what was sent out in relationship to the grant proposal we might be hearing tomorrow on whether or not—they were talking twenty-one days. 5, 9, 16, 19 It's such a tight timeline. 9 The state submitted their plan in January, and basically these programs are supposed to be running by July 1st. 8, 19 Basically the awards have to be done and then the contract and negotiation piece between the awardees and DHS. 19 They basically have the contract signed and get things in place on July 1st. 11, 19 It's been a real interesting process. 17 AS: You were saying one of the things it includes is six more beds, managed detox. 19 What are some of the other parts that you think are special or particular? 9 GA: A rapid response for overdose victims. 13 We're collaborating with Duluth police, the Lake Superior Drug and Violent Crime Task Force. 8 Jeff  Kazel can give you a lot more detail with that.  What we are doing through this particular piece we are looking at an expansion of Narcan or naloxone access. 9 Being able to provide naloxone or Narcan and training to use that substance. 6, 13 The target is all law enforcement agencies throughout St. Louis County. 8, 12, 13 I think sometimes I get lost in the details—I'm not sure if that's also going to possibly include other emergency responders, but definitely all law enforcement agencies throughout St. Louis County. 8, 9, 11, 12, 13 We're going to be partnering through our substance use prevention intervention initiative our social workers to provide rapid response in regard to follow up support. 6, 9, 10, 12, 13, 19 We're going to try to get out and see the individual in one or two days. 6, 16 If it's a Friday evening we probably wouldn't be able to do anything until Monday. 16 Being able to get out to the individual, provide them a Rule 25 assessment, which is the first step in access in treatment, and provide other alternatives or supports that may be applicable or necessary. 9, 12, 13, 14 Trying to establish that contact as early on as possible to get things in place to provide support.  AS: It's filling a gap where there haven't been enough resources or enough people to treat this quickly. 5, 9 GA: We're hoping that this will be a nice fit in regards to the detox expansion. 15, 18, 19 The thing is we all know the need is going to exceed the supply, but Duluth Detox will be able to bring individuals in and provide a place for them to stay so they can get in the program. 12, 13 Gary Olson and Duluth Detox is going to be working with north St. Louis County Range Detox in Virginia [Minnesota] being able to go into Range Detox and staying at Range Detox until they are going to be able to be brought out to the Duluth Detox program. 7 We'll be working on other ways, too. 18 If possible openings are available. 10 There have been discussions about transportation to and from Ely and bringing people down. 9, 17 The thing that gets lost with St. Louis County is geographically it is bigger than three states within the mainland. 11 We've got a large geographical area. 8 Another thing too, which we're reminded on a regular basis too, is that St. Louis County is so massive we're dealing with services and issues related to both urban and rural settings. 12, 13, 19 We need to be able to understand and put things in place to address things for both areas. 5, 8, 17, 18, 20 It helps me having grown up on a small farm to be able to better connect and understand some of those things. 8, 10, 17, 18 There are always discussions about, "This happens here. 15, 18 That happens there." 15 Well, you've got an apple and you've got an orange. 7 We can't make orange juice with an apple. 7 We can't make apple pie with an orange. 7 Although we can have apple juice and orange juice. 7 May not have been a great metaphor. 20 AS: In an ideal world, from where you stand today, how do you think this crisis can be solved? 16 From your vantage point as being someone who is figuring out where the money is coming from and going. 8, 10 Do you see this being solved anytime soon? 6 GA: It needs to be a community effort, and that's why we've got who we've got in the OARS group. 19 It's been so well documented throughout the past four or five years from law enforcement and judicial legal system we can't arrest ourselves out of this problem. 8, 12, 13, 14 We need to address this from both a prevention and intervention standpoint. 5, 10, 13, 19 We need to provide the support and services for those individuals dealing with the addiction, and we need to be able to outreach and provide education and support for the community so they have a better understanding of what addiction is, what the substances, the drugs, can do to an individual, and in the process also communicate the fact that individuals are not dealing with this by choice. 5, 6, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 18, 19 They are dealing with this because they are afflicted with a disease.  One of the key points we are trying to work on on a constant basis is the stigma. 9, 15 We need to be able to remove the stigma associated with chemical dependency and addiction. 9, 12, 13, 14, 15 There is a similar effort that needs to be done in regards to mental health. 12, 19 With the stigma it is very hard for an individual to come up and say, "I'm addicted to heroin. 9, 12, 14, 16 I need help," because there are so many signs and reactions from people like, "Oh, get out of here. 9, 11 You're not worth anything.  You're doing this because you want to.  You're making bad choices because you want to. 6, 10, 14 Just get out of here.  I don't have time to help you."  That type of thing.  I think there has been some progress made.  Just through discussions and experiences, and fortunately I don't have first-hand experience with this. 14, 18 I've been blessed so far with my own family. 12 In listening to others they've seen what's going on with others, their spouse, their child, or their sibling, and they see and understand the fact that they're not doing this by choice. 6, 13, 14, 17, 18 Through that—that just amplifies the importance of the support groups such as Nar-Anon that Verne Wagner is so involved with because it's through those mutual experiences that people share. 9, 12, 18 It ends up being a snowball that we like to have because good things are going to grow through the passing of this information and communication. 10, 12 We need to address things both from prevention and intervention and prevention. 5, 10, 19 We're not going to solve a lot just by addressing one thing. 5 We are reactive instead of proactive and we have to be both.  AS: How did you come by your education around chemical dependency? 13, 14, 15 Did you go to school for it? 7 Have you learned on the job? 10, 11 GA: I've basically learned on the job. 10, 11, 19 Through life experience, too. 10, 18 In my younger days when I was down in the Twin Cities and the more social active lifestyle I was in relationships with individuals that started out great and then all of a sudden it was like A, B, C, and D. 10, 13, 15, 16, 19, 20 This isn't good. 10 Ended up leaving a relationship and getting into another relationship and all of a sudden the same thing starts happening. 15, 19 And it's like, wow. 17 The interesting piece—I established a good friendship with one particular individual in grad school who was a part of the CD [chemical dependency] group in a veteran's hospital. 7, 8, 9, 10, 13, 16, 17, 20 Listening to his stories on individuals and the dynamics that were tied in relationship to addiction. 9, 12, 13, 14, 19 Hearing that kind of explained my earlier life experiences. 10, 15, 18 Basically through the work.  It doesn't matter if you're doing child protection or working with the elderly: 14 chemical dependency and addiction is going to be part of your work. 9, 12, 13, 14 One of the things we are working on from a department standpoint through our Substance Abuse Prevention Intervention Initiative is attempting to put substance use disorder training as a core training function for new social workers, new employees coming into the department. 6, 9, 12, 13, 16, 19 We're not there yet, but we're getting much closer. 9, 10 We have a wonderful training department within St. Louis County. 9, 12, 18, 19 We've done a lot of work with them basically getting quarterly trainings set up. 19 Parental substance use disorder, the ABC's of addiction. 6, 12, 13, 14 We do SBIR [Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral] training—which is brief intervention and referral to treatment—which is a screening piece that can be done by anybody. 12, 13, 19 You don't need a Ph.D. or a master's.  You don't need a college education to be able to do this. 7, 14, 15 Basically it's being able to ask some open ended questions and allow an individual to share and be able to listen to their own situation and develop their own enlightenment to the risks that are involved. 10, 12 Where the individual is at it can be as easy as saying, well, you need to get someone to drive you home at night. 5 Or, I have some phone numbers for you to call. 8, 16 I think it would be really good for you to get an assessment to see possibly if you might be eligible or if chemical dependency treatment might be a good direction for you to go. 6, 10, 12, 13, 18 AS: Do you see it as an education not just for professionals, but for everyone? 6, 14, 15 We seem to be sorely lacking public education around substance use. 6, 13, 14, 15, 19 It reminds me of sex education and how political it gets, and what a disservice we are doing to young, growing sexual beings. 10, 12, 14, 15, 19 GA: It's a tough and very uncomfortable conversation, which is conflicting with values that have been installed with us.  AS: It's as if we don't have any trust in people to make decisions for their own health. 9, 14, 19 GA: Absolutely.  Part of our program, what I'll call the 'sappy program' is we're trying to get, and we still have to do some work on this, basically being able to—we've had some experiences with school districts throughout St. Louis County. 7, 18, 19 We've worked on trying to provide some support, SBIR training, to employment agencies. 12 AS: SBIR?  GA: Screening, brief intervention, referral to treatment. 12, 13, 19 Referral to treatment isn't necessarily going to chemical dependency treatment, but it's referring services. 12, 13, 19 You can find a lot of information on SBIR.  It was a best practice established in ERs, not necessarily for substance abuse. 6, 13 It can be a very useful tool. 6, 13, 18 It's something we encourage.  We've done SBIR training now for over two years now within St. Louis County for social workers, probation officers, public health nurses. 8, 12, 14, 19 AS: People who have contact with other human beings and trying to help. 19 GA: Trying to expand a professional or personal toolbox.  AS: Thank you.  This has been really good. 10, 18 I really appreciate the heart you seem to have for this. 6, 9, 10, 18 I don't think people in these buildings with state jobs or county jobs get a lot of credit for the heart that they do have. 5, 9, 11, 19 Even though you're writing grants and doing all this stuff you have your heart in it. 9 GA: It's contagious.  Basically the energy and the commitment of the others that I work with have and display regarding this. 12 You can take some credit for that too with this interview. 5 I've been in situations where you're talking to someone but you're really not sure the purpose and intent, and you get a little guarded and concerned about how you are saying it. 14, 18, 20 Matt Johnson, one of our social workers, and I did a fifteen minute radio piece with KDAL 610 last Wednesday. 12, 15, 16, 19 Tom Hanson, who was the radio person that we were working with, and he was bouncing in and out of weather and international news and local news and that type of thing, but he went out of his way just for conversation to establish a more personal type of atmosphere. 15, 16, 18 Once things started—it doesn't often happen but Matt and 15 I got done with that interview and we felt really good about what we're doing, what we said, what we communicated. 10, 11, 14, 18 AS: It's really good work. 10, 18 I'm really happy to have the chance to come up here. 18 GA: It's important. 9 Any time we get the chance to share what we're doing for others to experience or read it's an expansion or an extension to what we're doing. 18 We've got an information card that we're going to start producing. 14 Law enforcement will have it at RAAN [Rural AIDS Action Network] where basically for individuals it's kind of on two sides—it's resources: 8, 9, 12, 13, 19 Range Treatment Center, Center for Alcohol and Drug Treatment, United Way 211 information and referral. 12 That's a key piece. 15 On the inside we're going to have risk reduction points: always use a clean needle, don't use with—harm reduction safety points. 5, 6, 9, 10, 13, 14, 18, 19 I'm blanking on some of the key points. 15 I'll forward you some of the stuff.  The Minnesota Department overdose reports. 9, 12, 13 AS: Thank you.  This was really helpful. 9, 18

Dr. Thilo Beck Narrator Amy Sullivan Interviewer February 16, 2017 Zurich, Switzerland Thilo Beck-TB Andrew Tuttle-AT Amy Sullivan-AS TB: 5 I think to put it short what we do here has very much to do with a pragmatic approach. 18 Pragmatism is, in my view, the way to go about it along with the harm reduction approach. 5, 14, 18 We ask ourselves what is useful, not what should be, what would be the best possible aim or goal. 6, 13, 18 We don’t think too much about therapeutic illusions or fantasies, which is very common in medication therapy. 12, 14 Focusing on abstinence and considering that the majority of the patients we are treating here is not going for abstinence at the moment. 6, 8, 9, 12, 13, 14, 18 This has to be respected.  AS: By abstinence what do you mean?  TB: From any substance. 6 All of the substances. 6 The abused substance has been alcohol. 6, 13, 16 I think that is one of the problems in alcohol therapy. 6, 12 Historically, it is based on abstinence and that is why it doesn’t work that well. 13 That is why it is not that successful.  Quite a few of our patients, I would say the majority, don’t want to abstain from alcohol. 6, 18 They are rather thinking about reduction or using in a more controlled way. 5, 6, 14, 18 That is a reasonable goal with most of our patients.  They resonate with it.  The old pattern of addiction therapy has been to push patients into abstinence. 12, 14 Make them think that they want to go for abstinence.  It is like a brainwash. 13 In society it is more of a moral thing, in a way. 12, 18 Abstinence is good and substance use is evil. 6, 10, 13 It has to be wiped out.  All these fantasies about substance free societies. 6 It is an illusion.  It is a ruse. 6, 13 AS: There are people who can handle substances and there are people who can’t. 6, 9 TB: That is one thing.  In political discussions when I try to get this over to politicians they still think that substances are dangerous, which is not true. 5, 6, 11 I know that is a provocative thing to say. 12 The majority of people use any substance in a controlled way. 6, 9, 13, 18 This is the case for heroin, which is unknown. 11, 12, 16, 17 Most of the people out there think that heroin is very dangerous and if you use it once you are hooked. 6, 9, 11, 13, 16 That isn’t true. 5 We know from studies -- in Switzerland there was a study, too -- and studies in the UK, there is a big group of heroin users that have no problem with using it in a controlled way and in a recreational way. 6, 12, 13, 16, 18 This is the case with heroin, alcohol, and cocaine. 6, 16, 17 There is a minority of people being vulnerable for genetic reasons, growing up in a bad environment that are vulnerable to the action of psychoactive substances in a self medicating way, probably. 6, 9, 10, 12, 14, 18 That’s not their fault.  This happens and it is a fact that we cannot avoid. 15 This is about fifteen to twenty percent of regular users with this risk. 6, 13 In my view this is a fact we have to accept. 12 It is part of the solidarity -- we owe it to these people to stand up and help them and not judge them and punish them. 9 We need to try to help them manage their vulnerability as best as possible.  This is also possible.  That’s another story -- once addicted always addicted, which is not true either. 5, 12, 14, 15, 18 Addiction, or dependency, is a state you can manage. 13, 14 There are long-term studies, prospective studies for twenty or thirty years that follow people up. 9, 10, 14, 17 This is also the case when we ask our patients in treatment: What did you go through? 12, 13, 17 They tell us they have been abstinent for ten years and they started to use again and they used controllably and then shifted into out of control use again, dependent use, and then they stopped again. 6, 8, 13, 14, 16, 18 This is not a linear development from abstinence into total catastrophe of addiction. 9, 12, 14 We still don’t quite understand the factors contributing to why people stop after ten years of use. 6, 9, 11, 13, 14, 17, 18 We still don’t know. 12 Sometimes we think therapy might have to do with it, but on the other hand -- AS: What kind of therapy? 12 TB: Addiction therapy. 12, 14 It might help people come to grips better. 9 Sometimes I think they have decided before they come to therapy that they wanted to change and that’s why they come. 12, 14, 18 We assist in a natural process that they would go through anyways. 17, 18 AS: You reinforce what they already are doing. 8 TB: Yes, what they already want.  I’m not quite sure we really contribute. 11, 18 I think what we can do for sure is help to reduce harm. 5, 14 This is for sure.  AS: Can you talk about what harm reduction means to you as a physician? 5, 14 I was talking with another historian last night who does HIV and drug stuff and he’s saying that what he has realized is that depending on where you are in the world the word harm reduction has different meanings. 5, 6, 14 Can you describe what harm reduction means for you here in this clinic in Switzerland? 5, 14 TB: One point is that it is something very individual depending on the individual patient.  Each person we assist.  It is trying to help this person to use substances in a controlled way, in a way with as least risk as possible. 6, 13, 18 This is individual harm reduction. 5, 14 There is also the political side to harm reduction. 5, 9, 14 We try to involve ourselves into the political process to help get the framework adapted that harm reduction is possible. 5, 14, 15, 17 I think politically there are goals that are not very useful that way. 6, 13, 18 It is not useful to criminalize users. 6, 8, 13, 18 This is causing harm. 6 So, if we tried to engage in harm reduction we have to see that those are adapted. 5, 6, 14 We try to work on that, which is rather difficult at the moment. 8, 10, 12, 14 AS: There is political opposition to harm reduction? 5, 14 TB: Switzerland went through a very important process back in the nineties. 9, 12, 17 The situation was that bad.  This was the biggest opiate drug scene worldwide. 5, 6 This made Swiss politicians and Swiss society move. 12, 15 That was rocking our system. 14 This made the four-pillar policy possible.  AS: Because of the extreme nature of the problem. 12 TB: There was a lot of pressure. 10 Now, we are suffering of the success of this approach because the opiate scene has disappeared. 5 The opiate dependent people are not seen in public anymore. 6, 9, 19 There is no problem perceived. 12 So, politicians and society have forgotten the lessons we learned back in the nineties. 10, 12 No more problems. 12 The questions coming up about why we should continue to pay for treatments. 12, 13 It is a recession and there is not enough money. 8, 10 People are thinking of how to save money. 8, 10 In times like this you start to think about shortage of budgets like this. 18 The first priority is to cut budgets of minority focus. 14 AS: How many patients do you serve here in a year or a day? 14, 16 TB: It is about two thousand patients.  We are running four outpatient clinics. 8, 11 We employ a staff of about one hundred and twenty people. 9 Nine hundred are in substitution treatment, opiate [unclear] treatment, which was our starting point. 12, 13 We were founded shortly before the needle park closed -- was shut down. 5, 9, 10, 18 We started with low threshold opiate substitution -- methadone treatment at that time. 10, 12, 13 That was twenty-five years ago. 13, 14 Now, we have evolved into being active in the whole field of addiction medicine. 12, 14 All substances. 6 AS: You’re model went from opiates to everything?  We have the exact opposite.  TB: We transferred our harm reduction approach into the whole of addiction treatment. 5, 12, 13, 14, 17 I’m very proud of that.  I’m working hard to push this approach. 9 I think we are getting on in the addiction medicine field. 12, 14 They start to slowly understand this approach. 10, 17, 18 AS: Even here?  TB: Yes, even here.  AT: As a therapist you need a personal kind of evolution into that, too.  I remember in the beginning when I was more like, “Okay, it is doable. 11 I can be abstinent.”  Over time you can think, “It’s just not going to happen.” 15 TB: You’ve got to become and accept things. 12 Accept the patient.  Accept the people that come to treatment. 9, 12, 13 It is about respect and taking them as they are. 11 In many addiction treatment programs this still isn’t the case. 12, 13, 14, 17 Still very much like abstinence oriented and not trying to understand about the values of this person. 17, 18 It is about the aim of treatment that will be abstinence. 12, 13 It’s just not perceiving the person as a human being with values and individual goals. 19 That is the point about individualized treatment. 12, 13 It isn’t general goals, it tailoring treatment to the needs of the individual patient. 12, 13 That is one very important part of this harm reduction approach. 5, 9, 14 Accepting that some people have their own concepts -- whatever! 9 I’m not the one to judge who is right and who is wrong. 8, 11, 12 Why they use substances. 6, 13 I’m just trying to help them to make the best of it.  AS: Would you mind giving me some background on your career? 14, 15, 19 How did you into psychiatry and addiction medicine? 12, 14 TB: Well, I started as a psychiatrist.  When I was in my internship at that time I was forced, because there were vacancies, into the addiction world. 8, 12, 14 I was forced to work there. 8 This is a stigmatized field. 9 Psychiatry is stigmatized in the first place, and then within psychiatry addiction is stigmatized again. 9, 12, 14 AS: Why is psychiatry stigmatized? 9 TB: First of all it isn’t paid well.  We are amongst the lowest income group in medicine. 10, 12, 14 Child psychiatrists are lower. 10, 12 TB: So we are low. 10 AS: I’m glad I asked.  TB: I know surgeons are ten-fold. 12 That is one point.  The other point is the perception that it’s a frustrating job with no results. 6, 11 AS: Because you are dealing with mental illness. 12 TB: No sufficient results. 6 All of that stuff.  That is the same in addiction therapy as well. 12, 14 They are lying; it’s not working, and whatever.  This is the result of the wrong approach. 6, 11 If you are going into treatment with somebody and you expect them to do something they don’t actually want no wonder it doesn’t work! 7, 12, 13 This has to be frustrating.  We try to advocate for -- AS: That is a great point. 20 It is the approach.  TB: We battle with resistance forever and feel bad and frustrated -- both the patient and the doctor. 12, 14 If you choose to find the right approach and just try to meet these people where they are and invite them into a therapeutic process that’s a collaborative process. 9, 12, 17, 18 I don’t know what is right for this individual guy. 12 This is interesting for me as well to find with every single patient what is important for him or her. 9, 17 What should the goal be?  And to develop options.  This is interesting and not frustrating at all. 17 AS: Go back to how you got forced into it. 8 TB: I started to find out that the patients there were people as well. 9 They were interesting. 17 I like working with people anyways. 9, 17, 18 I got fascinated with seeing how stigmatized they were and how much they stigmatized themselves. 6, 9 This was such a treat for me.  And seeing how much could be improved and done, or how badly the system was working. 6 From then on I was hooked.  I was fascinated by how much could be done.  AS: For the better.  TB: For the better.  There is so much that should be and could be improved.  There is incredible potential to help and to make things better and create a better society as well. 5, 6, 12 I am still intrigued.  I am still fighting and working for this.  AS: How long have you been here? 17 TB: I started to work here in ‘97.  This is the twentieth year now. 12, 14 AS: You said you talk to politicians.  Can you describe your job here and what you do outside of dealing with patients? 11 TB: Arud [Centers for Addiction Medicine] has always been a political organization as well, a pressure group. 10, 14, 18 This is because we are a private charity.  We don’t have to obey any government regulations. 12 Most of my colleagues are working in state clinics and they cannot speak up.  They have to be careful about that. 19 We try to use this as an asset. 6, 13 AS: Do you collect information from them?  TB: Part of my work is to network and try to get specialists and Society of Addiction Medicine to organize that. 14 To get the specialists together to lobby for improvement of policy. 8, 12 We work with the state authorities.  AS: If you are a private charity do you get government assistance? 12 We actually function like a private practice. 7, 9 AS: When you were talking about the government trying to cut funding you meant for state-run agencies. 8, 12 TB: We have the four pillars, we have consumption rooms, and we have stuff like that. 14 We talk about cutting budgets of these places.  In society we have fifty five percent of Swiss people now that think substitution treatment shouldn’t be covered by insurance anymore because it is their fault. 5, 9, 12, 13 AS: There has already been a swing back.  TB: Yes.  There has always been a majority of Swiss people remembering the experience from the nineties where the success was so obvious of the low-threshold harm reduction oriented therapy. 5, 9, 10, 12, 14, 18 The acceptance was high. 7, 12 There was sixty-five or seventy percent pro-substitution treatment. 12, 13 Now it has shifted. 8 AS: Do you think part of that is the general swing towards the right that we’ve been seeing? 6, 9, 12 TB: It is this neoliberalism thing.  AS: It is not just that the problem of heroin addiction is being controlled. 12, 14, 16, 18 TB: Like saying that obese people should pay more for health insurance because they eat too much and that creates problems and causes costs and they have to cover themselves. 6, 9, 12, 13, 19 This is the discussion, which is absolutely useless in my view because this is not their personal decision that they choose to use heroin and are fully responsible for it and they cover all the costs. 6, 13, 14, 16 That is not the way it goes. 18 That’s a discussion in the health treatment system: thinking how we can cut costs. 12, 13, 19 Make the people pay themselves. 9 AS: What about the disease model of addiction? 12, 14 We are still talking about this in the United States.  TB: Yes, I know. 12 Nora  Volkow is really strong on that. 18 AS: The surgeon general just came out with that.  In our society it is still a new concept. 12, 16 I’m wondering if yours is different. 15 TB: The disease model has been useful, I think, as a first step to fight stigma. 6, 9, 13, 14, 18 Then it shifted from moral to a disease. 8 Now I think we are stuck with the disease model and it is not that useful in my view. 6, 13, 18 AS: How does it fit into this? 15 If you are diseased you have to do what someone tells you to do to get better. 15 It is not just fate.  I think there are factors contributing to dependent behavior and risk factors might add up in a syndrome that looks like a disease. 5, 17 It is not something we have a pill to cure.  It is much more complex and there are so many other factors contributing, also societal factors. 13, 17 I think there are societies that cause vulnerability and make people use substances in a problematic way. 6, 9, 12, 13, 18 It is not the individual’s fault.  There are so many ways to manage this behavior. 18 It is not just fate and nothing to be done about it.  You cannot just take the medicine and see how it develops. 6, 12, 14 I’m not so happy with the disease model because it deprives the individual of their autonomy, in a way. 18 AS: It creates a dependency. 13 TB: It is a habit that there is nothing to be done about and that is not true. 5, 20 AS: A typical addiction doctor in the US would explain it as similar to diabetes. 10, 12, 14 It is a way to frame it because we do care about diabetics. 15, 18, 19 TB: I think it is good in the discussion about stigmatization because diabetes is not as stigmatized. 9, 10 If you make the analogy that is good. 10 AS: Heart disease is another one that they use. 6, 8, 13 TB: Talking about diabetes there are many things to manage besides taking pills. 10, 11 It is about a healthy lifestyle and living another type of lifestyle, maybe. 5, 10, 15, 19 There are many things the individual can do, and that is the case. 17 In general in psychiatry we deal with chronic conditions. 6 It is not so much about healing or making it disappear. 10 It is more about managing something; managing yourself.  Also talking about schizophrenia for example.  We have no right to push schizophrenic patients to medicate with neuroleptics, for example. 10, 12, 14 That is their point to decide whether they want to use medication or not. 6, 13, 14 To decide if medication might help them on their way as one factor or not. 14, 18 It is not the silver bullet.  It is just one possibility to assist.  This might work for some and others it might not.  AS: Is that how schizophrenics are treated here in general? 12 AT: Psychopharmacology is probably the cornerstone of the treatment; you can’t get around it. 8, 12, 13 TB: There are clinics where the patients are pretty much forced to take the medication, which in my view is not the right thing to do. 8, 10, 12, 14 AS: Even if they were going to self-harm?  TB: People have the rights to self-harm. 12 In my position I try to inform them as best I can of the possible risks.  If they still continue to self-harm I think I have to go along with this. 17 That doesn’t mean I am happy with it. 18 I am still, as a professional identity, I don’t approve this, but I accept their way. 12, 18 I think life is dangerous. 10, 11 Everything is dangerous in life. 10, 11 If we wanted to avoid all dangers we couldn’t live. 18 Taking substances is dangerous, driving a car is dangerous, and it is how much danger you want to take that is an individual decision. 5, 6, 11, 14 I think in my view it is free will.  I don’t think society -- as long as you harm only yourself, we don’t have that much of a right to interfere. 12, 17 That’s my individual opinion.  AS: Would you say your opinion is an outlier?  TB: No, I think there is an argument now in general about how much interference of the state is acceptable. 12 That is a public health discussion. 19 How much should the government make their citizens behave in a certain way? 12, 17, 18 There is no right or wrong to that. 11, 12 That is a norm you have to decide on. 14 AS: Do you see people here -- patients, is that what you call them here? 6, 9 TB: Patient, clients. 10 AS: How many would you say have a co-occurring mental health issue? 12, 13, 19 TB: Practically all.  That is who we have here that come to treatment. 12, 13 The ones we see here in treatment. 6, 8, 12, 13 There are so many studies in that as well, that co-occurring psychiatric diseases is three to four -- not only one.  That has to do with our system of diagnosis, the DSM. 6 You end up having quite a few disorders. 6, 13 There are so many co-occurring disorders. 6, 13 Schizophrenia is about ten percent of the population we treat here.  In the general population it is about one percent, so it is ten fold.  We see about thirty to thirty-five percent with ADHD. 6 The general population is about four percent.  About forty to fifty percent with depressive and panic disorders, or personality disorders. 6, 13, 15 Those are just the psychiatric disorders. 6, 13 Disorders like infections, hepatitis C, HIV, liver diseases.  AS: When a person comes in seeking treatment for addiction are they evaluated for other things right away? 6, 12, 13, 14, 18, 20 Is that integrated in a way? 18 TB: they come here with a substance problem because we are an addiction clinic. 6, 12, 14 Our job then is to try to check them for other disorders, which isn’t that easy in the beginning because they don’t want to see a shrink. 6, 11, 13 They come for a substance disorder, and if you start asking them about psychiatric problems that might be hard for them. 6, 9, 12, 13 That is our job to try to involve them into disciplinary approach. 11 We work in a very integrated way in psychiatry: internal medicine, we have social work. 12, 14, 18, 19 We try to offer everything under one roof because [unclear] are so frequent in our experience I can understand. 17, 18 It is very difficult if you have to see three or four doctors for all the different disorders you have to treat all together in one place. 6, 8, 10, 12, 13, 14 And then we try to prioritize and treat the disorder that is most impairing at the moment for the patient; the problem the patient wants to work on. 8, 12, 13, 14 We try to motivate them to get a sense of their other disorders and motivate them to get into treatment there as well, but we cannot force them. 6, 8, 12, 13 AT: It is very modest -- the scope that you can actually engage them to work on. 7 There are low levels of resources then the goals are going to be small. 10 AS: The resources in the person?  You have to adapt therapy to the resources of the client or the patient. 10, 12 It is a very important process to try to identify how much this person can do, what he wants to do, and focus on that and not try to make them understand that they should do this. 9, 17, 18 It is important to inform them and offer them information and education, but they have to make the decision. 9, 14, 15 To go along with their decision. 14, 17 That is very important. 9 AT: I find myself trying to tone down the expectations of patients. 8 They come in and are already burdened with all the expectations gathered from the environment they are living in. 5, 12 I say, “No, you can’t do that.  We have to take this step by step.”  “Yeah, but I want this.”  Then we will see where it goes.” 6 TB: That is the problem. 12 The extrinsic motivation is so strong.  We try to evocate that motivation.  It is the only motor that really works. 9, 18 As you said, very often if we see the patients the first time they are in a crisis. 6, 14 What is their first idea when they go through a difficult time in their life? 10, 14 I have to stop using. 6 Then they think that is the solution because that is what they hear from all over: it is bad that you use and you should stop. 6, 9, 13 When they have a hard time when they try to stop -- that that’s the idea -- then everything is okay. 9 If you try to analyze this, if you take your time and talk this through with a patient then they start to realize there is not a single problem to resolve just by stopping the use of a substance. 6, 12, 13 In contrary, it might even make problems bigger. 12 Many of our patients it is the way they structure their lives, their routine. 15, 18 No alternative at the moment. 8, 12, 14 You shouldn’t take it away because nothing is left. 14, 18, 20 That is not a good place to be. 10 We try to explain this to our patients that we have to find alternatives. 14 Before we cut down or take away, it is a much better position to have alternatives already than to decide to reduce or take the substance use away. 5, 6, 13, 14, 18, 20 Never do that without alternatives. 14 Obviously then you wouldn’t require someone to detox? 19 TB: No, it is useless. 6, 13 We have patients here that have been through twenty, thirty, forty times.  How many more treatments of that kind do you want to go through? 12, 13 Every time you go for one or two weeks and then you relapse and prove to yourself that you cannot do it. 15 You’ve failed again and you are a failure. 14 What is the use of this approach? 6, 13 It is not really useful. 6, 13, 18 Sometimes people say we are against abstinence, which is not true at all. 5, 9 I think abstinence is a state: it can be good, useful; it depends for who and what situation. 6, 10, 13, 15, 18 It is not per say good or bad. 10 It depends on the context. 15 AS: What would you say to someone who said that if they stopped using something like heroin or meth and they see drinking beer as triggering that desire -- I know people who have quit and then they think they can have a beer -- and within forty-eight hours they are using meth again. 5, 6, 9, 11, 12, 15, 16 How would that be managed in this environment? 12 Because that person would say that they should never have a beer again. 16 TB: That is our job to work with triggers. 11 I think education is very important to explain the mechanisms of what is happening. 9, 14, 15 I think that is pretty important. 9, 10 People feel less of a victim and it becomes something they can do because there is something happening. 15 There are different approaches to understanding that you can control triggers. 14, 17, 18 This is possible.  The earlier that you detect the starting point -- the triggers won’t just go away. 15, 18, 20 The more awareness you develop inside to realize when this starts low. 9, 10 The earlier you intervene the better you can manage. 15 That is what we work on with our patients.  That is pretty successful. 10 AS: I have been interviewing some people in long term recovery who are also in addiction treatment who are moving towards this model that you are espousing that is more individualized. 6, 9, 12, 13, 14, 17 A couple of them have said that they haven’t used anything for twenty years and now they have decided that if they want to have a glass of champagne or a glass of wine with dinner they do it, but how hard it was to go from the idea that if you ever touch it again you are an addict. 6, 9, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16 One man told me -- he runs a methadone clinic and would be very in line with what you are saying -- he said when he told his friends from AA [Alcoholics Anonymous] they said he was never really an addict. 8, 9, 14, 16, 18, 20 TB: I am having a problem with this twelve-step approach because it is too -- 12 AS: Does it have a place here?  It has a place, but not as much in the US.  AS: By here I meant in Switzerland.  TB: There are AA groups. 12 I have patients that are in AA groups. 12 There are patients that really like it there and it helps them. 18 There are some pretty good 10 AA groups here that are not that dogmatic, more flexible in a way. 12, 18 They accept the use of substances. 6, 12, 13 They work with people who are still using. 6, 9 I don’t know. 12 It depends on the individual patient. 15 For some patients it is too dogmatic.  Then it is stigmatizing again because it makes them feel bad if they use substances. 6, 9, 13 AS: Your model is more helping someone early on in the process figure out what they can handle and what they can’t handle versus a twenty year time period and then saying, “I think I could have a glass of wine.” 11, 14, 17, 18 I just think of the intensity of that decision after all that time and then having people who were close to you say that you were never an addict when that person’s life had fallen apart. 9, 10, 11, 14, 16 It just seems healthier. 6, 19 TB: This all or nothing approach isn’t really helpful. 9, 18 I am trying to advocate the continuing of possible goals and states.  This is not you are either abstinent or an addict. 14 There are all different shades in between.  AT: How can you achieve a manageable balance?  AS: Where you are in control of your life and happy. 10, 18 TB: The degree of control. 18 Even control is not an all or nothing thing. 18 There are different degrees of control. 18 We try to help our patients to improve control, whatever that means. 18 With one patient that might be to reduce their beer consumption from seven liters a day to five liters. 5, 14, 16 It is still an improvement. 12 For others it might mean they only drink on Sunday once a week, or whatever. 5, 15, 16 AS: They come up with that and try it out.  TB: It is our job to help them find their own goals and what works for them. 9, 11 That starts anew with every patient. 16 There is no recipe that I could offer that would say this is the way you have to go. 18 I think that is what the patients here appreciate about it. 10 Feeling accepted and respected and realizing that we listen to them and we depend on their view. 12 AS: How long do people usually seek services here? 6, 9, 17, 19 Aside from methadone. 9 TB: Methadone is another point. 8 Saying opioid addiction is a chronic disease. 6, 12, 13, 14 I think it is a chronic disease that we have here in treatment because they were not for their own faults sort of entrenched. 6, 12, 13 That is a result of the political and societal conditions we have had. 6 They were forced into this marginalized lifestyle. 8, 10, 15 They were made chronic. 6 They are so impaired, not by the action of the substance of heroin, but of the side effects of illegal lifestyle and these horrible years they went through. 5, 6, 9, 10, 14, 15, 16 That impairment makes their condition chronic. 6, 12 That is my view on that.  There are famous surgeons that have been living with opiate addiction and have been going through a very successful career because they had no problem providing themselves with clean morphine. 10, 12, 14, 15, 19 I think heroin addiction is not this hopeless chronic disease, per say. 6, 9, 12, 14 There are other factors contributing to this. 17 That is a misconception of it.  We treat the effects of the bad conditions they were living under, the impairment of this lifestyle. 10, 12, 14, 15 This is a group -- some of them have been having treatment now for twenty-five years already and they might continue until the end of their life. 10, 12, 13, 14 There is a very small number in that group of people recovering, in a way. 9, 18 Recovery is another term that can be understood in many ways. 17, 18 Recovery in the UK and in the States as well, I think, has been hijacked as a term for abstinence, which is not the idea of it. 17 Recovery means to get to terms with something and to be able to live a normal life with the substance or without, whatever you choose. 6, 10, 16, 17 It is about integration and being part of society with or without substances doesn’t really make a difference there. 6, 9, 12, 18 It is the degree of control. 18 There is this group that is in our treatment for long term, opiate addicted people. 9, 12, 13, 14, 17 If, for example, with alcohol or cocaine we see people come to treatment for a period of time and then they go ahead with their life, get to terms with it, and they might come back after five years and get another treatment. 6, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18 That is the pattern we see. 6 Some we might not see anymore. 6 AS: Do people come for group therapy or is this more one on one? 9, 12 TB: Swiss patients are going for one on one.  They hate groups. 12 I love groups and I think groups are very helpful. 9, 12, 14 We have started so many groups and they all ended up with one or two or no people. 9, 12 I think we are in the luxurious position that we can offer one to one treatment. 12, 13 There are other countries like Germany that have fewer resources.  The treatment system depends much more on group approaches because of resources. 12, 13, 15 Here we still have enough funds to finance one to one treatment. 12, 13 Also, because self becomes stigmatization and not wanting to have other people know they use, or whatever. 6, 9, 12, 13 That is another thing I am not really happy about. 18 Our patients are not really ready or up to political involvement. 12, 18 We have this in the UK, for example.  We have user unions and advocacy groups. 6, 12, 13 We do that for our patients and sometimes I feel a little bit sick of it. 15, 20 I voice for the patients who won’t speak up. 17 AS: We have had that issue with Alcoholic Anonymous because they want to stay anonymous; they are safe in that space. 13 Lately there are more people who are coming out to say what is happening, parents who will speak out, and advocacy. 9, 15, 20 We are actually getting legislation change because we are speaking up. 7 TB: It is very important. 9 This is what makes politicians move. 15 Somebody has to step up.  Somebody who has a problem. 12 If I come up and say, “I have patients who have a problem” that is not the same. 12 AS: That is how we got Narcan to be more available.  We have a law called the Good Samaritan Law so that someone will call when there is a person that is overdosing rather than just drop them or leave. 5, 11, 13, 18 It was a group of mothers who lost their children who then lobbied the legislators. 5, 11, 14, 20 Whether they were teary or not they made a huge impression and it was an incredible vote, almost unanimous. 5, 10 TB: That is very important, but it is really hard to hear. 9, 18 Sometimes I think it might be our fault because we have been very active from the start and we are used to this. 6, 13, 16 I think we should have pushed them more from the beginning or evolved our patients more from the beginning to the whole political process as well. 11, 17 AS: There is still quite a bit of stigma still. 9, 20 It isn’t that you have overcome stigma. 9 It is that you have overcome a different treatment model. 12, 13 TB: Yes.  There is lots of stigma still. 9, 16 We try to work very closely with general practitioners because I think they see a lot of people that have substance problems but don’t come for substance problems and go for other reasons. 6, 8, 9, 10, 12 I think they have a very important role in screening and prevention and trying to make people realize or understand about risks of drug and substance use. 5, 6, 9, 10, 13, 17, 18, 19 There as well the stigmatization is so strong. 9 General practitioners say they don’t want to deal with it. 8 It is like opening Pandora’s box: “Oh, no. 10 That’s too much.  I don’t want to know about that.” 12 That’s a problem. 12 AS: We have the same problem. 12 Is there medical school training around addiction? 7, 12, 14 TB: We have started to improve.  There is a new concept now for medical students. 7, 12, 14, 16 The Society for Addiction medicine has been invited to contribute to this program and it is getting better. 12, 14 I think we are learning from Canada. 10 Canada is pretty ahead in that way. 10, 14, 18 The medical students there already have quite a bit of addiction medicine -- because it is so frequent. 7, 12, 14, 20 It is underrated.  I think medical students should already practice and get experience working with people with substance use problems. 6, 7, 9, 12, 13, 14, 18 That’s what they emphasize in these courses too: that they should self reflect on their stand on substance use. 6, 13 AT: Using a lot of Ritalin to be able to study enough to pass.  TB: It starts with your own understanding and perception of the problem or the phenomenon. 12, 14, 17, 18 To get a normal approach to that. 16 There is still a lot to do.  With general practitioners sometimes I think this is a really hard job. 8, 9, 11, 18 They are still very much in this paternalistic way of understanding medicine. 12, 14, 17, 18 The expert: “I tell my patients what they have to do.  If they don’t listen I tell them harder, and then even harder. 9 If they still don’t listen I throw them out of the treatment. 12, 13 I don’t want to see them anymore because they don’t want it.” 6 AT: The other ones you also don’t hear about a lot. 8, 9 I know a lot of general practitioners that have a really good approach to addiction. 8, 10, 12, 14, 18 They are really good. 10, 18 They are the people that people go to, too. 9 TB: The ones I am talking about I would say are the old generation. 8 It is coming to an end now. 12 The ones that are in their sixties now. 8, 12 They have just grown up in another way. 10, 18 The younger practitioners think differently, but still aren’t educated well enough in that field. 8, 14, 20 There is a big lack of knowledge. 12 AS: The thing I’ve heard is they ask what they would take out and remove from course time because it is so packed. 9, 15 What would they not teach?  TB: What we really work a lot with is the motivational interviewing approach. 18 That is an approach that has been done a lot in the alcohol therapy field. 6, 12 Miller and Rollnick back in the sixties.  That was so helpful. 9 This is now getting adopted all over medicine working with chronic diseases. 6, 12, 14 It works with intrinsic motivation: 9 trying to make people want to change for their own sake. 9 This approach is so helpful working with people with obesity, or diabetes, or HIV, or whatever. 9, 10 They have to manage the long lasting condition where they have to have a motivation to do something and be active to manage their health. 17, 19 This approach I think should be already taught with medical students because it is an attitude. 7, 14 AS: Do you use that here? 6, 13 TB: Yes, we do.  Understanding that you have to advocate intrinsic motivation and that therapy wouldn’t work otherwise. 12, 14 You should forget about treating people if you don’t know what they really want. 9, 12, 13, 18 That’s where therapy starts. 12 This sounds pretty trivial, but so many doctors don’t really talk with their patients about what they want: “Do you really want to take those pills?” for example. 10, 12, 14, 18 On behalf of adherence. 14 Only half of the pills prescribed are really taken. 10, 14, 18 That is also a result of that. 6 Nobody really cares about what the patients actually think. 7, 18, 19 There is this shift going on in medicine at the moment -- slowly, but it is -- that we understand that patients are human beings as well and we do a job together with them. 8, 10, 11, 12, 14, 17, 18, 19 It is not just us saying what they have to do.  There is also the Internet and all that stuff contributing to that because patients inform themselves.
