They are getting out of their role as a victim and getting more active, which is good. 10 I think those are the most important points of our approach. 9 Ever since Arud was founded -- it has been twenty-five years now -- we have always been growing. 10, 12, 14, 18 I think this is also a good thing to see. 6, 10 I think this is because we offer a treatment that fits. 12, 13, 15 We still have a long way to go and we will continue to grow because there are still so many people out there not coming into treatment because they don’t find a treatment that fits. 9, 10, 12, 13, 15, 17, 18 They don’t want to hear, “You should stop again. 9 There is no other way. 18 You are bad.”  Feeling that their doctor is frustrated and they don’t want to talk about it because they are just supposed to stop. 12, 14 There is still quite a potential for us to grow. 6, 10 That is what we have always been true to. 5, 18 We never say we are full. 14, 16 If all our therapists are busy then we just employ new therapists. 15, 16 AS: You don’t turn someone away? 18, 20 TB: No, never. 16 I really believe in low threshold treatment. 10, 12, 13, 18 You have to use the window of opportunity. 6, 13, 19 Whenever someone has the feeling that they need assistance you should be ready to offer this within twenty-four hours. 15, 16 AS: There are some people starting to do that in Minneapolis. 9 TB: I think all this waiting is terrible. 11, 15 AS: Many of our children are dying because they aren’t getting in at that moment, especially young people. 5, 8, 9, 12, 14, 20 You finally somehow twisted their arm and then you have to wait ten days. 8, 16 TB: In the UK and in Scotland I have been several times to assist them.  They are about to open a heroin assistance treatment now, but it has taken three years of lobbying and sharing our experiences with them. 12, 13, 14, 16, 18 Up there they have a waiting list of up to six weeks for someone with opioid addiction to get admitted to agonist treatment. 12, 13, 14, 15 This is just impossible.  That’s not the way. 18 Here anybody can just walk in and within twenty minutes is in treatment. 12, 13, 15, 16 AS: That’s what you call low threshold. 10 You don’t have to prove anything.  TB: Yes.  The only thing you have to do is take a urine specimen to prove there are opioids in the system. 6, 12, 13 AS: Is that the only time you would do a UA [urine analysis]? 6 TB: Yes.  We shouldn’t start opioid treatment if someone is intolerant. 12, 13 That would be dangerous. 11 Sometimes you have people coming in and saying they need substitution treatment. 9, 12, 13 I had one patient that was a schizophrenic just pretending to be an opiate dependent. 10 Then you can only tell with the urine analysis. 6 If there are no opioids in the urine then you won’t start treatment. 6, 12, 13 That is the only condition.  Then we start right away. 12, 18, 20 In opiate assisted agonist treatment what is very important is the individualization to be able to use as many different substances as possible. 6, 9, 12, 13 We started off with methadone in the nineties and that was all there was around. 12 Now we know that, as with any other medication, there are different individual side effects. 9, 12, 14 People tolerate substances differently. 6 Now we use methadone, buprenorphine, slow-release morphine, and heroin, the original substance. 6, 10, 13, 16 That is the very important thing to be able to do. 9 It is long-term treatment and it is about quality of life. 10, 12, 13, 17 You have to find the substance that fits best for the individual patient. 6, 15 That might be methadone, that might be heroin, that might be morphine. 6, 8, 16 In my perspective it is very important. 9 It is amazing to see how life can change for a patient who has been on methadone for twenty years because it was the only thing around and now changing to slow release morphine. 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 14, 17 We have had patients that say, “This is like a new life. 10, 16 I feel so much better.”  Others have the same experience with Buprenorphine. 10, 18 I think it is really important to give them a choice. 6, 9, 18 There is no medical indication for what substance is best for what patient. 6, 7, 14 They have to find out what is the best for them.  What we really aren’t happy with in Switzerland is the state of heroin treatment. 12, 13, 16, 18 We are still very much restricted by law. 13 AT: I was just going to ask I mean morphine, buprenorphine, and methadone can be obtained through pretty much every pharmacy. 10 TB: That is regular treatment. 12, 13 AT: Do you think heroin should be that available? 16 TB: Absolutely.  There is no problem with that. 12 We have twenty-three years of experience with heroin treatment. 12, 13, 14, 16, 18 We run the largest heroin clinic in Switzerland. 8, 16 We have about two hundred and twenty people in heroin treatment and we have been doing this for twenty-three years. 9, 12, 13, 14, 16 It works exactly as any other agonist treatment. 9, 12, 13 The only thing when we started heroin treatment in ‘94 one hundred percent of users were using intravenously. 6, 12, 13 This is an international, European trend.  There are less and less people injecting, which is good. 9, 10, 13 AS: How do they get heroin treatment? 12, 13 Is that injected as well?  We offer injectable heroin. 16 The majority of patients now have shifted to oral avenues. 8, 12, 18 AT: That was my question.  I have noticed some of my patients have started to get oral heroin. 16 How does that make sense?  My understanding of the pharmacology of heroin is that it very quickly gets transformed into morphine. 10, 14, 16, 17, 18 Does any of that reach the brain in the form of heroin? 13, 16 TB: Yes.  I was so amazed, but the ones who get the oral heroin tablets use it nasally. 6, 8, 13, 16 There the onset of action is a bit faster. 20 AS: It isn’t a tablet?  TB: It is a tablet, but they crush it and snort it.  I don’t have anything against that because snorting it is still much more safe than injecting. 13 We are very happy with this trend. 18 Only twenty-five of our patients do injection only with the heroin treatment. 12, 13, 16 Forty-five percent have shifted totally to tablets. 8 I think this type of tablet based heroin treatment could be transferred to regular treatment. 5, 12, 13, 17 Any general practitioner could give these tablets away. 8, 18, 20 Nothing speaks against that.  AT: I am a little wary about injectable heroin because I think there is a risk of doctors becoming dependent. 12, 14, 16, 20 TB: Well, we have to live with that risk.  I think the injectable heroin is another story. 15, 16 The onset is so fast that it can be dangerous. 11 That is why injecting is still supervised here. 13, 16 They have to inject on the premises. 10 AT: In case they overdose accidentally. 13, 17 TB: If they have used alcohol or benzodiazepines before and they inject the onset is so fast that you can end up having an overdose within two minutes. 6, 13, 15, 16 AS: Are people asked if they are on benzos and alcohol before they get injected? 6, 9 TB: We know them, and we know which ones are risky guys and use a lot of other substances as well. 6, 12, 13 That’s manageable.  We have never had anyone die in twenty-three years. 14, 16 Nobody died on the premises. 10 The only thing that can happen is they breathe less or they stop breathing for a while and you have to assist everything and they come back again. 15 It’s not really dangerous as long as you know how to proceed. 11, 12, 17, 18 Anyways, with the heroin tablets we restrict the take home dose to two days. 16, 18 People with heroin treatment on tablets have to show up at least three times a week. 12, 13, 15, 16 Considering that this is a long-term treatment that should enable people to live autonomously and integrate into society and have a job and have a family life. 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 17 How can you do that having to show up three times a week at the treatment center? 12, 13, 15 Traveling there.  It is just not the thing to do.  AS: Do you think they should have access to more tablets? 9 TB: This is counterproductive. 14 The aim of those treatments is to help people reintegrate in society and live a regular life. 9, 10, 12, 13 Having these restrictions makes it impossible to engage in a regular lifestyle. 10, 15 AS: Can people take methadone home? 9 TB: Yes.  Ninety percent of the patients we have here are on regular agonist substance treatments. 6, 12, 13 Heroin treatment we can only offer in licensed facilities. 12, 13 That is another clinic of ours on the other side of the river. 9 Ninety percent of the patients we treat here in regular agonist treatment have at least one week of take home, which is no problem. 12, 13, 15 They are in control. 18 Many of them work; they go for business travels and whatever.  They don’t have to come here all the time.  AS: But some people do start out that way and have to come here everyday? 9, 16, 18 TB: That’s an exception.  If they are in a psychosis or a very deep depression and are suicidal or for psychological reasons are not able to handle take homes. 10 They might lose them or are not in control of dosing them, but that is the exception. 9, 18 AS: It is very different because we police it very heavily in the US. 8, 16 TB: That is useless. 6, 13 That is another way of institutionalization. 18 It is causing harm and impairing patients. 6 AS: There are all kinds of people who hang around who are trying to sell. 9 It brings the culture that they are trying to get away from right there to the place where they are trying to get better. 12, 18, 20 That treatment now is so stigmatized that so many people won’t even say they are on it. 9, 12, 13 They don’t want to go.  Many treatment centers will not refer you to methadone. 6, 8, 12, 13 They will only do Suboxone or Vivitrol. 8 TB: I think in the States the general practitioners are only allowed to prescribe buprenorphine. 8, 10 AS: Yes.  No methadone. 6, 8 They are only allowed a certain number of patients and they have to go through a DEA [drug enforcement agency]. 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 13, 14, 17 AT: Each one of those substances has advantages and disadvantages over the other. 6 Ultimately it’s got to be the user who decides. 6, 13, 14 TB: And not the state and not the government. 12 It is really an absurd situation. 18 If you look all over the world you have countries, for political reasons, like in the north -- Finland -- has only buprenorphine. 10, 14 That’s a political decision because they thought any other substance was not safe. 6, 14, 17, 18 Same in France.  It has improved now. 12 It is still about eighty-five or ninety percent of this agonist treatment is with buprenorphine because the government thinks that it is safer. 10, 12, 13, 17 AT: It is a partial antagonist. 9, 13 TB: Yes.  That is also called Indivior, the company that manufactures buprenorphine has been very politically active advocating for buprenorphine and getting quite a lot of government on their side. 9, 12, 14 These are economic reasons.  AT: Drug pushers.  AS: Thank you,  you have been very generous.  [walking around clinic] 14, 16 TB: This is the medical department. 7, 9, 12, 14, 19 This is where we treat Hepatitis C and HIV and other disorders. 6, 13 We see an increasing number of age related comorbid medical disorders. 6, 7, 13, 14 The average age of the opiate dependent cohort is forty-five years. 14 That’s the nineties generation heroin and they are aging. 12, 16 There are hardly any newcomers. 9, 16 Heroin is out.  It is a loser drug. 5, 6, 9 We hardly see any young, new heroin users. 6, 9, 13, 16 The epidemic is over. 13 What we see is a cohort of aging heroin users. 6, 13 They are twenty years older than their actual age. 14, 20 They have aged twenty years because of the lifestyle they have been forced to live. 8, 10, 14, 15 This lifestyle made them sick, not the drugs. 5, 6, 10, 15 We treat the results. 6 This is the lab.  This is quite an important machine. 9 It is sort of an ultrasound, but it measures the fibrosis of the liver.  That’s very important in treating hepatitis c. 9, 13 This is an issue at the moment all over: hepatitis c treatment is still quite expensive. 8, 11, 12, 13, 14 Gilead, which started the whole thing off, earns billions.  AS: They have kept the cost pretty high? 7, 10 TB: Yes, it is about sixty thousand dollars a treatment. 12, 13 AS: Where are they based? 13 For how long? 17 TB: Six weeks. 15 The United States.  They didn’t even develop the substances themselves. 6 They bought the patent and now they are making a hell of a lot of money. 8, 10, 12 We have this problem that sixty percent of the cohort of the opiate dependent population we treat here are infected with Hepatitis C. 12 Also a consequence of the lifestyle and not of the drug. 5, 6, 10, 15 Actually, we should treat them all with this new treatment. 12, 13, 16 It is very effective and has a ninety to ninety-five percent success rate.  We should treat them all; that’s how you treat infections like that, but it’s too expensive.  The government decided to make limitations on the treatment, so we can only treat them if the fibrosis has progressed to a certain level. 12, 13, 14, 17 They have to be pretty sick to get the treatment. 10, 12, 13, 15 It would be wiser to treat them earlier before they get to that degree. 15 That is why we measure the fibrosis grade to get them into treatment. 5, 12, 13 AS: We had the same thing happen with Narcan. 15 The price went up to two thousand dollars right at the time when all the state governments were allowing more access to it. 9, 10, 12 TB: This is internal medicine here and all of the rest of the premises is psychiatry. 10, 12, 14 We work very close together because all of the patients are comorbid and we are trying to get the treatment to fit the needs of the patient. 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 15 We have five hundred patients in agonist treatments. 12, 13 That is quite a numbers.  That’s why we have computerized systems.  We get all the medication per patient for the comorbid disorders. 6, 13, 14 This is the amount for one week because most of them come once a week and get all their medication. 14, 15 This is a project where we are going to move together the four clinics in Zurich next year to one place. 5, 8, 14, 15 We have centralized the outpatient clinics into one place. 11 We think we can offer more comprehensive and better quality treatment if we are all under one roof. 10, 12, 13 That is going to happen the end of this year. 14, 15 AS: You are open six-thirty a.m. to nine-thirty p.m. six days a week? 15, 16 TB: Seven days a week. 15, 16 Now we think of reducing the service over the weekend because ninety-nine percent of our patients are so stable we don’t have to offer the services. 5, 12, 14, 15, 19 That was important in the beginning back in the nineties when people are still very bad off and they needed much more support. 9, 11, 12 Now it has stabilized.

Emily Brunner Narrator Samantha Aamot Interviewer June 28, 2017 St. Paul, Minnesota Emily Brunner-EB Samantha Aamot-SA SA: 8 First I’ll have you state your name and say that you give us permission to use this recording. 6, 13 My name is Emily Brunner and I give you permission to use this recording. 6, 8, 13 SA: Great, thanks. 11 Do you want to talk a little bit about your childhood and where you grew up and your family? 12, 14, 20 EB: Sure.  I grew up in Ridgefield, Connecticut which is a small town in Fairfield County, Connecticut. 20 I also briefly lived in California--Palo Alto--and my father is a physicist and my mom is a choir teacher, but she didn’t go back to work until I was about nine, I think I was in third grade--no I was in middle school, but she was home for most of my childhood. 5, 7, 14, 16, 19, 20 She never drank or used anything and neither did my father, but we had a history. 5, 6, 13, 15, 16 My grandfather on my mother’s side was an alcoholic and that was why she didn’t drink. 5, 6, 9, 16 I kind of knew that growing up. 10, 16 SA: You were in California at this point?  EM: Both California and Connecticut.  I just remember that being talked about very early on.  SA: And did you grow up having that idea for yourself? 10 Yeah, I definitely remember at one point my grandma offered me a thousand dollars if I could get through college without drinking alcohol, but it wasn’t worth it. 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, 20 [laughs] 15 She had watched how problematic that was for my grandpa. 12, 17 He ended up going to alcoholics anonymous and periods of sobriety, but then he would relapse. 6, 12, 18 SA: And this was your mom’s parents? 14, 20 My mom’s parents. 14, 20 And then my dad’s family all lived in Wisconsin and a lot of them drank heavily and they were often drunk when we saw them. 5, 7, 8, 12, 14, 16 It looked fun, but like my parents didn’t drink and they were also kind of awkward people and that seemed connected to me, I think. 5, 6, 9, 14, 20 They were sort of embarrassing.  I don’t know. 12 I guess every kid thinks their parents are embarrassing, but I certainly did as well. 8, 17, 20 SA: Did you see your mom’s parents’ drinking affect your mom in any way that you remember? 5, 6, 11, 14, 18, 20 I think she was just very clear that we don’t drink because we have a history of alcoholism in our family. 5, 6, 12, 15 I think she probably puts a lot of characteristics of adult children of alcoholics, but I wasn’t terribly interested in much of that when I was younger. 5, 6, 14, 20 I just thought, You’re awkward and embarrassing. 17, 18 SA: And it was because they didn’t drink. 5 And it’s because they didn’t drink. 5 Well, I mean I think I was pretty committed to the idea of not drinking when I was younger but maybe developed that later on. 5, 10, 11, 20 I certainly had a pact to like never drink. 5, 8, 16, 17 SA: Did you have any siblings?  I do, I have three younger siblings. 20 I was the oldest of four. 20 Two younger brothers and a younger sister. 20 SA: Do you want to talk a little about your high school years or deciding that you wanted to go into medicine? 7, 12, 14, 18, 20 EM: Sure.  And I didn’t decide in high school. 7, 14 It’s actually kind of a funny story where I went to college because--so I was like an uber nerd with not a lot of friends. 7, 9, 15, 16, 20 I had one very, very close--two very close friends who I am still very close with who were kind of like siblings because I wasn’t close with my siblings. 9, 10, 16, 20 We were one the debate team--one of them and me--and we went to a junior year debate meet and went to MIT to a frat house and I got super drunk there. 5, 6, 8, 13, 14, 16, 18 SA: And this is in high school? 7 It was a trip where we went to Boston [Massachusetts] for a weekend and my parents weren’t among the chaperones and we were all such good kids that they gave us the freedom to not have anyone check on us at night, and so we developed the plan to infiltrate a MIT frat party. 6, 8, 9, 10, 13, 15, 20 My dad went to MIT. 14 He was a grad student there, but I always thought MIT was a place that I could be cool basically because it was so nerdy. 17, 18, 19 And so I tried to go there.  SA: What else happened at the party? 9, 15, 20 I certainly don’t remember that much of it, but I kissed a boy, which was a thing I had never done before. 7, 8, 16, 17 I loved being drunk. 5, 8, 14 SA: Was it one of your first experiences with alcohol? 6, 14, 18 It was definitely my first. 9, 14 Wait, no.  It’s always hard for me to remember the details because it’s amazing the power of minimization. 9, 17, 18 I had gotten drunk at a family Thanksgiving sort of sneaking sips of wine when I was thirteen. 5, 8, 12, 14 I remember dancing on a table.  Then I actually took everyone else’s wine after they left the room. 7, 14 I also blacked out that night.  I always loved to drink. 5, 14, 18 When I would drink I would drink to blackout basically from the beginning. 5, 11, 19 SA: So beginning junior year did it start escalating or were these just a few instances? 11, 14 Just a few, discrete like--because I got in lots trouble after all of those things happened. 15, 16 In fact after the debate team thing happened I got kicked off the National Honor’s Society and had to do Saturday suspensions. 15, 16 I think it was only three or four instances.  I also didn’t have access to it. 9 I wasn’t really hanging out with the cool kids. 17, 18 That experience at MIT by the way I liked so much that I went there for college and drank many times. 5, 7, 16, 18 SA: So you went to MIT knowing you wanted to go to medical school? 7, 12, 14, 18 I didn’t actually. 7 I was interested in being an engineer.  SA: What changed? 13 EB: I hated engineering.  [laughs] 15 I sort of theoretically wanted to do it because not many women go into engineering, but I didn’t like it at all. 12, 18 I switched to environmental engineering as a major, I thought that was neat, a lot of it, but finding out that the practical job applications were sewage treatment plants was interesting to me. 11, 12, 13, 17, 18 I think it was late junior year that I loved science and I loved talking to people and I wish there was something that combined those things and someone was like, “Idiot. 9, 14 That’s what being a doctor is.” 12, 14 So I decided to be pre-med at that point. 10, 14 So it was pretty late, but at MIT you were required to do an amount of sciences that fulfilled a lot of the prerequisites, so I had already done all that. 5, 10 I just added on some biology and then I took the MCAT and took organic chemistry my senior year, and actually I loved that. 7, 14, 15 I drank heavily during college, but when I decided to apply to med school I was able to sort of pull it together and stop for a while in that period. 5, 7, 8, 14, 16, 18 SA: What year was that? 14 EB: Junior year of college. 7, 14 I graduated high school in ‘98. 7 SA: Do you remember every thinking you were drinking too much or wished you drank less in your college years, or was that just kind of normal for you? 5, 7, 11, 14, 16 EB: Yeah I certainly had a lot of negative experiences related to it and I stopped drinking for thirty days once just to prove that I didn’t have a problem. 5, 8, 11, 12, 16, 17, 18 The thing that sort of perpetuated me thinking it was okay was that I continued to be able to pull it out for tests, and so I had a pretty high GPA and it wasn’t interfering with that aspect of things and that made it feel okay. 7, 10 However, I isolated a lot of people who I had been friends with. 9, 16, 20 I definitely gravitated towards people who drank heavily and I blacked out a lot, but I liked it. 5, 9, 16 I really liked it. 18 There was a period of time where [unclear]. 18 It’s amazing how potently biological that part was. 6, 9 So, I eventually sort of got things together. 5, 8 I worked at an environmental engineering mechanical device company that was in the Boston area after graduating while I worked on getting into med school. 7, 8, 12, 14 I had a year between college and med school. 7, 14 During that period I did not drink or use very much. 5, 6, 13, 18 I should mention in college there was an experience I had where I took ecstasy a few times and I really loved that to the point where I remember thinking I’m going to use this until someone stops me. 6, 7, 12, 13, 14, 18 And that scared me so I stopped. 5, 19 I never used it after that again. 6, 13, 16 After all of that stuff it wasn’t actually alcohol that got me into rehab, personally, it was opiates and benzos and those came a lot later. 6, 7 I had a period where I had it fairly together. 8, 9, 18 I would drink every one or two months always to excess. 5, 11, 16, 18 I had met my husband at this company I worked at. 14 We were fairly serious fairly quickly and he would sort of drive me on those times. 5, 9, 11 He drank heavily when we met, but actually just sort of stopped as he grew up in a normal way, but I continued to escalate. 5, 7, 16, 18, 20 During med school it was always in a very, I don’t have class tomorrow so I can get drunk tonight. 5, 7, 8, 14, 18 There was an element of responsibility, but it was always to the point of blacking out. 12, 18 When I went to med school I was most interested in cardiology or something like that, but after rotating-- [pause in conversation] 6, 7, 13, 14 I also like egotistically wanted to be a kind of doctor that was hard, but in rotating around I really, really liked family medicine. 9, 12, 14, 18 I felt it was a field where I could actually do the kind of medicine I pictured doctors doing when I was little and could answer questions for my family members. 5, 7, 11, 12, 14, 20 I really liked the variety of it. 18 I have always really liked people’s interesting stories and family medicine has a lot of that. 9, 12, 14, 17, 18 While I was in med school I got a tumor and my experience of being diagnosed was I was on rotation and I was sleeping in the hospital two or three nights a week. 7, 8, 15, 16, 18 Not really sleeping--not sleeping in the hospital two or three nights a week. 8, 15, 16, 18 [laughs] 15 I found a stomach swelling and went to the doctor who said I needed to get an ultrasound and the ultrasound lady knew I was in med school and tipped it around so I could see and there was clearly a giant abnormality and I asked her what is was and she said, “You know, I don’t know. 6, 7, 12, 14, 16 I need to get the radiologist right away.” 12, 18, 20 And it scared the crap out of me even though it turned out to be--anyway so at that period of time I had to take a medical leave from medical school. 5, 7, 14, 18, 19 I had to get a surgery and when I was getting the surgery I was consented to have all my ovaries and uterus taken out. 5 At that time I had not really thought much about having a family or the future, but I really started to want one. 12, 17, 18 I had also had sort of strong feelings that strong women don’t get married and at that point sort of changed my tune. 7, 12, 13, 15 I had been living with my now husband for a couple years. 11, 12, 14 I don’t know, I hadn’t thought much about making a family. 10, 12, 17, 18 So that was really frightening. 12, 18 Then first doctor I talked to said, “I am going to give you this ativan. 12, 14 Take it as much as you want,” and I took a lot.  I loved it. 14 It was sort of pill alcohol. 6 SA: What year was that? 14 I stayed on the ativan intermittently since that time until I went to rehab in 2009. 17 So after that I got pregnant my first week of intern year at St. Louis. 7, 10, 14, 15 So sort of fastforward: decided to get married and have a family. 7, 12, 14 We started trying--the plan was to have a baby during residency and it would probably take us a while to get pregnant because I only had one ovary and one fallopian tube; the others got taken out. 7, 9, 10 It turned out that the tumor was benign, I forgot to mention that. 12 I got PTSD around that time.  It was frightening. 12 I ended up getting pregnant in 2007--right at the same time as I started residency at the University of Michigan. 7, 9, 10, 12 It was really challenging to be pregnant and an intern. 7, 10, 18 I really tried to not do anything differently than the other residents because they were sort of irritated with me because if I was out they would have to do more work. 9, 18 In fact one of them the first day of our residency tried to have us make a pact that none of us would get pregnant during intern year and I said, “I’m not making that pact.” 7, 8, 9, 10, 14, 16 It was uncomfortable.  I was really sad during that period of time. 18 I had close friends in medical school and then I moved away. 7, 9, 10, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20 At that point I got married. 7 I didn’t really bring up that my husband was Lebanese, but there were all kinds of sort of complications with his family because of that, but really they were wonderful people. 9, 12, 14, 18 But it was like sort of one more thing that was unknowable, and my response to things like that was always to use. 6, 12, 13, 18 I loved family medicine; it’s really hard and it’s hard to juggle everything and the training where I went. 9, 12, 14, 18 It was really physically and mentally challenging at that time to go through residency. 6, 7, 9, 12, 18 I ended up on bedrest because I was trying to work too hard. 5, 9 I went twenty-one days without having a day off when I was about twenty weeks pregnant. 7, 10, 15, 16 I started having contractions. 14, 19 I ended up having a short cervix. 18 I went on bedrest, and during that period of time I wasn’t drinking or using while I was pregnant, but I had this bottle of ativan that I would just count sometimes. 5, 6, 7, 10, 11, 18 That was a little weird. 20 It was awful being on bedrest, and I sort of sunk into isolated depression because it wasn’t like the people at residency had time to visit me or anything, you know, so I was just kind of alone. 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 I was at Michigan at this point and all of my family was in Connecticut. 12 I delivered then. 5 It was a little bit of a scary delivery. 20 That was in October--sorry, that was in March of 2008.  I got a huge supply of oxycodone after delivering, which was kind of my first exposure to opioids, and I absolutely loved it. 6, 13, 14 I was given like one hundred pills with a refill and then I called to get more refills. 5 There was a comfort that the doctors were prescribing to me because I was a resident. 9, 10, 12, 14 At that point I had never heard anyone say addiction was an illness. 9, 12, 14, 16 I thought the way I drank was probably not right, but I really didn’t know what was wrong with me. 5, 11, 12, 16, 17, 18 I was trying all kinds of anti depressants, I had postpartum depression, and it was really just an awful period of time. 9, 10, 11, 18 I loved my daughter so much, I had never experienced anything like that, loving someone so much, and when I had to go back to work it really broke my heart and I didn’t want to, but I felt trapped. 8, 9, 11, 14, 16, 18 I talked to the residency director who was a douchebag and he basically said, “Well either come back or don’t come back, but there’s no way we can work out any kind of schedule,” which actually isn’t true, but they weren’t really willing to work with me. 5, 7, 9, 18, 19 Around that time I started drinking more and more. 5, 11 Well, so I sort of held it together because I ran out of--when I went back to work I didn’t have anymore oxycodone, I wasn’t using it, and I started going to this like secret residency doctor to help with mental health of residents, which is a nice resource to have but she was giving me a lot of ativan as was my primary doctor and they weren’t really cross-checking and I started using a lot of that and combining it with alcohol. 6, 7, 8, 9, 12, 14, 18, 19 I had some back pain which I think was pretty legitimate, and I also remember thinking, I know medicine and no one can tell me I don’t have back pain, and so I was doing physical therapy but also using oxycodone. 6, 8, 10, 12, 14 At first it was prescribed and then I was just picking it up and taking it and just crossing all kinds of--I mean I descended into a person I didn’t recognize quite quickly. 10, 11, 14, 17 Got in trouble in October of 2009 in terms of--that’s when I went to rehab. 17 That was a terrible period of time and I don’t want to go into too many details except that I became a person I didn’t recognize rapidly and ended up going to Talbot in Atlanta. 11, 17, 18 For me I got sober largely through a twelve-step, AA based program in a place--Talbot treats doctors and pilots and is very expensive, so my parents had to get like an RV in order to send me to rehab. 12, 13, 14, 16, 20 I will be forever grateful for them.  So that was seven and a half years ago. 13, 14 I actually have not drank or used an illicit drug since that point. 5, 6, 7, 13, 16 I was put on opiates once when I had a nose surgery, but I was under the care of an addiction medicine doctor who like--I went into a monitoring program, I still go to AA now, my recovery has been a really important part of my life. 9, 10, 12, 14, 18, 19 Actually, I am very grateful for the experience. 18 I will transition into talking more about the addiction medicine because that is how I became interested in it. 12, 14, 17 I was like, What the hell this is a disease?  No one--why didn’t someone tell me? 8 SA: Why didn’t I learn this in medical school? 7, 10, 14 I really had not--I had learned the side effects of liver disease from alcohol, but not that there was any hope for people stopping or that there are medications to treat alcohol. 6, 9, 10, 14, 18 SA: Or about prescription opioids. 6, 10, 13 EB: Right, well we were taught that they were safe.  I went to med school during the period where it was like if you have pain we have to treat it. 6, 7, 18 Pain is a vital sign. 11 You can’t get addicted to opiates if you have real pain, which is wrong. 6, 11, 12, 14 I had always done well on tests and stuff, and had the ambition to be able to make some sort of impact in the field of medicine and became by far most interested in--also, I got really lucky because the doctor who sent me to treatment and evaluated me was probably the best addiction medicine doctor I’ve ever seen practice. 5, 6, 8, 12, 13, 14, 18, 20 His name is Pat Gibbons.  He has passed away since, and I’m pretty sure he’s available regarding historic--he was like an amazing, wonderful mentor and doctor and I hated him at first because he held really high standards for how he would treat you. 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, 18, 20 There were also a number of doctors in my area that were in recovery, had been sober a long time, and took me under their wing. 8, 12, 14, 17 I had an amazing sponsor who was a cardiothoracic surgeon who has been sober for twenty-three years, so she was like invaluable. 9, 14 Early sobriety--I was out of work for eight months, and when I went back it was with restrictions and I was on a monitoring program and had drug testing every one to two weeks and calling every day for three years. 5, 6, 11, 12, 14, 15, 16, 18 That structure--I wouldn’t have stayed sober without that. 15 I wasn’t really interested in [unclear] and I wanted to keep my license. 13, 18 And I loved my daughter. 14 At first I was still mad at my husband for making me go to treatment. 10, 12, 13, 14 I was like obsessed with the idea that we needed to get divorced. 7 He was like the most wonderful, amazing guy and kept our family together. 8, 9, 12, 18 I got to fall in love with him all over again in sobriety, as well as sort of expand the interest in addiction medicine. 12, 14 I did family medicine as a second year resident they made me repeat my second year, which was, you know, they should have, so I got to really thoroughly learn that, and then after that I started working at a clinic in Michigan as well at a place called Pain Recovery Solutions in Ibsoleny with two doctors, three doctors who were really excellent at doing addiction medicine and I was there one day a week. 9, 10, 12, 14, 15, 16, 18 You could do an addiction medicine study specialty without doing a fellowship, and you still can, but that’s going to close now. 9, 10, 12, 14 I decided that that was going to be my goal and started doing that in 2012. 14 I got boarded in 2014.  That was around the time I wanted to have one addiction medicine job and moved to Minnesota to work at Hazelden. 7, 11, 12, 14, 15, 18 Also, I had met Bob Levy at conferences and we were friends and he worked there at that point too. 16, 20 SA: So you got to Hazelden in…  EB: December of 2014.  This whole period of time in 2012 to 2014 there was this escalating opioid use epidemic and a lot of talk about whether suboxone was just another drug replacing a drug and that was very controversial in doctors who were also in recovery. 5, 6, 12, 13, 14, 18 The CMO of Hazelden had decided that they were going to be both abstinence based twelve-step as well as using medication so it was kind of a big deal. 6, 13, 14 I was excited to be able to come be a part of that and I wanted to be able to do studies on it and stuff. 9, 18 I was primarily at Hazelden treating opiate use disorder. 6, 13 Most of my patients were eighteen to twenty-six, and severe opiate use does have a huge amount of comorbidity, mental health issues, profoundly ill. 6, 12, 13, 19 I became struck by how much more effective suboxone was than vivitrol as well as than nothing. 8 Suboxone is so much more effective than nothing.  Than treatment alone. 8, 12, 13 I developed a belief that treatment alone for opiate use addicts who are younger than twenty-six is inadequate. 6, 8, 12, 13, 14, 20 That’s my personal opinion.  But it was hard to watch that happen. 9, 15, 17 It’s hard to watch all the misinformation about suboxone go through the world. 9, 17 It is a medication that reduces the risk of relapse and death by fifty to seventy-five percent and is hugely effective and we do not employ it with the vast majority of patients. 5, 14, 18 They’re dying.  I’m tired of watching; it breaks my heart. 5, 8, 9, 17 SA: What sorts of things struck you about how Dr. Levy and other doctors that talked about addiction when you were learning about them or went and saw them? 10, 12, 14 EB: It just was inspiring to me.  I knew so many people from recovery who had been sort of shamed by their doctor. 9, 12, 14, 16 I think addicts have the world’s most fascinating stories. 9, 14 That was always something I liked about addiction medicine. 12, 14, 18 It was probably Herb Malinoff and Pat Gibbons, these doctors in Michigan, who got me the most interested. 12, 14 I mean if you interviewed Herb Malinoff on the phone and he was okay with it, he’s like an amazing practitioner in Michigan. 8, 9, 16 I just wanted to learn to do what they did. 10, 18 I would see it being handled in my primary care clinic in a horrible way. 6, 10, 18, 19 SA: Do you have any examples that come to mind?  EB: I just remember in residency my last year spending an hour and a half with a patient who wanted oxycodone for back pain and ativan for anxiety, which weirdly were my two drugs of choice, and just recognizing that they were having a problem with it and trying to give them these tools of other ways to help with back pain like acupuncture and they were just so angry and like immediately went from complaining to about what a bad doctor I was. 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 14, 15, 18 Luckily at that clinic they were like, “That’s exactly what you should do.”  Around that time there was a doctor from Chelsea who had really high doctor Yelp scores who was selling--was cracked down on by the federal government for selling oxycodone. 7, 8, 12, 14, 16, 18 Anyway, it really struck me that the doctors I looked up who were getting one to two star reviews because they pissed people off because you really shouldn’t be doing what your patients want you to do, you should be doing what is in their best interest. 9, 12, 14, 18 Even though you should do it in a kind, loving way. 18 That was what I really admired about those doctors was they were not mean or shaming or unkind or judgemental, just like, “Here’s what I can safely offer you,” and that’s what I wanted to learn how to do. 5, 10, 12, 14, 18 Because you don’t really learn those skills about how to have difficult conversations with patients. 10, 18 But in a deliberate way you sort of end up learning as you go. 10, 18 SA: When did you leave Hazelden? 18 EB: I left in 2016. 14 It was not out of any kind of bad feelings in anyway. 15, 18 It was a wonderful place, but I missed the medical system and being able to get labs rapidly, see patients efficiently, see patients on Medicaid because they didn’t take Medicare or Medicaid, so it was a really different patient population. 6, 7, 14, 18, 19 So I had met this doctor from Health East at the Minnesota Society of Addiction Medicine conference who said they needed new doctors and like a year later I contacted her and said, “Do you still need new doctors?” 12, 14, 16 [laughter]  “I kind of miss medicine.” 12, 14 Not that it wasn’t medical there, but it was like [unclear] a new clinic and it was primarily for seeing counselors. 6, 7, 14, 16 And I had three kids.  I really love what I do. 14, 18 I feel really blessed and proud and happy and it’s kind of not where I ever thought I would be. 17, 18 I had no plans to move to Minnesota, be an addiction medicine doctor, and have a lovely family, like objectively that was not the plan. 12, 14, 15 It’s so much better than I would have guessed.  That’s amazing. 9 Do you still do family medicine with addiction medicine? 12, 14 EB: I mostly do addiction medicine. 12, 14 I would like to do some family medicine again someday, but right now there’s such a vast, gaping need for addiction medicine doctors. 12, 14, 16 SA: Have you seen the field growing? 6, 10 EB: I think more people have talked about it in a way that has minimized stigma, and it is certainly a great thing that there’s a formal, medical subspecialty board, but I think it’s a field that if the Medicaid expansion is taken away it will be decimated. 7, 8, 9, 14, 17, 18, 20 So, I’m very worried about the safety of my patients. 19 SA: Do you want to talk a little bit more about what has been going on or what you see for the future or what your worries are? 6, 20 EB: Sure.  I think that it’s pretty scientifically established how you treat opiate use disorder. 6, 10, 13 I don’t see that being implemented the way that it needs to be. 6, 12, 18 I’ll just say I think making an opiate commission headed by Chris Christie is asinine. 10, 14 I think that we should just be expanding funding for treatment right now and finding in-house places for people to recover. 6, 9, 12, 13 One population that is very dear to my heart is mothers with addiction issues, and there’s no social supports for them, we’re not well networked between medical field, the healthcare field, even the research field, and the CD world, and the legal world. 7, 9, 12, 13, 14, 19 It’s all split up, and that kills people, and I hate that because it’s actually not that complicated to treat. 7, 9 We just have not had the resources to do it.  SA: You mentioned more focus on treatment. 8, 12, 13 In your day to day is that what you wish there were more avenues to? 16 EB: Yeah, and to find an addiction medicine doctor in the Twin Cities is tough. 12, 14 We don’t take new ones at the clinic 8, 16 I’m at unless they go through the residential, so there’s really limited options to step in with an allocation [unclear]. 9, 13, 18 A lot of them are cash only.  There are some great doctors that are cash only because it is really hard to deal with the insurance companies. 9, 10, 12, 14, 18, 20 But it sucks.  It puts up a huge barrier.  Often the mental health comorbidities aren’t well managed. 12, 19 There’s still certainly a lot of pejorative stigma surrounding suboxone, language around not being clean if you’re on it, which I think kills people. 8, 9, 14, 17 If I’m prescribing someone a medication they are taking as prescribed then they are abstinent. 10, 11, 14 I hate when people tell them that they’re not. 9 SA: That goes along with AA’s-- EB: Well, AA has a pretty clear--it’s really different now how they implement it. 10, 12, 17, 18 It’s pretty clearly delineated in there that, “We’re not doctors, we do not mean to interfere with physician treatment,” but there is sort of a historical stigma that has preceded--and actually when I was in residency I had to do a research project and I did mine on stigma across different levels of the healthcare field, and the trend was that you got more of it in med school and residency and people had less preconceived notions about addicts and we intensified those with exposure to people. 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 19 You don’t really see--when I go to the doctor sometimes I say, “I’ve been sober for seven and a half years,” I tell it to them the first time I go, but there are a lot of people in sobriety who don’t. 6, 9, 12, 14, 18 Doctors can be real idiots about treating it. 13 I went to the ER six months ago for an ear infection and they offered me morphine. 5, 11, 13, 16, 20 They didn’t ask me.  SA: And then it’s up to you to say no.  And I was able to but, you know, there are probably days where that could have ruined my life. 10, 12, 16 SA: Or killed you. 14 EB: I think just because I got sober without suboxone doesn’t mean that’s the right thing for everybody. 12 That was--first of all there was a period of time where lots of other people I went to treatment with are no longer sober or alive. 9, 12, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18 SA: We can go through a typical day you have in the clinic. 16 EB: I primarily now see outpatients with opioid use disorder. 6, 11, 12, 13 I would say one to two of them are in active relapse everyday, and so a lot of what I do is try to check for mental health, talk to them in a way that’s non judgemental and exhibits caring and--you know I get urine drug screens from everyone I see regardless of how long they’ve been sober because you just never know. 5, 6, 12, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20 I try to be a sort of safe point that they can access, but you know, one or two no shows, one or two people that are high on a day to day basis, and some of them are doing really well. 7, 9, 12, 16, 17, 18 It’s really rewarding. 18 Again, I just really love what I do. 14, 18 It’s pretty cool. 10, 17 I use suboxone a fair amount. 6, 9, 13 The majority of my patients are on it. 18 SA: Do you prescribe methadone at all? 10 EB: That’s only in specific clinics.  SA: Are you limited in prescribing suboxone? 8, 10 EB: I have a limit of 275 patients and I don’t really see myself ever hitting 275 because it’s pretty unusual to see them any less than monthly. 6, 10, 16, 18 I think it is really stupid that there is a limit because fentanyl is so much more dangerous and has no limit and any doctor can prescribe it. 10, 11, 12, 14, 18 If there’s one thing I could change and promote about addiction medicine changing it is getting more doctors to get a suboxone waiver and treat with it in primary care. 8, 12, 14, 17, 19 I think if you’re going to limit something it should be [unclear] not suboxone because it is very safe if you use it as prescribed. 6, 8, 10, 13 I think there is going to be a trend of a benzo epidemic and I see more and more people using meth and benzos. 6, 9, 13 Meth is pretty frustrating to treat because there’s not a lot we can offer to help. 10 SA: Why do you say that?  EB: I have been seeing more and more patients using those things. 6 For benzodiazepines there are pretty good New York Times articles showing that fourteen percent of people over the age of sixty-five use them on a daily basis. 6, 9, 10, 13 That’s not good. 10 They aren’t really recommended for any long-term purpose, but they are used that way often by people who don’t understand the risks of doing that. 6, 9, 12, 13, 16, 17, 18 It’s basically pill alcohol. 6, 19 SA: Do you think a change in educating young doctors is what it is going to take to-- EB: I think that would be helpful. 9, 12, 14 I don’t think that that’s going to happen. 15 I think Bob Levy may be the sole zion of that.  That was part of why I came to St. Joe’s to be able to-- and I still am connected to Hazelden in the sense that I work with them doing consulting to go do training to other health systems for how to treat opioid use disorder and implement the COR-12 program [Comprehensive Opioid Response with the Twelve Steps]. 6, 9, 10, 12, 13, 19 I am able to do some slight advocacy stuff.  SA: One last question and we can wrap up.  Can you talk a little bit about being a woman in your field, and anything that goes along with that? 17, 20 EB: Yeah, so addiction medicine has this definite old boy club with like long term AA men flavor. 7, 12, 14, 17 I started going in my first year of sobriety to this international doctors in AA conference that has addiction medicine as part of it. 9, 12, 14 I go every year and actually bring my family. 7, 12, 14 Whenever I go, even now, when I have been going for six years, everyone thinks my husband is the addict and approaches him. 12, 14, 16, 17 It’s just really--in all of medicine there is that feel of there is still a difference of a gender bias that occurs, but I think there have always been pretty amazing and now like Nora Volkow, who’s the coolest. 9, 10, 12, 14, 17, 18 She’s awesome.  So, I think there is a different experience of interacting with patients that can feel more physically frightening I think because a lot of them have also had violence towards women in the past and stuff. 6, 12, 18 It’s certainly very possible to sort of move through that stuff. 8, 15, 17 I had a lot of advice on that from my sponsor, so I saw it role modeled really well just sort of how to integrate. 10, 18 She was awesome.  Now I’m part of the executive council for the Minnesota Society of Addiction Medicine; Bob Levy does that, too. 9, 14 We’re trying to build more of a place for that to be a kernel of learning, but there’s not a lot of funding unfortunately. 10 SA: Thank you so much.  EB: Sure.  It’s great you guys are focusing on this topic. 6, 20

Jamison Danielson Narrator Samantha Aamot Interviewer May 18, 2017 Duluth, Minnesota Jamison Danielson-JD Samantha Aamot-SA SA:  Okay, I'll have you state your name and tell me you give me permission to record you.  JD: Jamison Danielson, I give permission to be recorded.  SA: Do you want to start with talking about your childhood? 14, 20 Or we could start with the work you do here.  Really wherever.  There's a lot of space between that, holy shit. 18 So, I have a very interesting past. 17 I am one of five children and four of us are living. 5, 14, 20 My life changed drastically the day that my sister died. 5, 10, 13, 16, 20 She died when she was nineteen days old of SIDS and it was extremely rough on my parents. 16, 20 They couldn't bring themselves to stay in the house that she died in, and they couldn't bring themselves to not stay in the house that she died in. 6, 13 So, their grief stricken course of action was to stop paying the mortgage and pretty much stay there as long as they could, but also being forced to leave, which was, I don't know, I was in second grade, so it was complicated in my mind. 5, 8, 10, 12, 14, 17, 18 Eventually, we got our twenty-four hour notice. 15 From there we stayed with my mom's friend, who was pretty toxic. 10, 14, 20 Her husband was an alcoholic. 6, 14 SA: You and your four siblings?  JD: Yeah, me and my four brothers. 20 I am the oldest--now I'm twenty-eight. 12, 20 My other brother is twenty-five, my next brother is seventeen, the next one is eighteen, so there's a bit of a gap in between us. 8, 20 SA: This is in Duluth?  JD: Yeah, here in Duluth.  From then we stayed in campgrounds and hotels and it was just kind of a rough go of things. 14 Then we were able to access transitional housing through Salvation Army, and we were like on an on-sight managed program for some time just to see like, "Are these people respectful? 6, 9, 17 Do they behave?  Are they worthy of our resources and time?"  So after, I don't know, six months or a year there we were given an opportunity to live in a house instead of a managed house, which is really rad because the Salvation Army has three of those on Park Point. 6, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16, 18, 19 So, to be a poor kid and get to live out on Park Point coming from nothing was really fucking rad. 18 Yeah, it was really cool. 17, 18 Like I said my sister passing really damaged my family, and so I grew up in a pretty toxic household. 6, 10, 12, 13, 18, 20 There was a lot of emotional abuse and physical abuse, and me and my mom just didn't get along. 6, 13, 14, 17 I acted out quite a bit as a teenager due to that. 20 I ended up on probation as a teenager. SA: Do you remember if this is middle school or high school? 7 JD: This is, I don't know, however old you are in ninth grade. 5, 12 I don't know, high school was really abnormal in comparison to most people's experience. 7, 9, 12, 16, 18 So, yeah, however old you are then. So, yeah, I was just kind of locked up a lot. So, I lived there for a while. 7 I just kind of went through a lot. So, yeah, I came to a point where I was going to take steps I needed to take to transition or I couldn't see myself being on earth. 6, 17, 19 I don't know if you know much about trans stats or anything, but forty-one percent of trans people attempt or complete suicide. 9, 12, 17 That was a very real thing for me and the way I felt was very scary. 11, 18 Living in Duluth there is a population of eighty-six thousand people. 9 For many years I didn't know or hadn't met anyone like me. 12, 14 Yeah, I felt really, really, really alone. 8, 11, 18 I educated myself on the path I needed to take to start T, and so I was like okay I need to talk to a therapist, they write some kind of letter, then I see a doctor who looks at the therapists' letter that says I'm good enough for hormones. 6, 8, 10, 12, 14 It didn't go well at first. 14 I found a therapist and I remember walking into his office and he had his degree's on the wall and his name was very religious. 16 I was like, "Okay, that doesn't necessarily mean anything." I didn't really like her, but I was like, "Alright, I have to jump through your hoops to get what I want." 12, 18 I remember one day when I was seeing her--she had couches in her office--and I was sitting in the recliner with my feet up, but she was talking about my ex that I was with for five years, and she had asked if I would attempt to get her to come to a session because she thought that would be helpful for us to maybe have some peace or whatever. 5, 6, 9, 14, 16, 17, 18 That made me really angry. 11, 18 So I was sitting up there with my feet and stuff, but I did get like loud, but I didn't move or anything, and she was like, "You're acting aggressive," and I was like, "Or I have feelings and you brought up a touchy subject and I'm going to get loud about it." 15 She asked.  JD: Right, like don't fucking ask me things if you don't want--I'm not a robot.  I'm going to react to stuff. So right after that jail experience I found this local trans group that was meeting, so I sat in a room of five trans women I had never met and just started crying about my jail experience or whatever, and then kind of connected with them, took the journey that I explained to you about T. And then that group kind of died off. 12, 14, 16, 17, 18 There was one person running it, and it's fucking exhausting to be a community organizer and have so many people heavily relying on you and looking to you for everything, so I understand why she did that. 8, 9, 16, 17, 18, 19 So, me and a friend and a couple of other people--I guess he wasn't really a friend at that point. 9, 11, 14, 18, 20 There were a couple of trans people in town that decided like, "Hey, let's sit down and see what we can do." 6, 9, 11, 14, 17 And so that's when I met who is now one of my best friends, and we decided to revamp the group. 12, 14, 16, 20 It's now called Trans Plus. 12 We have support group and work group.  Work group is kind of like what can we do to change things on a local level, and, you know, advance our place in the world because not a whole lot of people care about our community. 9, 12, 14, 19 So we kind of revamped that and that's been going on for a couple of years now. 11, 12, 14 We have, I don't know, anywhere from ten to thirty people attend group, which I never thought in my life I would ever know thirty trans people from Duluth. 8, 9, 10, 12, 16, 17, 18 And now I, I don't know, I see a trans person just living their life every day and say, "Hi," to them on the street. 6, 10, 12, 16, 17 Some of my best friends are trans. 16, 17, 20 My partner is trans. 9, 17 And so it's really a night and day difference to my world. 16, 18 I'll talk a little bit about my work stuff. 20 So I initially started doing harm reduction work for Center City housing, and I worked at their San Marco location. 5, 6, 14 So, it's a harm reduction facility for alcoholics who are actively using. 5, 6, 14 Before San Marco existed in Duluth many of them were making frequent visits to hospital, jail, detox; it was costing a lot of money, and these people had no where to live. 8, 9, 10, 19 They were just going through this revolving door, which just wasn't helpful to our community, and to those people, you know, more importantly. 9, 12, 19 So they opened San Marco and there are two sides: one is low-income housing side. 6, 9, 10 Some of them drink, some of them don't. 5 They don't require much care from the staff. 19 They just kind of exist.  And then the other side--I can't remember the exact number, I'd say somewhere around thirty. 9 It's for people who are chronic alcoholics, so they are often drinking to the point of black out daily. 5, 6, 9, 11 There are just different ways we treat, you know--some people had to have alcohol plans, so maybe instead of a liter of vodka they got a pint of vodka daily and a six pack of beer, or something. 5, 6, 9, 12, 18 But I felt really good about doing that kind of stuff because of their addiction they have nothing and no one. 8, 10, 11, 12, 14, 18 A lot of their families won't speak to them. 17 While that's sad, you know, sometimes we have to suffer the consequences of our choices while we're using. 6, 12 So, they hadn't personally impacted me so I was able to be friendly and talk to them and be open to them. 20 SA: What do you think got you started with harm reduction? 5, 14 Like walking in the door and knowing you wanted to work there? 12, 16, 18 JD: I guess because I like to live really authentically. 18 I'm a trans guy who works at a needle exchange and lives in an artist coop. 9, 10, 17 [laughs] 15 And so I never like did the college thing because, yeah, money is cool and you need it to live, and whatever, but I'd much rather be rich in happiness than be rich in green pieces of paper. 7, 8, 10, 16, 17 So I had worked at a group home with individuals who were mentally ill, chemically dependent, or both sometimes. 12, 13 I was onsite staff there, and I was just kind of sick of living where my, you know I had my own apartment, but I was kind of sick of living on sight. 5, 9, 11, 12, 15 So I looked around and found out about San Marco, and then a friend of mine is the sight director there, and she has known me since I was eleven years old. 11, 12, 14, 18, 19, 20 She was actually my parent's case manager at some point. 7, 17, 20 So she knew everything. 16 She knew that I really got it. 16, 18 I really--having been in dark places, dark times in my life, I really want to do that kind of work because I know that those kind of people--nobody wakes up and decides, "I'm going to be an alcoholic" or "I'm going to be a drug addict." 5, 6, 9, 10, 12, 14, 17, 18 Those things are because of trauma and disconnection, and I really understand those things. 17, 18 So I wanted to not wear a suit and tie and be able to say, "Fuck," at work if I wanted to say fuck. 18 [laughs] 15 And I wanted to be able to be useful to people, and really let them know that somebody was there that really understands it and doesn't judge them. 6, 9, 12, 13, 17, 18 I think I'm really good at making clients feel that. 10, 18 I'm often told, you know, "You're easy to talk to. 12, 16 I feel comfortable talking to you.  It feels like you get it."  Clients are going through things and they bring stuff up, you know, not to take away from their experience, but I'll minimally insert something about my life so they know, you know--in the winter we have clients who come in here and they are cold and they are like, "My feet are wet." 10, 12, 18, 20 We get sock donations from a thrift store down the block.  And so I'm like, "Hey, man.  I've fucking slept outside. 9 I fucking understand." 17, 18 And we look through the socks and wet socks are the worst.  Exactly.  So, yeah I just wanted to live authentically and actually make a difference with people. 7, 9, 18 And then I really liked my job there, but that's kind of where I went through my name transition. 11, 17, 18 A lot of them were older, white, cis men, veterans, and those are not very open minded people. 9, 12, 19, 20 So I had a guy, he came up and whipped a Bible at my head and told me that's what I needed. 14, 16 Some of them threw all kinds of, you know, their booze bottles at me, or an open beer can so I'm covered in beer and trying to work. 5, 12 Some of them would come up to the desk and be like, well, you have these parts so that's what you are. 9 Or Kyra, who was the site director there, 18, 19 "Kyra says we are supposed to call you this now, but this is your ﻿real﻿ name." 12, 14 SA: Not a safe working environment. 12 JD: Right. JD: I think one of the main things is that people are becoming more aware of it. 9 People are a lot more accepting of it, which I think is really necessary. 12, 18 One of the comparisons that Maggie likes to make that I really appreciate is sometimes when we do presentations we bring out a shot glass. 5, 10, 11, 18 We go, "How many of you have used this in the mast month or the past six months?" 6, 11, 13, 16 Most people raise their hands. 9, 17 Well, alcohol is a drug, and a shot glass is a way you administer the drug. 5, 6, 11, 18 It is a drug utensil. 5, 6 So why should we look at people who are using a different drug and they need a different utensil? 5, 6, 9 We are all altering our state of mind just in a different way. 18 So I think I'm seeing a lot of people coming around to that. 6, 9 Or people who have never heard of it and I explain it and they are cool with it. 9, 16, 17 Just,  "Wow, I've never heard of that, but that's cool." 9, 14, 16, 17 I guess when I first started doing this job I was talking to my grandparents about it and they were like, "Wait, wait. 11, 14, 20 So you're giving syringes full of heroin to people?" 9, 14, 16 And I was like, "We do not have a budget like that!"
