12, 14 Go to your doctor. 12, 14 People coming into treatment based on the DAANES data, only six percent of people coming into treatment are referred by doctors. 5, 9, 12, 13, 14, 17 Nobody really wakes up and says, “Oh gee. 18 I’m sick of my life. 10, 15 I think I’ll go to treatment today.” 12, 13, 16 That just doesn’t happen. 15 It’s either family, the criminal justice system, or your employer that says, “You’ve got to do this or else.” 8, 12 AS: If our health care system was functional we would have more access and more time with doctors. 9, 12, 14, 19 If they had more training they would look for signs. 11 The fifteen-year-old that’s wanting birth control to the family nurse practitioner could be screened for other things as well. 8, 12, 14, 18 They could talk about all kinds of things with them.  Do you think that opioids have changed anything in the way that we look at addiction or do you think it’s just another drug in the grand march of drugs of the day? 5, 6, 12, 13, 14, 16, 18 CF: I think they’ve put a spotlight on how we deliver treatment and what treatment is delivered. 5, 6, 12, 13 The science is overwhelming that the use of medication in the treatment of opioid addiction is very effective. 6, 12, 13, 14 Yet, treatment providers in Minnesota as well as over the rest of the country have been very reluctant to embrace that as part of their practice. 9, 12, 13, 19 People aren’t getting the kind of help they need.  Hazelden was one of the first treatment programs in the state of Minnesota if not the first to use Suboxone in the treatment of their opiate addicted patients. 6, 8, 12, 13, 14 They had a huge influx in the number of opioid patients and they were noticing that they were leaving without staff approval. 13 Once they left a number of them were overdosing and dying. 14 They wanted to do something and introduced state of the art medication assisted treatment. 12, 13, 14, 18 Now people go through a program they have at Hazelden that includes that. 9 Trying to get other treatment providers to incorporate the use of medications in the treatment of opiate addiction in the state of Minnesota was one of my primary goals as a director of the State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Agency. 6, 12, 13, 14, 18, 19 I liken it to pushing a piece of string.  It just collapses on itself.  I had trainings through the professional association of treatment providers. 12, 13 I had trainings through DHS that we would put on and have different panels of parents and law enforcement and doctors. 8, 12, 13, 14, 20 I did a number of those.  AS: Talking about the benefits of medications? 14, 15 CF: Yes, here we are.  This is the only drug category, well alcohol there’s some medication too, for which there are effective medications. 5, 6, 14 We want to be science based in Minnesota not based on ideology. 13 Let’s use the science to deliver treatment. 6, 12, 13 There is a lot of barriers to it here.  I wasn’t able to do that.  AS: When did you start that?  Do I think it’s made progress?  What’s that it’s almost ten years. 14 AS: Hazelden won’t touch methadone either.  CF: Really?  They won’t touch it.  CF: Still?  AS: Suboxone is not really their thing anymore. 8, 18 Vivitrol is their…  CF: That’s the same as Suboxone. 8 AS: They won’t touch methadone because they said that’s not their client base. 10, 14 CF: And how many people who are on methadone go to AA meetings or Narcan meetings and are told, “You aren’t really sober.”? 9, 16, 18 It’s very frustrating.  The analogy I use is that someone has high blood pressure. 6, 7, 10, 13 They go to their doctor. 12, 14 The doctor says, “Lose weight, exercise, and watch your diet.” 12, 14, 17 Then they go back in a year because nobody really exercises or loses weight. 9, 14, 18 Here it is a year later they still have high blood pressure. 7, 10, 14 Then the doctor says the same thing, “Diet and exercise.” 12, 14 Then the person has a stroke and dies.  If you were the family of that person and you knew those prior conversations wouldn’t you say that doctor is guilty of malpractice? 12, 14, 16 He didn’t even mention that there’s a medication for high blood pressure. 7, 10, 12, 14 What kind of doctor are you going to? 12, 14 He doesn’t even mention that. 12 In treatment you have people who go into treatment programs and they say, “This is what we do for treatment programs.” 9, 12, 13 It’s all cognitive behavioral therapy. 12, 15 They don’t even mention there are medications that can really help with the craving. 12, 14, 18 There are medications that you can be on long term that really help manage this disease with behavioral components. 8, 14, 15, 17, 18 They don’t even say that.  One of the changes that’s happened is there’s now language in a law that says treatment providers have to inform their patients that there are medications. 6, 12, 13, 14, 15 CF: A couple years ago. 11, 13, 14 I’m not sure how that’s going.  I’ve been at a distance and just reading these list serve emails about the language.  Big fights about the language in it from people who do not believe. 9 If this is really a disease you should use what the science says is available to treat the disease, not your personal beliefs about it. 6, 13, 18 “I just don’t believe in that.”  AS: Do you think that’s an impact of the Alcoholics Anonymous model or do you think it’s the moral model of addiction? 12, 14 CF: I think it’s both of them.  It’s news to me that Hazelden still does not accept patients with methadone. 6, 8, 12, 15, 16 However, I’ve taught at their graduate school and everything. 7 There’s this belief that some of the people who are treatment providers now, back in the day were trained in the belief that a drug is a drug is a drug and methadone is just a drug. 5, 6, 8, 9, 12, 13, 16 Whenever I talk about this publicly it tends to be students who are in the counseling in training programs at different places who say, “I was taught that a drug is a drug is a drug.” 5, 6, 16, 19 I don’t know if there are any programs that have counselor training programs in the state and I don’t know where they’re still hearing that. 9, 12 What also floors me is that just two weeks ago I got a call from a woman about a speaking event that I’m doing. 13, 14, 15 In the course of talking about what I would be covering I talked about this issue. 13 The use of medications and how much resistance there is to integrating them into effective treatment models in the state. 6, 12, 13, 14 She goes, “Oh boy that’s my son. 7 He’s been to treatment twelve times and he’s nineteen.” 12, 13 I thought, “It’s still going on.” 17, 18 I was stunned.  That just tells me. 15 This was unsolicited from this woman.  He had been to twelve different treatment programs. 12, 13 I said, “Well did anybody ever mention Suboxone to you or Vivitrol?” 12 I gave her the name of a doctor to talk with. 12, 14 I gave her the websites of how to read about these medications. 14 AS: This is someone who’s planning to bring you to speak?  CF: Yes.  CF: She’s a nurse.  She’s taken her kid.  He’s had twelve formal treatment episodes. 12, 13 It’s never been mentioned. 8, 12, 16 AS: It’s never worked because he’s addicted to opiates. 12, 14, 16 CF: She didn’t know what medications. 12, 14 She said, “He also has mental health problems.” 12, 19 I said, “That’s really common too.” 18 AS: You can stabilize him on methadone or Suboxone. 6, 8 Those drugs have such stigma. 5, 6, 9 CF: That blew my mind.  I could not believe my ears.  That was two weeks ago that that came up. 13, 15 Totally unsolicited.  We were talking about something else.  Then she said, “That’s my son.”  We talked for twenty minutes about her son. 15 He never had any treatment programs that brought up medications. 12, 13, 14, 16 AS: It’s criminal. 8 CF: It’s horrible. 10 It’s not limited to Minnesota.  Yes, people who are addicted are very challenging patients. 9, 12, 14 People are long term chronic pain patients are very challenging patients. 6, 17 But we have to give our medical system and our treatment provider system the tools they need to help these people get better. 7, 9, 12, 13, 14 That’s one thing I realized going to all these events that it’s so polarized.  AS: Then you also have the DEA who are involved in the monitoring of methadone and how difficult it is to even prescribe that or have a clinic or the doctors. 10, 12, 14, 18 They’ve changed the law. 13 If doctors aren’t trained how to understand how to prescribe it and monitor it, they won’t agree to have a hundred patients. 5, 10, 12, 14, 17, 18 Didn’t they even up the limit to three hundred?  AS: Yes, but who’s going to do it unless they understand it. 17, 18 CF: Doctors, why would they volunteer to treat the most difficult patients. 10 AS: The people who got worse. 9 CF: “I think I’ll get my Suboxone training so I can start treating addicts.” 8, 13, 14 That doesn’t happen either. 15 AS: Even though one doctor I interviewed said he has a great practice. 12, 14, 20 He has very few problems. 12 He is a primary practice physician who has a specialty in addiction medicine. 12, 14, 19 “These aren’t the people coming in the ER who see me. 6, 9 This is after we’ve gotten their lives stabilized.  They’re much better.”  It’s when are we going to quit the ER scenarios, the overdoses.  That’s the mythology around addicts is that they’re just these horrible people. 9, 10, 14 CF: Which reminds me.  The things that are different about the opiate crisis are not only that we have to look at the usual prevention, treatment, law enforcement, and the practice of medicine. 8, 10, 12, 13, 14, 19 Also what distinguishes it from other drugs of abuse is that it’s got high abuse potential, high addictive potential, and high overdose potential. 5, 6, 7, 13, 14 Unlike methamphetamine, unlike cocaine, unlike the hallucinogens, just a little bit too much can kill you. 6, 8, 16, 20 That’s what makes it different as well.  The final thing that makes it different is this onslaught of China produced fentanyl that is appearing not only in the supply of sniffable drugs whether powder fentanyl has been mixed with heroin as well as cocaine. 5, 6, 13, 14, 16 It’s getting mixed with the supply of powdered illegal drugs. 5, 6, 13 Also it’s being put in counterfeit prescription pills. 10 That is really only in the last year or so. 14, 18 That is implicated in the death of Prince and everyone who becomes addicted to prescription pain medications at some point runs out of the supply that they legitimately get. 6, 8, 10, 12, 13, 14, 18 They seek them out on the black market. 5, 6 They find a guy who knows a guy who knows a guy. 12 People who may be selling these counterfeit pills probably have no idea there’s fentanyl in them.  A little too much can kill you. 20 That’s the other thing.  AS: That’s the case with the woman who sold to the five. 17 CF: She was selling heroin that had fentanyl in it? 16 AS: Yes.  CF: I’ve looked at this death data for thirty years. 13, 14, 18 Historically fentanyl deaths were either like an anesthesiologist diverting it or someone not taking it as medically prescribed. 7, 10, 11, 14, 18 The classic case of that was a death of a guy who had knee pain and then was treating his knee pain with a heating pad. 6, 7, 13, 17, 18 Then he had the surgery and went home and still put on the fentanyl patch and put the heating pad on it.  Of course because it’s transdermal it opened it up and his wife found him when she came home from work on the couch with the fentanyl patch with the heating pad over it deader than a doornail. 14, 16, 17, 20 That was just not taking it as prescribed. 10, 11 Those were the kind of fentanyl deaths. 18 Then one case, this was a law enforcement report where kids were trying to roll up and smoke fentanyl patches with a joint on the inside. 8, 9, 12, 13, 17 AS: You’ve heard some stories I bet. 9 CF: I’ve got a ton of them.  That makes it new to this wild part of the counterfeit drugs. 5, 6, 9, 16 AS: So now you’re doing the drug abuse dialogs. 5, 6, 12, 13 How busy is that keeping you? 15 Do you want to stay busy? 15 Do you want to keep working in this?  How do you feel about it?  CF: That’s personal.  AS: Sorry.  CF: We have a lot more drug education going on because law enforcement drug task forces in order to get their federal funding have to deliver training. 5, 6, 8, 12, 13, 14, 15 We have a lot of non-profits who are delivering training. 15 There’s more training available to people. 9 AS: Then what you experienced in the beginning when you were asked to be in communications? 11, 14, 18 CF: Right.  There’s a lot more free training.  It’s a challenge doing it as a business.  AS: I didn’t mean that as a personal question.  There is more education. 14, 15 CF: That’s primarily what I want to do.  It’s hard to find a niche in there when people provide it at no cost. 9 I’m still sought out by the media quite a bit and I’m on TV three or four times a month. 16, 20 People come into my house. 6, 13 AS: Well you’re a good sport. 10 Thanks for taking the time with me for this project. 5, 11 Is there anything else you wanted to share? 18 CF: Looking over the course of my career 15, 19 I think it’s very disheartening because the drug abuse situation in my estimation as the trained observer of it is as dire and tragic as it has ever been. 5, 6, 9, 13 Compared to when I got into this thirty-five years ago drugs are more accessible, they’re more dangerous, they’re more unknown. 5, 6, 9, 11, 12, 13, 14 Our public policy response over the past thirty years to me is not as swift as it needs to be or as broad to adequately address it. 5, 13, 14, 19 AS: That ends on a sad note.  Your perspective is important. 9 Thank you.  [End of Recording]

CG: So, and it was on display in Bemidji for many years—lent by my uncle. 14 He died, and my oldest cousin, Nule Carson [confirm name], decided he wanted it back. 14, 18, 20 So, my cousin has it now. 12 But, I am connected to Leech Lake, and really to White Earth by that story. 15, 18 And so, you wanted me to tell you about my past and so I'm telling you about my past. 15, 18 That story is known to a few people in the Beltrami County Historical Society and to my own family. 9, 11, 12, 15 And a couple, two and a half months ago, my wife Gale and I, and my cousin Nule and his wife Barb—who drove on short notice all the way from Kalispell, Montana— got to meet Donny Hedbird [confirm name], the great great grandson of Shaynowishkung. 5, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16, 18, 20 And, got to meet a couple from Texas who are from Mary and Elle Carson [confirm name], heritage—descendents of Shaynowishkung. 11, 12, 18 So, we all got together and had supper in Bemidji. 8 Met them for the first time. 14 That's history and that's oral stories. 9, 15 So, it isn't directly related to your book but now you know more about who I am. 12, 18 AS: Exactly, thank you. 11 So, what was your path to becoming a medical doctor then? 7, 12, 14 CG: I don't ever remember a time when I didn't talk about wanting to be a doctor and a minister. 12, 14 That's what I said as a little kid, and it used to amuse my mother. 6, 13, 16, 20 My grandmother took it seriously. 5, 11 And, that's just how it was.  But, I'm quite sure that it had to do with my parents and their health problems. 11, 12, 19, 20 I don't remember my father. 16 The only thing that I remember about my father is the smell of his pipe tobacco, he was a pipe smoker. 16 Not, a traditional Anishinaabe pipe smoker, a Western pipe smoker.  So, I remember only the smell of his pipe tobacco and I don't remember anything about his health problems. 12, 19 But, my aunt Grace was a legal secretary in Saint Paul, and she got pro bono help from her employer to try to get us some benefits since my father was millwright. 12, 15, 16 Fell off the ladder at work when he was working, in a situation that called into question responsibility of his employer.  Anyway, it didn't work out. 18 But when I got older I got to read that. 20 My family got no benefits. 12, 15 And I'm sure, I probably as a kid heard my mother and grandmother talk in distress about how they were gonna survive. 5, 7, 9 And, my mother's breast cancer metastasis was a horrible thing. 10 I do remember as an eight and a half year old kid, standing by my mother's wheelchair in our little rented home in Eden Valley, Minnesota and watching her have a seizure. 8, 14, 17, 20 And, she would come out of the seizure, look at me, and cry.  She couldn't talk, but she would just cry.  And I remember being very angry at her doctor. 11, 12, 14 Not specifically, not knowing him, not anything. 12 But, just angry at the doctor for letting my mother die, and I'm sure that there was some anger in me. 11, 12, 14 And, I'm sure I decided that I was gonna grow up and become a doctor and fix everything and cure cancer and make the world better. 10, 12, 14 I grew up and became a doctor and spent, I've spent over forty years now, and I realize that you can't fix everything and that bad stuff does happen. 12, 14, 15, 20 And that, that doctor probably did everything he could to help my mother at a time when there was no Affordable Care Act and there was very little support system. 12, 14, 20 And that, my mother was lucky to have anywhere to go like the Anoka State Hospital. 8 No one ignored her and no one did anything wrong. 5, 8, 11 But, I'm sure that my experience as a child, and knowing about my parents' fates, probably gave me an exceptionally strong motivation to not give up and to succeed. 12, 14, 18, 20 I went through a church school system, the seventh adventist system. 5, 7 My grandmother became an adventist when I was eleven, and I joined the adventist church along with her. 5, 17 I am no longer a seventh adventist because of my own personal experience of noting administrators in that church, promulgate subtly the idea that if people didn't believe like adventists they would not go to heaven. 5, 9, 17, 18 And, you know, there are a lot of wonderful adventist people, I'm not telling you the story to condemn that, but I left that particular church's politics and ideology for that reason. 9, 12, 14, 15, 18 But, they have a very strong commitment to health care based on compassion, based on Christian values, based on the beatitudes, based on the teachings of Jesus Christ. 12, 13, 14, 19 And so, I went to boarding school. 7 I went to adventist boarding school right on through college and medical school because I got accepted at the seventh adventist medical school Loma Linda University in Southern California, and I did my training there. 5, 7, 12, 14 And then, I came back and did my residency in family practice at Hennepin County medical center in Minneapolis. 7, 9, 12, 14 And then, my wife Gail and I achieved my dream of becoming a family doctor in rural Northern Minnesota. 5, 12, 14, 20 We moved to Park Rapids. 7, 15 We spent eighteen years there, but due to a number of things, I reached the point where I wanted to connect with my Anishinaabe history. 14, 15, 18 And, I discovered that I have actually a few drops of Anishinaabe blood. 5, 7, 11 The old joke about nose bleed Indians, I mean no disrespect, I have to tell it on myself. 16 I try to avoid fist fights 'cuz if I get punched in the nose I'm gonna lose my Anishinaabe blood in the first thirty seconds. 9, 14 But I do have some blood, it's from Bowantan [unclear] from the Salto [unclear]  Anishinaabe —the Sioux band, the Sioux Saint Marie band.  And so, I wanted to connect with my Anishinaabe heritage, and the stories about marrying into Shaynowishkung's family. 9, 12, 14, 18 And so, on relatively short notice I made the decision and Gale supported me, and we left our job in Park Rapids and came here. 11, 14, 18 And we've been here for twenty years, and every day has been a joy. 14, 16 Because I can joke with people, and then talk with them about spiritual things, and then talk with them about tribal health business, all in the same conversation as perfectly fine. 9, 11, 17, 19 So, I've found a lot of what I was looking for.  Learned a lot about Anishinaabe spirituality and also been able to help.  And so, that's my medical background in being here. 7, 14 AS: That's fantastic.  Did you always wanna be a family doctor? 12, 14, 18 CG: I went through some struggles my last year of medical school. 7, 14 I thought about becoming a pathologist, but I'm red green color blind so that pretty much checks off looking at microscope slides. 5, 10, 17, 18 I thought about becoming a psychiatrist. 17, 18 Forty years, I've learned that basically family doctors are unlicensed psychiatrists in much of what we do. 10, 12, 13, 14, 19 So, I also thought about being a pediatrician, but in family practice you get to take care of kids and families. 12, 17, 18, 19 So, ultimately I decided for family practice. 12, 14 But those other thoughts certainly went through my mind in the intense last year of medical school trying to make some decision and to find some match. 7, 8, 14, 17, 18 AS: Did you ever have interest, or I mean did you ever have experience with addiction or a personal connection? 12, 14, 18 I wanted to kinda transition to... did you have experiences in your life that have later influenced you? 10, 17, 18 CG: Not during my childhood. 14, 20 My grandmother... certainly as a historian you must know about Carrie Nation? 5, 8, 12, 17 AS: Mhm, yes!  [Laughing]  I teach about it!  CG: When I was in third grade I watched my grandmother who weighed a hundred bounds soaking wet, bodily throw a drunken 200 pound man out of our apartment who had wandered into the apartment. 5, 8, 9, 11, 12, 14, 17 So, my grandmother was abused by her step-father when she was a teenager back in the late 1800s. 5, 6, 13, 16 And, my grandmother made it clear to me when she said that at age 13 if she had been strong enough and tall enough to get her step-father's gun off its mount on the mantle, she would've killed him. 5, 14, 16 So, that's a pretty harsh thing to say. 10 My grandmother wasn't a violent person. 5 She was a devout Christian, and believed in forgiveness and everything.  But she also told me that story. 15, 16 So, he was an alcoholic. 6 And, people in the throws of active alcoholism like other drug abuse, can do things they would never do if they were in their right mind and with good judgment and impulse control and everything. 5, 6, 9, 10, 12, 13, 16, 18 So, that's my family connection, but not in my immediate family. 12 As I said, we ended up living in the projects from the time I was middle school aged until the time I went away to college, and I still lived there came home from college. 5, 7, 14, 18, 20 So, we saw the effects of chemical abuse in the families that were our neighbors and friends in the projects. 5, 6, 13, 16, 17, 20 So, we saw that, but my grandmother was a very gentle woman who was iron fisted when it came to anything related to alcohol abuse, or any other drug abuse. 5, 6, 13, 14 And, white [unclear] people didn't mess with my grandma. 9, 19 And didn't try to argue with her about that.  So, on anything else she was very tolerant, understanding, and even often very progressive in many of her views. 14, 17, 18 But, do not talk with her about any kind of drug abuse being okay. 5, 6 Don't even try!  So, that's my background.  And I began to of course in high school learn about kids who got kicked out of boarding school for going out and getting drunk. 5, 7, 8, 10, 14 And then, in college learned about kids who got into all kinds of trouble. 7, 10 I was always involved in the seventh adventist church school system and they also had no tolerance whatsoever. 5, 7, 18 And didn't often, you know, in the sixties and seventies didn't often offer much harm-reduction focused sympathy on young people who were abusing drugs. 5, 6, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16 They just got booted.  So that was, you know, kind of a harsh and fairly one-sided view, but that was my growing up view. 9, 10, 12 And then when I got to medical school all of a sudden, my relatively protected childhood was ended as I got involved in clinical work, taking care of patients, and studying the science of substance abuse, and the damages it could do. 6, 7, 11, 13, 14, 19, 20 AS: Do you have children? 5, 14, 20 CG: No, my wife and I were never able to have children. 5, 14, 16, 20 And it was a spiritual and emotional ethical debate for us.  But what we ended up deciding to do was number one, to throw our lives into our professions. 14 My wife's a dietician, and she did dietetic consulting in all the years in Park Rapids. 14, 20 And then, did dietetic consulting here.  And as a historian, you should know this little fact that is not trivial. 12, 20 My wife, Gail Gardner, developed the diabetes Bingo game. 10, 20 which is now very popular, both in places like Oklahoma and other places where there are reservations, and also places where there aren't reservations. 12, 19 She and her assistant Paulie Nyson [confirm name] developed a game based on bingo that teaches good diabetes self-care. 10, 13, 19 It was developed right here about sixteen seventeen years ago. 12, 13, 14 And, a printing company out of Fargo Moorhead area, printed up the games. 8, 14 And, a number of them have sold.  My wife hasn't made any money on it, it belongs to the tribe since she developed it as an employee, but she helped to develop diabetes bingo. 8, 10, 17, 20 So, we threw our lives into our work, and also we decided we would rescue big dogs. 14 I always wanted a big dog. 18 When I was in medical school, one of my classmates and his wife went away for holidays. 7, 14, 16, 18, 20 Gail and I couldn't afford to do that.  And they asked us to take care of their Saint Bernard Golden Retriever mix—Ginger. 19 A wonderful gentle dog. 18 And we weren't going anywhere, so we took care of Ginger. 8, 19 And I took her for walks in the neighborhood when I hadn't been out in the neighborhood very often cuz I was busy studying. 15, 16, 20 And, one of the first walks we were taking, out from an unfenced yard that was about a foot and a half higher than the sidewalk, came a full sized Great Dane running right up. 7, 8, 9, 11, 12, 14, 16, 17 And, I, you know my life passed before my eyes. 10, 12 And then I thought, my god Fred will kill me. 5, 11, 17, 18 This dog is gonna kill me and then kill Ginger, and if I wasn't dead already Fred'll kill me when he got back. 5, 16 And the dog came up to me and...  Pardon me, I respect your space, but this is [acting out the scene]...  I'm a storyteller! 15 The dog came up to me just like that and went [licking sound].  [All laughing].  And as I was laughing, and wiping my face off, I said to myself, "Damn I'm gonna have a Great Dane someday." 16 So, after we moved to Park Rapids, in 1981, a few years later we adopted our first Great Dane, Chuckie. 7, 14, 15 Who was a mis-breed of the breeder.  He had a slightly short jaw, and the breeder couldn't sell him for big money, and so we adopted him for less than big money. 8, 10, 18 And he died at three and half of osteosarcoma. 14 Great Danes get spinal cancer. 10 He died of osteosarcoma Christmas week, when he was three years old. 14, 15 And Gail and I, amidst oceans of tears and anger against fate, said we'd never adopt another dog. 16 And one month later we got a call from a couple in Osage: "We heard your Great Dane died. 9, 11, 16 We have a Great Dane named Sarah.  And, she's been running the neighbor's cattle. 8 We're farmers too. 8 We're not willing to fence her.  Our neighbor came over and just said, 'You know folks, I love you guys, you're wonderful neighbors. 12, 14, 18 But next time Sarah runs my cattle I'm getting out my deer rifle.' 8 And so, would you take Sarah?"  And Gail and I looked at each other.  We had said never again will we have a dog, we're not gonna go through that kind of grief again. 16 So, we took Sarah, and we've kept it up through the years. 14 So we've had eight or nine Great Danes and other breeds.  And we also had cats for a while.  But, Sarah was our general.  Sarah had a higher IQ than me, I'm sure. 7, 17 Not that mine's that high, but hers was well-higher. 7, 17 And she, if we had let her run free, she would've organized all the dogs in the neighborhood into an army. 8, 20 And she was the general.  Our neighbor was the Becker County canine officer deputy, and he kept his canine at home. 8 And when the dog wasn't working, it got to run free. 8 And the day I brought Sarah home, she was indignant about being on a leash, and she and I were trying to work that out. 16 And the neighbor's dog came running over to introduce himself, and Sarah yanked the leash out of my hand, turned around, and my god.... 8, 11, 14 Sigourney  Weaver would have been less terrified of Alien than the snarl that Sarah offered that dog! 5, 20 And she chased the police dog back into his yard. 8 And then she turned to me and looked at me like, "Well let's get this over with."  So, I picked up the leash and started walking down the road, and that dog came back out again. 16 You know, head down, tail down, crouched, and tried to walk up to Sarah and make amends. 12, 14, 16 And she turned around snarled and chased him back into his yard, and he damn well never into our yard again! 14, 16 So that was, Sarah, our second Great Dane.  And she was wonderful. 18 She lived almost thirteen years, which is exceptionally long for a Great Dane. 7, 14, 17 And she enriched our life with laughter and tears and wonder at her brilliance and her organization, and that's how we became dog rescuers. 10 And we specialized in Great Danes for years. 14 But, our last great dane a few year ago, Reggie, had congenital hypothyroidism. 6, 13, 14, 20 And by the time I convinced the vet to do a thyroid profile on him, "Listen Gardner.  You're not a vet!  You're a family doctor. 12, 14 Your problem is you feed him too much." 12 He weighed 279 pounds.  And when, the vet finally said, "Well, bleep! 16 I guess you were right and put him on thyroid medicine." 12, 14 He got down to a svelte 212 pounds.  But, when he developed serious heart failure at five years of age, Gail and I couldn't lift him anymore. 9, 11, 14 so we, decided we better rescue smaller dogs. 14 So, we now have a couple of Australian Shepherd Great Pyrenees mix dogs, that weigh about 60 pounds each. 11, 12 And they have double merle syndrome, which renders them partially blind and deaf. 5, 9 And we got them from a shelter in Southern Minnesota, who got a call from a shelter in Oklahoma that was a kill shelter, that said: [Feigning a Southern accent]  "Would y'all send someone down and get these dogs, we don't wanna kill 'em they're such nice dogs." 18 And so, Gail and I always tease people up here and say, you know our dogs bark with an Oklahoma accent. 9, 12, 18 But they came to a Minnesota non-kill shelter.  We found out about them on the internet and went down and got em.  I'm sorry, but you're a historian, and you like hearing stories and I'm a story teller, so! 9, 15 [All laughing]  Okay, so we should move on. 15 CG: Yeah, those are our children. 5, 14, 20 But we should move on. 15 AS: That's great, that's fantastic. 20 So, why don't we talk about at what point...  well why don't you tell me what your job here is exactly. 11 And, if it's changed. 13 Like, what did you start here, and what are you now? 12 CG: My job now is, I am the medical director of the tribal health department. 7, 9, 11, 12, 14, 18, 19 That is not the top position.  My boss is Pat Butler, RN-BSN-PHN.  She was the long time director of public health nursing here. 17, 18, 19 And when the predecessor director of health services left, she took over that job. 5, 10, 11, 14, 18, 19 So, she's my boss.  But, I'm the medical director. 7, 14, 18, 19 And I'm the medical director of the White Earth ambulance service, a rural ambulance service that does 700-900 runs a year. 7, 8, 14, 18, 19 Far, rural, long-run times. 8, 17 Difficult, low-budget, lot of challenges, and a lot of overdose calls. 10, 16 And, a couple of years ago I became the chair of the White Earth research review board. 11, 13, 14 The White Earth tribal council, now called the reservation business committee, decided in the wake of Havasupai Incident, do you know about that? 12, 14, 19 AS: No. CG: You should read about that.  It isn't about drug abuse, but it's about abuse of power. 5, 6, 13, 17 A researcher from Arizona State University got the agreement of the Havasupai Nation, that live in the Grand Canyon, to allow blood to be drawn to do genetic research on diabetes. 5, 10, 12 And, it was all fine and good, and the consents were signed. 5, 10, 11, 14 But, several years after the study was done the lead researcher allowed frozen blood samples to be used by other researchers who were doing anthropologic, sociologic research. 6, 10, 13, 14, 16 And ultimately, that was used to put forth the theory that the Havasupai people came across on the land bridge from Asia. 6, 9, 13, 16 And the Havasupai people were pissed as hell! 9 That's against traditional, spiritual, historical viewpoint of how we originated on Turtle Island.  And, they didn't even tell the Havasupai anything about that.  But, a research review board member of the Navajo research review board, was reading and discovered this article and said, "How did they get any Indian people to agree to that?" 5, 9, 14 And followed through, and found out what had happened. 10, 15 She told the Havasupai tribal council, and they took Arizona State University to court and won the case. 16, 17, 19 Got a substantial monetary damage from Arizona State, and it was very embarrassing. 8 Arizona State administration felt terrible. 11 That's not what they set out to do, or how they wanted to do it. 18 But, it all just happened by the taking the easiest route. 11, 15 And so, in the wake of that, our tribal council decided we better have a research review board and institutional review board. 14, 19 And so, it was established two years ago. 13, 14 And, I became a member, and I got voted in as the chair. 14 And so, we're dong that work here now too. 12 So that will inform you about my extra caution.  So that's what I do now. 12 But I came here in 1999, my first act as an employee after being hired by the IHS clinic, was to call in sick [laughs]. 5, 14, 15 You should laugh at that!  CG: Gail and I moved directly from Park Rapids to here, no time off. 7, 15, 18 We did our furniture moving and everything evenings and weekends. 15 And, two days before I was to finish work there and start work here, I ruptured two disks in my back. 5, 16 My left leg went paralyzed and I ended up with an emergency neuro surgery. 14 So, I called in sick. 15 But, and I was here to work in a week cuz I was scared I'd lose my job. 5, 9, 11, 15, 19 And now, I have to tell you another story. 12, 15 You can just slap me up when you're ready [Sullivan laughs] 15 But, some historian should know this story. 12, 15 Poozy Hags [Confirm name], Clifford Hags.  You know about tribal nicknames? 12, 16, 19 AS: Mhm, mhm.  CG: Clifford was the director of evening housekeeping services at the clinic. 6, 13, 18, 19 And the week I started, my leg was still paralyzed! 15 Took months for it to get better after the surgery. 11, 16 And I was dragging my shoe, and I had the kind of shoe that would make marks on the floor. 5, 14 And Poozy did the evening floor cleaning. 14 And so, like the third day of work at the IHS clinic, I was sitting in my office doing insurance forms and paperwork, like family doctors do in the evening. 12, 14, 16 And, in came this very Indian man.  And he said, "You must be Gardner."  And I stood up with my cane and limp, and said, "Yes. 14 I'm Carson Gardner.  Nice to meet you!" 18 And he didn't even put his hand out.  He looked at me and he said, "You're making marks on my floor. 5, 10, 14 You come out here and I'll show 'em to you.  We'll get along just fine if you quit making marks on my floor." 5, 10, 11, 14, 17 And I had no idea that Poozy is one of the biggest jokers on the res, and the biggest story-tellers. 15 And you know, if I'd have known him, I would've laughed and said, "Ah c'mon Pooz." 11, 12 But, he took me out, showed me the marks, and said, "You go buy another pair of shoes!" 5 And so, I told Gail when I got home, and you know, I took it very seriously. 11, 12, 16 I'm an OCD kind of a guy, and so I was very worreid about it.  So we went to Fargo, went to Penny's, I bought a pair of shoes, and I insisted to the sales person that I put them on, get up, and find the nearest linoleum on the store and rub my shoes.  And my wife Gail tells me that while I was doing that, the salesman turned to her and said, "Does he do stuff like this often?" 15, 20 And Gail said "Yeah, all them time."  So, I bought the shoes, I came back, I showed Poozy, and then he got a big grin, and said, "Ah, we're gonna get along great!" 17, 20 And Poozy became my secret agent here.  He was the evening housekeeping lead who did the floors. 6, 13, 14 But he would come in, and we would trade stories during his break. 9 And I'm sitting there anyway, not being paid for doing paperwork. 18 So, he would come in and tell me a story. 15 But then, he'd say, "By the way Gardner, one of these days ‘so-and-so's’ gonna come in for some little thing, and you need to know that they're having trouble with a heroin habit. 12, 16, 18, 20 And you should see if you can figure out a way, don't tell 'em I told you, but see if you can figure out a way to get 'em to talk about it, ‘cuz they need help." 6, 16, 18 So all the years I worked at IHS, Pooz was my secret agent in the community. 14, 19 He was as much a healer as any of the rest of us, snd maybe more so. 5 ‘Cuz he could get away with that, and to hell with HIPAA and all that. 18, 20 Don't every tell anybody I said that.  You may have to erase that.  There may need to be a small blank on the...  AS: You just mean it…  you mean it, in a kind of philosophical way. 18 CG: So, that's what I did first. 14 That's what I did first, from '99 until 2011, and then I retired. 5, 14 And my retirement lasted three months and I got hired here, and I've been working here ever since. 5, 10, 11, 12, 16 And I will probably keep on working for any number of reasons.  Probably the most important one is a statement that I only heard verbalized recently, but I realize rapidly became my own personal unstated prayer: "Creator help me to live in a way today that will make my ancestors proud." 8, 9, 12, 16, 18 I just heard that recently, but actually a lot of the stuff we all do here, is based on that. 7, 9, 13 My boss, Pat Butler, in department head meetings, again and again says to us, "Just remember people, we have to do things twice as well here as anybody else to be considered equal." 5, 9, 12, 14, 18, 19 And so, if you look at the Western administrative records, you'll see that White Earth has developed many best practices pilot programs. 6 And it's because of people like my boss Pat Butler, who believe that, yes we do have to do things twice as well as everybody else to be considered equal, so let's damn well get busy and do it that way! 5, 9, 15, 18 AS: That's great. 20 So, you mentioned you, that you know that Poozy told you about someone with a heroin habit. 8, 12, 16, 20 Was that the first time you had heard about it here? 9, 14 And then, when did it start kind of becoming part of what people were talking about? 9 CG: When I interviewed here, which was just a couple of weeks before I was hired, I called Howard Hayes, the medical director of the IHS clinic. 5, 7, 11, 14, 15, 18, 19 When I decided ethically and spiritually it was time for me to investigate working on an Indian reservation, I called him, he answered. 5, 14, 19 And I said, "Hi Dr. Hayes, my name's Carson Gardner.  I'm a family doctor in Park Rapids, not too far from you. 12, 14 And I was wondering if you had any job. 11, 15 And he said, "When do you wanna start?'"  So, I went for an interview, and he took me around—nice man. 18 But he said, when we did the interview, he took me into the Pine Point, little Pine Point clinic, he took me to NATUA, and in the car he said, "You know Carson. 12, 20 The Anishinaabe cure will test you.  Just the first day someone will come in and want narcotic pain medicines, and you need to know what your own personal ethics and values are on that issue because we do have problems with that here. 6, 12, 13, 14, 16 And, I'm not telling you you shouldn't prescribe pain medicine, but you need to know that you will be tested. 6, 10, 12, 14, 15 People will always come to the new doctor here. 12, 14, 16, 18 People are struggling with substance abuse and will always look for the easiest source. 6, 13, 18 Howard said, "I'm not criticizing our citizens, I love them, I'm here too. 14 But, you will need to develop your own ethics and your own values and your own decision making process on that because some people will push you very hard to get narcotics." 9, 10, 14, 17 And so, I guess, in my interview a few weeks before I started here that's what I learned. 10, 15 And then I came and started seeing patients and saw that it was true. 5, 6 And, I was probably one of the most conservative prescribers of narcotic pain medicine. 6, 10, 12, 14 But, after a few years we all realized we needed to take a more aggressive step in standardizing our approach. 14 So, we developed a chronic pain management program at White Earth in the early twenty-first century, where we all sat on a committee, all of us medical prescribers at the clinic. 6, 7, 10, 12, 14 And, we developed a pain contract. 6, 19 And, we developed policy and procedure.  And, we developed random drug testing policies. 5, 6 And, we developed policies on what to do if a person tested positive, and policies on what would be the criteria for second chances, and what would be criteria for release from the chronic pain management program and everything. 6, 12, 14 So, we did that here, and we certainly used resources. 6, 8, 13, 16, 17 You know, other places, we looked at their policies and prodcueres as templates. 12 But we did that in the early twenty-first century here, because we, like many other IHS clinics, had to use locums doctors to fill in. 5, 6, 12, 13, 14 And the locums doctor from elsewhere might have a whole different view on prescribing... 10, 12, 14 AS: What's a locums doctor? 12, 14 CG: Locum tenans doctors. 12, 14 That's I guess latin, and I haven't looked it up, but it's a doctor who specializes in doing fill-in work. 5, 12, 14 All they ever do is fill in for other clinics. 5 They go and work two months at White Earth, and then they have two months off to go sailing, and then they go and work two months at Pine Ridge, and then they go work two months in Oklahoma, and... AS: Is it mostly through IHS? 11, 12, 16 AS: Oh, okay, but it can be anywhere, but? 8 CG: Yeah, it could be anywhere... 8 AS: But once you're in that network.  CG: I'm just using Native American examples. 6 But there are locums doctors that that's their own choice. 6, 12, 14 They want to work very hard for a few months, and then have several months off to not do medical stuff. 7, 9, 11, 14, 16 And, you know, a busy family doctor finds that attractive sometimes. 12, 14, 15 But, locum doctors have no context, and they have their own set of rules. 12, 13, 14 They can come into an IHS clinic, and if there is no policy on it, they will do whatever they think is right. 12 And, it isn't always necessarily conducive to managing responsible opioid prescribing. 10, 13, 14, 16, 18 And so, the chronic pain management program helped to better standardize the policies and procedures for locums physicians. 6, 12 And of course, while we were doing that Clinton and his team were being formed.  And I won't tell Clinton's story, but he started consulting here from a harm reduction program in the Moorhead area. 5, 8, 14, 15 This is Clinton's home, but he was working there in harm reduction, came here to help out, and he will tell you the story about how there was a Hepatitis C cluster here in our community that sort of was the eye opener that helped community leaders to realize we needed a harm reduction program. 5, 14, 15, 19 And, he'll tell you the story on that, but harm reduction was being started on that basis at the same time we were starting a chronic pain management program policy and procedure at the clinic. 5, 6, 12, 14, 15 AS: And this is around 2011?  CG: Clinton will tell you, it was, I don't remember what year. 14 But probably, in the early 2000s.  Sue, do you remember?  SP: Maybe around 2006, 2007?  Somewhere in there.  CG: Yep.  And so, it was probably about that same time.  Maybe even 2005... when we started developing our chronic pain management program. 6, 12 I retired in 2011, but the chronic pain management program had been going for a number of years there prior to that. 5, 6, 12, 14 AS: So, you retired for a few months and then... CG: I retired in 2011. 5, 11, 16 AS: And then you came back?  CG: And, I got hired here by Monty Fox who was the director of health services at that time. 5, 18, 19 So, that's why I joke about my retirement lasting three months. 11, 12, 16 AS: Right.  So it was still like, 2011?  CG: But I became a desk jockey. 15 I hung up my stethoscope in 2011, and that was painful. 6 I still see old patients here, who say, "Damnit Gardner, why don't you come back and take care of patients at the clinic?" 6, 19 And I always smile, and acknowledge the joys of clinical practice, but I have been a desk jockey here and administrative physician since 2011. 12, 15, 18 AS: So, besides the chronic pain management plan, how's the public health and the medical system here approached the opioid epidemic? 6, 7, 12, 13, 14, 19 Could you describe how it first started, and what it became? 14 CG: A couple of things happened to raise my consciousness, and I regret that I didn't get to meet Sue at that time. 11, 15, 18 But Sue, undoubtably was working with Clinton at that time.  Clinton and his harm reduction team, Minus Bala, Karen, Keller, and not Rachel Lawfranir. 5, 14 [confirm names] 16 She's on the team now, but she wasn't on the team then. 12 But, the harm reduction core team brought Sarah Gordon here. 5, 14 Do you know Sarah Gordon? 12 CG: Yeah, I hope so. 9 If you haven't interviewed her, you pardon my french, damn well better!  AS: I'm going to [laughs], I'm going to. 15 CG: You better, you better!  AS: She's on my list.  CG: Because, she came up here to talk about harm reduction, and specifically to talk to medical providers. 5, 7, 14 I was one of the few who attended that talk, but she showed the video produced by anypositivechange.org, you should know about them they're out of Chicago. 12, 13, 14, 18 Do you know them? 12 AS: Mhm.  CG: Have you seen their video? 6, 18 AS: No. CG: You should watch it, it's on their website. 17 I can tell you exactly what happened. 15 I had been very conflicted.  Not about ethics, and responsibility, and compassionate care, but about how far I should participate in harm reduction. 5, 9, 14, 19 But in that video that's still available on their website—I checked it a year ago—they're still showing it. 13, 14, 18 They use primarily people suffering from active substance abuse, and not actors in that video. 6, 9, 13, 18 And, one of the scenes in the video, a young woman is sitting—calm, well-dressed, alert—and saying "I got clean and sober, but my man is still doing heroin. 5, 16, 18 And, I want him to quit, but you can't quit for anybody else.  And so, I carry a naloxone kit, because if he's dead he can't recover, can he?" 16 And the video goes [mimics "swooshing" sound effect], to black. 18 And I couldn't sleep that night. 16 And I thought really hard about that. 9, 17, 18 And I thought, okay, I have been a compassionate family doctor, and I support good care, but I haven't been active in harm reduction. 5, 10, 12, 14, 17, 18, 19 And, it's probably time I get active in harm reduction. 5, 14 And so, it was Sarah Gordon, and Clinton, and Mina, and Karen, and that video—which you should watch—that was the turning point for me. 17, 18, 20 That's when I got involved saying to Clinton, what can I do to help?  And shortly after that, one of our child welfare workers gave a talk at a community forum meeting, and said, "I just want you guys to know that last year we had twenty babies from White Earth that had narcotic withdrawal syndrome, and we damn well need to do something about it." 5, 12, 14, 18, 19 And, it was a shock in the community, and we had more meetings and said you know we need a treatment program specialized to helping our pregnant moms who are struggling with substance abuse, but can we do that? 6, 7, 10, 12, 13, 14, 18, 19 And so, medical minded people like me sat down and thought about it, and did our OCD thing, and wrote out timelines and flowsheets and said, at a meeting in 2013, late 2013, "Well I think we can put this together. 7, 8, 9, 10, 14, 17, 18 We can do it, but it'll take us about a year, maybe a year and a half to have it together." 5, 8, 14 And, Tara Mason, our tribal secretary treasurer, was at that meeting. 18, 19 And she stood up, and said, "Okay, it's December now. 12 I want this program open and taking clients in June." 10, 11 And then she walked out of the room. 14, 16 And then we looked at each other and said, "Well hell!  Nobody told us we couldn't do it!" 16 So we were open by June taking clients. 10, 11 And the mom's program is still open, and it's won Minnesota state awards, and it's won some national awards. 14 And so, that was the other thing, they asked me to put together a debate position on the negative side 'cuz no one would do that. 8, 9 They had some nurse practitioners come up from the Twin Cities and present the positive position: 5, 8, 10 This is why we should have subaxone treatment program for pregnant women on the White Earth reservation. 7, 10, 12, 13, 19 Well, we need someone to argue the other option so Gardner why don't you put it together. 8 That's your job. 11 And I, put together a lot of information, decided I really couldn't argue the negative position, 'cuz it needed to be done. 8, 14, 18 So, that was the first active role. 10, 14 And then in 2014, my boss Pat Butler said to me, "You know we have a lot of overdoses. 12 You know that because you're the ambulance medical director. 7, 12, 14, 18, 19 We need to start teaching nalaxone rescue."  "Well, I uhm, uh, uhm..." "Put together a program! 8 I want to get going here in the next few months." 11, 16 So, in early 2014, and I guess the motivation was I had told her that the Minnesota legislature was reviewing what became Steve's Law and about to pass it. 14, 16 And that's when she said, "We need to be teaching nalaxone rescue.  We don't have to have state support, we're a sovereign nation, but it'll be good to have state support, so why don't you put it together?" 8, 10 So, the ambulance manager  Devon Green and I, put together a teaching program. 8 And I went back to Pat, and to the tribal council and said, "You know, we're having overdoses. 12, 19 And you know, we're attending funerals here. 12 And so, we need to do this."  And that was at the time the Minnesota legislature, I think they passed it as of July 1st, but they weren't gonna implement it until late August or early September. 12 And I, I said to Pat, "You know it's silly, I've got the program ready. 12 We could start teaching.  No experience, but we could start teaching. 18 The sooner we do it the better, but according to Minnesota legislature we can't start." 8 And Pat said, "Let me talk to the tribal council." 19 And, like three days later they passed a resolution saying that we should start teaching and giving out nalaxone immediately, which for me, I'm not licensed by the tribe I'm licensed by the state of Minnesota. 9, 13, 16 And I thought, holy hell. 17, 18 If I do this, and some legislator gets pissed at me, they could yank my license, or have the Minnesota health department sanction me. 9, 12, 13, 19 And I, talked to Pat about it.  We looked at each other, and we said, well they wouldn't dare!  The tribal council would raise such a racism argument that they would get backed against the wall. 12, 19 So, we went ahead. 14 We started teaching nalaxone rescue here a month before the actual implementation of Steve's Law. 12, 16 Of course, it worked out fine. 11 And we met, Clinton, Matt, and I, eventually Matt Luxey Read Holtum [unclear] and you know, made that connection and all the wonderful good that has been able to happen here. 5, 10, 12, 15, 18 So, I haven't compiled the statistics for the last month, but as of a couple of months ago, and believe me there is no spiritual implication for this, so don't even think about spinning that. 11, 13, 16 But, as of a couple months ago, we had trained 666 "nalaxoners." 8, 11, 13, 16 [Sullivan laughing].  And better than that, and that's ambulance service training, but about a year and half ago the ambulance service and harm reduction said, we really should get together and do team teaching. 5, 8, 13, 14, 18, 19 The ambulance service has done classes for groups of employees, and for behavioral health therapy group members. 7, 12, 15, 19 And harm reduction has done individual one-on-one counseling, so ten to fifteen minute individual training. 5, 14, 15, 19 Gardner's class and hour and a half with all the science and "Oh god... 7, 11, 14, 15 Garner's gonna talk again."  But, actually people like it. 7, 9 They become the ambassadors to correct misconceptions about, "Oh overdose?  Give em, shoot up milk!"  Or, "Throw 'em in the snowbank!" 12 Or, "Put 'em in the shower!"  Or, you know, our students from our group classes get to help correct misconceptions, and say, "No, no. 7, 12 You have to see if they don't respond to pain. 6 You have to breath for 'em, cuz nalaxone won't work if they aren't breathing.  And then you have to give 'em the nalaxone, and then you have to keep breathing for 'em 'til they wake up. 8 And this is how long it'll take, and this is what you can expect." 17 So, the ambulance service and our tribal first responders, who are the security officers at the casino, have a 120 nalaxone saves since the summer of 2014, 120! 7, 8, 10, 14, 19 And twenty of them are the first responders at the casino. 14 They're basic emergency medical responders, not EMTs, not paramedics. 7, 14 But, they came to me in the fall of 2014 and said, "Doc, we'd like to get in on this too.  We see overdoses at the casino." 6 So, I'm gonna guess that with twenty saves, that first responder group is probably one of the premier first responder groups in Minnesota for nalaxone rescue. 10, 12, 14 But they came to me, to us!  To Devon Green and me and said, "Will you train us?  We wanna get started."  So, but then you'll talk to Clinton and he'll explain to you, that Clinton and I, and Mina, and Karen, and Rachel Lawfrenir, estimate that for every one save, the ambulance has, citizen harm reduction trained rescuers have done three of four, maybe five. 5, 10, 14 So, we're pretty solid on estimating our 120, is probably 480. 10 So, we probably have pretty close to 500 saves, and with all the individual trainings that harm reduction has done we have probably trained, we have certainly trained over 2500 nalaxone rescuers on White Earth reservation. 5, 8, 9, 10, 14, 17, 19 And, "Isn't that enough Doc?"  We will not stop, I like the quote from the director of the Baltimore Maryland health department who said, "My goal is to have everyone over twelve years of age who lives in the city of Baltimore trained as a nalaxone rescuer." 8, 9, 12, 14, 18, 19 So, our goal is, we'll stop training when we have a year of no overdoses at all. 14 We'll consider stopping training, we might not even stop then, but we ain't stopping training until we have a whole calendar year of not one single overdose on White Earth land. 9, 14 And you know what, the truth of the matter is, as we struggle with the peaking of this opioid abuse epidemic, and the sinister introduction of fentanyl, and fentanyl cutting of heroin, that isn't gonna just happen like that [snaps]. 6, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16 So, we're gonna be doing nalaxone training and rescuing for a long time yet, and we will continue to do it as long as is needed. 17 AS: Would you, do you know, if it was pain pills that introduced heroin here? 6, 12, 14 Is it the same narrative that we're hearing in most of the U.S. about the upsurge of heroin was because of pain pill addiction? 6, 9, 12, 14, 16 That pain pill addiction started... 6, 12, 14 CG: I'm certainly sure that that's a factor. 8, 17 I'm not convinced that that's the primary origin of opioid abuse here. 6, 13, 19 I don't have statistics for you, but I know the street level view point of the matter. 12 We had a serious crack-cocaine problem here twenty years ago, and we've cycled through the various changes in drugs, substance abuse of choice, and everything. 5, 6, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16 I believe that there was a small heroin problem here prior to the twenty-first century, but I have no doubt that pain management and prescription opioid use fueled a serious worsening here. 6, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16 So, I have no doubt about that.  I don't have statistics on it.  What I can tell you is, a year of two ago, the Minnesota health department put out statistics from 2000 to 2015 on county drug overdose deaths. 5, 6, 9, 12, 13, 14, 18, 19 Including the counties that shared with reservation land here- Becker, Mahnomen, Clearwater. 5, 12, 16, 19 And they estimated forty-five drug overdose deaths during those years- 2000 to 2015. 5, 6, 14, 18 And everybody I've talked to from tribal council to Poozy Hags, to everybody else says, "Phew. 19 That's a gross underestimate.  We've had a lot more deaths than that." 18 Which has brought up the issue of busy old family doctors who are tired and have a desk stacked with insurance forms and death certificates and which one's gonna get more attention? 5, 8, 12, 13, 14, 15, 18 And, what gets put on the death certificate? 18 And, does the coroner take the time to say, "Well you know, cardiac arrest. 8, 12 Yes, of course, but...  AS: This person was twenty-five... CG: "...This person was nineteen-years-old, or twenty-five years old, so, I'm gonna call old Gardner and say, 'You know Gardner I hate to be a pest, but you said this twenty-five year old died of cardiac arrest. 12, 14 Well, of course, that's the final mechanism but was there anything else that was a contributing factor or?'"  "Well yeah, they were a heroin user." 6, 13, 16 "Well, wouldn't you wanna put that on the death certificate Gardner?" 18 You know, that's hypothetical, but you get the idea. 6, 12 AS: But, how things get lost. 11 CG: I'll insult myself and not somebody else.  So, there has been a problem with struggling with substance abuse disorder here for quite some time. 6, 12, 13 And it did include street heroin and other street opioids, but I'm certain that the 1990s concept of pain as the fifth vital sign, and articles from LA or New York about doctors being sued for providing inadequate pain control, and big pharma's advertising "Oxycontin! 6, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18 No problem! 12 You wont' have any problem..." [sarcastic tone]. 8, 12 AS: Nobody gets addicted. 12, 14 Right.  CG: [Continues]  "Yeah, come have dinner.  We'll buy you dinner, and wouldn't you like to prescribe Oxycontin?" 10 I'm sure that that had a lot to do with it.  I came in 1999…  yeah I'm sorry I talk too much.  AS: I'm just keeping track. 16 No, you keep going!  CG: I came in '99 here, and as I told you, Dr. Howard Hayes warned me. 16 There was a problem with prescription drug seeking, certainly was here. 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 17 But I think, my opinion, working at IHS was, that we weren't necessarily the center of the problem. 12 There were other physicians practicing, not associated with IHS, in fact, do you know the Lee clinic story? 12, 15 AS: No. CG: Dr. Lee, god rest his soul… 11 Was he here, around here?  CG: Graduated from a residency program in Fargo, and opened up several urgent care clinics that people could walk into any time, and prescribed tons of narcotics. 7, 9, 10, 16, 19 You know, relatively speaking. 12 And, ended up being charged with malfeasance and losing his license, and later committed suicide. 13, 14 So, very very sad story. 15 Don't remember his first name, but… 14 AS: Fargo.  In Fargo did you say?  Moorhead? 14 CG: Yeah, Dr. Lee.  And the clinic I think is called the Seven Day Clinic.  It's in Detroit Lakes, and it's near Menards.  Sue, if you know Detroit Lakes. 12 That was originally a Dr. Lee Clinic, and it got bought out by someone else after his untimely and sad death. 18 And, ultimately....  Essentia bought it up because they believe in mitigating competition when they can, but they don't run it that way. 5, 8, 18 They run it as a responsible urgent care clinic, but there were several clinics like that. 8, 16, 19 And, Clinton will know about Dr. Lee. 12 And I, you know, I didn't see any court records or any board of medical examiners' records. 6, 7, 12, 14 But, that was going on in the 1990s.  And, I think that, very likely that situation helped to fuel a, you know, a serious habituation to opioids in this whole region. 6, 11, 12, 13, 20 And you would have to look into that.  I can't give you any authoritative history, but I, but I was here when that happened and we heard the stories about people saying, "Oh I can go down to Lee's clinic, I can get as much 'oxy' as I want to. 9, 15 I can get as much 'vic' as I want to.  What the hell's wrong with you IHS doctors?" 11, 12, 14 So, we heard that. 9 And, apparently so did the North Dakota board of Medical Examiners. 14, 20 And so did the North Dakota judicial system. 14 So, you may wanna look into that.  It goes across the border.  But, many of his urgent care clinics were through this area, rural Minnesota. 8, 19 In the 1990s.  And, they were handing out 'oxys' and 'vics' like candy.  AS: Right, right. 12 CG: And so, isn't it nice for Gardner to blame someone else. 18 There were various narcotic prescribing strategies by IHS doctors, but we had a solid core group from 1999 till about 2005 or 2006, we had no turnover in doctors and nurse practitioners. 8, 10, 12, 14 And, it was amazing 'cuz the whole IHS joke is, well you know, two years pay off your public health pay back, and then you leave. 9, 12, 14, 18, 19 But we have the same group of five medical care providers, primary care, from before '99 until about 2005, 2006. 7, 14, 19 And then it fell apart and people started leaving, and we got in short termers and locum tenens doctors, and it became more an issue with varying philosophies. 9, 11, 12, 13, 14, 17, 18 But, from '99 when I cam until 2005 or 2006, we had dependable reliable team of primary care providers who were concerned about the issue and established policy and procedure to help minimize the risks of doing harm by opioid prescribing. 10, 13, 19 So, I don't think in that time of '99 to early twenty-first century we were the primary cause, but we certainly saw the problem. 6, 8, 12, 13, 14, 17, 19 And, yes we did prescribe. 10 And I had, I had an individual who had pain issues. 6, 12, 13 This is an interesting story. 15, 17 I'll try to leave out any identifying factors. 17, 18 So, here's the story. 15 This was an individual who was a community member who had pain management issues. 6, 12, 13, 19 Who came in to see me, and I did prescribe narcotics for the individual for a period of weeks. 6, 10, 15, 18 And then, I realized that there were red flag signals here of inappropriate requests, and early refills, and suggestion of using in excess of prescribed doses. 5, 6, 10, 11 And so, I had a visit meeting with this individual and laid out the issues and explained to them that I was going to have to stop their narcotic prescription. 10, 12, 13, 18 And, they threatened to bring a gun to my yard!  Now, I have to give you the perspective, I've been a family doctor for forty years, I've been threatened four times. 12, 14 Three of them were by white people in Park Rapids. 9, 19 So, don't think this is an "Indian thing."  But, but this was an individual who was desperate and said something desperate.  And, I reported it to the tribal cops and we looked at each other, and they shrugged and I shrugged. 13, 19 And you, know, no harm was done to me. 12 And so, that happened, but that's not the end of the story because a week and half later I was on emergency call, and this individual came in having a profound severe heart attack. 6, 9, 14, 15 And I got to care for them, and I looked at my nurse and she looked at me, and I said, "Ueah we're gonna care for this individual." 19 And so, we did care for that individual, and it was nip-and-tuck and the ambulance had to rush him to Fargo. 19 And they ended up with fairly extensive sub-specialty management. 9, 12 And on that, that's all I'm gonna say.  But here's the thing, I lost track. 11, 16 Ajd a few months later my nurse came to me and said, "'Member 'so-and-so?'" 11, 16 And I said, "Oh yeah, I remember 'so-and-so.'"  And she said, "Well 'so-and-so' is here and wants to talk to you.'  And I said, "Geez what do you think?"  And she was a community member here and she said, "Oh yeah, you wanna talk to 'so-and-so' today." 16, 19 So, so-and-so's put in the room, and I go into the room thinking, "Okay, chapter two of the 'What's the matter with you damn doctors?'" 12, 14 I walked in, the individual had come to me to apologize for threatening to bring a gun to my yard, and to thank me for participating in the team that helped to save their life. 9, 10, 11, 16 So none of the three white persons in Park Rapids ever came back... 8, 19 [Amy and Sue laughing] and said I'm sorry.  But, that individual did, so that's the whole story. 15 But, that happened here. 15 And I would guess that if you talked to everyone of us who had practiced at that time, each one could tell you some other story. 8, 15 AS: Oh, almost every doctor has told me a story like that, yeah. 12, 14, 15, 16 CG: So, that's mine and I tried to de-identify it as much as a I could.  AS: You did a great job. 11, 20 CG: If you would make that into a big deal, I, you know some people who know, "Well, I know who that is 'cuz I 'member about 'so-and-so's' heart attack and I 'member about this and such." 9, 12 CG: But, so those were the kind of things that were happening in the early twenty-first century. 14, 15 But I still maintain that narcotic prescribing at the IHS clinic was not the main problem that fueled the opioid abuse crisis here. 6, 10, 12, 13 I think there were other factors in play. 17 We certainly did prescribe narcotics, and yes some of our patients did misuse them. 6, 8, 10, 13, 17 But in the years that I was here, we proactively tried to be very careful. 14, 19 What we weren't good at was we weren't good at harm reduction. 5, 10, 14 We didn't say, I'm going to have to stop your narcotic prescription, but I would like to have you talk to Clinton Alexander and Minus Bala [confirm names], and let's see if we can get you a substance abuse baseline assessment and some support here. 6, 9, 10, 12, 13, 16 And maybe we can work out some harm reduction help that will help you get through this. 5, 14 And I still wanna be your doctor. 12, 14 And you know, don't wanna have this end on a bad note, let me put together a team that will help you. 8, 12 We didn't do as good a job at that as we should back then. 10, 11 We're doing a much better job on that now. 11, 12 So, we had to grow up and learn about harm reduction. 5, 10, 14 I told you about Sarah Gordon. 16 I told you about the video. 16, 18 Profound turning point in my professional life was Sarah Gordon's visit and that video. 10, 18, 20 And she will tell you I give her a hug every time I see her. 6 I give her a hug and she laughs, "You've already thanked me!" 11, 15 But, that was a profound turning point in my professional and my personal life. 10, 20 SP: Government lady! 12 That's what she's known as up here. 11, 12 AS: Government lady? 12 SP: [Laughing].  Government lady! 12 AS: So, what about, can we talk about medicine for opioid maintenance? 12, 13, 14 CG: Sure.  AS: And, and what have you, when did that, when did subaxone and probably, do you have, you don't have methadone...? 6, 8 AS: No, can you talk about how that fits into the story? 15 CG: I was involved in doing basic research for the mom's program. 14 We recognized that although we were determined to create a program that included traditional medicine wheel, spiritual healing, human services support, psychological counseling and support, substance abuse assessment and support....that we were going to need to develop a medically assisted treatment arm of the mom's program. 6, 7, 12, 13, 14, 17, 19 And so back in late 2013, early 2014, I did the research along with others.  I wasn't the only one, but I'm the OCD guy who in my next life is gonna be a medical librarian [Sullivan laughing]. 7, 8, 10, 14 So, I did the research, present it, and said, "Look subaxone is what we need. 5, 10 We're not, you know, we have to move heaven and earth to open a methadone clinic here, but we can get a subaxone clinic open. 12, 15, 19 You can find the staff who have some experience, or who can get the experience." 18 And, Julie Williams and Minus Bala who helped Julie Williams start the mom's program here agreed with that. 14 And, Tara Mason, the tribal secretary treasurer, agreed with that. 19 And, all the other members on the work-group agreed with that.  And so, we went with a subaxone program.  And it was the same thing that I've already told you. 16 No one told us we couldn't do it. 8, 16 So we put the program together! 8 And we didn't think too much about it.  Except Tara wanted it by June of 2014, and so it was there by June of 2014- working well not working clumsily and ineffectively. 18 And then, a year or so later people started coming and saying, "How the hell didn't you get this program going out of nothing? 9, 14 Tell us how you did it!"  "Well, no one told us we couldn't! 8, 16 We looked at the literature, saw what it would take, got the people, got the training, started it!" 9 So, you know, it would be good for you to talk to some of the mom's program. 10, 12, 14 AS: Yeah, I did meet Julie. 18 CG: I sound like I'm bragging, I'm not!  I'm bragging up the White Earth philosophy that we can do this together. 8 We have to be twice as good as everybody else to be considered equal, and we can do that. 5, 9, 10 So that's how the mom's program got started. 14 And, if you've talked to Julie, or do talk to her, or will talk to her, she'll tell you more of the detail.  But, it became obvious to me and everyone else on the work-group that subaxone, buprenorphine nalaxone, was what we needed to use. 6, 8, 13 And subutex without the nalaxone I think is an initially what was used. 6, 8, 13, 16 I'm not sure now. 12 I am not a behavioral health employee, and the mom's program is a behavioral health program. 14, 15, 19 Jerry Jaskin is the director of behavioral health. 15, 18, 19 Pat Butler is the director of tribal general health services. 18, 19 So, I was the crossover consultant helper.  And so, I know the literature now says there is not any likely harm from nalaxone, and so pregnant women could certainly take subaxone. 7, 8, 10, 12, 17 But the tradition was to use subutex. 6, 13 But we got that started real fast, and made it work, and provided the traditional spiritual support and healing.  Provided the human services support. 19 Provided the substance abuse counseling. 6, 13, 19 Provided child support, baby sitting. 14 Provided good parenting training. 10, 20 Provided group therapy. 12 Provided…  everything Julie can tell you about.  And, our program has worked very well, and we have served a lot of our equawa [unclear] our Anishinabe women who have struggled with substance abuse disorder, and who have been pregnant and needed help. 6, 7, 10, 12, 13 And, many of them are now clean and sober and helping as counselors in our community and other places. 12, 19 So, that was one of the crossover points.  I told you about the video. 16, 18 I told you about "fade to black." 16 I told you about "I didn't sleep well that night." 16 One of the big issues for me was medically assisted therapy 'cuz I had been resistant to that. 7, 12, 13, 14 I had supported what is still a very important tenet of the traditional viewpoint, and that is we can provide healing through medicine wheel traditional spiritual methods. 6, 9, 12, 14 And I still believe that, but even our traditional spiritual community are very gaetae [unclear] 19 Anishinabe.  Our very conservative, old-line traditional spiritual healing community, has come out in favor of the mom's program and what the MAT [confirm acronym] program is doing. 9, 14, 19 What they have said is, "Now, just so long as you don't do what Western medicine always does, damnit! 12, 14, 17, 18 They always leave us out and think that we're some kind of bizarre, extremist group. 18 And you know, 'blah blah blah blah Western medicine and traditional healing could never work. 12, 14, 16 Our medicine wheel healing works. 9, 12, 14 You Western doctors need to understand that you're pretty good at curing stuff, but curing doesn't last. 10, 12, 14, 17, 18 What we do is heal people. 9 When you guys'll wake up and invite us to join the team, and help to heal, then your curing will last.  And then we'll do some good." 10 We're working on that.  I just got a call from out of the blue from an American Heart Association staff member in Minnesota, who has some American Heart Association regional funding and wanted to put on a conference fro Indian Health Service care providers and happened to call me because they have my name. 14, 15, 18, 19 And, like I always do, and have done for years, I said, "Well you know, there are several things you could do. 12, 14, 18 You know, you do a rapid heart attack response, that' great. 9, 12, 13, 20 You do rapid stroke response, that's great. 13, 20 You teach medical providers how to use a lucus to external compression device. 6, 7, 10, 13, 14 That's great. 20 Why don't you sponsor a healing counsel here and get together Western clinicians and traditional healers and have us all talk together as equals about how we can help with heart health on the reservation here?" 8, 9, 19 And that always ends the conversation. 18 "Ah well yeah, that sounds really nice... and well thank's for the call we appreciate it..." [Sarcastic tone]. 8, 10, 11, 18 But this person said, "You know, let me talk to my boss, but that sounds like a good idea." 10, 12, 18 I got an email back and said, "I talked to the Minnesota AHA vice president here who's in charge, and they said we can do that!" 9, 10 So I turned it over to our cultural director, Merlan Deegan [confirm name] who will follow up with it. 10, 14, 18, 19 But, you know I'm not gonna hold my breath. 12 I've been saying this since about the year 2000. 10, 14 But actually, I know that person professionally, not personally, and when they say they're gonna do something, based on American Heart Association promise, they do it. 7, 12, 13 So, we may actually have that after all these years, and that would be a very important advance here for Western medicine to invite traditional medicine with respect and humility, and listen to what traditional medicine says. 7, 9, 12, 14 And, you don't have time for me to continue on with this, but I was asked by Dennis Hisgun, one of the senior substance abuse counselors here, a traditional Anishinabe and Dakota healer and substance abuse counselor, and you should hear his story! 6, 9, 13, 15 AS: What's his name?  CG: Dennis Hisgun Senior.  H-i-s-g-u-n [spelling], Dennis.  D-E-N-N-I-S [spelling].  He's about almost eighty now. 12 I'll have tell, I'll have to do the abbreviated story. 15 AS: Okay.  CG: But, Dennis asked me to put together a group of essays he could use to work with teenagers in recover to show them that traditional healing as a stature equal in value to Western medicine. 6, 8, 12, 13, 14 And I thought, I said, "Dennis okay I'll do it." 17, 18 And I thought, "Yeah I'll have a few..." 17, 18 By the time I was done I had fifty-two essays!  And I've, I keep a notebook now, and I've collected several other ones since then. 8, 12 I studied for a decade with a traditional healer, Wimba Okan Ogima [confirm name and spelling], he's gone to the star world now. 12, 14 And, when I talk about Western medicine and traditional healing, I always point out to the audience, "Wimab Okan Ogima [confirm name and spelling] came to me at the IHS clinic for Western medicine, and I went to him at his sweat lodge, because we believed it was good to combine the best of traditional medicine and Western medicine. 10, 12, 14, 18 Now, he's gone to the star world and I'm still here so I guess that tells you whose medicine worked best!" 12, 14, 15 [Sullivan and Purchace laughing].  And the audience always falls over laughing. 18 AS: That's great. 20 CG: But, he used to say to me, "You know Gardner, I feel bad for you Western doctors. 6, 12, 13, 14, 16 If you wanna develop a new medicine, you have to spend twenty million dollars to do the research. 10, 12, 14, 16 And then you have to spend forty million dollars to convince the FDA to okay it. 10 All I have to do is ask Creator and the Healing Spirits what to do for my client, and then damn well do it!" 10 And we would laugh about that.  But, then he would also say, "You know the other thing that you need to think about Gardner is you Western doctors joke about placebo effect. 12, 14 You call it lying to the patient, but that's Creator teasing you.  Because what placebo effect really is, is it's the inherent spiritual healing power that Creator has put into a human being. 17, 18, 19 You look at your own Western research.  Often a placebo effect works a third to a half of the time, and you call it lying. 9, 14 It's Creator saying, that there is inherent healing power in a person that can be activated. 17 But Gardner, you Western doctors aren't willing to admit that you have to believe in it for it to work. 12, 14 We believe in it."  And there was just a study that came out in the Western medical literature, I just read about it a month ago, and it talks about what's called "open-label placebo studies." 7, 13, 14, 16 And that's a whole new thing in Western medicine. 12, 14, 16 Western researchers get people into the study and they say, "We're going to do a study on this medicine 'triple crown barbecue sauce.' 9, 12, 14 [Sullivan laughing].  We don't know if it works. 9, 12 It might not work at all.  We don't know, but we'd like to do a study, would you be willing to try it?" 12 That's what they tell people, it's just sugar water. 9, 16 And people say, "Yeah! 9 I'd love to be in your study. 14 You don't know if it's gonna work, have no idea? 12 Not gonna hurt me?"  "Nah it won't hurt you, but we don't have any idea it's gonna work.  We don't have any reason to believe it'll work, but it was suggested and we'd just like to find out."  So, they give it to people and hell it works! 9 A big percentage of the time!
