So, Western researchers are now saying, "Maybe we should be doing open-label placebo studies because when people believe that the sugar water's gonna work, they get better, at a much higher rate than they do if they don't believe that they'll get better!" 7, 9, 12, 16, 17 And so, that's actually happening now in the Western medicine literature. 7, 12, 14, 15 So, okay here's Dennis Hisgun's story. 15 Dennis comes from a family, Anishanabe and Dakota. 12 He had a good stable childhood. 10, 12, 14, 20 Two parent family. 12, 20 I think his dad did farming, ranching. 8, 14 But when Dennis was about thirteen, his dad died in a traumatic accident, and it just broke Dennis' heart and he ended up as a teenager on Franklin avenue in Minneapolis and that's where I grew up- pretty near Franklin Avenue. 8, 9, 10, 13, 14, 20 So, I wonder if Dennis and I ever met each other.  But, Dennis would overdose on various things—whatever drug he could get ahold of. 5, 6 Certainly alcohol, certainly other drugs. 5, 6, 8, 17 And many people up here and over in South Dakota from his Dakota relatives said, "You know, just leave Dennis alone. 8, 9, 12, 18 you know, he doesn't wanna get better. 12 He's never gonna make anything. 16 He'll end up dying in an alley down there, and just leave him alone." 8, 18 But one day, when Dennis came out of old Hennepin General after yet another overdose, there were a few Anishinabe men standing on the sidewalk: "Hi Dennis, we're here to take you home." 9, 12, 14, 16 "I don't know you guys! 12 Leave me alone!" 8 "No, we're taking you home!" 11 "Let go of me!"  "Dennis, we're just like you.  We're trying to stay sober and recover.  And we're gonna, we rented a house on Franklin Avenue. 6, 13 We're gonna do this together." 8 "Well, I don't wanna go with you!  I don't have a job, I can't help!" 11 "That's okay, we'll float you alone Dennis until you're feeling better and can get a job and help us out." 8, 11, 15 So, what're the chances that that would work?  What is one human life worth? 10, 19 What is another chance worth?  Dennis went with 'em cuz there was no HIPPA, he didn't have a choice. 6 They grabbed 'em and they took him.  But it was good. 10 And Dennis got sober.  He thought things over. 17, 18 He had the childhood, and the background, and the support that would help someone to get back into sobriety. 12, 14, 20 And, he made that transition and he stayed there for a while—helped at the house. 6, 13, 17 Then he came back up here, took an EMT class, became an EMT here for a number of years. 7, 14 He was an EMT here and helped save lives, and then he realized that Creator wanted him to be a substance abuse counselor, and so he got that training and became a substance abuse counselor here, and in the intervening more than forty years. 6, 10, 13, 14, 18 He's number one, stayed clean and sober one day at a time. 14, 16 And number two, he has helped thousands of people make a start on the red road of sobriety. 5, 9, 12 You can't get sober for anyone else, but you need someone there to help you when you're ready to make a try.  And Dennis Hisgun Senior is the one, and so when I'm giving a talk and someone raises that, "Ah c'mon Doc what's one life worth?" 8, 10 I tell 'em Dennis' story—I got Dennis' permission. 15 But you would need to get Dennis' permission to tell his story, but he gave me permission to tell it verbally [Amy laughing]. 15 That's his story. 15 If those guys hadn't grabbed him, he probably would have died in an alley.  He will tell you, he had bad active addiction at that time to a number of drugs. 5, 6, 12, 14 But it took, and he dedicated his life to helping other people, and he's now almost eighty. 9, 10, 12, 14 He's still working part-time on the res. 9 He helped the mom's program. 14 He's helped our Oshki Manidoo center in Bemidji.  He's working right now with behavioral health. 12, 15, 19 We're doing regularly scheduled peer support recovery classes. 7 We have tribal certification authority to certify peer support workers, and we do the training, and he's on the team that does the training. 12, 19 So that's what one life is worth. 10 If there hadn't been someone to say, "Wait a second.  We oughta give Dennis another chance.  See if we can help him.  He might do something good with his life." 10 He did, but if someone hadn't of stepped up with harm reduction help—it was homemade, but it was harm reduction SP: 5, 14 That's right! 12 CG: You know Dennis probably would've died in an alley of liver failure and other overdose. 12, 14 So, you need to hear Dennis Hisgun's story. 9, 15 And, you have just heard it from me, but you really should try to talk to him. 9, 18 AS: Oh definitely, definitely. 9 SP: Dennis was at the conference, the harm reduction conference in San Diego, with the mom's program. 5, 14 AS: Oh really? 18 CG: Yeah, I think so.  There's Dennis Jr. his son, who works here. 9 And Dennis Sr. but he's in his late seventies.  SP: Jr… how old is... ?  CG: He's a young looking man!  He doesn't look like he's in his late seventies but he is.  SP: So, that that's the same Dennis that I met.  CG: Yeah, probably.  CG: Yeah so, I love and honor him and wish I had met him many year sooner. 8, 14 But, Dennis' story to me is the story of what one life is worth when you step up with harm reduction help and you don't give up on someone and you offer them yet again, help. 5, 10, 14, 15 SP: Harm reduction is home-grown. 5, 10, 14 CG: Yes, of course!  SP: It's the important piece about it. 9 CG: Of course!  You're right! 12 And I, I knew you'd love the story if you hadn't already heard it, but that's a story that should be heard. 9, 14, 15, 16 And Dennis tells it when he tells his own story, but he hasn't made a big deal out of it. 15 It's never been published anywhere, and if I write it in an article I dub him "Mato," M-A-T-O [spelling], which is the Dakota name for "bear." 8, 16 I don't use his name "Dennis." 6, 13 But I talked to him and he gave me permission to tell his story, so if I tell it like this I use his name. 6, 13, 15 But if I write it, I use the name "Mato," M-A-T-O [spelling]. 6, 13 AS: Okay, Okay.  I think you've already answered my question about your ideas and philosophies about best practices. 5, 18 If there's anything else you wanted to add about that? 18 CG: Best practices here…  AS: Yeah what you've come…  are what we need to do to help our fellow community members to find safer ways of living, and to find hope to heal the underlying generational trauma and adverse childhood experiences so that then they can receive long-term healing of the superficial issue of drug-abuse. 5, 6, 9, 10, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20 Drug-abuse is a superficial issue, but it's a lethal one. 8, 13, 16 But, if you don't offer red-road healing, if you don't offer healing of generational trauma and adverse childhood experiences, then the superficial but lethal problem is going to continue. 5, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20 And, no I can't show you any community here where we have zero drug problem, but we are working very hard to offer healing for the underlying problems and trying to bring that to the front. 5, 6, 9, 12, 19 It's always been in the background, but it hasn't been the front. 18 And all of our tribal public health, behavioral health, harm-reduction, judicial organizations—a couple of years ago we started an adult drug court, we've had a juvenile drug court, restorative justice courts... 5, 6, 11, 13, 14, 15, 19 AS: Is that called the Circle Back Center?  CG: Circle Back is a, is an outpatient recovery maintenance group, therapy program for teens. 11, 12 But, it's connected with the adult drug court DIY—Dually Involved Youth Program—and the juvenile court program. 5, 6 So, they get referrals from juvenile court from the DIY program, and then Circle back can take kids just at their own request of their parents' request with no organizational referrals. 20 AS: Oh, Okay CG: So, we're doing good stuff like that. 10 But we, have been trying since 2013 when we opened the mom's program, to bring to the front the concept that we need to find ways to offer durable medicine wheel healing—physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual—for the underlying wounds of generational trauma and adverse childhood experiences. 6, 12, 14, 18, 20 And, when we do that, then we'll have a platform for effective long-term sobriety. 12, 17 So, those are the things in general that I think all our divisions and departments are working on, and we have a program that we call the Drug Task Force. 6, 9, 12, 19 Has Clinton told you about that? 16 SP: I don't think so.  CG: What the tribe declared a drug abuse emergency in 2011, or 2012—just around the time that I had my three month retirement and started working here—but shortly after the declaration the tribal council established the Drug Task Force. 5, 6, 12, 13, 14, 16, 18, 19 It is not a police group. 8 It's a group where representatives of every division and every department get together and meet once a month, sit down at the table in the administration building—the big table—we all sit there and say, "So what problems are we seeing in our community now related to drug abuse? 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 16, 18, 19 What are the wounds?  What is the healing that's needed?  How can our programs work together across department and divisional boundaries to make things work?" 6, 8, 9, 12, 19 And certainly that was one of the motivations for getting the mom's program going, 'cuz it was that table where Tara Mason said, "I want it open by June." 8, 14, 17 And walked out of the meeting. 16, 18 It was a Drug Task Force meeting. 18 So, a number of our other programs in recent years have been based on that, and the cultural division director is the facilitator of that meeting, which is really good—Mike Larak [confirm name and spelling]. 6, 10, 13, 14, 18, 19 The police chief comes, representatives from drug court come—from substance abuse, from behavioral health, from tribal health, from harm reduction—but it's the cultural director of our nation that is the facilitator, Merlon Deegan [confirm name and spelling]. 5, 6, 8, 10, 13, 14, 15, 18, 19 You should talk to him too.  D-E-E-G-A-N [spelling], Merlan.  He is a former cop, he's a former tribal policeman, who has traditional healing training in both Ojibwe and Dakota traditional healing. 8, 19 He's a nephew of Dennis Hisgun Sr. So there's a story there. 15 And so Merlan is our cultural director, and he chairs that committee to help us all keep on task and focus on the fact that we need to provide medicine wheel healing for the underlying wounds of our people if we want to establish successful long-term sobriety strategies here. 8, 9, 12, 14, 17, 18, 19 AS: Do you feel hopeful? 9 CG: Yes.  Very much so.  AS: About the opioid epidemic? 13 CG: I do, but I don't feel hopeful for any quick-fix solutions. 9 What we need is the work of the Drug Task Force, the work of the mom's program, the work of our MAT program, the work of our traditional cultural division. 6, 14 Merlan has spent a number of years struggling to work with a consultant, Roxanne Delille. 14 She's a PhD level educator and an medaywan [unclear] woman, who works at Fond 9, 14, 16 Du Lac College.  And, she has been working with Merlan an a group of us, a work group, to develop a new employee orientation program. 16 And as it stands now it's three four hours segments, that talks about the cultural history, the spiritual history, the history that the conquerers got all wrong, the history of work the White Earth nation has done to help its community members, and to help others, and the last section is being completed. 7, 11, 12, 15, 19 And Merlan's hope with the support of our reservation business committee is that every new employee will get to sit in those sessions, and learn that history of "Gawa ba be banicka" [Speaking in Ojibwe] [Unclear. 9, 10, 15, 16, 19 Confirm words for translation.]— "the land of abundant white clay"—its history, its culture, a little bit about its language, its spiritual traditions. 15, 17, 19, 20 And, how they relate to issues today like drug abuse and like public health work, and human services work, and... 5, 6, 12, 13, 16, 19 Being a transportation bus driver! 5, 17 Being a child care worker! 14, 19 Being a whatever!  Everybody's gonna get that.  And, a commitment's been made to have all current employees attend that training too. 12 So, that's a big deal for us.  And that's work that Merlan has helped to keep on the front burner, and not to be forgotten about.  Because that's part of that, you have to deal with the underlying issues. 9, 12, 13 And, you have to acknowledge the hope that Anishinabe people have always had, but has often been distracted from by issues of colonization, issues of internalized oppression, issues of discrimination, etcetera, etcetera, etcetera.. 9, 10, 12, 13, 18 You know those lectures and that's not why you came here, but I will tell you two acknowledge phrases that you don't need to learn but you should know about. 10, 12 One of them is, "Gaween..." [Speaking in Ojibwe] [unclear.  Confirm words for translation.] 17 It took me a long time to learn that. 10, 17 I am not a fluent speaker, I've worked very hard to learn that, and here's why. 9, 10 Do you know what that means in English? 12 This is what it means in English: "You cannot destroy one who has dreamed a dream like mine." 5 So, even if you don't ever learn any other Ojibwe, that's what you need to know as our working policy here, and not everybody can say that. 10, 12 I've worked hard to learn how to say that. " 9, 10 Gaween......" [Speaking in Ojibwe] [Unclear.  Confirm words for translation.] 17 "You cannot destroy one who has dreamed a dream like mine." 5 And the "you," is not Amy Sullivan or Sue Purchase, the "you" is the life. 10 Okay?  "You cannot destroy me life. 10 You cannot destroy one who has dreamed a dream like mine." 5 That is, an ancient Ojibwe saying from [unclear]  Memorial.  It applies right now to the drug abuse crisis. 5, 6, 12, 13 And, we're working on using that in our work here. 6 The other thing you need to hear is this one. 8, 9 This is from Roxanne Delille, who's helping with the employee orientation program.  She taught us this one. 8 I call these two sayings the "Gaweens" [Ojibwe.  Confirm spelling of word for translation.] 17 This one starts out with Gaween. 8 "Gaween...." [Speaking in Ojibwe] [unclear.  Confirm words for translation.] 17 Also took me a while to learn that! 10 What that means in English is, "It is not without reason that I do this."  That is another Anishinabe saying.  "Oh geez, oh why did they burn that sage, I always think that smells like weed, you know? 12, 18, 20 'Joe!  Look at putting down tobacco by a tree and there's food in that plane.  That must be some aberration!" "Gawenn..." [Speaking in Ojibwe] [unclear.  Confirm words for translation.] 17 It is not without reason that I do this.  Merlan can explain, I can explain a little, Roxanne can explain, his team can explain, many of us who have learned can explain. 10, 20 There's a reason.  A healing powerful reason, for each and every ceremonial thing we do here. 10, 17 And, I have to tell you this about smudging, this isn't why you came here, but we smudge a lot.  Harm Reduction smudges a lot. 14 You probably know that. 12 Did you know that there are only 400 nerve receptor endings in the human nose for sense of smell? 12, 19 They're on a little piece of mucosa, about the size of a postage stamp in the back of the nose, 400! 20 You've got hundreds of billions of neurons! 5 I mean 400, that can't be very important. 9 Those 400 receptors are like a 400 character password.  They can recognize more than a trillion different individual inputs, and those sense of smell receptor nerve endings are the only nerve endings in the entire human body that go straight into the brain. 13, 17, 19 They don't go to the spinal cord, they go straight into the brain. 13 And do you know where they go? 12 They go right into the limbic system, the amygdala, the hippocampus, the part that's damaged by drug abuse and needs healing. 5, 6, 9, 12, 13 And, do you know that Western researchers have discovered that human beings who can be given a brief meditational routine that helps to center them on healing thoughts will do much better in recovery, but it's very hard because in our text messaging, and phones, and blogs... 5, 8, 9, 12, 16, 17, 18, 19 it's very hard to get people to do that. 9 That's what smudging does.  The Anishinabe "Seven Fires" prophecy, more than a thousand years ago, actually warned the Anishinabe that drug abuse was coming, and said that there would be something to help. 5, 6, 7, 13, 14 Smudging is a direct line into the human amygdala, to remind our brain centers of, "Gaween..." [Speaking in Ojibwe] [Unclear. 5, 9, 13, 18, 19 Confirm words for translation] 17 So we smudge here.  "Gaween..." [Speaking in Ojibwe] [Unclear.  Confirm words for translation] 17 "It is not without reason that we do this."  It's part of our hope. 9 So, that's my own eccentric version...  AS: No I don't think it's eccentric.  CG: ...but I'm pretty sure that people who are not as eccentric as I am, will agree with that. 9, 10 And that's one of my essays, in my group of essays that I gave to Dennis Hisgun, is don't laugh about smudging.  Let me tell you about human physiology, neuroanatomy and how it works. 9, 19 Smudging really works! 9, 18 AS: Will you share some of those with me?  The essays?  Are they ones that you've written? 8 CG: Yes.  AS: Oh, oh okay.  They're not, you aren't collecting research.  CG: Nope!  Here's the deal, I got tired of not admitting that I had written them. 5 I gave 'em to Dennis, but I wrote 'em and so...  AS: Ah, [laughing] the truth comes out!  CG: You can go on to Barnes and Noble, or SmashWords, and you can type in Carson Gardner, and you will see an ebook on a reinterpretation of the Dao De Jing... 6, 10 AS: Oh wow. 17 CG: And you will see an ebook of very eccentric sonnets, and then you will see an ebook of essays. 6 And, I have probably sold ten, so I am not marketing, and I don't give a damn whether you look at 'em or not. 5 But, if you wanna read them you can get access to 'em, 'cuz I got tired of not sharing them. 5, 9, 18 And, I decided well, I'll put em in an ebook and then I'll die. 14 And, after that people will actually look at it. 7, 9 So, I'm hoping to become a famous dead poet and a famous dead essayist! 16 [Sullivan laughing.]  So, the fact that they're available is just a way for you to look at 'em, otherwise if you want a totally free copy instead of spending four or five bucks... 10, 18 AS: No I'll buy it.  CG: I'll email it to you from home.  AS: No, it's okay.  I'll buy it and then you can say you've sold eleven!  CG: I have no desire in making money but, the whole fifty-two that are in there as eccentric as they are and I, you know, there's nothing off color or intolerable, but it will take you down a path that Western Historians don't often go down. 8, 10, 12 But I'll stand by everything I put in there.  SP: You mentioned they're on Amazon, what's the other one? 8, 12 CG: They're not on Amazon they're on Barnes & Noble.  AS: Barnes & Noble.  SP: Barnes & Noble.  CG: Amazon requires that as an ebook author you have to sell 2,000 dollars worth of ebook before they'll even put it on Amazon. If it sells we want ten percent of your profits." 15 That's pretty reasonable. 10 And so, that couple is making a decent living on that, most of us never sell anything. 10, 11, 14, 16 You know, Grandma buys one, our cousin whose always liked our poems buys one, and nobody else does. 12, 18 But, they do it free, and they still do it free.  Costs you nothing except the rigamarole of getting the electronic text right. 10, 12 But they buy their groceries because 5-10% of their authors actually sell a bunch of copies, and so then they get paid. 7 AS: That's great. 20 SP: I'll have to check it out CG: Yeah, yeah, you get on SmashWords, you can get it somewhere else. Bring it in for a landing Clinton!"  So, you can tell Clinton I warned you. CG: Clinton will have some pretty good ideas about the rates. 10, 18 The IHS Clinic of course is reticent to just hand us information like that, but they do keep records, and Clinton is working with their new public health doctor. 12, 14, 16, 19 They hired a new public health doctor, that's a physician with a masters in public health. 5, 12, 14, 16, 19 Who has interest in things like PREP for people at risk of HIV and Hepatitis C treatment. 9, 12, 13 You know Clinton in harm reduction has developed a consulting relationship with, I think a Twin cities hepatologist, who is providing low cost Hepatits C care here. 5, 7, 10, 12, 14, 19 So i'm pretty sure Clinton can tell you stats. 10 But I don't know if he has full access to all the IHS statistics. 9, 12, 14 He might though...
