Tends not to have such a good success rate. 10 [laughs] 15 That was the first category. 14 That was the number one.  The next category was beauty salon operator, floral designer. 11 I had no idea I was gay! 9 [laughs] 15 Stereotyping; don’t take that personally!  I don’t feel that way, but what I thought at the time was, Great! 17, 18 I’m not a drug addict. 5, 6, 14 I’ve got kids, how am I going to provide for them.  In that same grouping was psychologist, counselor.  AS: Right.  Someone that works with people. 9 CH: Someone that works with people. 9 I thought, I’m already in on this whole drug addict thing. 5, 6, 14, 17, 18 It was believed that most counselors at that point -- historically we know differently -- were people in recovery and that you needed to be in recovery to be effective. 9, 12, 14 The whole idea that one addict helping another addict, which is very effective. 14 I said, I’ll do the chemical dependence counseling thing. 13, 14, 19 At that point it was a two-year program at Inver Hills [Inver Grove Heights, Minnesota]. 14 I went and got signed up at Inver Hills, I took the tests, and I only scored a couple that were over the one hundred -- I had to take a few remedial math class, but other than that everything was over one hundred, which wasn’t bad considering eighteen to thirty-one I hadn’t had an education. 5, 7, 9, 11, 14, 15 They said to take classes that you like so you can have some time to get used to college. 6, 7, 13, 14, 16 Take a class that you like and that you think you’ll do well at. 7 I took creative problem solving for one and I took a writing one because I have always had a flare and a knack for writing, and then I took a math class that was like introduction to algebra or something. 7, 12, 14, 18 For some reason I don’t have a mind that things algebraically.  I’m not a linear sequential person. 9 I think very geometrically and am more spatial.  Those things just make sense to me.  Algebra just doesn’t work.  My first day of my first class -- I am thirty-one years old -- this is January 3, 1996. 7, 14, 16 I am all of ninety days sober at that point. 16 You think a guy would be comfortable for all the things he has been through.  I was totally insecure.  I’m going to be the old guy in the community college school with the kids who couldn’t get into the good colleges go! 7, 10, 14, 19 That’s not true, but that’s what I’m thinking. 5 I walk into class and there were only a couple of people in there. 7, 9, 11, 16 There were two that looked like they were nineteen or twenty, and there was a woman who looked to be about my age so I went and sat by her.  I did and that was my introduction to college. 7, 14 The college went really well. 7, 18 The woman that I sat next to is now my wife. 12, 20 AS: Honestly? 8 Oh my gosh.  I had a feeling you were going to say that. 15 CH: It was the creative problem solving class and it worked really well for me. 7, 12, 18 I took it because it was fun, it would be interesting, and I had a knack for it. 17 My now wife took it because it fulfilled criteria in two core areas and therefore it would mean she would have to take one less class. 5, 7, 8, 12, 14, 20 That is about all you need to know about her and I to understand the nature of our relationship. 12, 17, 18, 19 She was actually going into marketing and advertising. 5, 7 I obviously had just come out of that among other things.  She liked the books from the classes I was taking. 7, 11 She never considered social work. 5, 9, 16, 19 I was going to school and decided I was going to -- because I have to have a plan -- I was going to get a two year degree, become a chemical dependency counselor while I finish my four year degree with a bachelors in social work. 7, 13, 14, 19 Did my master’s in social work so I could be an LICSW [licensed individual clinical social worker]. 13, 19 I had this eight-year plan lined up. 9, 14 She liked my classes so much and had never considered being a social worker that she flipped her classes. 5, 7, 9, 14, 16, 19 She was going to school because she had been laid off and had a package from her employer to go to school. 7 She is an LICSW now, which I never got because I ended up in administration. 12, 16 She jokes because she says, You knew you would always have LICSW after your name, you just didn’t know it would say, Mrs. 12, 16, 18 Charles Hilger, LICSW.  [laughs] 15 AS: Did you finish your alcohol and drug -- CH: I did. 5, 6 I finished my two years and I did have a knack for it. 14 It was daunting because the professor would be like, Oh you’re the -- it was unfair. 9 I remember I was telling my therapist about it and she’s like, Oh, you’re the superstar? 15, 16 I don’t know what that means, but it stuck with me. 12 I was taking these classes and getting As in these classes. 7, 11 I was thinking, These teachers are dumb because I can’t be this smart.  AS: Right.  You are still in that mindset.  CH: Over time it bears out and I graduated after two years. 7, 14 I had taken a job as a tech in a halfway house overnight so I could study. 6, 11, 13, 14, 18 I always give my wife a hard time because I say, I was thirty-one years old, three months sober, no driver’s license, no vehicle, living downstairs in my parents’ duplex with my dad driving me back and forth to school, with a job -- don’t take this the wrong way -- I was monitoring security alarms overnight and usually when we met, if your alarm goes off at your house I’m the one that calls the police. 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11, 13, 14, 16, 18, 20 It was like for seven or eight bucks an hour. 15 Is that like a good social experiment, or what? 10, 12, 19 I have no idea.  Oh, this will be fun!  Let’s see where this goes. 6 I mean, what was she thinking.  [laughs] 15 I finish my two years. 14 She had taken a job at detox as a tech, I had taken a job at Cochlear Programs and they happen to be next to each other. 11, 15, 19 I worked for a year as a tech while I was going to school. 7, 14 They hired me the day I graduated to start detox as a counselor. 5, 7, 16, 19 I worked at detox for six years, which was a great experience. 14, 18, 19, 20 I saw about a thousand patients a year. 14 That’s a lot of patients over six years to assessments with. 12, 13, 14 I continued and did my bachelor’s degree in social work. 19 We moved in together in ‘97 and got married in 2002. 7, 8, 15 We blended our families. 17 She has a son that is the same age as mine.  Our sons are just six months apart. 9, 11, 16 They were fast friends at the age of seven when they met and they are still fast friends. 16, 20 I was finishing up my bachelor’s at University of Wisconsin River Falls where Kinnic Falls campus is located.  No irony left on me there. 14 I still go back there every semester and talk to their class. 7 AS: Talk to which class? 7 CH: Use, abuse, and addiction. 6, 12, 13, 14 About harm reduction services. 5, 14, 19 I went into working with opiate addiction. 12, 14 My wife and I worked side by side as counselors for about two of the years of detox after I became a counselor and she became a counselor. 9, 14, 19, 20 She did that for like two years and then we finished our BSW and she wanted to do something else. 14, 18 She went off and did a couple other things and ended up working in a methadone clinic at some point and said to me, This is great because you have patients for two years. 11, 14, 20 If we are going to LICSWs this most looks like the therapeutic model where you have these patients engaged in mental health care and counseling for a long time. 12, 17, 19 It’s a great training ground because you have the same fifty patients. 20 I applied to that company as well and I went to a different location than where she was at. 14 I started working in 2003.  I was a counselor for a year. 14 The company was a national one and they didn’t have a lot of leadership or strength here. 8, 14 The treatment director resigned and I applied for the position. 11, 12, 13, 18, 19 It was three counselors in the clinic -- it was a small clinic.  I think there were 150 patients in the clinic at that time.  I took over as the treatment director. 12, 13, 18, 19 CH: Dakota Metro.  AS: In the Twin Cities?  CH: Yeah, down in Burnsville.  AS: It is a methadone clinic? 6, 8 CH: It is a methadone clinic owned by a management group. 12 I don’t want to be disparaging towards them.  AS: What year is this? 14 In 2004 I was a counselor.  In 2004 I took over as the treatment director. 12, 13, 18, 19 I made a few changes and the clinic took off. 6 I had to double the size of the clinic.  We just did really well. 18 I was fortunate enough to find a few really solid staff members, enough people that knew enough about the treatment modality that I didn’t know yet like the pharmacy and the nursing piece. 9, 12, 13, 16, 18 I used the medical model because I worked in detox before. 6, 7, 13, 14, 16, 19 I do have my license back by this point. 13 [laughs] 15 In the spring of ‘96 Brownie, my wife, gave me the money to pay to take my test and get my license back. 8, 10, 13, 20 She was tired of driving me around. 5, 14 My dad gave up the job he was like, You got it now! 11, 12, 14 The clinic took off and we did really well. 18 I got a call from a friend of mine I knew from the state. 16, 20 I knew him from working at detox next door. 16, 19 He was like, Hey, just so you know another national company is sniffing around Minnesota looking to open clinics. 12, 14 I notified my boss and he notified the CEO and he called me and said, The only way to stop this is to open up more clinics and I want you to do a footprint, get you boots on the ground -- you know Minnesota better than anybody -- and tell me where to put three clinics. 12, 18 Give me three locations.  I worked that out and figured it out with my process and about a year after I became treatment director and I had put this proposal together and my regional director resigned. 5, 8, 11, 12, 13, 14, 17, 18, 19 He was a man I have tremendous amount of respect for and is an amazing individual, great boss, one of the best people I have ever worked with. 9, 12, 20 I was sorry to see him go. 6 It was between me and another guy for the regional director because two of us applied for that position. 18, 19 I had kind of done that groundwork for the clinic.  The CEO knew what I could do but the other guy applied and he had been there longer. 16, 17 In fact, he was the guy that hired me, and I got the job. 5, 11 He hired me as a counselor, then we were peers, and then I got hired. 5, 14 I found out he didn’t know how to run a clinic and I had to terminate him. 8, 12, 17 Terminating the guy that hires you is not fun.  I opened up two methadone clinics for them here in the state. 14 We never did open the third one. 8, 16 AS: Was that Valhalla?  CH: No that would be St.  Cloud Metro and Rochester Metro.  For five years 14 I had seven clinics in Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Indiana.  In that time, because it is a national company I got to work with Dr. Thomas Payte since the late sixties, you look at the tip forty-three, which has all the ‘this is how you do methadone.’ 6, 8, 14 He is one of the authors.  He is one of the top ten in the field.  When they point to the elders he is one of them.  He knew the people that pioneered methadone. 5, 8, 9, 16 Doctors Dole and Niswane.  Just an amazing physician. 9 He has a heart for patients and a realistic approach and view of methadone. 9 I got to work under him for five years. 14 The company I was working for didn’t allow for things like additional care like mental health. 10, 12, 14, 19 I was working on my master’s degree for mental health so I really had a penchant for that. 12, 18, 19 They thought it was a good idea but it wasn’t baked into their model. 10, 17, 18 If you add in mental health you end up reducing your profit. 5, 12, 14, 15, 19 They didn’t want to do that.  It was their model.  AS: Because it was just maintenance?  CH: They had all the licensed drug and alcohol counselors, right. 5, 6, 12, 13 When you try to start bringing in higher cost therapists AS: ...let’s treat that problem that you keep talking about. 7, 12, 17 I see. 6 CH: The man I worked for was very difficult to work for. 10 People are surprised that I worked for the five years that I did. 14 Eventually we agreed to disagree on the topic of patient care and I elected to leave. 18, 19 I figured I was finishing my MSW and I needed my hours so I would go work at House of Charity in downtown Minneapolis for a person who used to be a treatment director. 5, 6, 12, 13, 15, 16, 18, 19 I work for her now. 12 We always got along great. 17, 18, 20 I was never one to be caught up on [1. 38.59]. 16 Let’s just get the job done and do it right. 11, 12 I started working at House of Charity, which is a group-housing unit with service for mental health, CD [chemical dependency] services, the whole nine yards. 6, 12, 13, 19 We were doing groups. 12 Can’t do mental health yet, at that point, but I’m doing groups. 12, 19 I have all the methadone patients on the side because that’s what I do on the side. 9 I am taking on consulting jobs so I’m doing some consulting for Valhalla, which is a relatively new MAT [medically assisted treatment] program at that point. 7, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16 My friend at House of Charity quit and they offered me the treatment director job. 5, 6, 11, 12, 13, 18, 19, 20 If I take the treatment director job I’m never going to get my hours for my LICSW. 11, 12, 13, 15, 16, 18, 19 I was just finishing my master’s at that point.  I got to the point at St. Thomas [St. Paul, Minnesota] where I was finishing my master’s degree, it has a clinical focus, but I did the two-year program. 14 I was in year five of the two year program when my advisor who I had never talked to before called me in and said, You will not be the first person to take my two year program and turn it into a six year program -- this was in March -- You have until the end of the semester to finish or we are going to wash you out and you cannot return. 14, 16 I had all the research, I had all the data, and it was just a matter of getting it written. 13 I tend to be a bit of a perfectionist. 17, 20 I finished it.  I was consulting with Valhalla and when they found out I had this treatment director job they were like, We could use you here if you are interested in leaving that job. 6, 11, 12, 13, 18, 19 They were getting ready for their first accreditation. 5, 14 I told them I would work for them although I had a five-year noncompete with my other employer so I had to be a counselor, I couldn’t do anything else. 14, 16 I was a counselor that was writing policy procedures manual.  And I had a [unclear].  At that point I was the eighth employee hired. 5 My wife had left that other methadone treatment program and opened a locked CD treatment program for people that were committed down in Hastings and the Cochran Programs. 6, 8, 9, 12, 13, 14, 20 She moved to Valhalla as a counselor. 7, 15 This was the third company we had worked for together, which works for us. 8, 9, 14 Valhalla was owned by a person that was on a methadone treatment program. 12, 13 The company that I used to work for -- I didn’t know him -- but he wasn’t happy with the way he was treated so he established Valhalla in a way that was a place that I would want to go to and I would want to be treated in terms of how counseling is handled, how insurance is handled, how medical services are handled. 6, 7, 12, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18, 19 His idea was a much broader approach.  My only piece when I went to Valhalla was,  It is fine but we have to do mental health care. 11, 12, 19 I won’t do this unless we do mental health, thinking at some point I might get my hours in. 12, 15, 19 [laughs] 15 They agreed to that.  I was the eighth employee.  We had one hundred and fifty patients and that was October of 2009.  Through a whole series of things like the increase in the opiate epidemic, someone who knew how to do marketing, the expansion of services into mental health. 5, 12, 13, 16, 19 We took that clinic from one hundred and fifty to one thousand active patients in just three years, which means we are hiring a counselor every six weeks. 14, 15 It is crazy to think what we went through. 20 We opened a second location in Brooklyn Park, Minnesota, and transferred like one hundred and fifty patients because they were actually closer to that location, and the company was sold last June when we had about 2,300 patients in 2016. 5, 7, 9, 10, 14, 17 We integrated mental health services so that patients coming in would get a mental health diagnostic assessment in addition to the regular counseling services. 12, 13, 19 We had full time nurse practitioners and physician's assistants and doctors that are on site most of the day and most of the days. 8, 12, 14, 16 Just a whole different level of care. 19 We had expanded Valhalla Place to add a medical clinic that you couldn’t do certain things from the treatment program to provide better and consistent medical care to patients with persisting issues besides do the physicals and the annual physicals. 6, 7, 9, 12, 13, 14, 17, 19 That was really huge. 18 It has been amazing. 9 I never did go and get my hours. 15, 16 I actually never sat for the licensed social worker test that you sit after you’ve finished your master’s. 7, 13, 16, 19 In a short time in Valhalla I moved from counselor to treatment director to executive director. 7, 12, 13, 14, 15, 18, 19 They tried to come after me for the noncompete, but it’s pretty difficult when that’s what a person does for a living; for their career. 10, 14, 15, 19 It would have been an uphill battle for them.  It is a different model and I’m not using what I learned there. 6, 10 I’m using what I knew what I wanted to do and it fit with what the owners wanted. 6, 15, 16, 18 AS: The pursuit of your interest in counseling led you to change the model in a methadone clinic setting that actually has improved patient outcomes? 6, 7, 8, 14, 19 Was that a new model for Minnesota to have the mental health aspect integrated? 12, 16, 19 CH: There are other people that have done integrated mental health models. 9, 12, 19 It really depends on the philosophy and the approach. 15, 18 Many of them are in larger mental health centers and medical centers. 7, 12, 14, 19 They are driven by a medical model. 5, 7, 14 Instead of being patient centered it is really about, This is our program and this is what our physicians do. 5, 18 It is not guided by the patient and if the patient is or isn’t progressing through treatment. 12, 13 Is their quality of life stable? 10, 12 Are they looking for something better?  Can we help them improve that if they want to?  Is this as good as it gets and we need to be okay with that? 10 A lot of the patients we have at Valhalla and a lot of the initial growth were patients that have been on a clinic tour for years because they would spend three years at a clinic, they wouldn’t get the results that the clinic expected, they would kick them out, they would go to the next clinic. 6, 10, 14 Wanting to grow, people are always taking patients even though they know -- they think it’s going to be different or whatever. 9, 10, 11, 12, 18 With the mental health patient in tact we can take the more challenging patient and we can work with them. 12, 19 We don’t say that this is going to get that much better.  You’ve been in four methadone programs in the last two years and it hasn’t gotten any better. 14 You’ve been through eight inpatient treatments, three outpatient treatments, four group residential housing. 6, 9, 11, 12, 13 Why do you think if we provide you with methadone it is going to be any different?  We fight for stabilization.  Let’s not expect more than what it is going to be.  There is a percentage of the population that just kept doing a clinic shuffle.  Mental health issues kept getting in the way and they do fine for a while and then they have a manic episode and they go off and do something silly. 11, 12, 13, 18, 19 They would sell their doses or whatever and then no one wants to deal with them. 8 Just developing that and being able to do the medical care. 7, 14, 19 Now the patient is more invested in the program that they know they can go to where they say methadone and they know the provider is not going to roll their eyes or say, I’m not going to prescribe you any pain medications. 6, 10, 12, 14 AS: It is destigmatized. 9 It is completely destigmatized. 9 People don’t tend to move away as much from our programs. 15, 18, 20 When you look at our numbers ninety percent of patients that have been on the program for a year are free of any illicit opiate use. 6, 13, 14 AS: For one year? 14 CH: Not for one year. 14 At one year. 14 When you do the measurement, ninety percent are testing negative for any illicit substances. 6, 12 Seventy percent test free of any elicit substances. 6 Between the seventy and the ninety mark is predominantly people who continue to use THC [tetrahydrocannabinol]. 5, 6, 9, 10, 13 I’m not going to put someone out, but is this something that is interfering with your quality of life? 10 Do you want to change it because it is illegal?  You might get drug tested at your job? 5, 6, 11 If those things aren’t an issue -- AS: 13 You don’t kick them out of the program.  CH: No, I’m not going to kick them out of the program.  Anyway, it is still ultimately their choice to make. 6, 18 The funder at some point may say, If you continue to stay positive you’re going to do -- we offer high intensity outpatient treatment, which is a twelve week program for five days a week, three hours at a time for twelve weeks for people that have more challenges making the changes they have to make. 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 15, 16 There is no reason to add the outpatient element. 11, 12 Some of them just want to go to in order to get the stability.  The outpatient piece has been critical. 11 The counselors get more training than they ever did, but they still don’t have the depth of knowledge that licensed mental health professionals have. 12, 13, 19 They are teaming up to work with this patient and figure out what needs to happen. 15 It has been a fascinating journey.  The pieces that made the biggest difference were the things that weren’t supposed to -- certainly there is serendipity that has come into play with the church thing and a couple of other things, but the right place at the right time, everything happens for a reason, whatever you make peace with or you look at it. 8, 11, 12, 14, 15, 17 I was the person that was cornered in for treatment, which we all know never works. 5, 9, 12, 13, 16 I thought that was kind of funny. 9, 17, 18 AS: It didn’t work right away. 12, 18, 20 CH: The Road Less Travelled was a book that I picked out for a guy that had been my roommate at the treatment center. 12, 13, 14 We went down to the library and I picked it out for him and I said,  You’ve got to read this because I think this is what you’re looking for.  [laughs] 15 He elected to leave the halfway house, so he left it on my desk. 6, 13, 14, 18 He said, Would you mind returning this? 20 It is the only reason I read it.  There are a number of those very crystallized moments where I’m like, That was weird. 8, 12, 14 Getting into school, therapy was huge, the mental health piece, the treatment piece was huge. 7, 12, 13, 19 My twelve-step piece was critical as well.  I did CA groups as well, cocaine anonymous groups, for two years at ADAP. 12, 14, 16 I would still go back frequently probably for three years. 14 Eventually I stopped going and haven’t been going for years. 14 Doing harm reduction strategies, we do syringe exchange, we distribution of Narcan and training for Narcan across the state. 5, 10, 14 The numbers that were coming back for 2016 it looks like more than twenty-five percent of the kits that we distribute are being used to reverse overdoses. 6, 13, 16 Huge numbers.  We distributed over two thousand last year. 14 Five hundred reversals out of those two thousand kits.  Watching people go through recovery over the years, people that I still see today that we on my original fifty case load in 2003 -- I always joke that you never forget your first fifty. 6, 9, 14, 16, 17, 18 I’ve certainly lost patients over the years. 8, 11, 14, 17 My belief in the dogmatic approach to recovery, you know the ‘once an addict always an addict’ just doesn’t apply. 12, 14, 18 There are people that it is never safe for them to go back to using. 6, 9, 16 Using anything, using something. 6 People have different physiologies, they respond differently with chemicals. 13 I had a bad accident in 2000 and they sent me home after five days in the hospital. 5, 8, 13, 16 I had a broken collarbone, five broken ribs, and a punctured lung. 5, 8 They sent me home with Dilaudid, and all this stuff I had been listening to people saying were great drugs. 5, 6, 9, 20 I took them with a little bit of, I need to get rid of this pain, and a little bit of anticipation. 6, 20 I don’t get it.  I am a go fast guy.  Thank God they don’t treat those things with cocaine because it would have been a different story. 15, 16 [laughs] 15 It would not have worked out too well.  I believe that our mindset that because someone has problems at some point in their life with alcohol or drugs does not mean that they cannot ever use again. 5, 6, 10, 12, 13 I would be irresponsible if I ran around saying that everybody should find out if it was just a phase. 16 I would never do that. 16 Several years ago I made the conscious decision that drinking at this point in my life would be okay for me. 5, 10, 11, 13, 14 Two and a half years into it I consumed it socially, and I have never gotten any problems because of drinking. 5, 11, 12, 14, 16, 19 AS: You still have your license. 13 CH: I still have my license. 13 [laughs] 15 My methadone piece when I do the eight hour MAT 101 and I kind of roll this out slowly in the presentation but I still have narcolepsy and at age thirty-five it started to get bad to the point where I was counseling in my first year at MAT and I was starting to have problems staying awake with patients, which doesn’t convey any positive regard. 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 12, 14, 15, 19 They were like, Chuck, come on.  The good part is coming. 9, 10 Is your dose okay?  Are you nodding?  Do my pupils look small?  I went to the doctor because they told me it wouldn’t get any worse. 12, 14, 16 He told me I was just getting older so the effects are more pronounced. 16, 20 Thanks.  That’s getting worse.  I don’t care how you sort it, that’s getting worse. 19 Despite the fact that based on the twelve-step philosophy that taking any stimulants -- because stimulants are my drug of choice -- is a slippery slope, then ultimately is going to lead back to regular use and or abuse or addiction, ultimately addiction and jails or those types of institutions, if not death, I elected that I did not want to sit at home and be on Social Security because I cannot drive my car because I cannot stay awake behind the wheel, which is what ultimately could have happened. 5, 6, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 18 I elected to take the risk and take stimulants.  I am fifty-two and I have been on stimulants for -- I joke and say the only time I ever abused them was the morning I had four ibuprofen in one hand and four of my ten milligram Ritalins for the day. 6, 13, 16 Instead of taking the four Ibuprofen I took the four Ritilin. 11 That morning went by really fast. 18 Other than that I have never abused it. 6, 13, 16 I have never taken it in excess and it allows me to function. 9, 10, 16 Here I am now, here I am a person taking a kissing cousin to my drug of choice. 5, 6, 11, 12 People abuse Ritilin; it is a stimulant. 6, 13 Stimulants are my drug of choice but I take them to maintain functioning so that I can do what I need to do. 5, 6, 9 Without it I wouldn’t be able to do that and it would definitely have a negative impact on my quality of life. 9, 10 Yet, my patients that take methadone, and nobody ever questions whether I’m sober or not. 6, 8 When I started drinking and I did tell a few of the guys that have been in long-term sobriety with me -- and I still consider myself in recovery and long term sobriety and recovery -- that I had made the decision, because I didn’t want to keep any secrets, we were talking about, Oh you’ve got so much time and I said, Well, I’m not counting alcohol anymore. 5, 6, 9, 11, 12, 14, 17 They were like, What do you mean you aren’t counting alcohol? 6 I was like, Well, six months ago I decided it wasn’t an issue for me. 11, 13, 14, 16 I’m not sober from alcohol anymore. 6 They threw me out of the damn club because now I wasn’t really an addict. 12, 14, 18 Now I’m not really a person in recovery because nobody can do that. 18 Nobody could ever go through a phase in their life where they used alcohol or another drug as a maladaptive coping mechanism, and then at some point later in their life go back to use at a regular level. 5, 6, 10, 13, 16 They would say, You were never an alcoholic anyway. 6, 16, 18 To go back to the methadone thing my patients taking the kissing cousin to their drug of choice in order to function on a daily basis -- it can be abused -- some of our patients do abuse that, they mix it with other medications, they do it in order to get an effect. 5, 6, 8, 9, 11, 13, 14, 16 The vast majority, eighty percent of the patients don’t do that and it works just fine. 9, 11, 18 Fifteen years ago even to say that out loud it could put your whole career into jeopardy. 13, 14, 15, 19 I actually work it into the eight-hour medication assisted treatment -- AS: To say what out loud? 7, 12, 13, 14, 15 CH: To say that people could return to normal, social consumption drug of choice, perhaps without the same outcome or the same consequences. 5, 6, 9, 16, 19 AS: Even something like an opioid? 13 CH: Even something like an opioid. 13 An opioid is just another drug. 5, 6, 13 It affects a different area of the brain and it is a very primary area that is part of our reward circuitry for sure. 8, 9, 13, 14, 19 It is part of our survival function; it ties into all those pieces. 9 But, to say that a person, and certainly we have evidence of this, I don’t know if people that are going to go back and try to start using -- I’m not going to go back and start using cocaine recreationally. 6, 8, 9, 12, 16, 17 Alcohol fits more into the social strata. 15, 19 AS: I’m thinking heroin. 16 Some people are using it socially, at first, but then they get hooked. 6, 9, 14, 19 CH: More people recover on their own from anything than they ever do by going to treatment. 9, 12, 13 AS: We just don’t know who those people are. 9, 12 CH: At best, the studies that we have show a twenty percent success rate.  AS: For treatment? 12, 13 CH: For treatment. 12, 13 When you try and say it is only successful twenty percent of the time people say, Is that their first or second time through? 9, 14 People really get it their second time through. 18 There are people that should never use again. 6, 9, 13, 16 I have seen people that have one beer and they change. 6, 9 For whatever reason -- chemically it is a bad idea. 13 I certainly have heard stories of people who have two beers and go to lockup. 8, 9, 17 You shouldn’t drink ever. 5 I think we need more people out there that say people who go through midlife crises -- they lose their jobs, grief and loss issues, and they may choose to use alcohol or some other drug as a maladaptive coping mechanism. 5, 6, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13 Ultimately more often than not they move away from it on their own without having to go to treatment. 12, 13, 15, 18, 20 Second of all, if they ever use again it doesn’t mean you are going to be dead in six months. 6, 11, 13, 16 With opiates compared to drinking you are dealing with a whole other level of unknowns. 5, 11, 12 You’ve got carfentanyl, you’ve got fentanyl, you just don’t know. 12 There’re so many variables.  People die from alcohol related disorders every year; more people than are dying from opioids. 6, 9, 13, 14 It’s just quicker with opiates.  Right, you die much faster.  CH: That’s an important piece to get out there. 9 I don’t think we are doing anyone any favor with the war on drugs. 5, 6 AS: That’s a whole other issue. 13 CH: I will point to Portugal and leave it at that. 18 Their numbers are there.  You can’t say it would be the same across cultures, but I think it would be pretty darn close. 9, 10 Statistically it would be in the ballpark.  AS: Thank you,  Chuck.  CH: You didn’t ask any questions.  That’s what’s good. 10 CH: It’s hard! 9 This is going to be a twenty-hour story if I did all the twists and turns. 15 AS: We might need a part two that is just an hour. 9, 15 I might want to come back and talk about harm reduction and where you think this is going. 5, 14 CH: That’s right! 12 That’s how we started out and I completely disregarded that. 14 AS: I think it is really important because it helps me filter and think about how I am going to write. 9, 18 When I wrote the chapter about mothers I didn’t know what was really going to come up. 12, 18 There was this piece about them being embattled.  CH: I hope you wrote something about the crack babies. 9, 16 I’m still waiting to see something about the crack babies. 6, 15, 16 CH: What do you mean they aren’t there?  Sorry.  [laughs] 15 AS: Someone else already wrote that: Susan Campbell.  This idea of mothers being embattled and embattled motherhood and also being addicted to mothering in some way. 12, 14, 18 So, themes come up.  That’s why I enjoy hearing the whole story. 9, 15 Thank you so much.  CH: There are so many pieces.

Deb Holman Narrator Amy Sullivan Interviewer May 19, 2017 Duluth, Minnesota Deb Holman -DH Amy Sullivan -AS AS: It’s May nineteenth, this is Amy Sullivan I’m with Deb Holman.  Deb do you give me permission to record this interview and will you state your name?  DH: Yes, I give you permission.  This is Deb Holman.  AS: Thanks.  Okay so Cloquet.
