San Marcos, they even discriminate against drug users I feel. 5, 6, 13 They have the drinking side which is like a Waukegan or a wet house. 5, 6, 9, 11, 13 They can have thirty two on that side. 9 The other side of the building has forty units with single room occupancy. 9, 14, 19 There's a ton of people probably using drugs in there. 5, 6, 9 It's not really, if they know you use drugs coming in it will be an issue getting through the process. 5, 6, 12, 13, 17, 18 It just came up the other day. 16 It's like, "Well, he's trying."  These people still deserve housing. 6, 9 There are some grants being written right now for more outreach to substance abuse users. 6, 12, 13 Part of this is the OARS group, they're involved.  I think there's two going on right now. 12 I don't know where they're going to find the housing. 6, 12 It's like get people into housing no matter what they're using or what their mental health is and then start getting them hooked up with services. 6, 9, 12, 19 Get them inside first of all. 9, 14 I don't know where the units are. 12, 19 We'll see. 6 I've kind of been rebellious and dropped off all meetings because I question authority I guess. 5, 11, 18 I'm so sick of the bureaucracy. 15 I go, "Oh I just do what I do everyday." 16 There's good and bad to that. 10 I probably have a strong voice in that. 17 People get mad at me.  I stand up for it.  When necessary I would still do it.  I remember we went through this, I haven't been to the Summit to End Homelessness for, this is the fourth one and I haven't been for two years. 5, 14 The first one I got so pissed. 8, 14 It's like everybody went through the whole day and at the end they came up with bullet points. 14, 16 Outreach wasn't on there.  I wish Duluth would have even like safe spot camping like Oregon has where people can just go. 6, 9 More like inreach than outreach. 12 This town you've really got to rely on tips. 18 For a lot of years I would walk the trails. 14, 16 It's fruitless to do that.  There's so many woods and trails and hiding places that you've just really got to rely on tips. 18 AS: You get tips about where to go find people. 9 DH: Yeah, to really go looking you can just waste a whole day looking and not find anything. 16, 18 When you mean outreach you mean you go looking for people? 9 DH: Yeah, I go out in the woods and stuff.  AS: Like that picture you posted of the tents when it was pouring rain this last week. 15 Yeah, I think it's funny because people like my dog pictures more than they like and pay attention to...I didn't even talk about the dog thing. 9 Somewhere along the way I started working with animals in this. 18 My first one was in St. Paul which I did get in trouble for. 8, 14 I had gotten Rusty out of the pound and I put him in my name.  When he ended up there again it was an issue, it's against their rules. 13 DH: I had bailed this dog out of doggy jail so the dog was in my name.  They felt it was a liability to them because the dog was living with these folks but was bailed out in my name. 11, 12 The funny thing is HDC, on my HDC time I can't take dogs home but it's always on my HDC time. 9, 18 So I just say, "No, I'm on CHUM time."  AS: What does HDC stand for?  It's the Human Development Center. 12 They're HIPPA, they're a mental health agency. 6, 12, 19 We are too I guess but we don't have a lot of the records.  AS: So you're rescuing homeless people's dogs? 9 Yes, somehow I started taking pets home. 8, 11 I don't know when I got the first one. 12, 14 2005 some homeless guy had him in his backpack.  He was just this beautiful little puppy. 20 It was like twenty below and he's drunk. 5, 8, 14 Bless his heart, Benny and Joy a couple were out here. 9, 11 I asked if I could take the dog home.  The rest is history. 15 I think Benny's eleven now. 12 The real Benny died.  I fostered a ton of dogs. 5 I had my two originals just together for a long time. 8, 17 People are out here, they have pets, they can't access shelter. 9 I'm like, "Are you willing to foster your pet?"  Yeah, I've developed a little bit of a network too. 20 Obviously I can't take every one. 8 AS: So you'll take care of them until the person can find a home. 19 DH: Yeah but you never know if they're going to come back really. 12, 16, 18 Most of the time they do.  Now I actually have five. 7 I think I'm going to have a permanent four.  Then this little Yorkie that I just took home the other day who's kind of driving me nuts. 5, 14, 16, 20 AS: The one who's not potty trained? 6, 8 She's in the cage.  She was last night too because she peed on my bed the first night. 14 You're just going to stay in the cage.  The owner told me she let her dog go to the bathroom in her bathroom. 14, 16 Which I don't really know what that means. 12, 18 I'm like, "On the toilet?"  They're like, "No on the floor." 14 Now I got to take that one out on a leash. 8 I'm carrying a Chihuahua up and down the stairs because that guy, well that's a long story. 15, 17 He's really struggling with meth and he's living in a condemned house. 6, 13, 18 They're just condemning it right now. 12 Somebody gave him five thousand dollars to get things back in order and it was gone in a week. 8, 11, 15 He knows that his little dog, it's this little eleven year old Chihuahua that came from a puppy mill. 12, 14, 20 She's had like ten litters.  I really didn't want her forever. 18 He knows he can't have her. 12 I kind of look at her and go, well really is she a trouble? 18 She just lays on the couch and doesn't really do much. 18 Then I start to feel kind of tied down because of all these animals.  AS: They just hang out at your house while you're working? 6, 13 I've got two cats.  The ex, I moved two blocks from her just to haunt her. 7, 15 No, we're still friends. 16, 20 The new person, there's an issue with her and me. 13, 16 I don't know if she feels threatened or what. 12 She doesn't have to obviously.  Carol comes over and lets them out everyday while I'm at work. 16 I'm flexible.  I work twelve hour days. 15, 16 I can go home.  AS: Five days a week? 15, 16 AS: Do you give yourself weekends? 15 I don't work twelve hours every single day. 15, 16 I'm trying to now just so I can have my weekends off in the summer. 7, 12, 15 If I'm not busy, if I'm just at home I usually will always answer my phone for the police or the hospital even on the weekends. 8, 15, 16, 18 Sometimes it's just a quick question or something or with that coordination thing going on.  I don't mind.  If I'm at home and somebody really needs something I don't really mind if I'm not doing anything. 18 The weird thing about my siblings is none of us ever got married or had kids, all four of us. 7, 8 I think that's super strange. 7, 16 I do see my brothers. 6, 20 They live in Cloquet.  They remind me of Felix and Unger in a way. 18 They're good guys. 10 My sister I don't see her a whole lot. 6, 20 I don't know how to explain. 12 She's always been kind of judgemental of my drug use. 5, 6, 12, 13, 18 I think she's coming around a little bit. 20 There's been a number of times where basically she's got drunk and I'm at her house. 5, 6, 8, 13, 14, 19 Sometimes with co-workers. 12, 19 I stay there when I go to hunt for stuff.  She starts shit. 18 It goes way back to when we were kids and the fact that I did drugs. 5, 6, 18 I want to say it was three Christmases ago she flipped out on me. 13 She's kicked me out a number of times at like eleven at night.  I'm like, "Really?"  I just draw a line with them now. 5, 9, 12 I won't be around her when she's drinking. 5, 11 I even told her, 16 "No drinking at Christmas." 5, 11 If you're coming to my house. 6, 13 She didn't come.  I don't care if they drink. 5, 19 Just don't get super drunk. 5, 8, 14, 16 Let's have a few and get along. 17 I don't fight, she does.  AS: I think I probably have to wrap it up.  DH: That's okay.  I probably do to.  I haven't even been to work yet today. 16 CHUM is like that though.  They don't care. 19 AS: You do some incredible stuff watching out for the people that nobody else is watching out for. 5, 8, 9, 17

Chris Johnson Narrator Amy Sullivan Interviewer January 26, 2017  At the Home of Amy Sullivan Minneapolis, Minnesota Chris Johnson -CJ Amy Sullivan -AS CJ: I'm not an addiction specialist but you can't be involved in this problem as much as I have without learning something about it. 10, 12, 14 The typical model of putting someone in someplace for however long and you take away their job. 11, 17 AS: Thirty days, sixty days. 16 CJ: Yes, they feel better.  Then, "Well that works then. 9 Look they're feeling better." 15 It's sort of like, I liken it to someone who treats compulsive hoarding by just cleaning out their house and saying, "Oh look isn't it nice to have a pretty house now." 6, 10, 12, 13, 18 Without dealing with the underlying compulsion.  Why with that pretty house did this person feel like keeping every newspaper? 6, 10, 13, 15, 16 Why did they attach emotional significance to having every ﻿City Pages ﻿even with coffee and other stains on it? 11 AS: We're just going to clean you up and get the drugs out of your system. 5, 6 CJ: Without dealing with the underlying, what sort of mental anguish were they escaping from. 12 That also explains why certain people are unique. 9, 17 You look at their history and say, "That was going to happen." 15 Severe physical or sexual abuse. 6, 12, 13 A person with that little self-worth, every minute is an anguish. 15, 20 That person is looking to escape that constantly.  Some people do get better with intensive therapy. 9, 12 They get into a new situation where they can find an answer and they don't feel that. 16 Sometimes you can't.  Sometimes that person tragically—let's say they were eight years old when all this happened or just high school, these experiences where you're trying to develop a sense of worth and trust in the world and you permanently destroyed it. 7, 14, 15, 18 A person like that, a high percentage much higher than the average population, that person is a higher risk for developing chemical dependency. 7, 13, 17 The stress, the anguish they're escaping is just them every day. 7, 16 I think the traditional treatment community doesn't get it. 12, 13, 19 I think they do what's typical, what they can build for.  When it doesn't work they come back and build some more.  It's in their interest to have people relapse because that just fills their beds again. 5, 9 I'd like to say that medicine would have higher ideals but my experience has been not really. 7, 12, 14, 17, 18 AS: That medicine would? 12, 14 CJ: That medicine looks out for what's their long term health. 12, 14, 17, 19 AS: You would hope that that would be the case. 9, 17 CJ: My experience has been I've found that that has been compromised. 14, 18 Have you seen my talks? 6 AS: I saw you at the Saving Lives.  AS: In September.  That's when I met you and a lot of people came up to you at the Convention Center in September, Downtown Minneapolis. 9 It was put on by Hazelden and the DEA.  CJ: I just did a panel, was I just sitting up there with a bunch of people or did I have a whole hour? 9, 15 AS: I honestly don't remember but I remember being impressed with what you said. 8, 10 Why don't you just say some of those things but if you've already got the text or video of things that you would want to share with me you don't have to repeat them right now. 12, 18 CJ: They recorded it.  If they send me a recording I can forward a link to you.  I sent you my articles right? 5, 12 AS: No. CJ: Really?  AS: No. CJ: You saw my CNN article right? 12 AS: No. CJ: I'm sorry.  AS: It's fine Chris. 11 We're just meeting each other. 18 It doesn't matter right now. 12 CJ: People request me to talk, I'm like here's some of my stuff.  This was just going to be an interview.  I'm going to pause this for a second. 6, 13 People say their best things in the first couple of minutes. 11, 14, 15 [pause recording] 6, 13 CJ: If you're not familiar with some of my opinions on this my guess is you just saw me as a panelist. 8 AS: I saw you apologize on behalf of all doctors. 12, 14 You talked about quite a lot.  CJ: Did you see slides? 6 I don't think so.  CJ: I don't think you did.  I think you got me as a panelist.  If there's no slides and it was the convention center, are you sure it was the convention center?  Then I did not speak with my slides.  It was put on by the law enforcement. 8, 12, 13 I was one of a group of seven.  AS: Law enforcement and Hazelden. 8, 12, 13 CJ: There were seven people up there. 9 CJ: I got a ten-minute spiel. 15 AS: I can tell you why I'm interested in this and how this all came about. 14 Oral history is my area. 8, 15 I looked at the 1970s, a tragedy at a Girl Scout camp in the 1970s where three girls were murdered and had been sexually assaulted, three little girls. 5, 7, 11, 12, 20 I went back and interviewed survivors because I was at that camp that night as a survivor myself and grew up with no knowledge with what PTSD was or anything like that. 12, 20 When I did finally learn that and work through all those things as a women's history student I had an epiphany one night that this was what I needed to write my master's and my dissertation about. 10, 12, 15 I went and I found women who were now, some of them, were willing to talk. 12 I learned a lot about trauma and how things change. 10 Of course historians look at how things change over time.  I saw a parallel to what's happening with heroin and opioids with a shift in thinking about it and a little bit of a decrease in stigma in some respects and a demographic shift from who were the main users and how are they being treated differently from previous users. 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 20 I wanted to just document people who are active in this world right now for an oral history collection of interviews. 9, 12, 14, 15, 18 Then I was approached by an editor at the University of Minnesota Press who asked if I was interested in talking to him because he saw I was doing this project. 5 We started talking and he said, "Well why don't you think about it as a book and let's talk about it."  That's kind of how this has come about with chapters that look at different sectors of what's happened since 1980. 14, 15 I'm not sure exactly what year I'm going to start with but up to the present. 5, 10, 14 I'm interviewing doctors as well as treatment specialists. 12, 13, 14 I'm very interested in looking at what places like Hazelden are doing with this.  I have a historian's eye on it and understand the history of why the Minnesota Model came to be. 15, 17, 18 I understand that but I think with the opioid epidemic and meth I'm not sure it's helping everybody in the way that it could be. 6, 13, 17, 18 CJ: You understand that the Cochran Club Organization looked at twelve-step recovery and found no evidence that it did anything. 17, 18 No evidence.  Honestly it shouldn't surprise you. 8 It's a religious based program. 13 AS: I'm very interested in your childhood, where you grew up. 14, 20 Tell me how you want me to start.  AS: I want you to start by saying your name and that you give me permission to record this interview.  CJ: My name is Chris Johnson, I'm an emerging medicine physician working at urgent care with Allina Health. 12, 14, 19 I give you permission to record this interview.  AS: Thank you.  Now we can kind of start.  What was your childhood like, where did you grow up? 10, 14, 20 I'm also as a writer, not just as a historian, I'm more of a narrative driven person. 5 I would really love to hear some basics about your childhood and how you got into medicine. 9, 12, 14, 18, 20 CJ: My childhood, there was some significant family dysfunction in my childhood. 9, 11, 12, 14, 20 My parents were and are, one of them is not alive anymore, they're both very bright. 12, 20 Both my parents went to Harvard. 20 My mother was an economist, majored in Econ at Harvard and my father was English. 5, 16 That's where they met.  AS: He was an English major?  CJ: He was an English major.  He did not have a very functional career. 9, 15, 19 He was a bit disorganized, very disorganized. 20 He couldn't decide what he wanted to do after Harvard. 14, 18 He apparently got into Columbia Law but stopped Columbia Law after two years then got into the PhD program at Tufts University for English, never finished that either. 14, 16, 20 Things started off looking well then lost interest. 11 Ultimately ended up being an opera singer.  He was a good singer, he was in the Harvard Glee Club, that was always one of his passions to sing. 10, 16, 18 My mother, she didn't have the traditional female skill set.  It was maybe reversed. 5 She was math, she was about the mathematics.  She will say she is a failed mathematician in the sense that she couldn't do math like the real Harvard math people. 9 She could do pretty well. 10 She went to the PhD program at MIT for Econ, the best Econ program in the country. 19 After that got a job teaching at Stanford, Economics. 11 I don't remember things much before California.  My early memories of life are Palo Alto. 10 My mother was there as a Stanford Econ professor.  My father was singing in the San Francisco Opera. 16 How old were you by that point?  CJ: Do you even remember things at age four?  AS: Four is when you moved? 7, 15 CJ: I think I moved when I was like three. 7, 15 I don't remember.  My earliest school memories are in Palo Alto, California. 7 I remember saying goodbye to my dad every day, he had rehearsal which I guess was in the evenings or something like that. 9, 10, 14, 16 I'd see him the next day. 6, 16 I realized later the marriage was kind of breaking up at that point. 14 Part of the going away in the evening wasn't just for rehearsal. 9, 18, 20 In any case, that family life that at least my brother and I. 10, 12, 17, 20 I have one younger brother, he's one year younger than me. 14, 20 The last time we were together as a family would have been 1979 in California in Palo Alto. 8, 12 My mother did not get granted tenure at Stanford which is not all that unusual as an Associate.  You go there to begin and then you go off and hopefully you become famous and publish. 9, 14 Then if you can come back when you're famous.  She did not get tenure and she was snatched up by the Federal Reserve in Washington D.C. to be an economist there.  That's when my family moved to Washington D.C. My mother, my brother, and I moved to northern Virginia right outside of Washington D.C. A town called Falls Church, Virginia. 7, 8, 12, 15, 20 At that point it was single mom. 14 My mother worked as an economist for the Fed.  We lived in a small single family home. 7, 12 My brother and I went to regular old public school in Fairfax County Public Schools. 7, 19, 20 Eventually it became clear, the story initially was my father was going to rejoin the family, he was going to get more and more important opera parts and then maybe try out for The Met in New York. 5, 9, 12, 15, 16 There's lots of banks in New York. 16 She could be an economist at a bank in New York.  That was the vision.  It turned out later it wasn't going to happen. 15 I won't go into that, that's not for the book.  In any case, I grew up with my younger brother in Falls Church. 17, 20 AS: How old were you when you moved? 7, 15 AS: You were born in 1970? 14 CJ: I was born in '70. 14 From that point on it was just going to finish elementary then junior then high school. 7, 12, 14 Then I went to college at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville. 7 Neither my brother nor myself were as smart as they were. 20 I applied to Yale, I went to public school. 7, 19 It worked out.  Now I'm actually very proud that I haven't gone to a single private school in my education ever. 7, 14, 15 Public school the whole way. 7, 18 People will say, "Oh yeah.  UVA, so tough.  The mean streets of Charlottesville, Virginia with Monticello and Jefferson. 5 It's a tough environment. 12 Dodging bullets on your way to art history class." 7, 15, 18 At UVA I was actually a government major. 7, 12 It wasn't medicine. 12, 14 I sort of had this kind of a social justice part of me that was always kind of there. 9, 18, 19 I thought maybe policy or law was a way to manage big problems. 5, 12, 13, 17, 18 I'll admit I wasn't a great student. 20 I wasn't the best student.  I did things that didn't make a lot of sense.  I was government/foreign affairs; it was more foreign affairs. 9, 12 Wouldn't it be great if people could just get along on a national level? 9, 17, 20 I concentrated on the Soviet Union.  I was so stupid; I didn't take Russian.  What do you plan on doing with your great theories about improving relations if the nation you're studying and their government structure, which was the Soviet Union with a central committee, but I didn't speak any Russian. 12, 15, 20 While I was there then the whole thing fell apart. 9, 11 That's when the revolution happened again and the Communist Party went away. 15, 18, 20 Now technically it's back in a different form.  The same sort of centrist is back.  I won't say that I had a great deal of direction in how I proceeded with my academic career at UVA. 15, 18, 19, 20 When I graduated I considered with a degree in government you choose academics or you choose law. 5, 7, 9, 12, 13, 14, 20 I paralegalled for a little while. 20 I mean like a year. 14 In the Washington D.C. area. 8 That was a pretty serious recession at that time. 10, 11 That was when Clinton got elected.  Jobs were tough to come by.  It was not a very happy time of my life. 10, 18 You graduate college in 1992, I think I just got out of a break up. 7 It was bad.  On top of all that there's no jobs. 11 Especially for young, undergraduate degree in D.C. Paralegal work was all I could get not even full-time paralegal work but temp paralegal work. 14 It was enough for me to learn about the law. 10, 13 I realized very quickly even though I was not doing law type work, I learned about the process of law. 10, 13, 17 Some jobs I got to interact with lawyers quite a bit and learned about what was it that made them interested. 10, 11, 13, 18, 20 You realize that it's just the process of filing this and being sort of a champion, usually it's one company suing another company. 14, 17 Your contract said this, you owe us this. 19 It's the company defending themselves against the Department of Justice. 9, 12, 14 You violated this anti-trust whatever.  If you didn't really enjoy the process of it and that sort of confrontational, it wasn't for you. 17, 18 The whole idea of fixing big problems on a national scale, a bit naive. 12, 20 I thought well maybe if I can't do national level problem solving maybe I can do it on individual levels. 5, 12, 17, 18 I did like science.  If I was a physician, I could fix problems on a patient by patient level. 12 I'd only taken some introductory science at UVA, I didn't do well. 14 I was a goof off.  I was one of my high school valedictorians, I was at the very top with the 4.0 plus something. 7, 14 I used that as a reason to goof off for first semester in college. 6, 7, 13, 14, 16 I had the 2.2 GPA to prove it.  It was that time I took Chemistry and it was impenetrable to me.  When you only study one day a week lots of things were going to be impenetrable. 15, 16 The poly exclusion principle of up and down arrows for the electron orbitals. 20 I thought, "Who can understand these orbitals and quantum theory and stuff." 17, 18, 20 Then you realize later on when you took it again, one goes up one goes down.  You just count.  You don't have to figure it out.  They figured it out you just have to do your little exercise. 5, 20 In any case, the idea came to me that maybe that science wouldn't be as bad if I actually studied. 5, 7, 17 I went back to school. 7 I did part time work. 9 I actually worked retail, I worked at Circuit City. 7 Circuit  City existed at that time.  I worked at Circuit City as a sales associate.  I took the science classes part time at a nearby university that was just a commuter. 5, 7, 9 George Mason is not well known outside the D.C. area; George Mason University is in northern Virginia. 8, 11, 12 It has a fairly large student body because a great many of George Mason students are commuters. 9, 20 They're getting more education while they live and work. 14, 15 I took the Chemistry, the Organic Chemistry, the Physics, some math, Biology.  I did very well because when you sort of get this idea when you studied, "Oh, it isn't that hard." 9 When you've got purpose.  I treated it like a job. 11, 12 I had a leg up over the eighteen or nineteen year olds who were kind of goofing off like I was years earlier. 14, 15 AS: By this point you're twenty-four?  It took a couple years to get it done. 11, 14 You can't take Organic Chemistry until you take Biology and regular Chemistry.  That set you back.  It took like two and a half years to get that done. 8, 14 I studied for the medical college admission test. 7, 14 I aced that.  I found out I had aptitude for science so I did it.  I applied to medical school and got in. 7, 14 CJ: I went to the Medical College of Virginia which is in Richmond, Virginia which is the home of Phillip Morris Tobacco and former capitol of the Confederacy. 14 They really never got over that. 16, 18 They still haven't gotten over that.  It's not Martin Luther King Jr. Day there it is Lee Jackson King Day.  As in Robert E. Lee, Stonewall Jackson, and the civil rights guy. 8, 12, 16 Civil War, Civil War, Civil Rights.  It's actually not called the Medical College of Virginia anymore; it's called the Virginia Commonwealth School of Medicine. 7, 14 There was always a relationship between those two but they just made it more explicit. 18, 19 What I'm saying is if you go looking for the Medical College of Virginia you're going to get redirected to VCU. 5, 14, 18 I went to MCV from 1996 to 2000.  After 2000, in that last year, I decided I wanted to do emergency medicine. 12, 14, 18 Hennepin County Medical 14 Center was at the top of my list of places to go.  Hennepin County Medical 14 Center was one of the top five, certainly top ten training programs for emergency medicine in the country. 8, 12, 14, 17, 19 I was a good medical student. 7, 10, 14 I wasn't top ten percent but I was top quarter.  On the board exams I was top ten percent in the board exams.  I knew my stuff. 16 I was lucky enough to match at Hennepin. 8 That's what brought me to Minneapolis and I haven't left. 14 I did my emergency medicine residency in Hennepin County, graduated 2003. 7, 9, 12, 14 Then practiced full time emergency medicine at St. Louis Park Methodist Hospital. 12, 14 That's sort of the arc of how I got here.  AS: How did you get into this work around addiction or opioids? 6, 12, 13, 14 CJ: How did I get into work with opioids? 6, 13 AS: How did you get into that?  CJ: It began at Hennepin County in the sense that we saw a lot of chemical dependency there. 13 They had sort of a program where you keep a look out for known people that are suspicious for this or that behavior. 9, 11, 12 But you kind of blow it off a bit in the sense that it’s a county hospital with a county population. 8, 10, 19, 20 You’ve got lots of minorities. 16 Not just minorities but people from terrible family backgrounds, absent fathers, prison fathers, single moms, mothers are gone, grandmothers are raising the kids. 5, 8, 9, 11, 12, 14, 16 Lots of pathologic family structures that lead to dysfunctional behavior. 9, 12, 15 I saw a lot of abuse of drugs like heroin. 5, 6, 13, 16 Also drugs like oxycodone, OxyContin, Vicodin, all that stuff. 5, 6, 8 Coming and looking for pain pills. 6 I was like, this is so absurd, “When I get out of here then I’ll get back to doing what I’m supposed to be doing.”  Then I went to Methodist Hospital in St. Louis Park.  They’re the patients from St. Louis Park, from Minnetonka, and Edina.  You realize, “Oh.  Suburban people are looking for oxycodone, OxyContin, Vicodin, Dilauded. 9 It isn’t just the inner city.  It is the suburbs, it’s everywhere.”  AS: Was it pretty soon before you realized that? 10 CJ: It was within the first year. 14 You couldn’t go a shift without seeing it. 6, 8 Someone who had a “chronic pain exacerbation.” 6 They’d have a diagnosis of chronic pain. 6 You’d look at their chart they’re on oxycodone plus OxyContin plus oxycodone for breakthrough.  They would come and say they were helping a friend move and helping a friend move is apparently the most dangerous thing you can do because apparently the friend will drop the other end of the couch, you’ll pull your back out and now you’ve got a pain exacerbation. 5, 6, 11, 12, 14, 15, 20 AS: They might have on their record chronic pain as a diagnosis? 6, 14 CJ: Yes.  AS: Then they come in for pain exacerbation. 6 CJ: Right.  AS: Which means they’re just looking for more meds.  CJ: Something flared up their...something stronger, something to temporarily boost them up now. 5, 12 Something flared it. 5 Chronic pain exacerbation became the bane of my existence. 6 It was the bane of everyone’s existence.  It got to the point where you couldn’t go a shift without it. 8 Usually you’d see more than one. 6 It was almost comical how often it was helping a friend move. 15, 20 You can see where if you’re trying to generate sympathy. 6 They’re just being a good friend. 10, 20 “I was trying to help my friend. 20 I didn’t want this.  I would otherwise be stable and fine. 11, 12 I was just trying to be a good friend.” 10, 20 Granted you can’t disprove whether than actually happened or not. 7, 15 It was a story that could generate sympathy. 15 AS: The fact that it got passed around and repeated.  CJ: It was repeated so frequently by that population.  It was suspicious.  It was certainly suspicious. 8, 17 What happened is maybe a year, two years of this, you’d see the same patients back again with another exacerbation for something. 5, 6, 14, 15 This time maybe they were in a car accident, someone rear ended them, it wasn’t their fault then either. 5, 13 “I didn’t ask them to rear end me.”  They don’t have an accident report. 13 “No we didn’t call the cops.”  Whatever incident was immune to disconfirmation.  They were there for flare up.  At that time the flare ups are treated, we were being told that pain is a disease, pain is the fifth vital sign, opiates aren’t really that addictive. 6, 11, 12, 14, 16, 18 They were getting multiple doses of Dilaudid in the emergency department. 9, 12, 17, 19 They would be there for about three or four hours. 15 After about three doses you’d ask them, “Hey can you go home now?” 12 Maybe you got an x-ray if they looked like something really serious might have happened. 11, 15, 18 Usually you didn’t have to.  They get two or three doses of Dilaudid.  Either they’d say they could go home or they’d get admitted.  They’d go home with another prescription or they get admitted, they’d stay for three days and then they’d go home with another prescription. 10, 16 Then they’d be back.  You would see that this was, the patients weren’t getting better. 6 They keep cycling through.  It was frustrating for us as doctors because they’re often very demanding patients. 9, 12, 14 They require a lot of nursing staff to keep going in there.  You’ve got other people to see. 6, 9 You’ve got the heart failure patients, you’ve got the COPD patients, you’ve got the septic patients, you’ve got febrile seizures. 9, 14 You’ve got other things to do.  The patients weren’t getting off their meds, they were staying on them and they were coming in with more flare ups. 7 What clinical progress are we seeing with them? 6 It was frustrating for the doctors. 12, 14 This is not interesting medicine. 12, 14, 17 It’s making my job harder to deal with this other stuff. 9, 10, 11 Invariably they can be very demanding patients that are difficult to get along with but you must be nice to them so they give you a good performance review. 9, 10, 14, 18 They became very stressful; you want to get customer satisfaction surveys to go very well. 7 The hospital wants to make sure you make everyone happy and they pay their bill on time and pay their bill in full. 8, 14, 18 It wasn’t good for the hospital in the sense that when these people get admitted they wouldn’t be compensated for the second or third day. 8, 9, 10, 14, 16 They might be compensated for one day. 16 The hospital’s losing money with these prolonged admissions of people who won’t leave but they won’t take the step of just kicking them out the door. 8, 9, 10, 17, 18 No one’s benefiting. 8, 15 The patients aren’t getting better, the doctors are frustrated, the hospital is losing money. 8, 10, 12, 14 I decided, I think it was 2005, I’m going to do something about it. 14 At that point I decided to contact the pain clinics in the area. 6, 8, 14 I spoke to the Britton Center, I went to MAPS in Edina, I went to United Hospital and spoke to Dr. Hesse.  I spoke to Dr. Belgrade. 5 I spoke Dr. Matthew Monsein.  I independently set up interviews with all these medical directors on my own and started talking to them. 7, 14, 18, 19 AS: On your own time?  CJ: Just on my own time and did it.  I found out later it was weird.  Most people don’t do that. 9 What’s this thirty-five-year-old doctor doing investigating pain clinics and figuring out what the hell are we doing wrong? 6, 11, 12, 14 This doesn’t make any sense.  AS: But they talked to you.  CJ: They talked to me.  They were happy to talk to me. 18 No other ER doctor, no one else asked them. 8, 12, 14 I told them what we’re seeing here. 6, 16 They said, “You need to have some sort of a policy, some sort of universal way of approaching these patients.” 18 That’s when I went to Methodist Hospital which was Park Nicollet, now it’s Health Partners. 12 It was Park Nicollet at that time.  I contacted risk management and said, “Hey look. 12 Everyone’s seeing this problem. 6, 12 The hospitals are furious. 8 It’s in everyone’s interest to get a committee together.” 8 We put together this chronic pain committee at Park Nicollet. 6, 8 Then I spent the next four years from 2005 to 2009 meeting every few months. 11, 14, 16, 18 I was a pain in the ass to them. 6 There’s no money to be made. 8, 10 AS: You’re just asking them to come before work or after work.  CJ: Or in the middle of work to meet and talk about this and what should we do and put together this. 7, 8, 18 It’s not making them money. 8, 10 It’s not going to make Park Nicollet money. 8, 10 AS: Who were the people who were on this committee? 9 CJ: Risk management was there; the director of the hospital service was often there. 8, 12, 18, 19 AS: You pulled those people together from the hospital. 8, 9, 11 CJ: From the hospital, the clinic system. 8 AS: You were trying to work within the hospital setting that you were in to make a change. 8 CJ: To make a change, to have a universal policy that we could all abide by.  The pain doctors said, “This is entirely appropriate.” 6, 12, 14 I brought that to them.  It took four years. 14 A few months go by and nobody does anything and then you see another chronic pain patient. 6, 11, 16 Then I fire off another angry email, “Oh hey. 11 Just checking on how we’re doing.  Just saw a patient.  Could have used this policy.” 6, 13, 16 After four years we eventually did come up with this policy about opiates and how we use them for chronic pain and how we would not do IV opiates for chronic pain exacerbations unless we found an objective new injury. 5, 6, 13, 14, 16 AS: That’s the Dilaudid that you’re speaking about?  CJ: The IV Dilaudid I was talking about.  You stay there.  CJ: If you have chronic back pain you came with a back pain flare. 6 Usually we just did IV Dilaudid but we’re not doing that anymore unless there’s a new kidney stone, okay. 8, 16 You’re back flared up again, no. 5 You’re going to get two tablets of whatever it is you normally take. 16 Two Vicodin or two Percocet.  You’re not going to be admitted for pain medicine. 6, 12, 14 If you feel you couldn’t go home safely, like “Oh I can’t walk.” 16 You’ll be admitted.  You’re still only going to get two more tablets, whatever your scheduled dose is.  You’re not going to get hooked up to the IV, here you go.  If you want to stay because you feel unsafe we’ll keep you because you’re unsafe.  You’d be amazed at how few people wanted to stay in the hospital when that was the policy. 8, 9, 18 They left. 14 They got up in a huff and stormed out of the ER with amazing speed for someone with that critical amount of back pain they were in. 6, 9, 14 That dramatically changed how the hospital functioned, having that policy. 5, 8, 9, 13 It didn’t change how difficult it was in the ER because the patients would still come in looking for this. 10 It helped the hospitals because they wouldn’t be admitted. 8 AS: You were still on the front lines dealing with people and having them be mad. 9 CJ: The hospital would never put out signs in the waiting room saying, “This is how we treat chronic pain.” 6, 8, 11, 14, 15, 16 They never did that. 16 They want you to register.  Once they register you they generate a bill.  Once they generate a bill they get money. 8, 10 They didn’t want to turn away any customers.  They didn’t want anything that would dissuade them from registering.  That’s not their reasoning.  “We don’t want to miss anything.”  AS: Something else could be wrong. 11 CJ: What happened is admissions for chronic pain went down to almost zero. 6, 15 These patients weren’t interested in coming in for what they could do at home. 14 AS: Can you describe who these patients are?  What’s their kind of demographic?  CJ: They’re middle aged, they’re in their forties. 7 Thirties to fifties.  Twenties is more like, it’s hard to have a chronic pain diagnosis at twenty. 6, 9, 14 Late thirties to early fifties would be it.  AS: Men, women? 12 CJ: More women than men even. 12 AS: Middle class? 7 CJ: Middle class people. 7, 9 AS: Mostly white in St. Louis Park? 19 CJ: Yes.  You’d still get minorities.  It was never Hispanic. 16 Hispanics hardly every have chronic pain. 6, 9 You have African Americans, but I don’t any more than just their normal percentage of the population. 16 AS: I’ve read something about this, I can’t remember what it is.  CJ: African American doesn’t mean you don’t have the chronic pain and all that stuff. 6 You’d see very few Asians, very few Hispanics with the chronic pain diagnosis. 6 It was mostly Caucasians. 12 That was the demographic.  Once the pain policy went into effect the admissions went almost to zero. 6 They would still come into the ER.  We don’t want to dissuade anyone from registering.  It didn’t make the ER jobs easier because you’d still have unpleasant conversations. 11 You used to do that.” 6, 13, 16 The truth is even after that I would see chart of my partners, even with this policy, they didn’t want the argument. 6, 9, 12 They would just be here, IV some more to go.  AS: Say that again?  CJ: Even some of my partners in the ER. 9, 12 AS: Would choose not to follow the policy? 10 CJ: Would just ignore the policy and would do what was easy.  AS: They didn’t want the conflict.  CJ: They don’t want the conflict; they want to make sure they still get a good performance review. 10, 14 AS: They don’t have to follow it. 10 CJ: There’s no teeth behind it.  There’s no punishment if you don’t. 12 AS: It’s a recommendation. 12 CJ: If you wanted to show the patient you could show a little letter. 18, 20 There’s nothing forcing you to follow it. 10 There was no punishment if you didn’t. 12 There’s no enforcement, there’s no teeth. 8, 12, 13 It was very much ignorable.  I only came across this because patients would come in, I wouldn’t do that, and they’d say, “Hey the last time I was here a month ago I got this.” 13, 16 I go, “Really?”  Then I would look it up.  Sure enough.  That’s exactly what happened. 15 AS: Did you confront your colleagues about this?  CJ: That’s a tough thing to do.  They’ll say, “This person was in tears.  They gave a good mechanism, I thought something was really wrong.” 10, 11, 17, 18 What are you going to say to that?  AS: That’s you questioning their decision as a doctor. 12, 14 You’re jeopardizing a partnership and a friendship to bring that up. 9, 12, 16, 20 AS: That is intense.  CJ: Hold on one second.  [pause]. 6, 13 People are reluctant to approach their physician partners and say, “What the hell were you doing?” 9, 12 They also didn’t want to get a negative performance review. 14 They don’t have any exceptions for that.  That would still go in your file.  There were still incentives to get it done.  Make them happy, get them out. 18 CJ: Around 2009.  Granted some partners were very good about that. 9, 10, 12 They knew what would happen. 15, 16 It gets that conflict over easy but then you’ve incentivized them coming back. 14 At least half, more than half did use the policy. 6, 13, 14 There were certainly handfuls of those who would not do it. 8, 17 AS: How many doctors are we talking about? 12, 14 CJ: The department group that I was in was probably about twenty docs. 9, 12, 14, 19 To staff all the shifts, it was around twenty docs. 8, 14 Most of them were good about it. 10 None of them went through the effort that I went through but they were all frustrated with how things were going. 8 They were frustrated.  They were good about it. 10 They would be frustrated with their partners when they wouldn’t do the policy because they knew they could expect to see them back. 6, 9, 12, 16 AS: The repeat behavior ends up proving that the policy might be necessary, it might be a useful thing. 6, 13, 18 CJ: It wasn’t enforced, there were no teeth behind it, it wasn’t universal. 8 It didn’t stop anyone.  All it takes is one or two, the patient’s like, “I might get it. 17 Might as well go in and see.” 6 For a patient who is dependent on these medicines. 12, 14 That’s the most important thing they’ve got to do that day. 9, 16 They have nothing they’re going to do.  There’s this asymmetry.  As a practicing physician you’ve got all these other patients.  You’re responsible for them. 16 This person’s going to try to take up all your time, is going to wear you down, is going to make things unpleasant, get the nursing in here to try to make it not worth your while to fight them anymore.  That would happen a lot. 15 It would also be especially compelling when they would bring their kids in.  When they bring their children in the pain doctors that I met over at the clinics had a word for that. 5, 6, 12, 14, 20 They were called props.  When you bring the kids in it sends that added message.  “You’re not only making me suffer but how am 10 I going to take of my kid in this pain?” 6 You’re harming them too.  That’s extra pressure they bring. 10 AS: You’re in a compassionate field.  CJ: Your default is to trust.  Your default is to care for and relieve suffering. 19 AS: Do you need to stop?  This person forgot that I was doing this.  2009 ongoing there was still that battle.  We had support but it wasn’t great support. 20 What I had hoped to see with that policy was the number of chronic pain patients go down to like zero. 6, 9 The word would get out.  That policy became my department policy but became department policy for all of EMPA, which is the largest emergency medicine group in the Twin Cities. 9, 12, 14, 19 It’s not large, large but it’s like six hospitals. 8 It became their policy.  Then it became the policy for the American Emergency Physicians, Minnesota Chapter.  This goes to show you that look, if you have a policy without enforcement who cares? 8, 12, 13, 19 Drunk driving is against the law but what happens? 5, 8, 13, 14, 15 We tell you not to do it again.  We penalize your license. 13 You’d have to be caught drunk driving twenty times before anything happened. 5, 8, 14, 15 Who cares that it’s against the law? 13, 19 Behavior doesn’t change.  The policy really never changed behavior that much. 13, 16, 18 The only thing that policy did was it helped the hospitalists because these patients wouldn’t be admitted. 8 Even with this policy the patients kept coming in.  As you can see, deaths haven’t changed. 6, 13, 18 The curve for opiate use and overdose and admissions, nothing changed really. 6, 13, 18 AS: It wasn’t saving lives.  CJ: It was doing some minor thing for hospital function but no real change was happening. 8, 9, 15 AS: Was it your intention to save lives at that point? 10 What that in your awareness? 9 CJ: I had thought there was a multi-pronged benefit to this. 15, 17, 18 The chronic pain patients weren’t getting better so this would help them. 6 The doctors were being extremely frustrated and burned out with all this so it’d help them. 12, 14 The hospitals were losing money so it would help them. 8, 10 I thought all would benefit. 15, 17, 18 It turns out really only the admissions, that’s all that really happened from this. 15, 18 They were still coming in, the doctors were frustrated, the patients weren’t getting any better. 12, 14 AS: They were just finding other ways to get their drugs. 5, 6, 18 CJ: Right.  After doing that, it was 2012 they were still having these meetings. 18 “Is there something else we can do?”  We’re having occasional talks about the chronic pain committee. 6 But a lot of these chronic pain committees after these policies went into effect was how do we make sure patients are comfortable coming out of anesthesia? 6 Making sure the chronic pain patients have enough pain medication after surgery so they’re comfortable. 6, 14 What are we talking about?  Why are we not talking about we have to get this massive population off these medicines? 12, 14 We’re talking about making sure they’re safe and monitored after surgery. 5, 10 Basically, there was some safety regarding that but mostly it was make sure the customer’s happy. 12, 18, 19 If you look in terms of how things are practiced. 17 If you think the ultimate paradigm is make sure the customer’s satisfied with their experience. 18 You will find that explains much of medical behavior. 7, 14 AS: The patient customer, together the two words. 8 CJ: The buzzword in the industry was the patient experience. 18 You want the patient to have a good experience. 10, 18 You just take the term customer and replace it with patient. 17 The customer experience. 18 Just swap them out.  The patient experience is the word in the industry for measuring how well you’re doing. 18 It is not patient outcome.  That is not the measure for how things are going.  If you’re measuring patient outcome with pain meds and opiates we’re doing terribly. 6 There’s more and more prescriptions coming out, more and more people becoming dependent, more people going into treatment. 9, 10, 12, 13 People are dying.  If you’re measuring it by outcomes you’re doing awful and you’ve been doing awful for years. 11, 14 I talk about this in the articles, I’ll send them to you so you can review them. 14 If you look at what governs how medicine is practiced in terms of what would make the most business sense you will find that is a streamlining paradigm to understanding how medicine behaves. 12, 14, 17, 18 AS: How’s that for you as a physician?  CJ: I feel that there’s been a great bait and switch. 20 We have the Hippocratic oath, we got the little white jacket, the health of the patient is the paradigm of everything. 19, 20 There’s no data saying even back surgeries are helping. 13 Back surgeries however make half a million dollars for one procedure.  It is cash money. 8, 10 Hospitals have spine centers.  Look at what’s serviced out there. 19 Is it mental health? 12, 19 Why do you think there’s heart and vascular centers everywhere? 9 Stents pay money. 8, 10 There’s actually very little data that stents do anything. 7, 13, 20 If you’re in immediate heart attack it helps. 9 It helps a small like three percent of the population that has what is called Severe Left Mane Disease which is the main artery coming out of the heart. 9 Unless you have Severe Left Mane Disease for your heart or if you’re in the middle of an acute infraction but if you just have chest pain from exertion relieved by rest that’s typical anginal pain. 6, 7, 9 A stint isn’t going to do anything.  It isn’t going to make you live any longer. 17 The only thing it’s says is it might improve your pain for about two years and then there’s no difference. 6, 14 Vascular centers and stents make huge dough.  You can throw a rock and hit them. 14 You can’t find a mental health clinic. 12, 19 You won’t find these other services which are neglected because they don’t pay. 19 AS: They’re nothing about technology.  CJ: As I’m doing all this chronic pain stuff I’m also observing this about how medicine is functioning and it increasingly looks like is the patient what they’re really thinking about or are they thinking about them? 6, 9, 12, 14, 18 They’re thinking about them.  The patient care is the means through which to maximize what’s benefitting them. 15, 19 It’s not like doing a stent doesn’t involve patients.  It isn’t like their number one outcome is what they’re thinking about.  AS: It’s for profit. 15 CJ: If it’s not for profit it’s for revenue. 15 Some hospitals are not for profit. 8, 15 AS: Of course they are technically.  You’ve probably studied this.  You just don’t have shareholders but you have business interest that you answer to and high salaries you try to pay. 7, 20 They know that very well. 12 If you look and see what you see all over the place is what’s paid for which is cancer centers, imaging centers, heart and vascular centers, neuro centers, even eating disorders, those pay. 6, 9, 10, 13, 14 AS: Even the addiction treatment centers and the recovery centers. 12, 13, 14 CJ: Those pay and you can hire cheap labor.  AS: People will keep coming back.  CJ: They don’t get well permanently.  I’ve seen the data especially with the opioids. 6, 13 I’ve seen it get worse and worse and worse. 6 I thought there would be this human cry from the medical profession, we’ve got to put a stop to this. 7, 14, 17, 18, 19 As you’ve seen it’s been very tepid. 6 You’re not seeing people up in arms. 6, 9 “Oh it’s so sad but you don’t want to cut off the people who need their medicines. 9, 12, 14 You don’t want to have them suffer.”  AS: They’re starting to feel like bad people now. 9, 12 CJ: It’s always these measured tones of “We’re not really doing that bad a job. 5, 8, 11, 18 You can’t make these people go through that.” 9 If you look at from a standpoint of you want to keep your customer happy that makes sense. 13, 18 That has been spurring my research not into just pain but also into medicine as a business. 6, 12, 14 I’ve done quite a bit of reading on that. 20 I think the American system is fundamentally broken. 8, 12 If it really had the patient in mind the opioid epidemic would have been fixed a long time ago. 13, 17, 18 It still isn’t.  AS: It’s rising.  It’s not even falling yet.  CJ: What do you see in the news? 6, 15, 16 You see we need more funding for treatment. 6, 12, 13 It’s a very consoling answer because medicine creates the problem and sells more medicine to solve the problem. 12, 14 AS: By medicine do you mean medication assisted treatment? 12, 13, 14 CJ: Medicated assisted therapy which is better than leaving untreated but they’re not doing what I advocate when I do all my talks. 12, 14 Stop writing for these medicines in the first place. 12, 14 Cut down drastically exposure. 5 Just like you have to smoke more than one cigarette to become addicted to tobacco, more exposure equals higher risk. 7, 12, 14, 17 You need to drastically reduce the amount of pain medicines that you are exposing the populations to. 5, 6, 12, 14 AS: This is just something that physicians can do.  More people are overdosing on prescription pain pills than heroin. 6, 9, 10, 16 CJ: Four out of five people who abuse heroin now started on pills. 6, 9, 12, 13, 16 You understand how it started with OxyContin right? 12, 17, 18 You’ve done all the research knowing that the opioid and heroin epidemic was not an accident. 12, 13, 16 This was engineering, this was engineered by deliberate pharmacy campaign in the mid to late 90s with the introduction of OxyContin to persuade the medical community that chronic pain is an undertreated epidemic characterized by needless suffering. 5, 6, 7, 10, 12, 13, 14, 19 Opioids are safe and the risk of addiction has been greatly exaggerated. 12, 14, 20 What were these long acting opioids used for primarily beforehand? 6, 13, 16, 17 Hospice patients mostly. 12 AS: Hospice and surgery recovery in hospital. 8 CJ: Acute injury in hospital and hospice patients but not back pain. 6, 8 Back pain doesn’t suddenly cure. 6 Back pain’s an ongoing thing. 6 You don’t take oral heroin ongoing for back pain. 6, 16 That’s what happened. 15 You can’t get rich on hospice patients.  You can make billions if you suddenly for every arthritis patient and every back pain patient you get them on these medicines which those things don’t go away, bulging disk and what have you. 6, 12, 14, 18, 20 It’s just the back version of arthritis.  Those things are lifelong. 10, 17 It’s a perfect drug for pharmacy. 5, 6, 17 They don’t want to do antibiotics which you take for two weeks and are done. 8, 15 They want you to invent a drug that you’re on for the rest of your life. 5, 6, 10 Lipitor, number one drug of all time. 5, 6 There’s not great data that says Lipitor helps anyone in the average population. 13, 20 It’s multi billions.  They pay physician leaders.  Cardiologists or the pain specialist at the Beth Israel Hospitals and Harvard recruit and pay the physician leaders at some of the top departments. 6, 9, 12, 19 Have them sort of fudge the data or find ways to manipulate the data. 13, 18 Spread the message down to the rest of us. 10 We don’t have time to go back and reduplicate all these studies. 5 We have to function with a level of trust like we do in all society. 9, 12 We trust that they’re giving us good information. 10 Porter and Jick.  AS: It wasn’t even a study.  CJ: It wasn’t a study it was a paragraph.  AS: It was a paragraph in a letter to the editor.  CJ: It was a five sentence paragraph. 5 It was an observation.  Observations are useful in that they often can lead to studies. 6, 13, 18 AS: That was a level of trust, coming back to the idea of trusting you colleagues with what their research is.  You reach a level of professionalism and you want to respect their opinion.  Of course you’re not going to go back and recheck everything.  CJ: Are you going to do every study about every condition?  You can’t be a sceptic because you don’t have time.  You’re taking care of people in pain. 6, 9, 11, 19 CJ: You have to trust that there is a code of ethics and rigorous scientific skepticism and that the population you’re intending to use these medicines for, chronic pain patients, you’ve tested it on that population. 6, 12, 13, 14 With Porter and Jick they tested on hospitalized patients briefly. 8, 19 AS: And said who was addicted? 12, 14 Who got addicted? 12, 14 One lady.  CJ: You got morphine after a fracture and you were likely to be okay.  We knew that. 16 It’s suspicious.  That letter to the editor was 1980.  Suddenly sixteen years later? 14 Now it’s evidence that opiates aren’t addictive? 14 AS: For Purdue Pharma.  CJ: That could only change the medical culture if they could coopt and manipulate physicians and they did that, paid them well. 7, 14 I’m very critical of my own profession that we are as vulnerable as we are to having our mission compromised by money. 8, 10 I can reach no other conclusion based on what I’ve studied and learned. 10, 13 That’s what happened. 15 The culture was changed. 13 Pain became the fifth vital sign. 11 The risks of opiates were exaggerated.  The prescriptions if you’ve seen the numbers went from like eighty million in 1992 to over two hundred and fifty million now. 6, 10, 12 You can just watch in lock step as the number of prescriptions went up. 10, 17 AS: So did the deaths. 18 CJ: So did the deaths, so did treatment admissions. 12, 13, 18 Which tells you another thing. 15 I say this in my lectures.  Traditionally addiction is a moral issue. 12, 13, 14 Here’s where I strongly disagree with the recovery community that uses terms like character defect and moral inventory. 6, 13, 17, 19 What an extraordinary thing that as marketing and sales changed and sales increased. 5, 13 At the same time, you had a dramatic increase in the number of immoral people in this country. 5, 9, 19 AS: Which huge character flaws. 13 CJ: With huge character flaws. 13 Who knew? 16 What a coincidence.  Right when you started throwing all these prescriptions and here’s five tablets, here’s thirty. 10 AS: And now we blame parents, parents blame themselves. 12, 20 It’s a perfect storm. 17 You can blame poverty.  There’s all these things that you can blame without having to look at what actually happened. 7, 15 CJ: Everyone should recognize too; the reasons these medicines do anything is your brain has a receptor for it. 12, 13, 14, 17 Your body makes morphine.  That’s what endorphins are.  Endorphin is just a contraction of the two words endogenous, meaning made from within, morphine. 10, 19 Endorphines or endorphins.  Your brain makes these chemicals. 13 In physiological doses, not pharmacologic doses.  Your brain doesn’t want you to be that happy all the time. 13, 18 AS: You’ve got stuff to do.  CJ: Giggling like an idiot all the time isn’t good for survival. 10 You need to be worried about is it too damn cold?  Do we have enough water? 16 Am I going to get eaten?  The state of the brain that helps survival is what evolution selected for. 13 It’s not giggling like an idiot all the time or that’s where we’d be.  AS: Or blissed out.  CJ: If you’re blissed out you’re not worried enough.  That’s not good for survival. 10 AS: You’re bait.  CJ: The brain doesn’t actually want you to be that happy all the time. 7, 13, 18 It wants you to be happy in selective situations and rewards them. 18 It doesn’t want you to be happy all the time. 18 What these chemicals do, you realize “I can be happy all the time. 13, 18 This is awesome.  I’m happy all the time.” 18 The brain pushes back. 13 The brain realizes, the brain wants homeostasis. 13 That’s a term in medicine that means the brain wants stability. 12, 13, 14, 17 It doesn’t want to be there.  The brain pushes back. 13 The brain stops reacting so well. 13 You take that medicine the next time, “That was nice but it wasn’t really quite as nice as the time before.” 11, 12, 14, 18 The reasons these medicines work is they cause an increase in dopamine in your brain’s reward center. 6, 12, 13, 14 That’s simplified but it’s a basic enough chemistry for most purposes. 15 It causes the release of dopamine, you feel euphoric, you feel awesome, “Why I shouldn’t I feel like that all the time?” 6, 13 That’s what leads people to keep going. 9 I can be happy all the time, who wouldn’t want that. 18 The brain pushes back. 13 Suddenly it doesn’t release so much dopamine.  It down regulates its receptors.  The morphine is there but there’s no receptor for it to bind to. 10 That’s what happens when people use it for a while. 6, 9, 13, 15 When you start to alter the brain’s chemistry you alter its receptors, you alter its circuitry, you’re in real trouble. 13, 15 Now when you stop using the medicine all together the brain says, “Alright this is not good. 6, 8, 10, 12, 13, 14 This is not good. 10 I don’t feel good.” 10 Because the normal physiologic morphine, you’ve kind of switched it off. 10, 16 The brains notices, “Where the hell is my morphine?” 10, 13 Because you’ve stopped making it. 10 Just as a body builder who takes testosterone their testicles shrink. 8, 17 The body says, “Why am I wasting all this metabolic energy making testosterone when I’m just getting it from the environment.” 8, 10, 12 So the testicles shrink.  Same thing happens in the brain. 13, 15 It realizes if it’s getting all this from the environment there’s no reason to make it myself. 12 When patients who are using these medicines and take it for a long time have completely distorted their brain chemistry you can’t just stop it because once you just stop it they feel awful. 6, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17 I can put you, me, you put all of us on it for around the clock for two months you will not feel good if we suddenly say no. 10, 11, 16 That is enough to change your brain chemistry. 13, 15 That’s the issue. 13 It’s not even just an issue for chronic pain. 6, 13 Obviously chronic pain, guaranteed, since chronic pain never goes away you’re going to be on these medicines for at least three months. 6, 11, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20 That’s plenty of time to change your chemistry. 15 Now you’re on it for good. 10 AS: Then your pain comes back and you feel bad. 6 CJ: It doesn’t feel like I’m addicted it just feels like my pain came back. 6, 12, 14 I’ve got to get back on.  Withdrawal is painful. 5, 6 People coming off heroin say they feel awful, they’re in pain everywhere. 6, 11, 16 Being on these medicines for chronic pain almost guarantees they’re going to be on it for life. 6, 10, 12, 14 Three months is plenty of time. 11, 16 It even is concerning when they have an acute injury like a surgery or something like that.  Even if you have a knee replacement or have this bad fracture. 12 It’s not like the brain says, “Oh well I’m not going to adjust to these medicines because look you broke your bone.” 8, 12, 13, 14 It will still start to change over time.  AS: Your brain will. 13 CJ: Your brain doesn’t care that your leg is broken, therefore I won’t respond to these medicines in a normal homeostatic reduced responsiveness over time way. 5, 8, 12, 13, 14, 16, 18, 19 Even if you do have a fracture don’t take these medicines for two months. 11, 12, 14, 16 Take it for two weeks and then realize it’s going to hurt while you heal. 15 Then you go back to the customer service thing. 19 AS: It’s been three months and I’m still hurting. 11, 16 CJ: I didn’t pay for this. If you don’t keep active your body ages and gets worse.
