CJ: I really feel this naive crusader in me that wanted to break policy things and right wrongs. 11, 12, 18 I thought I'd go to medicine to do it one at a time. 12, 14, 17, 18 Then as I learned in medicine, I'm not sure if I'm doing that. 10, 12, 14 Don't get me wrong. 11 Most people in medicine absolutely are trying to do the right thing. 9, 12, 14 They want to do the right thing. 12 We straighten out fractures and we intubated people in respiratory failure. 9, 14 That is the goal of most doctors. 12, 14 They still do great things. 20 The motivations that people who create that climate don't do it with the patient's best outcomes in mind. 9 When you hear these stories about patients being held in ERs for two days because there's no mental health bed for someone who's suicidal. 9, 12, 16, 19 There's a reason for that.  The ER doctor who sees them puts them on a hold because they're trying to do the best thing for them. 6, 12, 14 But the reason they can't find a bed for them but they can get a heart attack patient up there in thirty minutes is a matter of economic priority and who is invested in that and where does that come from. 9, 14, 15 That comes from the level above the level of doctor and patient. 12, 14 Anyone who tells anyone that what your health outcome is just you talking to your doctor. 12, 14, 15, 19 Nonsense.  It is never ever been you and your doctor. 12, 14, 16 What determines that outcome is also a matter of economic investment and priority prior to that doctor ever getting there. 12, 14, 17 That doctor who wants to do the best for their patient can get the acute heart attack up to the cath lab. 9, 12, 14 They can do that right away. 12, 18, 20 That same doctor is going to put their patient on hold and they're going to sit there for two days. 12, 14, 16 There's no medical outlet. 7, 14 There's no place for them.  We've decided this is not valued. 14 AS: Mental health and addiction are treated the same. 12, 14, 19 CJ: I sympathize with hospitals that are put in the position of losing money on some types of healthcare and having to make up for it by doing other stuff. 8, 10, 19 You'd like to think that healthcare that provides a service and a value should always be in the positive. 18, 19 Like you're doing something good. 10 You shouldn't lose money for doing a service that improves the health of someone. 8, 9, 10, 19 Hospitals are in the business where providing the service causes them to lose so they have to make up for it here. 6, 9, 13, 19 Don't think that doctors and hospital people are a different class of human that are removed from incentives. 7, 8, 9, 12, 14, 15, 19 There's a reason you need a federal act to stop patient dumping. 8 Do you know what the Emergency Medicine Treatment and Active Labor Act is? 12, 14 AS: No. CJ: EMTALA.  That was the act that stopped patient dumping.  That's why you can go to an emergency room and you have to be seen. 6, 14 AS: Any emergency room you go to now. 12, 14 Right because there were places that said "You can't come in here." 14 You could turn them away. 18, 20 CJ: They were poor patients they found that had appendicitis.  We're going to send you to county. 14, 19 They do a lot more than we do.  AS: Now I remember this but not the name of it.  CJ: That's what George Bush said, or George W. said.  That's what Mitt Romney said, "We do have a universal health care system. 19 We have emergency departments." 9, 12, 19 That's what they meant.  You had to be seen. 6 AS: That was their big Reagan era contribution to healthcare. 19 CJ: Understand if doctors and other hospital healthcare people weren't sending off the poor patients you wouldn't have needed that law. 8, 9, 12, 13, 14, 19 If they were doing what their oath said.  They were trying to maximize return on their time so they sent away the patients who weren't paying. 5, 14 They were forced by law to not do that. 8, 13 Don't think that you've got this different class of animal human in the healthcare industry that doesn't pay close attention to that. 7, 9, 10, 19 AS: What do you want to do in the next few years? 14 Where do you see your work and your career going? 6, 15, 19 CJ: I've moved to urgent care because the hours are better. 7, 15, 19 It doesn't pay as well.  I sleep at night better. 16 Would I go back to emergency medicine? 12, 14 Probably not full time. 14 The burn out in emergency medicine is really high. 7, 12, 14, 18 It's not what your body was meant to do.  I don't have children so I don't need tons of time. 5, 14, 20 This public health work I do does give me purpose. 19 I feel this is a good mission to be on. 10 It just so happens that this problem I began work on over a decade ago is now the number one public health problem in the country. 12, 13, 14, 15, 19 That's why I'm front and center on it, at least in this state.  Since it hasn't stopped I'm imagining that the work for me to do here is going to continue.  AS: For the meantime you'll stay in urgent care? 19 CJ: I'll just keep doing that unless I get to the point where the work I do public health wise, speaking educating, helping systems develop policy, that itself becomes compensated to a point where I could do that. 14, 19 At some point does North Dakota need help?  I haven't talked there.  Wisconsin do they have a problem? 12 I don't know of anyone doing my job in either of those places. 11, 12 AS: In this way. 18 What's the name of the opioid group that you're working on? 13 CJ: The Department of Human Services? 9, 12 DHS is the Opioid Prescribing Workgroup.  I'm also on the board on the National Organization of Physicians for Responsible Opioid Prescribing.  AS: I'm excited about your Opioid Workgroup.  Let me know if you need any help with that. 12 CJ: I think you've got a system of incentives that are poorly designed to solve this as they are constructed now. 11, 12 With people, many of whom are well meaning, but are operating in a system they didn't set up. 9 The people who can control how the incentives are set up don't want to change. 9, 18 That's our system right now. 12 AS: Thank you.  Thanks so much.  That was really great. 18, 20

Julie Hooker Narrator Amy Sullivan Interviewer February 2, 2017 Julie Hooker -JH Amy Sullivan -AS JH: Where can I go, what can I do?  I find help for the him but the beds aren’t open and they won’t be open for three weeks. 15 This guy’s using heroin daily and he could easily die between now and then. 6, 12, 16 That’s what we went to go tell the Lieutenant Governor, that we can’t as clinicians stand by.  Part of the reason why there’s a three week waiting list, this is why I went to her, we have a system set up in Minnesota and many states for people with public assisted medical plants, PMAPs they’re called. 7, 9, 14, 15, 19 The PMAP will pay for treatment but all the beds in the cities are filled and we’ve got waiting lists but in Wadena they’ve got an open bed. 5, 7, 12, 13, 15 They’re dying for people to come there because they’ve got open beds and clinicians ready to serve. 9 The PMAP won’t pay for it because it’s out of the seven county area, thereby funneling everybody back into the cities which creates the three week waiting list. 7, 8, 15, 19 My talk with the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, was can we take a look at that system and stop that?  If I can get somebody a bed in Wadena and they’re willing to drive down here and pick him up. 5 AS: They’ll come get them?  They’ll come get them.  The only way that it works, you think it’s great because this guy’s got insurance. 9, 18, 20 If he didn’t have insurance, if he comes in without any insurance at all now the county will say no because he has an open case here in Ramsey County so we’re not going to fund. 12, 17, 19 They might Hennepin and Ramsey but you have to work at it.  AS: Which is what I had to do to get my daughter into Tapestry.  So you know. 12 AS: I tried to do all kinds of things.  I tried to get a friend in St. Paul to let her sleep on his couch and say she’s homeless. 16, 20 I understood it but at the time to me that was not lying.  That was just getting my daughter in treatment. 12, 13 These are the barriers that I witness, we witness every day. 16 Part of my solution because the system is so broken. 8, 9 Even though somebody really could benefit from an in-patient treatment bed this is what Resurrection Recovery was kind of created for. 12, 13, 14, 15, 18 We’re an intensive outpatient treatment with intensive case management services and we have referrals for housing, transitional housing. 6, 11, 12, 13, 17, 19 We’re purchasing our own house. 6, 13 That’s what my bookkeepers are doing today. 16 We’re doing some year-end stuff to submit to the bank for our loan. 14 We will buy our own house because we’ve been trying to refer people to some of the GRH housing. 6, 9, 13 Have you heard of that? 9 AS: What does that stand for?  JH: Group residential housing. 6, 9, 13 The county will pay for those. 19 Even if somebody has health insurance. 19 Health insurance won’t pay for your housing but even if somebody has health insurance I can request that the county pay for the housing and I’ve never had them turn me down unless somebody has an open case in another county. 6, 16, 17, 19 AS: What constitutes an open case? 17 If they’re receiving food stamps or general assistance.  AS: I could see how those could get really complicated and just stop someone from getting treatment if they aren’t living… 6, 12, 13, 18 Why not a one payer system?  AS: Instead of each county dealing with all of it. 14, 19 You’re a Minnesotan, how about that?  Not a Ramsey County resident. 9 How about we got to a one payer system for the entire state of Minnesota.  AS: When you think of how many of us have to work in other counties, we drive home to another county, we might even drive to another sector of the state. 5, 19 But for poor people they’re not supposed to be allowed to have that kind of flexibility. 9, 10 It drives me crazy. 5, 20 Because this system is so complex and is creating more barriers for people. 9, 13 I’m on the ground floor with this and I have people in here sitting in that chair crying because nobody will help them. 9, 14 I just can’t sit by and say, “Well sucks to be you.  Okay I’ll see what I can do. 6 Somebody will call you in a few weeks.” 15 If you’re still living, if you still have a phone, if we’re still able to contact you, if you’re still in the city, if you’re still in the state. 8, 16 I’ll be just a little bit political here for a second. 20 We had a number of people coming from other states, specifically Illinois because Illinois doesn’t have as easy access to chemical dependency services as Minnesota does. 9, 13, 19 We have this huge influx of people that are non-native Minnesotans, not people living here or paying taxes here who immediately get put on county assistance and their treatment is paid for. 9, 12, 13, 14, 19 They get a bus pass, they get their housing paid for, all of those things. 6 That’s great. 20 It’s so nice that we’re that magnanimous but what about the people who live here who have paid taxes here, whose families are here who are paying taxes here and I can’t find a treatment bed for them. 9, 12, 13, 14, 17, 18 I just can’t reconcile that, I can’t.  If we’re going to open our door that wide for people from other states why close it on the people that live here now. 9, 10, 12 My solution would be the one payer system which everybody tells me is never going to happen. 9, 15, 16 AS: One payer for health care? 19 JH: Yes.  AS: Nationally?  Wouldn’t that be wonderful. 18 AS: I just wondered about the scope of your dream. 5 JH: Let’s start small.  Let’s start with Minnesota.  [Break in Recording]  It is our revenue generating business so that we can purchase houses and do things. 6, 9, 13 Then I started a nonprofit called the Continuing Care Center which does all the case management. 12, 15, 17 I have a MN Sure navigator so he helps people sign up for health insurance. 9, 11, 19 That office is in this building but in another office space. 19 All the clients that come to us are basically, have you heard of Maslow? 9, 10, 19 Maslow’s 10 Hierarchy of Need, the pyramid.  Almost everybody who comes here, their basic needs aren’t even being met.  As a substance abuse and mental health provider it’s proven a fact that they don’t a place to live and they don’t have any clothes, a winter jacket, and they don’t have an ID. 6, 12, 13, 19 “I lost my Social Security card and all my clothes were in a backpack and it got stolen.” 11, 14 Rather than just say, “Well just stop drinking and everything will be fine.” 5, 11 It was just so overwhelming in the very beginning. 11 I didn’t know what I didn’t know. 12 AS: In the beginning when you started this? 11 JH: Yes.  JH: Two years ago. 13, 14 AS: Just two years ago. 13, 14 Partly because I worked in the field for quite a while.  I have a master’s degree in Human Services.  I’ve worked in Community Services. 19 I’ve been homeless.  I’ve been an injecting heroin user. 6, 13 I’ve been incarcerated.  I’ve lived and people like us often make the best counselor because we can be relatable to people and not say, “Will you tell me why you’d this?” 7, 9 If somebody asked me that question, then I say you’re not ready to hear the answer if you have to ask the question. 9 It doesn’t make any sense.  It was just two years ago. 13, 14 I have a business partner and the two of decided, he doesn’t work here but financially we put this place together. 8, 9, 14 He works for Health Care for the Homeless which is inside the Dorothy Day Center through West Side Community Health. 9, 19 His employer is West Side Community Health. 19 He’s stationed at the Dorothy Day Center. 8 The two of us together were saying “What can we do to help this population now and in real time?” 8, 12 In patient treatment beds were so hard to come by, still are, with the bottlenecking of everybody with the PMAPS and the seven county metro area and the empty beds in Wadena. 8, 9, 12, 13, 14, 19 This is kind of the beginning step to changing that system. 11, 17 When people come in and I say, “It’s a three to four week waiting list and I can get you started here today. 9, 15, 16 I can get you in touch with case management services so that we can get some of these things moving.” 12, 17, 19 AS: Your model is to provide services immediately and to try to hold on to them, keep them for these three weeks before you can actually get them. 7, 15, 19 I’ll put out the call for a bed and we will continue to help the client call. 10, 14 AS: You’re kind of that bridge then that I was wishing for a few years ago. 13, 14 That many parents end up wishing for because we can’t have our children in our homes. 5, 14, 20 We’ve reached that point where it’s dangerous and destructive for everybody. 11 Are you familiar with TAM then? 8 JH: The Addict’s Mother. 14 AS: Oh yes.  I’m on that page.  We’ll backspace here.  Initially with my history, I’d been free from addiction if you will for over twenty years but for the first ten I didn’t want anything to do with people like me. 9, 12, 14, 15 I tried to work in the corporate world.  AS: I’m going to make you pause for a second. 6, 13 You have to say on here that you give me permission to record this starting when I started the recording.  You have to say your name and say that you give me permission.  Go ahead. 14 JH: Hi, I’m Julie Hooker and I do give permission to Amy to record whatever I’m saying today. 16 AS: We are at Resurrection Recovery in St. Paul.  Julie Hooker is the founder and director of this treatment and support center. 12, 13, 18, 19 I’ll have you sign this release form later when we’re done. 11 It’s great that you actually started this talking about what you’re doing here because on the way over I was thinking, “I think what I want to do is have her start with what she’s doing right now.” 7, 12, 18, 20 I’ve usually been starting these with your childhood and going backwards. 14, 20 You’ve kind of given a good idea of what it is you’re doing now but why don’t you start from the point where you tried to work in the corporate world and then let’s talk about your career in treatment. 10, 12, 13, 15, 19 Then let’s go back.  The other option would be you just tell your story as things come up. 15 It doesn’t matter to me if it’s chronological.  If I start with trying to work in the corporate world I’ve already bypassed the many “unsuccessful” attempts at recovery.  AS: Do you want to just start with your childhood and your addiction story? 12, 14, 15, 20 Where were born and where did you grow up? 10, 14 I’m a native Minnesotan. 14 I’m a blond haired, blue eyed Swedish Norwegian girl, Lutheran, ate lutefisk and lefse at Christmas every year. 5, 7, 14 AS: Where did you grow up? 10 In the Twin Cities area but we moved around a lot. 7, 8, 15 My dad was in social work. 14, 19 My mom was a stay at home mom. 14 I’m the middle born of six children. 5, 7, 14, 20 We were upper middle class. 7 There wasn’t a lot of drama. 5 There was a lot of love and affection. 14 I didn’t have that sometimes typical upbringing of neglect and abandonment and abuse. 6, 12, 13 There was a lot of alcohol growing up. 6, 10 I started drinking eight, nine because Dad always drank with a can of Grain Belt 5, 11, 16, 18 Beer between his legs and drove. 5 “Give me another beer honey.” 8 He was nice when he drank. 5, 16, 18 He was fun and he was friendly and he’d give us whisker rubs and he was not mean. 20 He was more fun.  I’d be like, “Can I have some money Dad? 8, 10 Can I get you another beer Dad?”  The reward for going to get him another beer was the first sip out of the can. 14 I had learned that that was a reward for doing something good. 10 AS: What year were you born? 14 I didn’t know that that was unusual. 12 AS: That’s powerful. 10, 17 I graduated high school at seventeen. 7 My dad got me a keg of beer. 14 For a party. 9, 20 That kind of upbringing that it wasn’t a scary or negative thing when people drank. 5, 9, 16 It was fun and everybody had a good time. 10 AS: There was no violence or despair or negative consequences? 6 Back then here in Minnesota you could, I remember doing this, I was probably fifteen.  You could go to the bar with your parents and drink as long as they were with you. 5, 17, 20 I learned how to shoot dice and play pool. 10, 14 It was a kind of different view on especially alcohol. 6 AS: Did you understand your tolerance then pretty easily? 10, 17, 18 My parents started serving us wine at dinner when we were in our late teens if it was a special occasion. 20 [Phone Call] 8 Yes, I guess.  I have recollections of drunkenness in my teens. 5, 8, 14 I never really saw it as being a negative. 16, 18 I’ve never had a DUI. 16 I don’t get drunk and have somebody beat me up. 5, 8, 14 Historically it just wasn’t that big of a deal.  The big deal I guess it was in the early 80s with cocaine. 16 In 1975 I graduated from high school. 7 In 1978 I went to Oregon on a vacation.  I stayed for twenty-three years. 14 True story. 15 I just fell in love with Oregon. 14 I ended up on this kind of hippie commune.  We were growing pot. 6, 10 It was a cool thing to do. 17 I’m kind of a hippie at heart. 9 AS: Whereabouts in Oregon?  That commune was in a place called Harlan, Oregon which is halfway between Corvallis and Newport in the coast range. 7, 14, 16, 18 I don’t know how well you know Oregon. 12 Kind of at the Northwest base of Mary’s Peak which is the tallest peak in the coast range. 7, 16 Twenty miles as the crow flies from the coast inland. 16 I lived there and then I’m a musician so I was playing in Lincoln City. 7, 9 AS: What do you play?  JH: Piano, guitar, dulcimer.  Old Joni Mitchell fan.  Who else plays the dulcimer besides Joni Mitchell. 9 It was there that I met the man that would be my husband. 14 We ended up doing cocaine together and growing marijuana. 8, 10, 14, 16 We ended up moving into town because I missed running water and a washing machine, a toaster, flushing toilets. 8, 16 AS: How long did you last on the commune? 17 JH: Almost two years. 14 That was a long time. 17 It was probably one of the most fond memories I have of my entire life. 10 It was phenomenal. 12 Even then things weren’t out of hand.  Everything was manageable, life was good. 10 Moving back into the city and being in a relationship that was a little toxic to begin with, that toxicity grew. 19, 20 There was a lot of betrayal and a lot of abandoning the principles of the vows we took.  AS: You got married? 7 We got married and were childless for the first eight years of our marriage. 7, 14 I couldn’t have any children. 5, 14, 20 I had to have surgery to make it possible.  Once had my first child my focus was no longer on my husband, it was on my child. 14, 17 Therein lies the problem. 12 He was not happy with sharing me. 18 It got really sick and toxic. 15, 18 I think from that, we had two children together, right after the second child was born it was very, very ugly. 5, 8, 12, 14, 20 We were living in separate rooms in the same house. 6, 13, 14 We divorced and then that’s when things just went kind of south for me. 7 I was just looking for some kind of validation.  When you split up like that it feels like I’ve done something wrong even though I don’t think it’s wrong for me to put all my energy into this baby that we just spent tons of money. 8, 10, 11 It’s day four, five o’clock come home honey kind of thing. 8, 16 It was after the divorce and the very first guy that I hooked up with was a career heroin addict. 14, 15, 19 Very first guy. 14 I was enamored. 5 I just thought that was cool. 17, 18 AS: With him or did you try it right away? 12, 18, 20 JH: Almost right away. 12, 18, 20 A little hesitation. 20 It went from no big deal to oh my gosh now this is a devastating thing. 12 It’s really hard to get out of once you’re in. 9, 18 I’ve heard many heroin addicts and myself included say, “The very first time I did it, it was like, where have you been all my life?” 9, 10, 14, 16 That’s exactly what happened to me. 15 It just felt wonderful. 11, 18 He said it felt like a warm hug. 11 I went, yes that’s what it does.  AS: You don’t have to have a person there to hug you.  Because people leave. 9, 18 Whether they’re there physically or not. 6 AS: How old were your kids at this point?  One and three, babies.  I don’t think she was even one yet.  Very quickly spiraled into selling cocaine and heroin so that I could get more heroin. 16 I smoked some of the cocaine and shot some of it too. 11, 14, 16 How did this happen? 15 It really was kind of that. 18 It wasn’t headstrong. 14 I’m a mom, I’ve got these little kids. 14, 20 I worked like hell to be able to have children and here I am going “What the hell is happening to me?” 5, 14, 15, 20 My house got raided in a drug raid. 5, 6, 13 AS: Was he living there?  Well he stayed there but he wasn’t living there.  He got charged with frequenting when it was really mostly his business. 12, 18 I got charged with possession with intent to distribute.  I immediately went to jail.  The kids immediately got taken out of the home.  My husband and I had been divorced for quite a while and we had joint custody. 7, 14 Thank God we had joint custody because otherwise the kids would have gone into the system.  My husband had remarried right after our relationship. 7, 12, 14, 19 He was forty I think and she was seventeen.  I’m not kidding.  AS: How old were your kids when the raid happened? 15 JH: About five, six years. 14 The worst part of it was about six or seven years. 9, 14 AS: The kids are six and eight.  It was terrible. 11 There were syringes around.  It was Hooker’s home for the homeless and soup kitchen.  Whoever wanted to come over came over. 14, 18 AS: Hooker being your last name?  JH: Yes.  Actually there’s a little funny story. 9, 15, 20 As things progressed and got worse and worse prostitution became a viable option.  I’d been arrested for that.  I will never forget the first time when I went into court and they call your name and they read the charges. 14, 16 They said, “Julie Hooker, prostitution” and the courtroom erupts in laughter. 14 Even the judge was covering his mouth.  My attorney started laughing.  He was a trick.  This is so humiliating and you would think would this not be enough.  I was charged with that.  Actually it was the only misdemeanor I’ve ever had.  All the rest are felonies because of the drug charges. 5, 6 In Oregon at that time they were just starting the drug court thing. 5, 6 I didn’t have any priors.  I didn’t even have a parking ticket.  I’d never been arrested. 16 I was a good, upper middle class, white, Midwestern girl. 7, 10, 19 How did this happen? 15 AS: By this time, we’re in the mid-80s?  Yes, mid to late 80s.  I went to jail that day. 16 The kids were terribly traumatized.  It was a SWAT team that broke in. 8 They had masks and guns and they used a percussion bomb to shatter my living room window. 6, 13, 14, 16 JH: I don’t know. 12 AS: They couldn’t just knock on the door.  That was the late 80s.  I had a neighbor that happened to. 15 It was frightening to be the neighbor. 12 It’s frightening to have it happen. 12, 15 My kids, for years I couldn’t talk about it without crying I still tear up a little bit. 14, 20 The kids were sleeping in a bedroom. 5, 14, 16 I was in the living room and I’m buck ass naked laying on the floor when this all happens. 14, 15 I’ve got all these masked, gun toting guys come in.  A guy’s got a gun to the back of my head and a knee in my back saying, “Don’t move.” 14, 15 I remember turning my head and seeing my daughter standing in the hallway. 6, 14, 18, 20 Oh my God it was horrifying.  I don’t have any violence. 6 I don’t have any guns.  The kids witness it and then they try to hand the kids teddy bears.  They came in with teddy bears.  The whole thing is like what the hell is wrong with you? 11 AS: It’s a teddy bear that gives comfort, not other adults.  JH: I’m handcuffed.  They threw a towel over me.  I couldn’t even hug my kids.  AS: To get you out of the house? 6, 13 For fear that I might try to hand them something. 10 I’m not kidding.  It was horrible. 10 The kids leave and I remember one of the officers was saying, “Take them to child protection services.” 8, 14, 18, 19 I said, “No, I’ve got joint custody.  You’re calling their dad. 14, 16 Here’s his number.”  They said, “Isn’t he a drug addict too?” 5, 6, 14 I said, “You sure didn’t do your research.”  He had some issues but he didn’t have issues like I did. 12, 13 The assumption was there that he must be too.  I had to fight with them.  They did bring the kids; they didn’t have to go into child protection. 14 AS: They did take them to your husband? 14 Yes, but he was married to that other girl. 7 They’d been married for quite a while and they had two little kids. 7, 20 They were living in subsidized housing where they couldn’t have two more kids. 6 Because of that they got kicked out of their house and were homeless and living in the shelter. 6, 13 I’m sitting in jail.  AS: With an addiction. 12, 14 Look at how many lives are just shattered all because of that. 5 What I know today is in other countries if something like that is going on, the percussion bomb and the SWAT team and the guns and all that stuff doesn’t happen. 12, 15, 16 It’s let’s pull you in, let’s sit down with a team full of people, a doctor, an addiction specialist, a mental health specialist and find out what we can do to help you. 9, 12, 14, 19 That’s what happens in other countries. 15 Here it’s still this war on drugs and that was literally a war on drug addicts. 5, 6, 14 AS: It was, it still is.  It still is.  AS: That was at the high point of that. 7 I was in the middle of that. 7 Consequently, that history informs who I am today. 15, 16 Having experienced that informs how I do treatment today. 12, 13, 16, 18 I’ve been working in the field for quite a while and every place that I have worked I’ve been called into the office saying, “Julie you can’t say things like that. 14 Julie that’s not how we do things here.  Julie she has to provide a UA today. 16 You can’t tell her to just go ahead and go. 14 You must toe the line.” 9 I have never been a firm supporter of the urine drug screen policy. 5, 6, 16 Let’s see what we can catch people doing kind of thing. 6, 9 That doesn’t matter to me.  What matters to me is what can I do to help you with what’s happening in your life today. 10, 15, 16 Not you have a urine drug screen today and people panic and come up with lies. 5, 6, 9, 16 AS: And bring in other people’s pee. 9 I had people who would go heat it up in a microwave and hand it to me. 9 It’d be hot.  One time there was a whole bunch of bubbles in there.  I’m like, that’s like Mountain Dew.  JH: Yes.  I said, “If you peed those bubbles out you’d be screaming.”  I just went through so much of that.  Working in the system of abstinence only and a punitive approach flew in the face of my personal belief system having experienced what I had. 18, 19 I’ve been through six different treatments myself, all abstinence based. 12, 13 That was the only indicator of wellness. 14 AS: You never were in a medication assisted? 14, 16 You never did methadone? 6, 8, 16 I refused to do methadone because I used to sell heroin and I was the girl in the parking lot at the methadone clinic. 6, 7, 8, 13, 16 You could come out with your carry outs and I’d trade you a little piece of heroin and I had the juice lined up in my fridge for backup. 9, 16, 20 That was a joke to me.  I understand how it can work, I do. 17, 18 There was no Suboxone at that time. 8 To me at that time methadone clinics were no different, it’s just the federal government was your dope dealer. 8, 12 AS: And you had to pee for them.  You had to stand in line in a humiliating way at a very, very early time in the morning. 9, 18 People would drive by and see this line of people. 5, 6, 9 AS: It’s set up to be humiliating.  It’s a punitive system. 19 Of course when we are humiliated we are going to stop the behavior.  In one of the treatments I was in, this is back when the field and clinicians thought this was the way to do it. 12, 13, 14, 17, 18 Back where they put you in the center of the room and everybody in the treatment group would tear you down. 12, 13, 14 I had a sign that said, “master manipulator.” 11 I had to wear that sign and everybody would tell me how manipulative I was. 11 AS: What kind of therapy was that called and where did it happen? 12, 15 JH: Oregon.  It was all over everywhere.  AS: I’ve heard about it. 9 You have to tear them down and build them back up.  Start from scratch.  Get rid of all the ego.  It didn’t work for me.  AS: It could also for some people, particularly be even more traumatizing and humiliating. 9 I already felt shame. 11 Ten times what they could give me. Ninety-five percent of treatment centers in the United States as of five years ago were abstinence only. 12, 13, 14 AS: You did your master’s thesis on the Minnesota Model?  JH: Not on the Minnesota Model but on abstinence versus harm reduction model. 5, 14 I know that harm reduction is not the antithesis of abstinence. 5, 12, 14 It’s a bridge.  Most people don’t see it that way. 6, 9, 18 “They’re just going to keep doing it if you provide them with clean syringes.”  The same thing happened with handing out condoms. 15 “They’re just going to have more sex if you give them condoms.” 12 No they’re going to have safe sex if you give them condoms. 12 I think that’s why it was really difficult. 10, 18 I used to have this spiel down because I said it all the time. 6, 13, 16 It was in the Ronald Reagan administration who made it law that this revolving loan fund shall be available in every state to provide the model for Oxford Housing. 6, 13 Oxford House started in 1978 by Paul Molloy in Silver Spring, Maryland which is a suburb of Washington D.C. Paul was a chronic alcoholic, politician, worked in the House or Senate or whatever drunk. 5, 6, 8, 13, 14 He beat his wife. 20 He wasn’t a really nice guy. 18 They were living in a halfway house and the halfway house lost its funding. 6, 11, 13, 14, 18 They were all going to get kicked out of this house. 6, 13 Paul in his infinite wisdom.  He calls it he stumbled into it because he was drunk. 5, 8, 14, 16 He stumbled into this idea of a democratically run, we can do it ourselves, let’s not close this place, let’s do it ourselves. 8, 9, 10 That’s how Oxford House started was this guy’s vision. 6, 13 A bunch of drunks could get together and vote on whether they were going to purchase an electric can opener or get the hand crank one. 5, 8, 14 They had to vote on it.  That’s a true story. 5, 15 He said they had a debate for forty-five minutes over whether they were going to purchase one or a hand one. 8, 15 That’s the democratic process. 17 I think that model was supposed to have been open to all states.  Ronald Reagan made it law. 13 When I came here I quoted it.  I used to have the spiel down perfect and I don’t remember it now. 6, 12, 13, 16, 17 I came here and I spoke to somebody in the Department of Human Services about it. 9, 12 His response was, “I think we may have had something like that but I don’t think it’s in operation anymore.” 13 I went “That doesn’t even make any sense.”  So because I couldn’t access any money through any kind of revolving loan fund that’s when I went to Oxford House and said, “What do you guys got in the bank? 6, 8, 9, 10, 13 Will you help us open this house?” 6, 13 I talked to the landlord and brokered a deal. 5, 8 AS: Were these rental houses? 6, 9, 13 They’re all rental houses. 6, 9, 13 Oxford House cannot own. 6, 13 It’s a transient population. 17 AS: The loan is for an initial down payment of rent? 12 First and last month’s rent. 16 AS: But people pay rent to live there? 9 You have to pay to live there.  AS: The benefit is you’re living with other sober people and making your own rules. 9, 10, 13, 15 You’re being supported.  AS: It’s the same community support that seems to work. 6, 19 Yes, and it’s lacking.  We have a little bit of it with this GRH but with GRH housing it is run by somebody. 6, 8, 20 If that person is kind and gentle and considerate then that transition can be wonderful. 9, 17, 18 If that person is not, I can think of a place now that’s transitional GRH housing for men where the guy who runs it is just a jerk. 6, 8, 12, 17 He’s mean to people, threatening people. 9 “If you don’t tell me who did this I’m going to kick you all out.”  That kind of...  You lose power; you don’t have power in that GRH housing because it’s not democratically run. 6, 8, 9, 17 It was autocratically run. 8 Minnesota believes that that system has been working for them and that’s what they want to continue.  I disagree and I really support the Oxford House model. 6, 13, 18 But guess what?  There’s no money in it for anybody. 8, 10 There’s no money in it. 8, 10 There’s nobody running it. 8 They run themselves. 8 It’s hard to fight against that system here. 9 I just recognized that pretty early on. 10, 17 I’m not fighting this battle right now. 12 I started to work in the corporate world.  I was working for an inventory service company that did inventory and probably traded companies. 10, 14, 19 I’m good at it but I hate it. 10 I absolutely hate it.  What happened was almost everybody that I work with would come to me at one point or another and say, “This is what’s happening and I don’t know what’s going on.” 12, 15 AS: In their own life? 10 In their own lives.  Then I was like, “What are you doing?”  AS: People should pay me for this.  I decided to go back to school to become a licensed alcohol and drug counselor which was a great idea at the time. 5, 6, 7, 13, 14, 20 I’m still pleased that I did it but it led me to become face to face with a system that I can’t work in, this punitive abstinence only system where I was in trouble almost every place I worked. 19 I would get called into the office saying, “Julie you can’t do that.  Julie don’t tell people that story.” 9, 15 You know what I mean? 12 “Julie don’t.  Julie stop.  Write Julie up.  Julie’s a malcontent.”  I was like, “Oh my gosh.  You’re questioning yourself.  Meanwhile I’ve still got Gabor Mate over here.  I’d been reading In The Realm of Hungry Ghosts and I’m like, “I know that person he’s writing about. 12 I love the way he’s responding to that person.” 14, 18 Relationships are everything.  This whole notion of abstinence only and the punitive nature does nothing to repair the disease, it perpetuates the disease. 19 I left, not really left the field, but started working in mental health. 12, 14, 18, 19 In the mental health field there’s more harm reduction and a little more compassion. 5, 12, 14, 19, 20 I don’t know how else to put it. 12 I went to work for South Metro Human Services, they call themselves something else now. 12 I worked on an ACT team which is a sort of community treatment where we go to people out in the field. 9, 12, 13, 19 We meet with them. 18 They don’t come to our office.  I was their first LADC that they had hired. 5, 14 I got to try and do some of this, they call it integrated dual diagnostic treatment IDDT, it was truly integrating the two. 12, 13 It was there that I saw my approach, the way I’ve always been my entire life was not only accepted but encouraged. 10, 12, 18 I went, “Well how do we do this in the field of substance use treatment?” 6, 12, 13 My business partner and I over many cups of coffee and lots of lofty dreams narrowed it down to let’s do this. 5, 9, 16 He’s working for Health Care for the Homeless.  He’s working with this very damaged population with great need and lengthy substance use, chronic. 6, 13, 20 AS: Like the Portland Hotel Society.  Exactly like that.  AS: His name’s Eric?  JH: Eric Bacon.  Just the two of us starting having these conversations.  He’s an AA guy.  He’s an abstinence only but he’s in that little bridge where he says, “Okay maybe.” 5, 20 He’s supportive of the Minnesota Model and whatnot. 19 I am too but I’m also flexible in there are multiple paths. 17 There’s not one size fits all. 15 AS: There are people who know that they can’t touch anything because touching the one thing, the one beer, leads them back to meth. 6, 9, 12 Then there’s people who’re like “I can drink a beer every once and awhile. 5, 9 It’s not going to be a big deal.”  I am one of those people. 9 I was told, “Julie don’t tell people that.” 9, 16 AS: When you would say that at work?  JH: Yes.  “I had some champagne on Christmas Eve.”  “Julie don’t tell people that. 9 You cannot say that.  Are you sure you’re okay?”  I’m like what in the world?  As I had said earlier, it wasn’t ever really problematic for me. 12, 15, 18 The problem arose with other substances and the trauma and the betrayal and all those kinds of things that happened to me. 6, 12, 15 I don’t drink. 5 I don’t call myself a drinker. 5 I can drink and not have to have ten. 5 I can have a glass of champagne. 11 I don’t run and go look for some heroin. 8, 16 Early on I was in AA and NA.  I had a sponsor.  I was doing the deal because that’s all I knew and that’s all I was told. 16 I scratched the cornea of my left eye. 14 I don’t know if you’ve ever done that but it’s so painful. 6, 12 It’s very, very painful. 6 I went to the doctor and said, “I can’t have any pain medication because I’m an addict.” 6, 12, 14 I had a couple of years at this time of sobriety. 11, 12, 14 I’d been taught  You were a heroin addict. 14, 16 If you take that opiate medication you’re going to run right off.” 8, 12, 14 The doctors gave me a shot of Tordol which is just liquid ibuprofen. 11, 12, 14 I’m thinking it’s a shot so it must be good. 10, 11 It didn’t do anything for the pain. 6 It was horrifying.  I actually considered going to get some heroin because I knew that would relieve the pain. 5, 6, 7, 9, 16 What is happening here? 15 This is not cool. 17 My sponsor said, “Don’t do it.”  If you do it, you’re going to have to change your clean date. 13 I said, “I don’t give a shit.” 18 I called the doctor and said, “This isn’t working. 12, 14 Please give me something to relieve this pain because I can’t take it anymore. 6 I don’t want a bunch.”  He gave me ten Vicodin.  I didn’t take all ten at once.  I didn’t crush them up and snort them or shoot them.  I took them as prescribed, they relieved the pain. 6, 10 I had two left over a couple of days later. 11, 14, 16 I didn’t even take them all.  It didn’t reignite the dragon as I was told. 5, 13, 16 My sponsor fired me because I refused. 5, 6, 13, 16 She said, “You have to go to home group and tell everybody you’ve relapsed.”  I said, “I did not relapse.”  AS: But it’s really common. 18 It’s still the same today. 16 This was years ago. 13, 14 Even then I went, “This is not right.” 12 It didn’t happen. 15 What you said was going to happen didn’t happen. 15 I like to question things.  I’m a person of faith but I’m also a person of science.  If you can defend a position I’ll listen to you but if you’ve just got some knack and you can’t defend it, shut up.  That’s what she’d been told. 16 When I questioned it she fired me because I refused to go and humble myself before the group and say, “I relapsed. 5, 6, 8, 13, 16 I’m sorry.”  AS: Did you go back to that group?  I never went back to any. 16 I sought support elsewhere.  I understand support. 17, 18 I’m a communal liver.  I’ll probably be her when I’m eighty.  I’ll find a bunch of other eighty-year-old women; we can all live together. 8, 12, 14 I can find support but that wasn’t support to me.  That was adhering to a strict set of rules as it was in almost any treatment center I’ve ever worked in. 12, 13 Adhering to these strict set of rules. 13 That just doesn’t work for me.  When Eric and I opened this place we talked at length about what the curriculum would be, how we were going to do it, and what role we could play in bridging the gap between coming to us for an assessment and finding an inpatient treatment bed. 10, 12, 13 What we have found is that many people didn’t actually need that inpatient treatment bed. 7, 9, 12, 13 What they needed was the support that we have to offer, referrals for housing resources, but immediate engagement in some kind of program. 6, 12 AS: The minute that they walk in. 15, 16 And I’ve seen so much success with that. 6 This business is only two years old. 14 Last year we had forty-three percent growth. 10, 14 It’ll be even more than that this year. 14 AS: How many people can you serve? 9 Sixteen at one time but if we have more than sixteen then we’ll split and we’ll just have two different groups. 12 AS: Have you stuck at sixteen right now? 12 Yeah because we’re not ready to jump off yet because this house. 6, 13 We’re going to start our own housing which will not be strictly GRH. 6 We will accept some GRH beds but we’re going to have beds available for people who have self-security disability. 9, 12 There are seven hundred and thirty-three a month. 16 We’re not going to take six hundred of that.  We’re going to take three hundred.  We’ll take a percentage.  You can have a safe supportive place to live. 19 Minimal outside involvement. 9, 12 We’re going to go on a case by case basis. 17 I don’t believe in kicking people out for continuing to use. 6, 9, 13 I just don’t.  AS: How will you screen?  Case by case. 17 AS: What are your thoughts about screening? 17, 18 How’s it going to be like an Oxford House versus a sober house? 6, 13 There still has to be, if we’re going to accept GRH funding then there has to be somebody that runs the house. 6, 8, 12, 13 AS: GRH is?  JH: Group Residential Housing. 6, 9 It’s funded through the county, through the chemical dependency treatment fund. 8, 12, 13, 14, 19 AS: You will need someone on sight?  For this first house. 6, 13, 14 I have bigger plans.  I want to head in the direction that the overriding theme of this whole conversation today has been about the supportive nature of communal living. 14, 16, 18, 19 It sounds to people, you just shake your head and go, “There’s no way it will work.” 9, 14, 18 I beg to differ.  I have seen it work. 6 It’s still working.  I can’t even tell you how many there are now. 12 AS: Isn’t it fascinating how that if the idea is not present within your little realm and you haven’t actually seen it work how long you can convince yourself that therefore it must not be able to work? 5, 6, 7, 10, 17, 20 “We already have that here.”  Or “That will never work. 16 We tried an Oxford House in St. Paul.” 6, 13 JH: I’ve heard those stories too. 9 AS: Things are changing in the treatment world really fast. 12, 13, 17, 18 One thing I’ve heard and I’d like to know what you think about this that insurance companies are starting to look a little bit askance at how many times people are going into treatment, how much it costs and how high their rate of relapse is. 7, 9, 10, 12, 13, 20 They’re not happy. 18 They’re losing a lot of money. 8, 10 They might start looking more favorably on programs like what you’re offering.  Do you think?  That’s kind of the goal although we didn’t come to that conclusion as a business model.  It has revealed itself to us.  AS: It reminds me of what’s happened with midwife assistant births. 15, 20 I was one of the first wave, after the 60s, in the 90s to use a midwife. 6, 13, 14, 20 I didn’t have a doula that came a little later. 20 I don’t even know the difference. 12 AS: A doula is someone who is just a labor support person.  To have a midwife assisted birth or to have a birthing center costs four thousand dollars or three thousand dollars but to go have that same baby in the hospital a natural birth costs fifteen. 8, 20 The insurance companies were like, “Let’s do it.” 10 It’s kind of reminding me of that system.  Very similar.  I think what will happen ultimately is it’s not like this was a novel idea that I just came up with and I’m that brilliant. 15 This is just the experiences that I’ve had in my life have led me to see that this is a viable option. 6, 10, 18 We have to operate within that little window of opportunity. 19, 20 The minute somebody calls. 15, 16 Right now if somebody were to call me and say, “Can I get a chemical health assessment?” 12, 13, 19 I’ll say, “Can you be here?  I’ll do it today. 16 If I can, I’ll do it today. 16 Or first thing tomorrow I’ll make room for you.” 14 Because I know that there’s that much. 12 For people that say, “I’ve got to have in-patient treatment.” 9, 12, 13 I say, “The beds are three to four weeks out. 15 I get that.  Can we get you started here?  So you can have access to services.” 9, 19 Sometimes those people end up not going to in-patient treatment because they’re receiving what they need immediately. 9, 12, 13 It’s intensive.  It’s four days a week. 15, 16 We have, this is the mental health room, we have two LICSWs. 12, 14, 19 We do the mental health diagnostic assessments. 12, 13, 19 They will do individual therapy with people and then they do group therapy every Tuesday. 9, 12, 16 Then we have the specialist with the LIDCs on board and integrating the two.  Our non-profit which is right down the hall. 12, 15 The guy that was just leaving today. 16 He got out of group at noon and was down there for two hours. 15 He got help doing whatever he was doing down there.  Getting some stuff done.  In house. 6, 13 AS: I don’t want to take the rest of your time.  I wanted to ask what is your assessment of what’s happening with the opioid epidemic. 12, 13, 15, 18 Is it going to get worse before it gets better?  Can you talk about what your take is on that and what we’re doing and not doing?  I have six years working in methadone. 6, 8, 14 I’m very, very familiar with the rules and regulations surrounding methadone. 6, 8, 13 I worked in methadone because I understand that population. 17, 18 Although I was never on methadone myself. 16 I understand the population and I can support that modality. 17, 18 Not permanently but as a tool.  I worked in methadone in six years. 14 While I was working in methadone my boss one day said, “Hey can you go to this meeting? 16, 18 The meeting was the Opioid Coalition. 18 It was at Fairview Hospital.  It was run by a woman named Mary Kay Bergstrum. 8 This is probably five, six years ago. 13, 14 I said, “Okay.  I’ll just be a representative for the company I was working for.” 5, 10, 14 I went to that meeting and went, “These are my peeps. 18 Yes.  I like this.”  Pharmacists, doctors, service providers, other methadone providers all focused on the opioid epidemic. 6, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 19 I had been a volunteer with Minnesota AIDS project handing out syringes. 5 I worked out of the ambulance and drove around and we passed out kits so people could have safe injecting materials. 5, 9, 13 I would walk around the park and handout condoms and syringes to people. 9, 16 I’d already been doing some harm reduction things. 5, 14 Meeting a group of people who had similar ideas was like, “Yay. 9, 18 We can get some stuff done here.”  Through that organization and through where I was working I met Lexi Reed Holtum.  This is probably six years ago; it was shortly after Steve died. 13, 14, 18 She was a warrior by herself.  We were at a sheriff’s conference or something and she just had a little table and she was on fire. 20 I was like, “I know her. 12 I just bonded with her right away. 12, 18, 20 She started attending the Opioid Coalition meetings. 18 I put her in touch with my dear friend Sarah Gordon who works with… 9, 20 AS: I know all these people. 9, 12 JH: Sarah and I are dear friends. 16, 20 Sarah and I met years ago because I was working in methadone and I wanted to do syringe exchange through methadone which thank God I’m doing now. 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 18 There was some political reasons because I was a malcontent.  Hepatitis C and HIV instant testing at these sites where we have people, this population is highly prone to these diseases. 7, 8, 9 Sarah Gordon and I have been friends through that process. 16, 17, 20 Sarah was coming to the Opioid Coalition, no she wasn’t but Lexi had said, “We’ve got to try to introduce a bill and get this Steve’s Law.” 14 It wasn’t called Steve’s Law at the time.  The Good Samaritan 911.  “You know how to craft legislation?” 12 I said, “I don’t know how.” 12 But Sarah said, “I do.”  I said, “Well Sarah you and Lexi got to meet.” 18 Me and Sarah and Lexi all got together and then this spark turned into a flame turned into meeting Senator Chris Eaton and hearing her story and meeting Star Selleck. 8, 9, 15, 18 AS: You know her too? 12 I know these people. 9, 12 AS: We know all these same people. 9, 12 I can’t believe that you sat down right next to me. 12 There are other places I could have sat.  It’s very serendipitous.  I know all these people. 9, 12 AS: I’ve interviewed, I’m going to or I have.  Do you know Sue Purchase? 12 JH: Who doesn’t know Sue? 12 AS: I didn’t know Sue. 12 I talked to her for an hour today. 15, 16 JH: She’s in Colorado.  AS: I’m going to go there and interview her.  She’s phenomenal because she has twenty years of this thing behind her. 12, 14 She started syringe exchange in Minneapolis. 10 AS: Women with a Point. 12 Sue is phenomenal. 12 Mention my name.  We’re dear friends. 16, 20 She would carry syringes out of the back of her Subaru and I’d meet her at the park and we’d pass out syringes in Loring Park. 18 All of these very powerful women all ended up kind of at the same place at the same time. 10, 12, 17 Steve’s  Law was created in those conversations. 14 I became part of the Steve Rummler Hope Foundation. 9 I went to Congress to testify.  I sat in the bleachers waiting to be called on because I have a historical, I was saved by Narcan. 10, 15 I was happy to share that. 18 It was pretty phenomenal. 10, 12 AS: It was really powerful. 10, 17, 18 JH: Mishan Jenkins, I’ve sure you’ve met Mishan.  AS: She’s who I walked around with to talk to the Senators. 16 We were called the Narcan Girls walking around the halls of the Senate Office Building. 16 Going Senator to Senator saying, “Will you support this bill?”  It didn’t pass the first year. 14 We had to make some adjustments. 12 AS: It must have been the second year that I was involved. 14 It didn’t pass the first year because Sheriff Richard Staneck, although he’s a supporter, was not supportive of the letting the drug addict go free. 5, 6, 9, 14, 19 Have you ever met him?  He’s fricken huge.  He’s like six foot seven.  I was in an elevator with him and I’m like trauma.  “Oh my God I’m going to jail.”  AS: You were having your PTSD?  A little bit. 20 I have some stories there. 9 He’s a friend to the cause but he challenged quite a few of the points. 6, 13, 14, 20 The first year it did not pass. 14 Then we got the bipartisan support with Dan Schoen. 9 The powerful stories of the women, it broke my heart to hear these testimonies before Congress. 8, 9, 10, 12, 17 You’re a parent. 20 AS: You can’t deny a mother’s grief when it comes to this.  It stops you a little bit in your tracks. 16, 20 JH: Hearing the stories. 9 Star Selleck, we call each other twinsies because oftentimes in pictures we look like each other. 7 Somebody will respond to a picture she’s posted going, “Julie you look great.” 20 Star will go, “That’s me.”  The same thing happens with me. 15 We’re doppelgangers, not in person. 9 She’s a lot larger on the bottom than I am but our pictures. 9 It’s funny. 9 When Star and I first met, we met at public television did a thing on the opioid crisis. 13, 14, 19 AS: I’ve seen that. 6 We were in the audience for that one. 8 We sat next to each other and just bonded immediately.  She’s a nurse and she told me the story of as a nurse she knew what her son needed when he died on her kitchen floor. 14, 15, 16 The powerlessness she felt as a nurse she knew exactly what he needed and didn’t have it. 11, 16, 17 Powerful stories like that helped create the Steve’s Law as we know it today. 9, 12, 14, 16 I have two Narcan kits here.  I do the trainings.  Back when Dr. Satterlee was the open prescriber. 10, 16 It’s somebody new now. 12, 16 It was Dr. Satterlee initially. 16 That was the other thing, when Lexi was looking for somebody to have an open prescription I got Dr. Solum who was a prescribing physician at Valhalla Place Methadone Clinic, said he would sign on. 8, 10, 11 AS: What clinic did you work at?  I worked at STS to begin with and then I worked at Valhalla Place.  I got fired from Valhalla Place. 5 It’s the only job I’ve ever been fired from in my entire life. 5, 10, 11 That’s okay.  It messed me up quite a bit but I still stand behind, I have a point here and I’m not going to remain silent. 20 AS: Was it about all the drug testing? 5, 6 JH: Yep.  I’ll just briefly tell you a quick story. 15, 19 I had a client, I’d been in methadone for a long time and I’d had clients follow me from STS to Valhalla Place. 6, 8, 10, 17 I’d been working with them for years. 14 This is profound because it doesn’t happen in this field. 15 I had this phenomenal relationship and I understand this client very, very well. 10, 12, 14, 17, 18, 19 This client is traumatized and has significant trauma behind bodily fluids and things that have happened in bathrooms. 10, 11, 14, 15 I know this. 12 Every time a UA would come up she would just go into crisis mode.  The law states, the FR42 says you have to have at least eight a year. 13, 14 The methadone clinic, the state says once a month. 6, 8, 16 The Feds trump, pardon the expression, that law. 10, 13 She only has to have eight a year. 14 I would let her go and not have to UA because it would re-traumatize her every single time.  The thought was… 17, 18 AS: How long had she been on methadone? 6, 8, 17 JH: Years.  She was being re-traumatized over and over.  I think partly why she clung to me was not because I was saying, “You don’t have to UA today.” 9, 16 But because I was saying, “I’m not going to traumatize you again.”  She would come in and say, “I’m using but I’m not going to UA. 6 AS: She was willing to admit to using to go ahead and get in trouble but didn’t want to do the UA. 6, 14 Because of the punitive nature. 19 There was another kid…  AS: She’s not being dishonest. 8 There was another kid who had something similar, a young guy, who had some horrible events happen to him. 10, 15 Having to provide a urine drug screen that was witnessed, that was his thing. 5, 6 He couldn’t have anybody come in that room with him if he had to pee in a cup because of things that had happened to him. 14, 15 He would literally roll up in a ball and cry.  The belief was that he was hiding something and he wanted to go in there by himself so that he could bring in adulteration urine. 6, 18 What little you know of me today, I couldn’t sit by. 12, 16, 20 I didn’t get into this field to do that.  AS: Especially given what we know about trauma, sexual abuse, post-traumatic stress disorders. 6, 7, 12, 13 Why can’t we integrate that?  That’s a whole other story. 15 I understand that when people are using other substances adding methadone on top can be dangerous and deadly. 6, 9, 11, 16, 17, 18 I get that.  I truly do.  There has to be another way. 18 AS: There has to be some exceptions to the rule. 13 I made those exceptions.  AS: And then you got fired? 5 Not just for that but that was over a long period of time. 17, 18 Write ups for those kinds of things.  I wear it like a badge of honor today. 16 At the time it was…  AS: I’m sure it just killed you at the time. 14 It devastated me.  I am the one true thing that’s working here with this movement and I’m being deemed a malcontent. 5, 12, 15 What the hell is happening here? 15 AS: Often people that are forward thinking, we get in trouble. 9 We push the boundary.  It’s been most of my life. 10 As funky as that was when it happened it laid the groundwork for this to become the reality because in essence I can’t be the square peg in the round hole. 15 I’ve got to make my own way and follow it through because there’s a part of me that says this is real and true and this is good, let’s move towards this. 5, 9, 10, 15, 18 This is the beginning of that bridge, bridging the gap in treatment, having treatment available today right now. 11, 12, 13, 16 Outpatient chairs are available all the time.  They’re always available. 18 The worry is they’re fine when they’re here for three hours and then they have to leave. 11, 15, 18 AS: How do you keep them?  We have a case management services organization who says, “Come in. 12, 17, 19 What do we need?”  AS: After group, how can I help you?  He was here for two hours after group getting help. 15 That to me is the essence of why we do what we do because we bridge that gap.  Although I can go into the Lieutenant Governor’s Office and say, “These are barriers.”  Change doesn’t happen overnight. 15 I know that and we’re talking and it could be a decade before things really change. 12, 14, 18 What are we doing in the meantime?  I don’t know that it will work or not but can we try this? 12 Can we try that?  We know what doesn’t work and we keep doing it. 12 That drives me crazy. 5, 20 To go back to your question about the opioid coalition and the opioid crisis. 13, 14 That’s been an ongoing thing.  I’ve watched it happen. 15, 17 I’ve over the years lost, personally I’ve lost nine friends during my addiction which was devastating. 11, 12, 14, 16, 20 I go to the vigil every year and I call out their names as a way of honoring. 14, 16, 18 Then I hold hands with Chris Eaton and Mishan and we just love one another. 14, 17 My goal here is we have, I have people coming in all the time. 9 I just had a kid last week, twenty-four-year-old, Caucasian, middle class, white kid. 7, 14, 15, 19 Started on some pain pills. 6 Couldn’t get anymore, got cut off abruptly and found heroin. 16 That’s kind of what killed Steve Rummler too. 14 AS: It’s what kills a lot of them.  It kills a lot.  He came in last week and I said, “Here’s what I can do.” 15 I gave him some options.  These are my people; I know what options you have. 9, 12 “What do you want to do?”  He said, “I want to get stabilized on methadone so at least I’m not sick. 6, 8, 15 Then I want to do treatment.” 12, 13 I said, “Okay.  He’s living with mom, he’s not working, he has a girlfriend who’s living with her mom. 7, 14, 20 They have a son who’s been taken by the state.  This is not uncommon.  AS: My expression is because I’ve heard all this before. 9, 10 My challenge to him was maybe some longer term support. 5, 17 I said, “You can recycle through these.”  “I need in-patient treatment.” 12, 13 What does that mean to you?  What’s going to happen at in-patient treatment? 12, 13, 15 You get out of mom’s house and eat different food for a month?” 6, 13, 14, 16 AS: And not have to think about…  Not take action, not think about it.  AS: Which actually could slow down your progress when you get out. 7, 10 My challenge to him was, and he’s doing it right now, he’s at a methadone program. 12 I know if he’s not stabile then he’s not going to be able to participate here. 9, 12 He’ll be off and running. 8 I stay in touch.  I’ve called him twice already to stay in touch with him.  Once he feels stable, meaning he can make it twenty-four hours without being sick or close to it, to come here. 9, 10, 12, 15 Then from here we’re going to help him find a place to live, find some employment, help him find some purpose and meaning to his life to empower him to get up off mom’s couch. 10, 12, 14, 17 She’s doing his laundry for him, cooking his meals for him. 5 Yelling at him because he keeps using. 6, 15 I can’t fix her.  I got him sitting here.  I’m going to help empower him to do exactly what I did. 17 AS: And what a twenty-four-year-old man should be doing. 14 JH: Yep.  What’s happening? 15 AS: Parents are part of the problem right now. 9, 12 JH: Right now for him in that case. 12, 17 AS: In this era, in this generation of parents we are definitely part of the problem. 9, 12, 20 JH: The enabling.  AS: When I was nineteen I couldn’t imagine having to live at my parents’ house for more than a month. 6, 13, 16, 20 JH: I couldn’t wait to get out.  AS: I loved them, everything was fine but it was nothing anyone did. 11, 14 You were gone. 8, 11 You wanted independence. 18 I wanted to see who I was. 6, 18 AS: They don’t even want their driver’s licenses now. 5, 12, 13 When my daughter turned eighteen she was still kind of lounging around.  I said, “You’ve got until spring.  You’ve got to figure it out.”  Spring came and she was not making any progress. 10 I said, “It’s spring.  Guess what?”  “I don’t have any place to go.”  “Why don’t we get a job? 11 Let’s do that.  You have until this time to get a job. 11 You better get off your butt and go look.”  There was a lot of, people call it tough love, it’s not tough love at all. 9, 14 It’s just straight up love. 14 I love you enough to say no to you. 14 AS: To teach you how to be independent.  That’s what my goal has always been. 18 I did well and then I did shitty and then I did well again. 18 Let’s keep going with the well.  AS: How are your girls today? 7, 11, 16 My youngest daughter is a buyer for Macy’s.  AS: How old is she?  And the thirty-three-year-old has two children, both out of wedlock. 5, 14, 20 One when she was fifteen, sixteen.  She struggles with some alcohol and marijuana use. 6, 13 She’s coming around.  I don’t enable.  I will support but not in the way of “Here’s some cash honey.” 8, 18 I’ll bring some groceries over every now and again. 12 I’ll put some gas in the car.  I’ll always be there to love and support and guide. 14, 18 She’ll say, “Will you please take off your counselor hat for once?”  I’ll say, “It’s permanently affixed to my head.” 14 AS: So you have grandkids.  I have grandkids, yes.  The gift there is that they’ve never known me like that. 11, 12, 16 My kids did but they’ve never known me like that. 11, 12, 16 That’s a gift that it stopped.  They say recovery is possible.  We do recover.  One last thing and I kind of brought it up to you….  AS: I’m so glad you just remembered because I almost forgot. 5 You know Gloria Englund? 12 AS: Yes.  JH: Gloria and I were in the bathroom just before I came back and sat down with you. 14 I saw her out in the hallway and went to the bathroom. 14, 18 You know, women we’ve got to go bond in the bathroom. 12, 14 She pees in one stall; I pee in the other.  “How are you doing Gloria?”  “Oh great Julie.” 20 She got locked into that stall.  She was going crawl out from underneath.  I go, “Gloria stop.  We’ll help you get out.”  She was going to crawl underneath.  “It reminds me of being stuck in the birth canal.”  I was like, “Oh my God.  Gloria you’re just so bizarre.”  We started laughing about that and we somehow or another came up to doctors. 8, 12, 14 I don’t know how it shifted from that. 8, 12 She had said something to me, “Are you still being treated poorly?” 12 It reminded me.  It keeps happening. 15 All these years of sobriety or recovery or whatever it is you want to say. 12, 14 AS: Twenty.  I’m a taxpayer and a voter and a productive member of society. 12, 14 When I was fifty, I’ll be sixty this year but when I was fifty I went to have a colonoscopy. 14 I don’t think I showed you but I have really significant scars on my arms. 11, 18 These are abscesses and tracks from injecting. 13, 16 These will never go away. 16, 18, 20 You can tell they’re old.  They’re not fresh.  There’s nothing fresh about them.  AS: They’re white and they’re not… 19 That’s arms.  I have some on my breasts and on my legs.  I went in to go have a colonoscopy.  I told the prep nurse, they want you to have the IV in this hand because you have to lay on this side. 9, 10, 16 I said, “You won’t get a vein here.”  “I’m a professional.”  “No, trust me.  You won’t get a vein there.  This is how we’ve got to do it.”  I’m explaining it to her.  She goes to tell the doctor and it pisses him off. 12, 14 AS: That you need to turn the other direction? 18 JH: Yes, no.  That I have to use this hand instead of this. 6, 13 Now my hand is hanging out over the edge of the bed where the guy who’s monitoring my, it’s fentanyl and versed that they give you to calm you down. 18 AS: It is fentanyl?  Yeah it’s fentanyl and versed which are pre-op drugs and anti-anxiety. 5, 6, 10 He’s already mad at me and I can tell.  I’m like, “Whatever.  Shut up.”  I feel kind of some of what he’s doing.  I remember moaning a little. 20 I like I felt that. 11 He said, “If you think you’re getting some more fentanyl you’ve got another thing coming.”  This is a true story. 5, 15 I’m laying there going, “What the hell?  What is happening right now?” 12, 15 I’m compromised.  Really?  AS: He thinks you’re drug seeking during your colonoscopy? 5, 6, 17 JH: Yes.  I’m thinking, “Then you’re really much less educated than you come off. 14, 18 If I want drugs I don’t have to come here and have you do this. 5, 6 I’ll go buy some” Good  Lord what is your problem? 12 Really?  I’m so mad at him.  AS: Didn’t you know that was the new thing to go get a colonoscopy? 12, 16 JH: I’ve heard, I won’t mention him by name, but I did have a doctor who worked at the Valhalla Place who was prescribing methadone physician. 9, 10, 12, 14 He and I would chat quite often. 11 He said, “You know, I just hate when those drug seekers come into the ED. 5, 6, 12 I’ve been working in the ED for years. 14 First thing I do is get them the hell out of there.”  I would say, “Richard why not help them? 9 Why would you just immediate disdain?”  This is just a few years ago. 13, 14 It’s still very common.  I wrote a letter of complaint.  My daughter was there to drive me home, I was sedated. 5, 13 I was telling her. 15 She was like, “Mom this has to stop.”  Stuff like that happened a lot. 15 I wrote a letter, nothing happened. 15 I didn’t even get a response. 13 Basically like, “Shut up you drug addict.” 5, 6, 14 I’m well enough to where I can take that but I’m mad as hell.  AS: It’s like the stigma of incarceration that you did your time but you still pay for it the rest of your life. 9, 10 That’s a whole other story because that did happen to me too because I have felonies. 15 That was a nightmare in and of itself.  It’s just one thing after another.  I went on a cruise with my brother. 20 We were up on the deck on the last day. 14, 16 It was cloudy and I got sunburnt like really bad on my legs, so much so that they were swelling. 18 I worry about a clot.  I went to Regents.  AS: Why would you get a clot?  When you have swelling like that and the skin swells then you can get a blood clot because the swelling constricts the veins. 14 I’m worried about that.  I know my veins quite well. 11, 12 I’m worried I’m going to have some kind of clot. 14 I go to the emergency department, it’s bad. 9, 12, 19 It’s a pretty significant burn. 10, 11 The guy comes in and he’s looking at my legs.  I do have scars on my legs as well which are much more pronounced now that my legs are all swollen. 12 He can see my arms and he says, “I’m going to go get my attending.” 6 I went, “Oh God here we go again.”  The attending comes in and looks at my burns and then looks at me and says, “I hope you know we’re not going to prescribe any pain medication.” 6, 9, 10, 12, 14 I said, “I’m here for the burn.  What I want is some cream to help my burns.  I wonder why you would think that was my first reason?” 14 I went and got a burn on purpose?  What is your issue here? 13 I’m just flabbergasted.  I could name a dozen other times where something similar has happened. 15 AS: You’re a middle aged white woman. 7, 19 JH: Well educated. 14 AS: They’re kind of going to this extreme.  These aren’t fresh.  AS: They’re not pink.  I can see sort of if they were fresh. 6 AS: And if you looked strung out. 8 Then the reaction should be, “Honey what can we do to help you? 8 Let me offer you some resources before you leave here today. 16, 18 What are you injecting? 13 Is it heroin? 16 Let me send you home with a Narcan kit.  Do you know where you can go to get help?” 12 They still don’t with me.  Not with that doctor but with another one I got a rash, a really bad rash, just external, no bumps just weird discoloring on both ankles. 8, 12, 14, 18 I thought “What the heck is this?” 17, 18 Three days later it was still there and maybe I should go have it looked at. 5, 16 She didn’t even look at the rash.  She just looked at my arms and my legs and started scolding me.  I wouldn’t even let her.  I was so mad at this point.  This is probably the tenth time it’s happened to me. 15 Okay lady now we’re having it here. 12 I stopped her and I said, “I have eighteen, nineteen years free from addiction. 12, 14 How many years do I have to have before you stop treating me like this? 13, 14 Thirty?  Do I have to be dead?” 16 I remember saying that.  “Before you stop treating me like this.” 13 She was mad.  How dare I question her?  She went even so much as to humiliate me.  The rash is here on both ankles but I’m in a gown.  She comes over and lifts, I’m totally naked, she lifts up the gown.  She asks me first, “Do you have it anywhere else?” 8, 14 I said, “No it’s just here on my ankles.”  She comes and lifts the gown in a humiliating fashion until I pull it back down.  I was so mad.  How many years do I have to have? 14 My goal is here, I’m a huge advocate for change and faces and voices and recovery, I’m on board. 17 I do with the groups, I’m the one who comes in to do the advocacy training. 8, 12 You have the right to be treated with dignity and respect. 12 You have the right to be thought of as capable of changing. 12, 17, 18 Those kinds of things.  I have a room full of people who don’t know that, who’s doctors talk to them the way they talk to me. 9, 12, 14, 18 Only their fresh and still immersed in the…  AS: In the shame.  JH: They can’t fight back.  I refuse to let their voices not be heard. 6, 9, 13, 17 That’s my big goal, a very lofty one.  It’s hard to change. 9, 14 AS: Little by little the acorn said. 20 I want to be heard in that respect. 9 One of the things that both my parents, my dad is eighty-six and my mom is eighty-three. 14, 20 The two of them will look at each other and go, “What?  That kind of thing, having become who they always knew I could be. 16, 18 AS: They say that to you.  The person that they always knew I could be. 16, 18 The people who in my opinion have the right to judge or question me are the people who support me the most. 9, 12 They don’t judge or question.  They say, “Oh my God.  You have emerged.  We always knew you were there.” 16, 18 What I’d like to see happen. 6, 15 Other people’s families may not have that same insight or support. 9, 17 Many people’s families are not. 9, 17 I want to help be the advocate and the supporter, this is a safe place to be.  This is a safe place where you can come in and say, “Bobby showed up last night with a rock and we smoked it.” 14 “Okay, let’s talk about that.”  Instead of saying, “You’re out.  Get out.  Come back when you’re ready.  You’re not done yet.”  That’s what I heard. 9 AS: I’ve heard that. 9 My daughter’s heard that. 9 What is done? 8 Dead?  People say, “You have to hit rock bottom.” 9, 14 Rock bottom, I kept digging a deeper hole. 9 There was no rock bottom, only death. 9, 14, 18 That is a ridiculous way to look at what is happening here. 14, 15, 18 The way to look at it is with love and compassion. 14, 18 The old tools aren’t going to work with the opioid epidemic. 13 AS: They’re not working because people are dying. 9 The really cool thing that has happened in the last decade and the most significant because I remember when it happened. 11, 14, 15, 17, 18 When Hazelden said, “While maybe we should look at some Suboxone because our recovery rate for people…” 5, 8, 9 They had so many people die. 9 Steve Rummler was one of them.  You know that right? 12 He went to Hazelden, they got him off every medication he was on. 14 Told him he couldn’t be on any medications. 14 That was the problem. 12 Sent him home with no medications and an opioid addiction. 12, 13, 14 He tried and couldn’t.  The easiest thing for him to find was heroin. 16 He bought heroin for the first time, did it, and died the same day. 14, 16 I’m not blaming Hazelden, I’m not.  Please don’t hear that. 9 That model.  AS: I agree with you one hundred percent.  It’s dangerous, especially with opiates. 11 Although we can and do recover, it took a long time for my brain to heal. 13, 17 It took a long time and it was really only through diligence and perseverance and going to do things outside of myself for other people that helped me stop obsessing on that warm... 9, 17, 18 They just out of the blue in the last ten years, Dr. Mars Sepala bless his heart, he dipped a toe in the water. 9, 14, 16 How did he put it?  They were going to do research.  “Let’s at least research because our addressing the opiate dependence problem is maybe not as… 5, 12 AS: It’s kind of an emergency.  You think?  AS: Thank you.  [End of Recording]

Jeff Kazel Narrator Sara Ludewig Sam Aamot Interviewers May 19, 2017 Duluth, Minnesota Jeff Kazel-JK  Sara Ludewig-SL Sam Aamot-SA SA:  First we'll have you state your name and tell us you give us permission to record this.  My name is Jeff Kazel, and you have permission to record the interview.  SL: We're at the Duluth Building for Public Safety.  Today is May 19th, 2017. 16 SA: Would you like to tell us a little bit about your childhood, or your background, before we get into the work you do here? 14, 20 JK: Okay.  I was born in New York and came out to Duluth when I was in Kindergarten. 14 I grew up in Duluth. 20 I ended up going to college here in Duluth. 7, 14 I joined the army—served in the army for a couple of years and then came back. 8, 11, 14 I eventually got into law enforcement here. 5, 8, 12, 13 SA: Did you go to college? 7 I went to College of St. Scholastica.  SA: Do you want to talk about starting off in the Building of Public Safety?  What you were doing right away when you got here? 12, 18, 20 JK: Well, we haven't always been here. 18 This is the new building. 16, 19 We moved up here in 2012. 7, 15 We were downtown before.  SL: Can you tell us about the OARS program?  What it does, how it got started?  JK: I wasn't one of the founders, but I joined the OARS group in 2014 when I became the commander of the Lake Superior Drug and Violent Crime Task Force.  The group was put together to look at ways of combating the issues we were experiencing with the opioid epidemic in this area. 8, 12, 13, 18 SA: Is the Lake Superior Task Force for a bigger area? 8 Our task force is now—we just merged with another task force in January of this year. 8, 12, 14 Our area of operation is from all of St. Louis County, Carleton County, Lake County, and Douglas County in Superior [Wisconsin]. 8 SA: Did you merge with that task force because you felt like that would better serve your mission? 8, 11 JK: There were many different reasons.  Some of it was grant funding and the criteria that task forces needed to continue to get funding. 8, 14 They were our northern partners and it was the right thing to do. 8, 9, 12 Now that we're finding that our contacts with north and south St. Louis County are a lot--the fact that we did the merger was probably a really good thing. 10, 18 SA: What do you do on a typical day? 16 What are you doing with OARS?  JK: With OARS we normally meet once a month. 16, 18 I'm part of the law enforcement and more of the proactive side of the OARS group. 8, 9, 12, 13 We deal with the enforcement side and trying to reduce the amount of drugs that are coming up to this area. 5, 6, 8, 9, 12, 13, 14 We realize that just enforcement alone wasn't going to be enough. 8, 12, 13 That was part of our reasoning to going to the OARS group and trying to look outside of the box, and more than just enforcement action. 8, 9, 12, 13 It comes down to economics.  You guys have taken economics in college, I'm sure, and it's supply and demand. 7, 9, 13 We deal with the supply and people that are sending the supply, but we never really looked at the other side of the equation—the demand. 9, 13, 16, 18 By going to OARS we brought in lots of partners that deal with the demand side. 9, 12, 16 We talk about reducing—we have a pool of addiction here in this area, specifically this area. 5, 8, 12, 14 That's why we had so many people coming here to sell because they know that there're people that are going to buy. 9, 12 We talk about reducing the pool of addiction. 5, 12, 14 Turning off the tap of people going into that pool. 9 Getting into the schools and talking to young kids and say, "Hey, do you really know what that pill does? 7, 12, 18 And what could happen if you become addicted to it?" 12, 14, 15 The fact that a prescription for Oxycontin is no different than a [unclear] of heroin down the street. 10, 16 It's the same stuff.  Getting that message out to reduce the tap—turning off the tap—of people going into the pool of addiction. 5, 9, 12, 14, 20 But also taking people out of it. 9, 11 The people that are addicts that are overdosing continually throughout the year—looking for a way of getting those people out of the pool of addiction. 9, 12, 14, 18 If we reduce it at that end we are going to make it a less attractive area for people. 5, 8, 9, 14 SL: What year was OARS started in Duluth. 14 JK: I'm not the person to ask.  Like I said I didn't found it.  I think it was like 2013, but I'm not sure.  SL: When did you get involved with it?  JK: I got there in 2014.
