You're not dealing directly one on one with residents. 9, 18 PD: I did a fair amount. 9 I had a primary treatment unit that was a psychiatrist and a social worker and some other disciplines and I was the treatment director on the unit. 9, 12, 13, 18, 19 So I did a lot with the units. 19 The two sixty bed units I was hands on there trying to direct the care as well and then trying to get the hospital to do stuff differently which continues to be an ongoing struggle. 8, 17, 18, 19 It was real apparent to me that while the intentions from the department of human services might have been good in terms of we really want a person centered, state of the art, mission driven services but there's so many conflicting interests because we had also had a public safety medical model. 5, 7, 9, 10, 12, 14, 17, 18, 19, 20 It was a very difficult system to try to change because everybody's worried about risk and liability. 10 AS: Are people hurting themselves or hurting other people? 9 PD: I did that for five years and then said, "Oh boy. 7, 14 I'm not committed to them."  Another epiphany.  I had a dream that if I stayed at that job I was going to get cancer. 5, 10, 11 It was one of those really, really obvious messages and so I listened to the dream. 5, 18 I gave them a year's notice and I left. 14 I worked my ass off for another year and gave up wrapping up these projects I was deep into. 5, 14 Then I moved on. 7, 15 I went traveling for six months and then got a job with People Incorporated which is a very mission driven pretty state of the art mental health organization. 5, 10, 11, 12, 16, 19 I worked for them for nine years directing a campus on the North side of Minneapolis. 9, 14, 18 I had a nice integrated network of services there that I helped develop and create and led a big capital campaign and built buildings. 18, 19 That was great. 20 I thought that was probably where I was going to end up retiring. 17, 18 Then I had another epiphany.  The universe keeps kind of just telling me what to do. 15 AS: You listened.  PD: It was a Sunday afternoon and I was in the tub and this message said you need to open a drug and alcohol treatment program. 5, 6, 12, 13, 16 What are you talking about?  You need to do this.  Alright. 12 At that point I was feeling pretty discouraged about having worked in mental health for decades now and seen the revolving door. 6, 10, 12, 14, 15, 19 All the stuff you talk about in your chapter, inaccessibility and the same things over and over that repetitive nature of things. 9 This is a continuous loop, barriers to access, unwelcoming, one size fits all, blaming the family, all the stuff. 9, 12, 15 I saw it and I saw it firsthand, I heard about it from clients over and over. 9, 10, 14 It's just like how long are we going to keep blaming the client for the system's failure? 10, 14, 17 I'd been trying to champion mental health person centered care for all of my career really. 5, 12, 14, 15, 18, 19 Mental health has been enormous strides towards moving toward a patient to patient recovery movement which is impactful. 12, 15, 19 I think we've come a long way in mental health in terms of making that a rehabilitative experience and much more person centered. 5, 10, 12, 17, 18, 19 We have a long way to go. 17, 18 But with drug and alcohol we were still stuck in the 50s. 5, 6 I guess in 2009, April basically given marching orders. 19 We opened that September and here we are today trying to recreate the system. 16 AS: Who would you say your marching orders come from in your epiphany?  PD: I think they're just universal.  AS: Something bigger than yourself.  PD: Yes.  I think I'm here to provide service and to give guidance. 19 I think that we all have access to that if we tap into that flow and listen, if we're willing to listen and be open. 9, 10 I think I appreciate you emphasizing that because I think that probably is what kind of keeps me going. 10, 15 I just trust that we're doing what we're supposed to be doing and we're doing the best we can.  AS: In the moment where we are. 8, 12, 14 PD: Exactly.  I'm not guided by fear; I'm not guided by liability or worry. 10 Let's just do the best we can to create an environment where people feel welcome and comfortable so they can get out of survival mode and start to open up and trust and heal. 9, 12 Whatever that looks like.  Do the best we can with that.  I just have an enormous confidence that if it all comes tumbling down then it’s time to do something else.  My survival doesn't rely on anything.  I trust that regardless I'll be okay.  I have two operating principles:  how's this going to read in the Star Tribune with big decisions? 14 Most times it reads fine. 11 It'll read okay.  How will it read?  That's kind of how we make decisions. 14 Most of what we do I think you can justify pretty clearly. 10 It doesn't fit the norms or the rules or always the safest routes but builds a hell of a good argument. 10, 12, 13, 15, 18 I can sleep with that and worst case scenario it all comes tumbling down, I'm going to be okay. 16, 17 There's other stuff to do.  That keeps us in the flow. 10, 15 When you're in the flow the universe helps you. 10 It just does.  AS: Were you raised in a religion at all? 14 Did your parents model this or did you kind of just get this as you grew? 20 My father's Catholic and he tried to impose it upon us but my mother she's a self-proclaimed atheist. 16 She didn't support him.  No way he's going to round up five kids and take care of it. 18, 19 There was this attempt at Catholicism but the closest we got to a church was the bingo hall probably. 9, 10 AS: So you didn't really have a formal religious education to speak of. 14, 15, 18 That's really interesting. 17, 18 Okay so 2009 you started Minnesota Alternatives. 14 Did you get your PhD?  PD: No. AS: You did not get your PhD.  Okay so tell me how did this come about?  You thought "I'm going to open up my own clinic." 17, 18 PD: I had been doing program development for a long time. 12, 17 My first job I was quickly into leadership roles and development programs. 10, 11, 12, 14 The state hospitals development programs and people incorporated my job as to develop programs. 8, 9, 11, 12 I know how to do it. 12 I know the rules. 12, 13 I know how to work the process of getting a program. 12, 17 I just kind of started networking to figure out where would be the best place to do it.  At that time, because of a rich history working in Anoka County it seemed like this would probably be the easiest place. 6, 15 That's where we started.  We started in Columbia Heights in 2009 and moved up here to expand in 2011, into Spring Lake Park. 7, 15 AS: Now we're talking about Minnesota Alternatives? 14 PD: Correct.  AS: Just for the record here.  PD: Minnesota Alternatives, that's what it's been ever since. 10, 14 The model has been evolving as we continue to get feedback from the clients about what's helpful and what's not helpful. 9, 10 We had a basic structure and the structure that we used was kind of drawing from my heroes. 5, 6, 13, 15, 16 Certainly William Anthony and person centered care. 5, 14, 19 Gabor Mate in terms of understanding trauma and attachment and the power of environment. 12, 14, 17, 18 I'm a fan of Mark Lewis, Joe Rispenza the concepts of being able to evolve your brain and looking at neuroplasticity and our capacities to harness, our ability to train our brains. 7, 13 Libhann has done a lot of skills and my training of Boston University was very skills based and helping people develop recovery visions, rehabilitation goals they call them. 9, 10, 13 Basically was a vision.  What does that vision look like?  What do we do to help you realize that vision?  Very person centered. 5 You decide and we help you figure out how to get there. 14 That's always the paradigm with which I've worked. 18 That continues to be the center of everything we do.  We build in more educational information about what's the best of the best and ways to help support people through a lot of trauma work for example and individual therapy. 9, 12, 14, 15, 18 Helping also with accountability.  If people need accountability we can do that too. 9 The system’s heavy on accountability that's not the piece that we emphasize but for a lot of people that's what they want. 6, 9 AS: The addiction treatment system? 12, 13, 14 PD: Absolutely.  Probation and addiction treatment are in bed together. 8, 12, 13, 14 That's just absurd how that developed.  We kind of think about these pillars of therapy and counseling and welcoming and comfortable and really priority on engagement. 12, 18, 19 Then we have education which hopefully is science based state of the art with a heavy emphasis on true informed decision making so that people know what the risks are. 5, 6, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15 Let them know the opportunities and the risks and they get to decide. 12, 14, 19 Heavy emphasis again on harnessing the powers of neuroplasticity and then overcoming well-worn pathways from addictive behaviors or any behaviors that we've been caught in for a long time. 14, 17, 18 Support, education, and accountability. 14, 15 People really want accountability and we can do that. 18 We can do that if they need it.  That has been the goal for the last nine years, is to offer an alternative for people other than traditional treatment. 9, 12, 13, 14 Our program's open ended, people get to decide how long they come, how often they come, what they do while they're here. 9, 14, 17 If they want to just come for skills fine. 10, 11 If they want to stay for the process, the goal is that everything we offer people participate in because they find it helpful. 9, 17 AS: If the 12 Step program doesn't resonate with them you have other options.  PD: Yes, and if it does that's fine too. 11 A lot of people actually are working the 12 Step programs and coming here. 7, 9 They're not mutually exclusive.  AS: What about medication? 14 How have you approached that?  PD: We are not a provider of methadone but we have prescribers who can prescribe sabaxone and there are addiction psychiatrists who can prescribe sabaxone and or any other medications that help reduce recurrence or severity of recurrence. 5, 10, 12, 14 We're big proponents of medications if people want them. 8, 9, 14 We have found them to be incredibly helpful along with psychiatric medications. 5, 9, 14, 18 AS: Do you work in conjunction with methadone clinics?  Is there a continuum of care or do people have to have those separate services, can what they do here count for what they might have to do at let's say Valhalla? 9, 19 PD: Absolutely.  We work real closely. 9, 10 We have a lot of clients who are at Valhalla and so there’s release signed and then we coordinate the care. 10, 11, 14, 19 It works really well because a lot of the clients that we work that they're working with they're fairly complicated. 9, 10, 18 There might be a lot of complex medical issues involved as well. 7, 12, 13, 14 We bring in primary care. 19 Then we kind of work together in terms of how we can best support people. 8, 9, 17 It works so well because they several paradigms in terms of trying to reduce barriers to engagement and keep them coming. 5, 9, 12, 14, 17 And harm reduction. 5, 14 When people ask what your program philosophy, I don't throw out harm reduction because people think all kinds of things when you say that. 5, 9, 14 I say, we are person centered, meaning we embrace a whole range of goals from abstinence to harm and risk reduction. 5, 7, 14 People get to decide. 14 I think that idea, that people come because they find it helpful. 9 We teach skills on a regular training curriculum like you would go to college. 7, 10 If you demonstrate that if you get this you, you're integrating it then don't go to that class that day. 7, 16 You don't need to be there, it's not relevant to you.  If you want to go because you want the reinforcement because you learn through repetition, fine. 8, 10, 11, 12 If you want to go because you want to support your peers in learning and be an example, fine. 10, 11 You don't have to do stuff that you already know. 12 AS: It keeps people from feeling bored and resentful. 5, 9, 15 PD: Exactly.  Ironically what we find is that most people don't want to stop. 9 We have to push, gently encourage people out. 9 AS: They're feeling very heard and at home here. 9, 15 PD: Why would I stop coming to something that helps me grow? 10 Why would I stop?  You've got a good point. 10 We really try to validate that for people but we have services on site. 9, 13, 18, 19 As people are getting ready to go and have got it, they've really developed mastery, they have gained or regained control of their lives then we say, "Why don't you start dabbling with some support services." 9, 14, 18, 19 Just start going over there while you're still actively in treatment and check out some of the support services. 12, 13, 19 AS: But that you also offer here.  PD: Yes, through the non-profit. 15 Try those then that's what helps people. 9 AS: What do you offer there?  Are there names of programs? 16 PD: Yes.  AS: What are those called?  PD: There's a co-ed, these are all led by peer specialists these are people who have gone through some clinical cure specialist training. 9 There's a co-ed group on Monday nights they call it a peer support group. 16 Tuesday we offer group for family and loved ones based on CRFT, the Community Reinforcement Family Training. 8, 12, 13, 14, 16, 19 Wednesday they're gender specific. 16 There's a men and women's group. 12 Also peer support groups. 12 Thursday we have Smart Recovery. 16 Then Friday is movies and a meal. 16 You can just drop in from four to eight Monday through Friday and just hang out. 5, 11, 16 AS: Just be there.  PD: It's all anonymous.  There's no paperwork anybody needs to fill out. 5 We don't require that they prove that they have any kind of diagnosis. 6 It's free.  It's like an AA club in that way. 18 There is no expectation that you have to say anything about who you are.  There's no paperwork tracking you. 16 AS: This is a boring question but how are insurance companies dealing with this program? 10 PD: Well, really well. 18 Curiously, you'd think they'd start to say, "You know what? 12 That has been there three years, I think it's time." 14 We have yet to have an insurance company cut anybody off. 14 I think because it's outpatient care and they understand that. 11, 17, 18, 19 AS: It's counseling. 19 It could be one on one counseling and group therapy. 12, 19 Do you offer group therapy? 12 I think that because it's not five days a week, five hours a day people might come once a month. 9, 15, 16 People might come...  AS: Someone here is saying, they're here so they get billed?  PD: Absolutely.  The health insurance companies understand that substance use disorders on the severe end are not episodic, typically, and don't just kind of go away. 6, 10, 13, 14, 17, 18, 19, 20 It's a long distance through the whole process. 17 It's a severe mental illness. 6, 12 Generally, people need to have the opportunity to move in and out of services fairly seamlessly if their acuity changes, if their needs change. 6, 9, 15, 19 To have a system that says, "We'll hang in there with people long term as they go through the ups and downs of their illness and then keep them engaged." 9, 12, 17 I think four years was our longest client. 10, 14, 17 The health plans, they're like, "We love that. 14, 19 They're still engaged.  It's keeping them from more higher cost services or emergency rooms." 7, 14, 17, 19 We're in network with all the health plans and I think if you ask most of them they say we're a good provider. 10, 19 AS: Did you have to sell this to health insurance companies or you just started it? 10, 19 PD: They were thrilled.  The health insurance companies are fed up with everybody getting the same old same old. 10, 19 AS: And relapsing.  PD: Not seeing any outcomes. 6 We've been measuring outcomes.  AS: That's at thirty, forty thousand dollars a pop.  PD: Exactly.  High cost and ineffectiveness.  We've been tracking outcomes from the beginning and we have really strong outcomes. 11, 16, 18 AS: Do you know those off the top of your head? 12, 14 You can give them to me later.  Probably close to sixty percent successfully complete. 9, 10, 14 That shows reduced use, it shows higher quality of life. 5, 6, 7, 10, 13, 14, 17 It shows less consequences as a result of use. 6, 13, 17 It shows that they're making changes, moving along the process of change. 6, 10, 17 We've been doing twelve month follow up. 10, 16 It's ninety some, high ninety percent of people are out there living with reasonable to high quality of life and not problematic use. 6, 7, 9, 10, 12, 13 Probably half of them at any given time might still be using. 6, 14 We just did another big evaluation; we just did another big call to try to get twelve-month post follow up response in terms of how people are doing. 9, 10, 13, 16, 17 We've been able to get maybe close to two hundred people and they're doing really well. 5, 9, 10, 18 They're doing well.  We've been tracking outcomes from the beginning. 11, 16 We're just doing another, we have all our 2016 outcomes that are all being compiled and all the client feedback. 10, 14 Every time somebody is discharged we do an admission and discharge survey to assess these things pre and post and at twelve months. 11, 16 We have data. 13 When I went to a health insurance meeting and they have all these providers come and they're like, "We want to talk about your outcomes" and nobody had anything. 18, 19 They had admission and discharge stats but nobody was measuring...  AS: The other providers?  PD: Yes, they were like no clinical outcomes.  AS: How can they get away with that? 18, 20 PD: Exactly.  Right? [Heavy machinery noise in background]  AS: Let's sit over here a bit. 20 Well it's only making a little bit of a buzz on here. 10, 20 I think we're still recording.  PD: I'm mostly curious about what it is. 12 AS: You talked about your best practices.  If you could predict something that would happen, something good to happen regarding addiction treatment what would it be? 5, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15 Or change the system somehow what you see where there would just be a huge shift? 6, 8 What's going to take?  PD: I think we have a mental health system that we can use to model things after. 6, 12, 13, 19 Mental health has a lot of community based services. 13, 19 Therapists see people long term; you don't cut them off because they have problems with their symptoms. 6, 9, 12, 17 You should be able to see your counselor long term. 6, 17 You should be able to get wraparound services in your home if you need that level that would include a prescriber and a nurse and a counselor and a therapist. 10, 19 That you have prescribers who are available to you long term that when your symptoms become more severe they don't cut you off. 6, 10, 17 If you need outpatient programs that you should be able to move through them fairly quickly without having to go through complex assessments. 9, 11, 12, 13, 15 You should be able to stay engaged with them long term. 17 A much more robust peer support system so that we've got peer support centers.  AS: Places where people can go when they're struggling or just want to have company. 9, 14 PD: And have outreach workers too so that their peers can go out in people's homes and reach out. 9, 12, 19 AS: Really model it like much of what we do...  PD: With mental health. 12, 19 We should be able to do a lot of the medications in primary care. 14, 19 One of my big questions right now, and I'm working closely with Allina with this, is that we help support their primary care providers to provide medications to help reduce recurrence and that they really start to robustly serve this population. 5, 9, 10, 12, 14, 18, 19 The way that we can support them is that we kind of do these warm handoffs or agree to these long term partnerships. 9, 12, 17, 18 And say, "If you've got someone that you see in your clinic and you're worried you call us. 6, 14 We'll go see that person. 6 We'll check in with them. PD: Absolutely and whether that's if we're co located which I think would be the logical thing to do, that we actually co locate right in the clinic. 7, 12 If they have somebody that they see and they want to refer them they can just send them down the hall and a very welcoming drug and alcohol or co trained mental health professional will start to talk with them about their needs. 5, 6, 12, 19 Then not assuming that everybody needs treatment but they would get referred to a mental health therapist or they just do some early intervention kind of prevention. 5, 10, 12, 13, 17, 19 There's a lot of people that come through the drop in. 5, 9, 11 I started talking to one of them and it’s like, "You know what. 12 You don't need treatment. 12, 13 Here's a rethinking drinking booklet, here's some information on Naltrexone, here's some strategies. 5, 8, 11 Here's a screen so you can actually monitor when you've gone from recreational into problematic use. 6, 7, 12, 13 Here's actually the screen they would use to determine here's the symptoms and if you have two or more you're kind of moving into trouble. 6, 7, 13, 17 Look at all this.  Call me."  A lot of people are like, "Oh God that's so helpful." 9 As opposed to "You've got to come in and get this three-hundred-dollar assessment." 12, 13 AS: And then go away for thirty days and disrupt your family. 12, 16, 18, 20 PD: Or this assumption that if you're an outpatient and you have a use episode that you need residential. 6, 9, 11, 13 That's the most absurd thing I've ever heard about. 9 You're in outpatient, you relapse, and then you have to head back in. 11, 14 PD: To residential. 9, 13 We accept goals other than abstinence because there's this whole theory of cross addiction that if once you have an alcohol problem you automatically have an opiate problem. 6, 12, 14 Or if once you have a cocaine problem you automatically have a cannabis problem. 12, 16 It's not founded. PD: Hopefully in February. 14 At any given time, there's a waiting list which is awful. 11, 15 AS: But your capacity here is one hundred?  PD: Probably a little less, it's a smaller space. 20 AS: Thank you Paula.  PD: I just want to say.  Amy what I really appreciate about your article is I just want to comment that I really like your ideas about mothers feeling empowered to start to challenge the status quo. 5, 10, 12, 15, 17, 18 All the judgement that the system gives, the blaming the parent, and your comparison to having a child in the military. 12, 14, 20 All your energy is just wondering is this person going to make it through the day. 15, 16 Your priority is to preserve life. 10 At what point, how long can you do that? 17 Then it becomes your own survival questions.  AS: Which is what we talk about in the rooms in Nar Anon. 14 Okay my life is out of control now because of this. 10, 12, 18 And what you're saying is we don't have to get to that point.  PD: Right, hopefully not for sure. 9, 14 AS: It's what most people get to. 9 PD: How do we help support people? 9 AS: The addicts are told when they hit their bottom, then I'm going to funeral more often than I really care to. 9, 14, 16, 18, 19 For people who shouldn't be dead. 9, 16 PD: Absolutely.  We're also a distributor of NarCan too.  AS: Good.  PD: I just really recognize and appreciate how you package this in terms of really helping people understand what it is to be a parent of someone who is struggling to help preserve their life. 9, 10, 17, 18, 20 How do they stay well enough to survive that experience or even better how do they stay well enough to become an agent for change? 18 AS: Thank you for that compliment. 12 That means a lot to me.  I really respect what you're doing here. 18 I wish I'd known of you some years ago. 11, 12, 13, 14 How it's unfolded is how it's unfolded.  She's alive and doing well, thriving with medication assisted treatment I should say. 12, 13, 14 PD: That's good. 10 AS: It's been a lifesaver. 10 I'm the preacher for it. 10 I tell anybody.  [End of Recording]

Sue Purchase Part 2 Narrator Amy Sullivan Interviewer May 9, 2017  At the Home of Amy Sullivan Minneapolis, Minnesota Sue Purchase -SP Amy Sullivan -AS AS: This is Amy Sullivan this is part two interview with Sue Purchase. 9 We’re in my house in Minneapolis on May ninth. 6, 13 Sue do you give me permission again?  SP: I absolutely give you permission Amy.  AS: Thank you dear.  I think we were around 2001.  If you want to go back a little further we can definitely start. 9, 20 I didn’t listen to the very end to find out where we were.  You were the director of Women With a Point from 1996 to ‘99? 12, 18, 19 I resigned in 2001. 11 AS: We did start talking about the Fit Pack and you started to work in Australia.  I talk about the Fit Pack with the disposal project that we did? 5 I don’t know but go ahead. 12, 14 SP: It ties in nicely with really raising awareness around harm reduction, the importance of certainly access to clean syringes. 5, 8, 9, 14, 17, 18 Some of the terminology was starting to change, rather than syringe exchange it would be syringe access. 9, 10, 17 There were more sources available for syringes for people actively using illicit drugs. 5, 6, 9 We had the pharmacy project going with four area pharmacies. 5, 8 One was in South Minneapolis on 26th and Nicollet.  I can’t remember the name of it.  They had two locations.  That one and then there was one on Lake Street, really well known. 11, 12, 18 Then we had one on the West Side of St. Paul where there was predominately a Latino population, lots of heroin. 5, 10, 16 There was one on the East Side of St. Paul, more of white working class, methamphetamine. 6, 7, 8 Then we had a pharmacy, I think it was Merwin Drug over on the North Side of Minneapolis.  This project involved community based pharmacists selling, they could sell the Fit Pack. 5, 13, 14, 19 The personal sharps container came packed with a ten pack of syringes and there was a mailing card.  There was a research component attached to it. 8 It had a sticker on the front that we had designed that really talked about safe injecting, safe disposal, and harm reduction message. 5, 11, 13, 14, 18 Then people were involved in that. 9 I can’t remember exactly how it all came about.  Participants at the storefront would participate in a survey; they got a t-shirt that had art on it that was designed by a program participant. 9, 11 It was of a demon being shot out of a syringe with flames behind it. 11 It was a circular image, red and yellow and very vibrant. 5, 10 In a really interesting font it said, “Be Blood Aware. 17, 18 Better Safe Than Sorry.”  We had this whole disposal awareness campaign. 9 Through that what we learned was how pharmacies were participating with users, what the cost of syringes were. 6, 9, 10, 13 The one on 26th and Nicollet oftentimes charged five dollars a ten pack. 8 They didn’t want active drug users in their pharmacies. 5, 6, 13 AS: Was that more money than they should have been charging? 8, 10 SP: Yes.  Syringes wholesale are seventy cents apiece or they were at the time.  You’d get ten of them in a pack.  With pharmacy access laws you were allowed to buy a ten pack but you couldn’t buy more than that at a time. 9, 10, 13 Seventy cents wholesale being sold for five dollars a ten pack.  Their policy around that was based on appearance. 13 If you appeared to be somebody buying syringes for illicit purposes you paid five bucks. 5 If you were a diabetic I think it was three dollars.  There was a price break.  That was interesting, not a surprise. 17 The pharmacy on the North Side of Minneapolis they were asking for identification and limiting the number of visits that a person could have to a pharmacy.  Really deterrents around enactment, on the surface it was really great to have pharmacy access but there were glitches in the system. 9, 12, 18, 20 This project the aim was to help alleviate those glitches, get more uniform policies throughout pharmacies, and give access to people, address safe disposal. 5, 9 AS: Was this a grant funded project? 5, 8 SP: It was a grant funded project. 5, 8 AS: With Access Works?  SP: Access Works with the Minnesota Department of Health. 9, 12 It was titled the Better Safe Than Sorry Disposal Proposal.  AS: We have those documents. 12, 14 SP: Yes, exactly.  That got funded and really created another level of awareness. 8, 9, 18 Working with participants, participants are more involved. 9 The project, although the research component of it was never fully completed, we worked in collaboration with Sarah Riebeckie and Seth Wells from the University of Minnesota. 5, 7, 8, 14, 16 I’m not sure whatever really happened with the data there. 13, 15, 18 Sarah might know something more about it. 12 There was that and that project was also replicated throughout New York City. 5 At the time the big move was pharmacy access for drug users. 5, 6, 9, 13, 15 Not all pharmacies in Minnesota wanted to participate. 9, 18 It was a voluntary thing.  Disposal had never been adequately addressed for pharmacists to feel real comfortable with selling syringes. 5, 16 With the idea that people would bring their used syringes back? 6, 9, 13, 16 SP: That there would be this personal sharps container.  The pharmacists were handing the syringes out within this ten pack and so they felt better. 11 The ten pack was in the Fit Pack.  They were handing out a disposal mechanism with the syringes so they felt better about that with the sense that discarded syringes weren’t going to be left laying on the ground. 11, 14 AS: Do you throw the whole Fit Pack away? 18, 20 SP: The Fit Pack can be thrown in the garbage.  AS: The whole thing when you’re done with those ten?  SP: Yes or it could have been brought back to the needle exchange. 10 There were so many valuable aspects to the Fit Pack in that it also created a much more positive relationship with law enforcement. 8, 12, 13, 19 People who were on the streets having some encounter with a cop, they didn’t have to worry about patting them down and that they’re going to accidentally get a needle stick because they were carried safely. 10, 13 It also provided a level of safety for the user because the dirty ones were going down inside, one way flap. 6, 8, 9, 13, 18, 19 You can’t get them out.  No one wants to stick their finger down there so that residue that will get people a felony when they’re trying to return used syringes to a needle exchange, that’s where some of the rub comes in. 6, 8, 9, 10, 13, 16 You want them returned but oftentimes people can’t hold on to them for fear of prosecution, something’s going to happen. 9, 10, 15 It was a win, win situation in that way. 18 It was a great project. 5, 20 It really raised awareness. 9, 14, 18 A lot of education happened that way not only for community pharmacies but for the individual user. 6, 13, 14, 15, 18, 19 Much more in a sense activism really a big part of Access Works was always about engaging and educating program participants, everybody, about whether it was know your rights, safe disposal, how do you write to your congressperson. 9, 12, 14, 18 In the storefront there was a room and all the walls were pretty bare. 10, 14 I think I bought two hundred dollars’ worth of posters and postcards from Northern Sun.  It was fantastic because we created this collage on the wall. 14 People would come look at them and ask about them and the quotes.  It was such a wonderful opportunity to educate and open a mind and put forth other ideas. 14, 18, 19 We had letter writing campaigns.  We had the nuns; they had Peace House on Franklin. 6, 13 Are you familiar? 8 They used to protest at the School of Americas. 6, 13, 16 What were their names? 16 They’re the Sisters of Carondelet.  I’m going to blank it out, I should know it so well. 12 They came and did stuff.  We had voter’s rights; the women’s users group had the League of Women Voters. 6, 12, 13 We did so many educational opportunities on a variety of topics. 14, 15, 19 AS: To just engage people who came through the door. 9 SP: Yes, an informed consumer. 14 AS: When we talk with Rae later we can go into what you guys did together and that stuff. 8 Do you want to focus on your life for this? 10 If you want to.  AS: So after you went to work for Fit Pack what’s been going on in your life since? 10 SP: I went to work for Fit Pack and I worked for them until 2004, 2005.  AS: Did you leave the cities? 7, 18 I moved to Tacoma, Washington. 7, 15 My husband 14 Dave ran a program in Tacoma.  Kind of a twofold, he had a needle exchange, it was the first publicly funded legal needle exchange in the United States. 8, 10, 14, 19 AS: How did you meet Dave? 18 SP: Everybody knew Dave Purchase. 16 AS: But how did you meet him? 18 SP: I met him at a conference.  I met him at the first harm reduction conference in Oakland, California. 5, 14 AS: Do you remember the year? 14 I thought he was a showboat. 17, 18 AS: What do you mean by that?  SP: Well Dave was a presence. 10 I thought that he was just a little too full of himself, met him there. 14, 17, 18, 20 Had to have a conversation with him about...  Dave had the needle exchange in Tacoma but he also had a larger national organization. 10 It was the North American Syringe Exchange Network, NASEN is the acronym.  NASEN involved technical assistance for startup needle exchange programs in the United States and other places in the world. 10 It had a buyers club for needle exchange programs. 10 It had a grants program.  Then I can’t remember if it was an annual conference or every two years Dave put on a conference. 14 He was a really well-known figure. 11, 12, 18 Dave was instrumental in starting all the New York programs. 12 He worked throughout the country. 14, 19 He worked throughout the world, programs in Hawaii and Vietnam and Puerto Rico, everywhere.  He’s this larger than life figure. 10 I think he’s arrogant and annoying.  I have to do business with him.  AS: Somehow a romance developed?  SP: Not so much.  Then a year goes by. 14 I had to apply for money with him. 8, 10 The needle exchange pots of dollars were so few and far between you didn’t not apply. 6, 10 I had to apply for money from him. 8, 10 I didn’t get funded. 8 I remember calling him on the phone and saying, “What’s the deal? 8, 16 Where’s my money? 8, 10 Why didn’t I get some?”  Out of that he sent me a little money for needle exchange. 5, 8, 10, 20 I remember then Dave was self-described as glib and he was.  He’d make some comment like, “Oh darling you should marry me and take me away from all of this.” 12, 18, 20 Then some time goes by.  I don’t know if it’s later that year but I’m at a drug policy conference in New Orleans and in the opening reception. 5, 6, 10, 12, 14 I think I was with my colleague Toni.  We’re standing at the bar. 14 I look across the room and I say, “Oh no Dave Purchase is coming across the room. 14 Let’s move.” 15 We said hello.  Later that night, Dave used to hold court in the bar, everybody was there. 6, 13, 14, 16 This was harm reduction in the United States. 5, 14 All these people who are the old timers now were young, having a conversation with him in the bar. 9, 12 It was a good conversation, it was an interesting conversation. 10, 14, 17 He wasn’t annoying.  It was enjoyable.  Then there was an attraction.  The conference goes on.  I don’t know what the hell he had said to me. 12 The last day or something he said there was a spark between us. 16 I don’t remember how I responded to that.  He was going on to Denver to another harm reduction conference. 5, 14 I was going home to Minneapolis.  I think I had told him that I’d lived in Colorado for years. 7, 14, 16 He had a sister that lived up in the mountains. 7, 20 He sent me a card that said something like, “Proof of purchase to follow.” 5, 10 I think he sent me some Fat Tire beer in the mail. 5 You couldn’t get it in Minnesota.  That’s when it said, “Proof of purchase to follow.” 10 He was coming to visit.  That was the proof of Purchase.  And visit he did.  What a human being, certainly human. 8, 17, 19 We had an amazing relationship for about nine years, travelled, worked together, my confidante, his confidante. 8, 9, 14, 19 We lived in Tacoma, Washington and he ran a program. 7 I had run a program. 8 I had run a much more progressive, comprehensive program. 8, 10 Dave had started a needle exchange and it didn’t really expand beyond where it was in 1988, on the corner of 14th and G Street. 10, 14, 18 Minnesota offers a lot of services. 19 Minnesota is hospitable.  Tacoma is not hospitable.  It’s the West Coast and there’s black tar heroin. 16 Tacoma was built on Indian burial grounds and I think the spirits were revolting.  I worked on the corner of 14th and G Street in a van. 14 The Tacoma Needle Exchange has a very strict one for one policy.  They might still have a strict one for one policy. 8 Dave created that policy when he was being glib with People magazine.  He got all this attention, it’s the late 80s and it’s a new thing in the United States. 16 Dave answered off the cuff and it became policy. 5, 14 Working at the needle exchange, if somebody didn’t come with a used syringe they weren’t supposed to get a clean one. 6, 8, 10, 13, 16 That program was constantly under the gun.  The people of Tacoma weren’t fond of the needle exchange at all. 9, 10 They were always looking to shut it down. 18 It was located on the corner of 14th and G Street is the Catholic Worker community. 14, 19 There’s St. Leo’s, the Catholic Church sits right above with the hospitality kitchen. 8, 12 There is Father Bicks who is in charge of stuff.  He was a Jesuit priest who used to protest at School of Americas all of this stuff. 6, 13, 16, 20 Bicks was an amazing human. 9, 19 There’s the Guadalupe House on the other corner and all the Catholic Workers. 6, 13 There is Joe the nurse who works at the medical clinic at St. Leo’s. 7, 9, 14 There’s a one for one policy.  There are people in the neighborhood who spy. 9, 20 People, in order to have a clean syringe, a sterile syringe had to dig around in the dirt, they had to dig around in the grass, they had to find a piece of a plunger.  They had to find evidence of a syringe and bring it.  Dave had people working for him that were very obedient but that wasn’t me. 9 I was a game changer at the exchange. 10 They’d come on Fridays and I’d say, “Five can get you ten.” 16 It wasn’t going to be a strict one for one. 8 I wasn’t going to be stupid about it but it wasn’t a policy I could abide by.  There was tension.  The black tar heroin, the sex workers, on the West Coast the amount of homeless with people sleeping outside in the jungle. 9, 12, 16, 19 AS: What do you mean by the jungle?  SP: The jungle was...you know Almond Roca candy? 12 It comes out of Tacoma, Washington.  So did Ted Bundy and the D.C. sniper.  As we go on I’m sure I’ll remember some other highlights. 7 Behind the Almond Roca factory, you know Seattle, Tacoma; the Northwest is really green and lush. 12, 18 Bushes, trees, you name it.  Behind the Almond Roca there was the I-5 that goes through there.  There was this big area, wooded under the freeway and behind the factory that was called the jungle that was the homeless camp. 8, 18 It was huge and dangerous and dirty. 11 There are sex workers; there was the Green River killer. 12, 19 At the needle exchange I took the bad date report. 10, 13 SP: The bad date report was for women who were sex workers. 12, 13, 19 If they had a bad date they could report it to us and we compiled a weekly bad date sheet so we would hand it out at the van for other working girls so they would know who to be aware of. 7, 11, 12, 13, 15 It might be so and so got picked up.  She was raped at knife point and thrown out of a truck at Tacoma  Avenue or something, some story around that. 15 We would compile that.  I’d take those reports. 13 There’s also SOAP and SODA laws in Tacoma. 13 There is in Seattle as well, in many places in the United States.  SOAP stood for “Stay Out of Areas of Prostitution” and SODA stood for “Stay Out of Areas of Drug Abuse.” 6, 13 If you had a crime, you’d had a drug crime you couldn’t be in those areas. 5, 6, 8, 20 All social services, all low income housing, the needle exchange, all of it are in these areas. 6, 8, 10, 19, 20 Most of Tacoma are SOAP and SODA areas. 8, 20 You could only be there between nine and eleven, nine and twelve, ten and twelve that you could be there to do your business.  Otherwise you were subject to arrest and brought back to jail.  The correctional system is a revolving constant.  AS: I’ve never heard of that before. 9, 16 SP: That’s a longer story too. 15, 17 We would help women escape the cops. 12 They’d be there looking for them.  They’d cruise the needle exchange. 10 I had several encounters with law enforcement. 8, 12, 13 The point of the needle exchange is not only that people get sterile supplies but also they can get some help with housing, they might need an ID, they might want to go to treatment, they might want to get on methadone. 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13 All of that takes time. 17 That’s the work we did there.  It’s long and complicated. 17 That was work that I brought there that had never been done there in the past. 16 It kept people hanging out at the van. 9 There were complaints about that in the neighborhood. 20 There was a dude named Wes who worked up at the hospitality kitchen and he liked to take pictures of the people who were participants at the needle exchange and then he would deny them food. 8, 9, 10 There was one woman in particular that I remember. 9 There’s MRSA going around, a drug resistant staph infection, eighty five to ninety percent of the participants had MRSA. 5, 6, 9 Abscesses, wounds that you wouldn’t even begin to believe.  There was one woman who was intent on saving her life and get a clean syringe. 10 She’d risk everything to come and get it.  She’d have to shoot dope on the fly.  Dope sick, got to get your fix, got to earn money, all those things that it takes to survive. 8, 10, 15, 17 The whole top of her arm, the left arm, was eaten away by an abscess. 14, 18, 20 You didn’t have to worry about finding a vein.  You could load it up and put it through your clothes and stick it in your arm while you’re moving and hiding from the cops.  Those sorts of situations I see more and more and more. 6 Dave and I have disagreements. 12 AS: Had you seen things as bad as that in Minneapolis? 6 AS: It was worse in Tacoma.  SP: Oh my God it was way, way worse. 18 SP: Yes and Minnesota didn’t necessarily have black tar heroin, they had China white. 16, 19 Black tar is nasty.  People would transport it under their fingernails; maybe it’s in their pussy. 5, 17 However you don’t get busted.  You think about all the bacteria and you’re shooting it. 6 The health risks are huge. 19 I would help sex workers evade the cops. 12, 19 I’d drive to the site. 5 I’d put them in my car, drive up around the block and drop them off so they wouldn’t get arrested. 5, 11 I brought people to clinics. 9 I went to meetings. 18 I talked.  I spoke up.  AS: This rubbed Dave the wrong way? 11, 18 SP: Yes.  It began to certainly he was getting more flak from the community because there’s more presence at the exchange. 8, 10, 17, 19 All the participants loved me. 9, 14 They showed up.  “Go see Sue. 6 She’ll hook you up.  She’ll help you out.”  I’m seeing all this stuff and I’ve got things going on in my personal life at the same time. 6, 10 AS: Were you married to Dave? 7 SP: We got married in 1999. 7 There’s so much that’s happening. 15 One of the things that happens towards the end, there’s a woman named Valerie. 15 She’s a Native woman.  She’s trying so hard to get her life together and get on track. 8, 9, 10, 16 She wants to go home to her family at the Flathead Indian Reservation. 12, 14 Montana is close to Washington. 9, 10 You get a lot of tribes. 12 She got shot in the head one block down on Faucet. 11, 14 Shot in the head and killed. 14 All I remember saying to Dave is, “Every social service provider in this town has blood on his hands, including you.” 17, 19 I had expectations of Dave.  I believed that he should be doing certain things a certain way. 14, 17, 18 He should have built that program and moved it along and been responsive to the needs of the community and he was not. 7, 15, 17, 19 I lost respect for him. 11 Then there was somebody else.  There was something else that had happened, which I can’t remember right now. 12, 15 I met a woman named Linda.  This is a story about stigma. 9, 15 Linda had lived on the streets for fifteen years in Tacoma. 5, 7, 14 She was beautiful when she was young.  She was from Montana.  She had kids that she was estranged from. 7 She did sex work to survive. 12 She had seizure disorder. 13 She would go to the medical clinic up at St. Leo’s. 7, 14 The nurse that ran St. Leo’s medical clinic was on the Catholic Worker community, Joe. 7, 14, 19 Joe had been a medic in the Vietnam War. 14 He had a heart of gold. 9 He understood what happened with people on the street and how hard it was. 9, 15 How I met Joe and I met Linda is they came to the van one day. 16 He explained what was going on with Linda and her seizures and she couldn’t hold on to her medicine and was always disappearing. 12, 14, 18 People like seizure medicine. 12, 14 You can get high on it. 7 The arrangement is I would hold on to Linda’s medication and she’d come by the van every morning to get them. 7, 12, 14 Linda wasn’t much of an injection drug user. 5, 6, 13 She was a crack smoker. 16 This arrangement worked for a while. 7, 12 I make sure that every day Linda gets one pill in her mouth. 16 It happens for a week, two weeks, a month. 15, 16 Then Linda disappears.  I don’t think much of it.  I hold on to the meds.  Then there’s this dude named Troy.  Troy comes by the van a lot, a good guy. 10 He’d come by and he’d say, “Sue, Linda got housed.” 6, 13, 16 I’m like, “That’s awesome.  That’s really awesome.” 18 He’d be like, “You should go visit her.”  I’m like, “Yes I should.  Then he comes by and he tells me that she has cancer and she doesn’t have long to live. 10, 15, 17 He really wants me to visit her. 18 I agree.  Troy and Linda had been friends years before. 14, 16, 20 I don’t remember what Linda told me. 16 Troy had a reputation on the streets for slashed throats. 5 The streets are rough. 5 He’s kind of funny. 9 He gave me this beautiful hand knit scarf.  He liked me.  He and Linda had had some issues. 12, 13 They got along. 17 They were friends, they were close. 9, 10, 16, 20 I finally go to visit Linda.  Her belly is really distended, she had liver cancer. 10, 18 Linda had been living with AIDS for twenty years. 14 She’d gotten housed for the last six months of her life. 6, 10, 11, 13, 16 She had this boyfriend. 7, 20 What the fuck was his name.  I can picture him in my brain. 13 I don’t think much of the guy.  She’s got a son in prison.  She’s got this guy as a boyfriend. 7, 20 Linda likes to smoke crack. 16 I go over and meet her. 18 We talk.  I meet her daughter in law, I leave. 13, 18 Somehow I get in the mix with Linda.  I started checking on her; make sure she has her meds. 14 She loved to smoke cigarettes and she loved to smoke crack. 14, 16 Somehow in there we had an agreement. 12 She needed some care; I could help out with it. 14, 19 I knew she smoked crack. 14, 16 I’m like, “Here’s the deal.  I don’t care.” 19 We became very close and I ended up helping her with the help of Joe the nurse and Linda’s boyfriend, we helped her die at home. 7, 9, 10, 20 It’s a longer story. 15, 17 It was representative of the stigma, the lack of services, and the lack of caring for people who were homeless, strung out, and had been drug users in Tacoma. 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, 13, 19 There was no harm reduction there. 5, 14 There was a needle exchange. 10 Needle exchange is a strategy that reduces harm but it does not mean that it’s done with compassion or with any sort of insights or care. 5, 10, 14, 19 It simply exchanges a syringe on a good day. 6, 10, 16 The marriage ended after that, not long after that. 14, 17 I moved back to Minnesota in 2007. 7, 15 Before I leave Tacoma Rae wants to leave Access Works. 18 Her computer had been stolen and she had had enough.  AS: We’ll have to have that story tonight. 15 SP: We’ll pick up there with Rae.  I went back to Minnesota.  She had called me saying, “Do you want the organization back?”  I said, “No, not necessarily.”  I was burnt out on needle exchange. 10 I was burnt out period. 18 AS: It takes so much energy to do it the way you were doing it, with more harm reduction model than just needle exchange. 5, 10, 14, 17, 18 SP: It takes a lot. 17 The idea behind needle exchange is it builds a bridge to other services. 10, 19 AS: It’s a part of harm reduction but it’s not the only part. 5, 9, 14 SP: Right.  I take it back on a temporary basis.  I was shocked by what had happened there, what had changed. 13, 14, 15 The program certainly was booming when I left but by the time I get back, this is four years later; there are youngsters there that are from the suburbs. 8, 14, 17 Pills are plentiful.  People are coming through the door.  AS: You’re saying the users changed, the people who came through the door between 2004 and 6, 9, 13 SP: Yes, it’s like the fall of 2007.  They’re younger, they’re from the suburbs, and they don’t look like they belong there. 17, 20 They are there looking to hook up.  AS: They’re there looking for heroin because their pills are too expensive or not available. 16 SP: Yes.  They’ve got a habit. 20 They’re coming to the needle exchange. 10 I’m looking around in part in disbelief of what I had created there. 9 It was working.  It was a drop in center. 5, 11 We had active drug users providing services across the board. 5, 6, 13, 19 We had people shooting dope in the bathroom. 6, 9, 14 We had kids…  AS: This is what was happening there that hadn’t been happening before. 15 SP: Not to the degree.  It was always a struggle because it’s harm reduction. 5, 14, 18 Even prior to me leaving people would dump off bodies that had overdosed. 9 They weren’t dead but they’d drop them off at our back door. 5, 11, 16 They knew we were a safe place. 16 I can’t even begin to tell you all of the stuff.  All of the reasons that that space served communities. 14, 19 There were funerals for people who were infected with HIV through injection drug use, had worked in the community and had died. 5, 6, 9, 13, 14, 19 Robert Preston, his was there.  The intention is always that it would be normalized community. 14, 16, 18, 19 That people, all people, were viewed as part of the community and welcomed if they wanted to come there. 9, 14, 18, 19 It was astounding.  There’s this safety issue. 13, 19 I think I showed you the sign that says, “Please don’t shoot dope in our bathroom, if you must please use the sharps container.” 6, 11, 13, 14 People would put syringes down the toilet.  We had wraparound services in there. 19 Rae can talk more about that from her experience in terms of being hired and what she had implemented in my absence. 5, 12, 17, 18 It was working and it was working well.  It had changed. 13 You could see certainly the increase in drug use. 5, 6, 8, 13, 17 During that time in that transition period with Rae and I, we’re getting Narcan brought in with a doctor, Jim Hervenco. 12, 14, 17, 18 I can’t remember what days we had the clinic and how the training happened. 15, 16 He wrote the prescription. 10 People had Narcan the first day that we had it. 14, 16 One of the outreach workers, Tommy Stevens, he had run in the front door of the drop in and said someone in two buildings over had overdosed. 5, 8, 11, 12, 19 I think he had fallen behind a couch.  Tommy Narcaned him, brought him out, saved a life, just that quick. 10 It was absolutely amazing. 9 I’m burnt out; Rae’s burnt out and has moved on. 7, 15 The board isn’t particularly affective. 9 Fundraising is difficult. 5, 10 I want out.  I didn’t like working with them.  I’m fried.  In my own life at the time I had friends dying of cancer. 10, 16, 20 My mother had died and suicides among friends, countless overdose deaths in Tacoma. 16, 18, 20 There were at least ten overdose deaths in Tacoma in the year that I was working at the exchange there, the woman who got shot in the head, Linda dying. 10, 11, 14, 18 AS: You’re just surrounded by trauma.  SP: Surrounded by it.  I remember sitting in there thinking...I’d gotten a divorce.  People continued to tell me one sad story after another. 15 AS: You’re off the chart for that list where you have to make a point for everything.  SP: I couldn’t be there anymore.  I didn’t have the magic to save that organization. 10 I think Rae had been in discussions somehow with MAP. 8 I don’t remember how that happened. 15 I’m like vehemently opposed to MAP having that program. 12 What happens is that they hire this woman… 15 AS: She did say, “We took over your program.”  SP: Yes she did, fucking bitch. 20 There was a woman named Laurie Wolner who was hired as the executive director. 5, 18, 19 Laurie Wolner had been a case director at MAP for many years, a terrible reputation, not nice to people, all sorts of things. 9, 11, 14, 17, 18, 19 She shuts it down.  She decides to close. 9, 10, 14 They tell people it’s a funding issue. 9, 13 Lorraine Teal could see the writing on the wall. 6 She wanted money for her program, her needle exchange. 8, 10, 18 During the history of Access Works there were times... 15 Dave’s needle exchange conference was in Minneapolis in 2000. 10 We had honored Dave. 5 He had beat cancer. 10 People came from all over the world for this conference. 14 MAP was there.  Bob Tracy was there.  He talked how MAP had deemphasized needle exchange. 10 There were grants that we had written that MAP plagiarized.  I knew people. 9, 16 I had friends that were the founders. 16, 20 They read my applications.  I think it may have been Dave.  He’d read my applications.  He read MAP’s application and recognized my program description. 17 They had taken my stuff and plagiarized.  AS: How did they get it?  SP: How did they get my program?  AS: How did they get copies of your grant proposals?  SP: A lot of it was public information. 19 You’d have access. 9 There was always competition for it. 18 In the beginning of Women With a Point, prior to funding through the Health Department, we’d want to have a collaborative relationship with MAP. 9, 11, 12, 19 We don’t have the budget, they’ve got it and we’re disposing the syringes we’re collecting with Minnesota AIDS Project.  They get to have our numbers.  Numbers matter for grant opportunities. 19 They got to count our numbers.  The first year in what I didn’t think was a successful year; it’s a brand new program. 14, 16 We exchanged ten thousand syringes. 10, 13 I don’t remember what MAP had exchanged, four thousand or something. 10, 13 It’s significantly higher. 7, 11, 17 We start getting funding and we’re doing our own disposal.  MAP can’t count our numbers anymore.  Competition stiffens.  In Minnesota for funding competition is everything.  It’s a competitive process. 17 They don’t encourage collaboration.  It’s a dog eat dog.  Lorraine is nothing if not competitive.  She can see Women With a Point and Access Works becoming the hottest gig in town. 6, 12 Everybody talked about it and we got more and more money. 8, 10 AS: You did get Ryan White funds.  SP: We got Ryan White funds, we got directly funded CDC grant. 8, 18 We were the first needle exchange program in the United States to have a directly funded CDC grant when federal funding for needle exchange was illegal. 8, 10, 14, 18 It was a coup.  She resented every bit of it. 5, 20 Opportunity knocked at her door. 19 They got it and they shut us down.  Access Works went away. 18, 20 That’s directly attributed to Lorraine Teal, without a doubt in my mind. 18 SP: I started Morpheus Project in Minneapolis.  It was a brief intervention needle exchange program with Lee Hurtle. 10, 19 I have to leave Minnesota. 18 At the time my best friend is dying of cancer. 10, 20 I was really in Minnesota because she was here dying of cancer not because I really wanted to live in Minnesota. 10, 18 My youngest son was still in high school and graduating. 7 I came back.  I ran Morpheus Project, distributed Narcan.  I really ran a needle exchange out of my house. 6, 10, 13, 18 I worked for Simpson Housing. 6 They wanted a harm reduction housing program for women. 5, 6, 12, 14, 18 They thought they’d hire me. 17, 18 It was a brand new start up program. 16 It had amazing potential. 6, 9 I had eighty five percent of my case load were chronically homeless native women. 6, 12, 14, 17 It was good work. 10 It was really good work. 10, 18 For me that was a slacker job. 11 I’m losing my shit. 18 AS: What do you mean?  SP: Mentally I’m struggling.  I’m in grief.  My friend Lisa had died. 20 Her son Grant had died from a suicide a year and a half before that. 14 It was just so much death. 18 My sister Dianne died. 20 I’m sure there were others, friends, overdoses in Minnesota. 16, 20 I know a lot of people. 9, 12 Simpson Housing, we have a parting of the ways. 6, 9, 18 I bug out.  I saw the Dalai Lama on Mother’s Day of 2011.  I’d been in grad school. 7 I was going to do an MBA on strategic planning and using a harm reduction model. 5, 6, 14 I had it all figured out in my head how it could work. 5, 14 I thought it would be a good place for me because it’s a liberal catholic women’s college. 7, 10, 12, 17, 18 It wasn’t quite liberal enough for me. 11 That went south.  I flunked out of grad school. 7 All through school I’d had a 4.0. 7 I just couldn’t keep it together anymore. 8 I sold all my shit, took all my stuff, brought my Buddha to Rae’s house. 6, 13, 18 I have a two hundred and fifty pound sandstone Buddha and he travels with me.  He had to go to Rae’s house for a while. 6, 13 Then he was over at a meditation center in St.  Paul for a while.  I retrieved him in 2013 when I moved to Georgetown. 7, 15 I had been in therapy and diagnosed with PTSD. 12 Drugs had become a problem in a way that was reminiscent of early days. 12, 16, 18 So I left. 14 I got rid of all my shit except for like two crates. 18 I brought those down to a friend’s house in St. Louis, stayed there for a bit, got healthier. 6, 13, 19, 20 Then I went to Colorado.  I went to the mountains.  My daughter is there and things aren’t good with her. 10 She’s in and out of jail and precariously housed at that point. 6, 10, 13, 16 She steals all my money. 8, 10 It’s just really hard. 9, 18 I worked at Loveland Ski Area for a season.  Then I got in my car and I drove to San Francisco and stayed there for a while. 5 I couch surfed and got my car towed on 4/20 in the Haight Ashbury neighborhood. 20 It’s kind of a funny story. 9, 15 I went down to Tucson, stayed with friends. 16, 20 Went back up to Seattle and stayed with friends there. 16, 20 In the fall I went back to Colorado and started therapy. 12 I’ve been there ever since. 10 Morpheus Project—for whatever reason I can’t not do needle exchange. 10 I have Rocky Mountain Morpheus Project up there, this fledgling little stellar mountain needle exchange program at the continental divide. 10, 20 My last real effort in developing a program in that way. 18 During my days of couch surfing I volunteered with the Berkeley needle exchange program which is called NEED. 5, 10, 16 I’ve worked at needle exchange programs and volunteered throughout the country. 5, 10, 14, 19 For that I am so grateful.  It’s an honor in ways that many people don’t understand. 9, 17, 18 What Dave liked about me and what he saw from the very beginning was that I got it. 11 Should we talk anymore about my personal life? 10 AS: You don’t have to say her name but could you tell me about the person who you brought to the harm reduction summit and what you were doing for her for those days? 5, 14, 16 I don’t want you to say her name because I don’t have her permission but if you could just tell me.  SP: I know her because I know her mother. 12 AS: Is that connected in any way to your harm reduction work? 5, 14, 18 SP: I’m always taking care of somebody. 11, 18, 19 My last big save or something before I bugged out is that I knew that she needed to leave the reservation. 10, 16, 18, 19 AS: Bugged out when?  SP: When I left Minneapolis. 14 She was struggling on a reservation in South Dakota. 19 She came to Minneapolis and lived with me for a few months. 7, 11, 16 I had gotten to know her through her mom. 12, 14 She would show up periodically in Minneapolis. 14, 18 She wasn’t necessarily living on a reservation then, she was somewhere else. 19 The first time I met her I picked her up at the emergency room at HCMC because she’d been down in the Franklin, Nicollet area and someone had stabbed her in the head with a screw driver. 5, 8, 14 Her mom needed her to be picked up at HCMC which is frequently referred to as the chop shop. 5, 14, 15, 17 I picked her up there.  That was the beginning of us knowing one another. 11, 12 She would periodically come and go out of Minneapolis. 14, 18 I always kept track with her mom. 14, 16, 18 She’d come and stay with me.  She had some things happen on the reservation that were awful. 11, 15, 19 She came to Minneapolis, she went to treatment. 12, 13 She’s been here ever since. 10 She was always a drinker in the past. 5, 18 She’s got a meth habit. 6, 20 She is a community theater performer on homelessness and telling her story. 15, 19 Everybody wants to hear a good homeless tragic story for whatever reason. 9, 10, 15 She talks about her hopes, her dreams, things that she’d like to do. 5, 9 She’d like to be a nurse.  She has an uncle who works for the tribe in South Dakota and does amazing work and they’re really close. 9, 10, 18 She wants to do work like her uncle does.  She’s got some stuff to work through.  I brought her up to White Earth with me.  I thought it would be a good environment for her, we’d have quality time. 10, 12, 17, 18 She’s got an apartment; she’s got a place to live. 5, 9, 11, 12 She’d be with some supportive people. 9, 19 She’ll tell you that telling her story is really hard and it opens everything up. 9, 15, 18 When the performance is over there’s nothing but a bottle.  AS: Really what is the point of all this?  SP: It’s to educate the fucking white people in the community about homelessness so they’ll rise to the occasion and do something goddamn different. 9, 14, 19 So they’ll be sympathetic and not stigmatize people. 9 So they’ll learn a lesson, so that they look around and wake the fuck up, all of it. 10 I’m so, so sad.  People think now that Trump’s in office look what’s going on in the world. 12 Where the fuck have you been?  The Democratic Party, there’s a lot of great things to say about Barack Obama but there’s a lot of shitty things to say about Barack Obama. 18, 20 What the fuck is wrong with people? 9, 11 The looky loo tour everybody loves it. 14 I used to take people down to Curry Avenue. 6, 9, 13, 16 SP: I used to call it the looky loo tour because there’s people that are liberal and they want to do what’s politically correct and then be hipsters and groovy at a cocktail party and talk about how edgy they are. 6, 9, 13, 14, 16, 20 I’d bring them down to Curry Avenue.  They’d have no idea.  What they knew was Block E and the drive by on the highway. 5, 7, 16, 18 They’d never been to Curry Avenue. 16 Some people got it and they were truly humble and appropriate. 9 Other people got baptism by fire and it was good for them. 9, 10 They would never forget it. 16 I would say that I have contributed a lot to Minnesota.  AS: I would say you have.  SP: Thank you for the opportunity to talk about it. 19 AS: You’re so welcome.  It’s been my privilege.  SP: There’s just so much sadness.  I can’t come here in the wintertime.  AS: Thank you Sue.  SP: You’re welcome.  I can fill in blank spaces for you in the future if you want. 5

Sue Purchase Narrator Amy Sullivan Interviewer April 27, 2017 Minneapolis, Minnesota  Sue Purchase -SP Amy Sullivan -AS AS: This is Amy Sullivan I’m at my home with Sue Purchase.  It is April 27, 2017.  At my house and I’m with Sue Purchase. 6, 13 Sue do you want to state your name?  SP: I am Sue Purchase and I give Amy Sullivan permission to record this interview.  AS: Let’s start with your childhood. 14, 20 You said you’d grown up in Cloquet. 10 Do you want to talk about your parents, your childhood, your early life? 10, 14, 20 SP: I grew up in Northern Minnesota. 20 I was born in Duluth in 1959. 14 Number five of what would be six children. 5, 14, 20 First four years were spent in Esko, Minnesota. 14 Esko is a suburb of Cloquet.  A very strong Finnish community. 19 Number five of six kids.  Moved to Cloquet when I was five years old. 14 Went to grade school there. 5, 7 AS: What did your parents do? 20 SP: My dad, he worked for the co-op store, very much Northern Minnesota. 14 He lost his job working there and then he worked at the paper mill for Potlatch. 11 I guess for the rest of his life. 10 I must have been nine years old or something. 14 He started working for Potlatch.  That was in the mid-60s, the paper industry was huge.  They had Potlatch, Diamond Match, and two other active mills.  There was a mill bus.  It was a mill town.  My mother, she never worked outside the house. 6, 13, 16 How would describe your economic situation growing up? 10 SP: I would say the working poor.  It’s interesting to think about. 17 What I remember, my mother always scrabbling for money. 8, 10, 18 Always worried about money, the things we could and could not have because of money. 8, 10, 18 I suspect that my dad probably made good money. 8, 10, 14 For the times and for the mill industry.  Given the times there was a living wage but he drank it all up. 5, 16 There was no money. 8, 10 I remember things like he’d come home drunk and pass out and she’d go through his wallet after the fact to see what was left, what there could be for school lunches. 5, 6, 7, 8, 14 It’s interesting to talk about. 17 I don’t know what year it was, ‘65 maybe, when free lunches started. 5, 12, 14 It must have been Lyndon Johnson’s war on poverty but we certainly qualified. 8, 17 I think that I was in the third grade... 5 It must have been around third grade however old I would be then. 5 They were blue and yellow. 10 I don’t know if one was free or one was reduced or you got one of the colors for hot lunch and one was for milk. 5, 12, 14 There was some sort of order to the tickets but I remember the shame.  I hated it.  I hated using them. 6 Growing up I always felt like everybody in town knew about my house, which was fairly true. 5, 6, 9, 11, 13, 16, 18 He was a drinker and he was violent. 5 I grew up at 1802 Carleton Avenue. 20 Carleton  Avenue was one of the main streets in Cloquet. 5 I always felt like we were on display for all of the dysfunction and violence and drinking that happened there. 5, 6, 9, 11, 15, 18 Always a lot of shame related to it. 18 AS: Do you have older brothers or sisters or both? 20 SP: My oldest sister Dianne, I think she was seventeen years older than I was. 14, 20 My mother’s first husband was Greek. 14 He was killed in World War II. 14 Dianne was a baby.  My mother was from Floodwood, another small town in Minnesota.  I think she had grown up with my dad so she knew him. 10, 14, 16 She had my sister Dianne and then she married my dad Charlie after the first husband was killed. 7, 14, 20 I don’t know how much older she was than my oldest brother, maybe four years. 5, 12, 14, 20 There was Dianne and then there’s my brother Chuck. 20 He was the first born son of my dad. 14 Then there’s my sister Scary Mary. 20 She just had a birthday. 16 She’s around sixty five.  Then there’s my brother Jimmy and he is four years older than I am. 14, 20 He was a drinker. 5 Scary Mary is a drinker, Chuck is a drinker. 5 Dianne was way into pills. 18 Then there’s my brother Michael. 20 He’s two and a half years younger than I am. 14, 20 He for sure is a drinker. 5 There’s been a lot of other drugs in the mix. 5, 6 Every single child. 14 Substance use, violence, and trauma. 6, 13 Absolutely.  My mother, she was really proud of the fact that she didn’t smoke cigarettes and she’d have a half a glass of wine. 11, 18 She wasn’t a drinker. 5 There was always some odd sharing of pills. 18 AS: Among who?  SP: My oldest sister for sure and with my mom. 14, 20 I don’t know if that extended beyond to my sister Mary Jane or not. 12, 20 There was a culture.  AS: Do you know what kind of pills they were sharing? 12, 18 SP: Generally speed.  AS: That makes sense because that was available.  It was prescribed to housewives with lots of children. 5, 6, 10, 13, 14, 16, 20 SP: Absolutely, to get stuff done and it’s good for a little depression. 10, 20 AS: We were at the school lunches, elementary school, junior high; you were telling me a story about your friend who you met in Cloquet, Debbie. 7, 12, 14, 15, 20 SP: So what happens, my parents get a divorce when I’m in the third grade. 5, 15, 20 The mid-60s in Northern Minnesota people didn’t get divorced. 7, 9 Small town environment, everybody knows everything about everybody. 12 AS: Was your dad violent with your mom? 14 SP: Oh yes.  AS: It was physical abuse. 6, 13 SP: All my life. 10 AS: Was everybody a target?  SP: Everybody was a target.  Me less than anybody else in the house. 6, 13 That’s interesting to me too. 17 They got a divorce.  My mother had lived in Oregon in the past and always wanted to go back. 7, 18 The summer between fifth and sixth grade we moved to Oregon. 5, 7, 15 It’s myself, my younger brother, and my older brother Jimmy. 20 We’re out there for about six months or so. 11, 16 I loved being in Oregon. 14 It’s not cold Northern Minnesota.  Then Jimmy doesn’t adjust well to it.  We move back to Cloquet in early February. 15 It sucked.  We moved back into this house at 1802 Carleton Avenue. 6, 7, 13, 15 The old man is still living there because he had moved back in the house. 6, 7, 13, 15 My older sister was there. 20 He had moved back in the house when we moved to Oregon. 6, 7, 13, 15 We come back.  He’s supposed to move out. 15 What I remember about that is just waiting for him to be gone. 8, 11, 15 I didn’t like him being around.  He was just a problem. 12 Two weeks after we got back he died. 15 He died of a stroke in the living room. 14 I might need to write to my therapist later tonight.  AS: We can pause whenever you want. 6, 13, 16 SP: It’s interesting because I’m in therapy and we do a lot of talking. 12, 17 There’s just so much stuff.  Sometimes not knowing what I don’t know. 12 There was a change.  When I think about myself it was Susie who moved to Oregon. 7, 15 I was always known as Susie, as a little girl. 7, 11, 12, 18, 20 My mother would always talk about how Susie was so docile and so calm and this and that. 14, 18 We get back and we always think about it as that’s when ‘A Boy Named Sue’ showed up. 18 My alter ego.  It’s absolutely—I love Johnny Cash. 14 I grew up hearing his music. 9, 20 I was really close to my brothers and I had to be a badass to survive. 9, 10, 18, 20 If I was going to be sweet and docile I wasn’t going to make it. 14 In the sixth grade he gets buried. 5 It’s cold when he dies.  They can’t bury him; they kept him somewhere until the ground was thawed in the spring.  I don’t remember much of that but the relief of having him gone. 8, 11 I didn’t have to worry about his violence any longer. 6, 17 It was hard in the sixth grade. 5, 9 There was a new girl who had moved to town, Connie Carlblom. 7, 15, 16 She had older siblings and a fucked up family life too. 10, 12, 20 We’re still friends to this day. 16, 20 There were some older girls in the neighborhood and we started smoking cigarettes and drinking. 5, 6, 7, 11, 20 My older brother was married and had a little girl and I used to babysit. 6, 7, 13, 16, 20 I used to steal their cigarettes. 6, 13, 16 I’ve probably been smoking since I was nine sort of. 6 Bringing booze to school in a baby food jar. 7 AS: And nobody caught you doing this?  SP: Nobody paid much attention to what I was doing.  AS: Because you were so docile and sweet. 14 SP: They were caught up in whatever else.  I think that it was every child for themselves. 14 AS: In your household? 6, 13 SP: Yes.  Dorothy was preoccupied in whatever else went on in her life. 10 Probably in retrospect she probably, I don’t know before my dad and before her first husband what happened growing up. 10, 12, 14, 15 AS: Dorothy is your mom? 14 SP: Dorothy’s my mom. 14 Sometimes I called her Dot Monster.  She probably had, I don’t know what her childhood experience was but when her siblings would talk about her, she was known as a problem. 11, 12, 14, 18, 20 Maybe bipolar, maybe borderline personality. 5, 15 Certainly she had a lot of trauma in her life. 10 She never drank. 5, 16 She didn’t do drugs. 5, 6 She knew divide and conquer really well and she could be wicked. 16, 18 She would play divide and conquer between her kids really well. 18 She wasn’t a supportive mother. 19 It wouldn’t be like, “Susie how are you doing now that we’re back from Oregon and your dad is dead? 12, 14, 16 How’s life in the sixth grade?” 5, 10 That wasn’t going to happen. 15 I had a lifelong friend, Lisa; we’d been friends since kindergarten. 10, 16, 17, 20 When I got back in the sixth grade Lisa was there as my friend. 5, 20 This other woman Connie.  We all got a really similar mindset. 18 We were friends, we had fucked up childhoods. 14, 16, 20 Connie and I in the summer between sixth and seventh grade we were with her older sister Gail. 5, 7, 20 Gail is beautiful.  She’s was just a hip chick.  So we’re at the glass block department store in Duluth. 9, 11, 12, 19 I don’t know why we were there together; we’d gotten dropped off somehow. 5, 8, 11, 12 We were there and we’re shoplifting. 15 I’ve got Gail’s purse carrying it.  It’s got a pack of Marlboro Reds with two joints in the pack.  We get busted for shoplifting. 15 Connie’s parents get called. 20 They come and pick us up.  The police must have been involved somehow, the school. 7, 8 Before I’m ever in the seventh grade I had to start seeing the guidance counselor. 5, 6 A man named Brian Burg, I really liked him. 18 I don’t know how all that got set up. 12 I remember sitting in his office.  I had to start seeing him before school started. 6, 7 He told me at the outset, he referred to me as being a survivor. 5, 16, 17 I remember sitting there thinking, “What the fuck does that mean?  How do you know that about me? 12 What do you know that I don’t know? 12 What does that mean?  What am I surviving?”  This is my life. 10 I don’t have insights.  It made me so uncomfortable.  So I just withdraw a little bit more. 5, 20 Certainly the pot smoking just continues. 6 In junior high in Cloquet all the grade schools come together and you’re united at the junior high. 5, 7, 8, 14, 19 My friend Lisa that I’d gone all through Garfield School with, the new girl Connie who joins us in the sixth grade, Debbie Holman. 5, 7, 16, 20 Along comes Debbie and then there’s another girl, Mary Dickinson. 7 There’s more but that was the core.  Mary and Debbie, they had been friends for life at the Sacred Heart school. 5, 7, 10, 16, 20 They’d gone to the Catholic school. 7 What a group of groups and energy. 12 There was about, I don’t remember how many of us in number but there was Robin Ward.  Robin  Ward came from Garfield School. 14 I knew her all my life too. 10, 16 In the fourth grade there’s modular scheduling. 5 I don’t know if you’re familiar with modular scheduling in the state of Minnesota but by that point it’s becoming the later 60s. 8, 12 Things are starting to change.  The traditional classroom is going away. 7, 14, 18, 20 There were twenty minute mods and children moved from classroom to classroom. 5, 7, 14, 15, 20 More autonomy, more independence.  That starts in the fourth grade. 5 It continues on throughout my school career up through high school. 7, 15, 19 I think I was the first year to get it and I think I was the last year to get it. 14 That was fun.  In the seventh grade we’ve got modular scheduling. 5 I’ve got to backtrack to this story about the fourth grade and Robin Ward. 5, 15, 16 We’re sitting in a classroom. 7, 14 There’s a teacher named Mr. Saliga.  Probably young at the time, twenties, I have no idea.  Older guy from a little kid’s perspective. 20 He would talk about shit that was so inappropriate while sitting at his desk to the classroom. 7, 14, 18 One of them, he talked about Robin Ward’s parents being divorced. 7, 20 I remember sitting there thinking, “Wow, there’s somebody else that can identify with me.”  Robin and I would be friends all our lives. 16, 20 Up until probably the last ten years. 14 He was sexually inappropriate. 12 We didn’t know. 12 We were little girls and didn’t have a voice and any place to share it. 7, 11, 17, 20 With divorced parents and things that had happened and nowhere to go with it. 7, 12, 15, 20 There’re these layers of stuff that start.  AS: That just kind of sets up the trajectory.  SP: So we get to seventh grade and we all get together. 5, 8 I’m not sure how we all met.  We formed our club. 14 It was the Weed Weevils.  It was given to us, this name by my friend Lisa, her older brother Joel, who was very instrumental all my life. 10, 12, 20 We all have Weed Weevil names. 16 We earned them somehow. 8 Lisa’s name, she was the queen of the Weed Weevils, she was Wee Helvi.  Not all of us are Finlanders but many of us are.  Then Mary Dickinson became Mad Dog.  She loved to drink Mad Dog. 5, 14 Her mother was a teacher.  She would leave early in the morning. 18 Her mother partied at night and she taught during the day, grade school children. 5, 7, 9, 14, 16, 20 This fledgling group of Weed Weevils, these adolescent girls would gather in Mary’s bedroom. 5, 7, 11, 14 We’d have an ounce of weed, a lid, four fingers and we would roll joints and each of us would have one and we’d keep them passing. 20 Then we’d get really high. 7, 18 Then we’d go to school. 7 We had a presence. 10 We were rascals and fun and outrageous and didn’t give a shit. 18 We weren’t shy.  AS: Were you getting in trouble all the time?  SP: We started.  That’s how we start seventh grade. 5 We smoke cigarettes in the bathroom. 14 AS: What was your name?  SP: Susie Monster.  I don’t even remember, in the seventh grade I’m sure I started getting suspended then. 5, 10 In the eighth grade I think it was Lisa and I, we had skipped out of school. 5, 7 We started dropping acid I think in the eighth grade, maybe not in the seventh. 5, 11 I think I was fourteen the first time I did acid. 14 It was at a junior high fun night, the school dance. 7, 14 It just continued.  Then the first day of ninth grade there was like four of us and we had planned, we got two joints and we were behind the school somewhere. 5, 7, 14, 16 There was a church across the street close to the junior high and we’re back there getting high. 7, 9, 10, 14 Somebody reported us so the principal comes from one way, the assistant principal from the other way. 13, 18 We’re caught and suspended from school. 7, 10 My mother was pissed.  AS: How long were you suspended for? 10, 17 SP: I think it was only three days. 16 I don’t think we got more than three days. 16 I had been on in-school suspension. 7 Just in trouble.  Still modular scheduling.
